Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident in his daughter's PM suspension case outcome.

site_title: Completed condo, private apartment prices fall 0.4% in November from October: NUS index
summary: Prices of completed private apartments and condominiums in Singapore fell 0.4% in November from October, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) flash estimates. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. Central region apartments, excluding small units, dropped 1%, while non-central region apartments held steady. Small units fell 0.4%, reversing October's 0.4% rise. Year-to-date, overall prices have climbed 3.2%, driven by a 4.5% increase in small unit prices.

site_title: Keppel bags residential site in Chengdu Tianfu area for 889.7 million yuan
summary: Keppel Land China secured a 4.7 ha residential site in Chengdu Tianfu New Area for 889.7 million yuan, to be developed into a community with 768 high-rise and 96 low-rise apartments. The site is in a prime location, close to educational institutions, commercial amenities, and medical facilities. Keppel Land China expects a total development cost of 519 million yuan and plans to launch the project in Q4 2019. The deal is not expected to impact Keppel's earnings per share or net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Keppel, SPH announce firm intention to make M1 offer
summary: Keppel Corporation and Singapore Press Holdings announced a firm intention to make a voluntary general offer of S$2.06 per share for M1 shares, via joint venture company Konnectivity Pte Ltd. The offer is subject to approval from the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) and will become unconditional when Konnectivity and its concert parties obtain more than 50% of M1's issued share capital. The companies had previously announced the intention on September 27, and the pre-condition has since been satisfied.

site_title: 20 years on, ex-Eurogroup head says euro a source of stability
summary: Former Eurogroup head Jeroen Dijsselbloem says the euro is a source of stability in Europe, 20 years after its adoption. He notes that the currency needs stronger buffers against future shocks but remains an anchor at a time of rising nationalism. Dijsselbloem, who chaired the eurozone committee from 2013 to 2018, credits the euro for surviving the Greek debt crisis. He believes the currency's stability is crucial for Europe's future, but also calls for improvements to its resilience.

images.alt_text: Mr Dijsselbloem says the key priorities are to finish the banking union and create real capital markets union in Europe.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% up on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 8.69 points, or 0.3%, to 3,053.43 on Friday, with gains outnumbering losses 222 to 158. The most actively traded stocks included Ezion, YZJ Shipbuilding SG, and DBS, which rose 0.8%, 0.3%, and 0.3% respectively. Total shares traded were approximately 942.5 million, worth S$539.9 million.

site_title: China customs gives green light for US rice imports
summary: China's customs administration approved US rice imports, allowing US rice exporters to enter the country after meeting inspection and quarantine requirements. The move comes as part of a 90-day tariff truce between the two countries, following a bruising trade war. The approval was made possible by a phytosanitary protocol agreed upon in 2017, which had been in the works for over a decade. The decision is seen as a step towards stabilizing sentiment in China, where the trade dispute with the US has hurt economic confidence.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, up 1.35 points to 1,692.07. The index saw 1.4 billion lots worth RM1.1 billion traded, with 385 gainers and 343 losers.

site_title: Australian shares clock weekly gains as Wall Street extends rally; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended the week up 1% at 5,654.30, with the benchmark advancing 1.9% on Thursday, following a rally on Wall Street. The financial sector rose 2.3% and clocked 4.6% weekly gains, while energy stocks rose 1% and 4.9% weekly. This marks Australia's biggest weekly gain since November 2016.

site_title: Music retailer HMV files for insolvency after weak Christmas
summary: HMV, a 97-year-old UK music retailer, filed for insolvency due to weak Christmas sales. The company, owned by Hilco Capital Ltd, had 125 stores in the UK and 2,025 employees. This marks the second time HMV has entered insolvency procedures in six years, largely due to the shift towards online streaming services. Despite performing better than the 30% decline in DVD sales, the company's decline is unsustainable. KPMG has been appointed as administrator, following a dismal Christmas for British retailers, which saw widespread store discounting and squeezed spending power.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday trading at 3,064.9, up 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 20.16 points, or 0.7%, to 3,064.9 at 1:01pm on Friday, driven by gains in Ezion, DBS, and YZJ Shipbuilding SG. The market saw 489.7 million shares worth S$236.8 million change hands, with 197 gainers outnumbering 121 losers. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Government to revise Budget 2019 if oil prices drop below US$50 per barrel
summary: Malaysia's government is considering revising Budget 2019 if crude oil prices drop below US$50 per barrel. A forecast by UOB suggests a revenue loss of 2-5 billion ringgit (0.1%-0.3% of GDP) if oil prices remain at US$55-US$66 per barrel. However, senior economist Julia Goh notes that new tax measures and asset sales could generate additional revenue, potentially offsetting the loss. The government may recalculate its budget if oil prices fall below US$50 per barrel, a condition set by Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng.

site_title: Benedict Cumberbatch to star in 'eye-opening' Brexit thriller
summary: Actor Benedict Cumberbatch is set to star in a two-hour TV drama, "Brexit: The Uncivil War," which will air on Channel 4 on January 7. The film will focus on the tactics used by Brexit mastermind Dominic Cummings ahead of the 2016 referendum, with Cumberbatch taking on the role. The film aims to provide an "eye-opening" exploration of the campaign's data-driven tactics and their impact on the referendum outcome, despite criticism and controversy surrounding the Brexit process.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the open on Friday, following days of volatility on global markets. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.04% to 25,488.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight gains. The market is cautious ahead of global economic events, including US-EU trade talks and potential Fed decisions.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.09% to 3,047.17
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.09% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 2.43 points to 3,047.17. About 58.6 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 92 to 55. The top gainer was Venture Corp. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 2.81 points to 1,687.91. The index saw a trading volume of 43.7 million lots worth RM8.01 million. Gainers outpaced losers 77 to 40.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares set to post weekly gains after Wall Street turnaround
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, edging closer to a weekly gain, after US stocks reversed earlier losses. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 9.4 points to 5,606.1, its highest in over a week. Financial stocks led the gain, with the "Big Four" banks rising 0.6-1.1%. New Zealand's benchmark index also climbed 0.3%. The Australian market is on track to snap two straight weeks of losses, but is likely to finish the year in the red, wiping out 2017 gains.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets jump at open
summary: Europe's top stock markets rebounded at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.9% to 6,646.28 points, and the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also gaining 0.9% and 0.7% respectively. This follows a late surge on Wall Street, which finished with impressive gains. Investors are seeking bargains amid concerns over slowing global economic growth, trade wars, and Brexit uncertainty.

images.alt_text: A zoomed overview shows the trading floor at the German stock exchange in Frankfurt. Europe's top stock markets rebounded at the open on Friday, after Wall Street enjoyed a late surge to finish with impressive gains.

site_title: Asia: Markets meek after global turbulence
summary: Asian markets ended the trading year with a loss, with Tokyo's Nikkei index poised to close with an annual loss for the first time in seven years. The market's decline was attributed to global volatility, trade wars, and the Trump administration's impact on the economy. Investors moved cautiously, with Tokyo's stocks down 0.5% despite a late rally in New York, and other Asian markets experiencing similar declines.

site_title: Oil watchers see US$70 a barrel in 2019 as recession fears fade
summary: US oil prices are expected to rebound in 2019, averaging $70 a barrel, as recession fears fade and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) implements production cuts to prevent a glut. Despite volatility and a decline in oil prices this quarter, analysts expect a tightening market as growth remains strong, OPEC's supply cuts kick in, and unintended losses in Venezuela and Iran escalate. Most commentators don't see an actual recession affecting the oil market next year, with some predicting a V-shaped recovery if conditions are met.

site_title: Murray happy with decision not to quit tennis
summary: Andy Murray, a three-time Grand Slam champion, expressed satisfaction with his decision not to retire from tennis despite missing 11 months due to a hip injury. Murray, who returned to competition with a world ranking of 256, aims to compete at a high level and achieve more goals in the sport. He is set to participate in the Brisbane International, which begins on Monday, and faces a challenging schedule to back up his performances. Murray believes he has given himself the best possible chance to return to a level where he is happy with his game.

site_title: It's blue skies in gold ETFs as investors flee equity turbulence
summary: Investors are seeking shelter in gold exchange-traded funds (ETFs) amid US stock market turbulence. The SPDR Gold Shares fund and iShares Gold Trust saw record inflows of over $643 million and $114 million, respectively. Gold prices have risen 7% this quarter, driven by concerns over trade negotiations, interest rate hikes, and the US government shutdown. Experts attribute the trend to gold's status as a safe haven and potential store of value, as investors fear the long-term impact of fiscal policies on the US currency.

site_title: 'All lives matter': Indonesia saves tsunami-stranded turtles
summary: A rescue team in Indonesia's hard-hit Lampung region saved a giant sea turtle trapped in marine trash after a devastating tsunami. The turtle, stuck upside down in a pile of debris, was freed by four staff members. This is the latest in a string of turtle rescues along the country's devastated coast. The incident highlights the impact of the tsunami on marine life and the efforts of rescue teams to save endangered creatures.

site_title: Winter storm snarls holiday travel in parts of US
summary: A powerful winter storm caused widespread disruptions to holiday travel in the US, with over 6,500 flights delayed and 800 cancelled. Heavy snow, rain, and strong winds made travel hazardous on roads, especially in the northern and central plains. Major airports like Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport experienced significant disruptions, and authorities issued travel advisories in several states. The severe weather affected thousands of holiday travelers, with many reporting ruined plans and stranded conditions. The storm was expected to persist through early Friday in north central states.

site_title: China Beige Book says plentiful borrowing fails to boost growth
summary: China's economy is deteriorating, with growth expected to be weaker in 2019, despite plentiful borrowing by state and private firms. Borrowing by firms has been strong for three consecutive quarters, but it's not boosting growth, according to the China Beige Book. Revenue and profit growth are at their worst since 2017, with only real estate seeing improved margins. Policymakers have launched a push to support the private sector, with measures including targeted reserve-requirement ratio cuts, inclusive finance, and tax cuts, in an effort to squeeze more efficiency from the economy.

site_title: Singapore trims industrial land supply in first half of 2019 to 11.86 ha
summary: The Singapore government has launched five confirmed list sites and seven reserve list sites under the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme for the first half of 2019, totaling 11.86 hectares. This marks a decrease from the second half of 2018. All confirmed list sites are zoned "B2" for heavier industrial use, while the two largest reserve list sites are located in Benoi Sector and Kaki Bukit Road 5. The government aims to ensure an adequate supply of industrial space in Singapore.

site_title: LionGold to receive investment, relieving debt burden
summary: LionGold Corp, a Singapore-listed firm involved in the 2013 penny stock crash, is set to receive an investment to alleviate its debt burden. Yaoo Capital Pte Ltd, a Chinese investment firm, will subscribe for up to 21.8 billion new shares at 0.1 Singapore cents each, effectively paying off LionGold's outstanding debt. The deal will not raise any new funds for the company and will transfer controlling interest to Yaoo Capital. LionGold will seek shareholders' approval for the deal, which is conditional on obtaining a whitewash waiver from the Securities Industry Council.

site_title: Mystery hacker steals data on 1,000 North Korean defectors in South
summary: A South Korean resettlement agency's database containing the personal information of nearly 1,000 North Korean defectors was hacked, with hackers gaining access through a computer infected with malicious software. The data breach, discovered last week, includes names, birth dates, and addresses of 997 defectors. A police investigation is underway to determine the motive and perpetrator, with speculation of North Korean involvement. The Unification Ministry is notifying the affected defectors and has assured there is no negative impact from the data breach.

site_title: Japan factory output falls in sign of rising pressure on economy
summary: Japan's industrial output contracted 1.1% in November, reversing a previous month's gain, amid rising global risks threatening the country's export-reliant economy. Despite better-than-expected data, manufacturers forecast a decline in January. The country's jobless rate rose to 2.5% in November, and labor shortages push up wages. Japan's aging population and shrinking workforce exacerbate the challenge for the Bank of Japan to achieve inflation goals, with consumer inflation remaining below target.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, despite a late rally in New York, as investors cashed in after the previous day's strong rises. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51% to 19,975.50, while the Topix index declined 0.78% to 1,489.97. The losses followed a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: At 20, euro is currency giant on fragile footing
summary: The euro turns 20, marking two tumultuous decades since its introduction in 1999. Despite surviving a make-or-break crisis, the single currency remains fragile without closer eurozone integration. Experts say the euro's survival was largely due to the ECB's actions, including buying unlimited government bonds, which calmed the waters but has never been used. While the euro is more popular than ever, observers argue that the 19 single currency nations have not done enough to carry out necessary political reforms to better arm the region for future downturns and achieve greater economic convergence.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE Lippo Healthcare, Creative, Second Chance, Manulife US Reit, Keppel-KBS US Reit
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare's hearing for a civil appeal is set for August 5-23. The company's claim against the Crest entities will proceed despite a court dismissal of their application to strike out the action. Creative Technology's shares plummeted 13% on Thursday, prompting a Singapore Exchange query, with no explanation provided. Second Chance Properties reported a 90% decline in first-quarter net profit to S$218,000. Manulife US Reit and Keppel-KBS US Reit expect proposed US tax regulations to have minimal impact on their consolidated net tangible assets and distribution per unit.

site_title: French 'yellow vest' protests planned for Saturday, New Year's Eve
summary: French "yellow vest" protesters plan to hold demonstrations on Saturday and New Year's Eve, marking a seventh straight Saturday of protests. Despite a 10 billion euro package of measures announced by President Emmanuel Macron, the movement remains divided, with some calling for dialogue and others demanding further action. New Year's Eve celebrations on the Champs-Elysees are set to proceed despite the planned protests, with thousands of people expected to attend a "festive and non-violent event".

site_title: Fit To Start
summary: Renowned Pilates specialist Rosie Gregory is hosting a week-long residency at The Sanchaya in Bintan, offering complimentary Pilates, Sculpt Method, and stretching classes. Her sessions will focus on physical and mental well-being, complemented by an enhanced wellness menu. The residency aims to help guests achieve their fitness goals in a beautiful beachfront setting.

site_title: Oil prices slide as concerns about global economy, oversupply weigh
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, retreating from an 8% rally in the previous session, as concerns about global economic growth and oversupply weighed. Brent crude futures dropped 4.24% and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell 3.48% to settle at $52.16 and $44.61 a barrel, respectively. The decline comes amid fears of a global economic slowdown and a glut of crude, with US crude stocks rising by 6.9 million barrels in the week ended Dec. 21.

site_title: China says new financial information rules aimed at providers for institutions
summary: China's internet regulator has introduced new financial information rules targeting firms supplying information to institutional audiences and specific investors, rather than the general public. The regulations, set to take effect on February 1, aim to prevent distortion of fiscal and monetary policies, economic order, and harm to the nation's interests. Financial information providers, including those involved in analysis, trading, and decision-making, are subject to the new rules, which do not apply to foreign wire services. The regulations follow a crackdown on online content deemed detrimental to the country's financial stability amid a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: China's internet regulator said on Friday the recently published rules governing financial information providers are aimed at firms supplying information to an institutional audience and to specific investors, rather than the general public.

site_title: Trump combative on sixth day of US government shutdown
summary: US President Donald Trump refused to back down from his demand for $5 billion for a border wall, despite a partial government shutdown that has left 800,000 federal employees unpaid for six days. Congress members returned to Washington with little sign of ending the impasse, with Democrats accusing Trump of overhyping the immigration problem for political gain. The shutdown has contributed to economic worries and a plummeting stock market, with some lawmakers calling for higher-tech alternatives to a wall to manage the flow of illegal border crossers.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymakers warned of darkening global outlook: Dec meeting summary
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers warned of a worsening global economic outlook, citing heightened uncertainty and risks skewed to the downside. The BOJ maintained monetary policy steady, but its governor expressed concerns about a slowdown in global growth. Recent oil price falls could further delay the bank's 2% inflation target. Policymakers also noted the impact of global economic trends on Japan's economy, with China's GDP growth set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The BOJ's December meeting highlighted the challenges facing the global economy, with risks to growth and inflation on the rise.

site_title: US consumers less upbeat about economy: survey
summary: US consumer confidence plummeted to 128.1 in December, the largest decline in over three years, as the erosion of short-term economic outlook and falling stock market expectations took a toll. This marked a 13-point drop in expectations and a 5-point drop from the 18-year high in October. The decline is attributed to concerns about moderating economic growth and rising interest rates, with a smaller share expecting job growth and a slightly larger share anticipating fewer jobs.

site_title: Malaysia theme park operator seeks Singapore listing on Catalist board
summary: Malaysia-based theme park operator Sim Leisure Group plans an initial public offering (IPO) on Singapore's Catalist board to fund business expansion. The company, led by founder Sim Choo Kheng, operates theme parks in Penang and expects to raise S$10-12 million. Proceeds will be used to expand existing operations and venture into new regions, including China and other South-east Asian cities. Revenue is projected to increase, with a new theme park set to launch in 2019, and the company aims to pay a minimum annual dividend of 30% of net profit.

site_title: On the edge of a new Cold War
summary: A new Cold War is emerging between the US and China, with strained trade relations threatening global ties. The two superpowers are clashing over technology, prompting concerns about a divided world. The US has imposed tariffs, and China has retaliated, affecting economies worldwide. Vietnam has benefited from sweetened US trade terms, while Malaysia's economy is shielded from tariff threats with a rate cut. The situation has raised concerns about the future of global trade and the potential for a prolonged economic downturn.

site_title: Nomura focuses on expansion of investment banking business in US
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc aims to increase its share of business arranging foreign exchange hedging, acquisition finance, and other deal-related services for corporate clients in the US, shifting its growth focus to the Americas. The bank is re-allocating global resources to build up businesses in the US without taking on bigger risks. CEO Koji Nagai forecasts a US$250 million revenue boost in the medium term through expansion of client financing and solutions business. This is part of Nomura's efforts to earn more stable income from advisory services, following a major restructuring in 2016 and recent losses in its overseas business.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings CEO Koji Nagai says the bank will keep its global platform though it has been shrinking businesses that are unprofitable and not needed by its clients.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare gains court OK to continue suit against Crest funds
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare's lawsuit against Crest funds will continue after the High Court dismissed an attempt to block the suit. The Court of Appeal will hear an appeal from entities related to Crest Capital Asia, which had claimed certain liability. The dispute stems from 2016 when Crest Capital appointed receivers over OUE Lippo Healthcare's subsidiaries, leading to a sale of one of the subsidiaries to Crest entities. The High Court previously ruled that OUE Lippo Healthcare owed no contractual liability to Crest, allowing the lawsuit to proceed.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip back to 2016 levels as Wall Street support evaporates
summary: European shares fell 1.75% to their lowest level since November 2016, wiping out over a quarter of their previous day's gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped after data showed consumer confidence in December fell to its lowest level since July, citing persistent worries about a slowing global economy and a trade spat between the US and China. The Stoxx 600 benchmark is set for its worst year since 2008, with all sectors and national indexes in Europe falling.

site_title: Saudi king orders government reshuffle after Khashoggi fallout
summary: Saudi King Salman ordered a government reshuffle, replacing key security and political figures, including the foreign minister, amid international fallout over Jamal Khashoggi's murder. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the de facto ruler, remains in power despite the crisis. The reshuffle includes appointments of new National Guard chief, head of a space agency, and foreign minister Ibrahim al-Assaf, who was detained in an anti-corruption sweep. The move aims to consolidate power and reassure foreign investors, but analysts say it won't address the kingdom's diplomatic crisis.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LTC Corp extends its exit offer to steel trading and property group shareholders until January 10, with acceptances reaching 89.77% as of December 27. Thakral Corporation signs a joint venture with CurrentBody.com, while EuroSports Global allocates $2 million for its electric motorcycle project. Mirach Energy proposes placements of 28.56 million new shares to raise funds. Transcorp Holdings warns of an expected net loss for the financial year ended October 31, 2018, citing lower car sales revenue.

site_title: US government shutdown to extend into next week after Senate adjourns
summary: The US government shutdown, now in its 12th day, is expected to continue into next week after the Senate adjourned without reaching an agreement. Negotiations between Democrats and Republicans failed, with President Donald Trump refusing to fund the government unless he gets funding for his border wall project. The impasse has left about 800,000 federal employees unpaid and non-essential government services unavailable. The Senate is set to reconvene on Monday and continue budget deliberations next Wednesday.

site_title: Putting the cryptocurrency bear market into perspective
summary: The cryptocurrency market is experiencing a bear market, with the total market cap dropping from $400 billion to $115 billion since its peak in 2017. The decline is attributed to the crypto gold rush of 2017, China's ban on ICOs and exchanges, and South Korea's ban on anonymous trading. Despite the downturn, institutional players, governments, and regulators are showing increased interest in the industry, with Christine Lagarde of the International Monetary Fund stating that central banks' involvement is crucial in preserving the industry's integrity. The bear market is also serving as a cautionary tale for investors, with prudent blockchain companies emerging as the strongest projects to survive.

site_title: France's Vinci to acquire majority stake in Gatwick for £2.9 billion
summary: France's Vinci SA agreed to acquire a majority stake in Gatwick Airport for £2.9 billion, expanding its aviation infrastructure portfolio. The deal, completed in the first half of 2019, values Gatwick at less than 20 times earnings. The purchase from a group of investors including sovereign wealth funds from Abu Dhabi and Australia will see existing shareholder Global Infrastructure Partners manage the remaining 49.99% stake. The acquisition will make Gatwick the largest single airport in Vinci's global network, following a series of investment plans to expand capacity at the airport.

site_title: The cost of natural disasters in 2018: US$155 billion
summary: Natural disasters worldwide cost approximately US$155 billion in 2018, with several high-profile events including the US hurricanes Michael and Florence, the California wildfires, Hawaii's volcano eruption, and a devastating tsunami in Indonesia. These disasters highlight the increasing vulnerability of humans and property assets in high-risk areas, emphasizing the need for preparedness and mitigation measures.

site_title: US: Dow finishes up 1.1% as stocks rebound
summary: US stocks finished higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 1.1% to 23,138.82. The S&P 500 climbed 0.9% to 2,488.83, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.4% to 6,579.49. The late-afternoon surge came after worries over slowing economic growth gave way to bargain-hunting, with investors taking advantage of low prices. Analysts say the rally is a positive sign for the market, potentially indicating a bottom for stocks going into 2019.

site_title: Raf Simons and Calvin Klein part ways
summary: Calvin Klein has parted ways with its chief creative officer, Raf Simons, due to a new brand direction differing from his creative vision. The decision comes six months before his contract was set to renew, and there will be no Calvin Klein show during the upcoming New York Fashion Week. The departure marks a setback for the brand's ambitious plans to grow revenue from $8 billion to $10 billion, which were attributed to Simons' high creative costs. The decision reflects the growing trend in the fashion industry of relying on a single creative to impose their vision, as seen in the success of Gucci under Alessandro Michele.

site_title: Home price gains in 20 US cities slow for a seventh month in Oct
summary: US home prices in 20 cities slowed for a seventh month in October, extending the longest streak since 2014. The 20-city index rose 5% from the year earlier, down from a 5.2% increase in September. Economists attribute the slowdown to higher mortgage rates and elevated property values, leading to reduced affordability and slower sales of new and existing homes. Nationally, home prices climbed 5.5% from October 2017, with the weakest gains in cities like Washington, Chicago, and New York.

site_title: May your city never become San Francisco, New York or Seattle
summary: The term "San Francisco-isation" refers to the growing suspicion among communities that the costs of urban prosperity, such as high housing costs, congestion, and homelessness, outweigh the benefits. Other cities like Seattle, Portland, New York, and Boston are also facing similar fears, with residents worrying about becoming the next "San Francisco" or another urban dystopia. Despite the arrival of tech jobs and high wages, many communities are concerned about the trade-off between urban growth and affordability, leading to protests against gentrification and the displacement of long-time residents.

site_title: Scary Comeback
summary: Indonesian actress Suzzanna, known as the country's Queen of Horror Cinema, is remembered through a new supernatural movie titled Suzzanna: Bernapas Dalam Kubur (Buried Alive). The film, set to release on January 3, 2019, pays tribute to Suzzanna's iconic scenes, with model-actress Luna Maya portraying her with striking resemblance and extensive prosthetic make-up. The movie recreates scenes from Suzzanna's classic films, including her infamous 'satay' scene from Sundel Bolong (1981).

site_title: Spice Up The New Year
summary: Singapore's award-winning Tanglin Gin has launched two new spirits, Mandarin Chilli Gin and Orchid Gin, to celebrate the New Year. The Mandarin Chilli Gin combines mandarin peel and chilli for a fresh, citrus flavor with a slight spiciness, while the Orchid Gin features juniper and modern ingredients like unripe green mango and organic oranges. Both gins retail at S$108 each and are suitable for classic cocktails or sipped neat.

site_title: Yen gains as stocks fall in broad-based selloff
summary: The Japanese yen gained half a percent against the dollar as investors sought safe-haven assets amid global stock market concerns. US stocks rose on Wednesday but fell on Thursday, while European equities dropped one percent. The yuan strengthened against the Swiss franc, and the dollar index slipped 0.2 percent. Investors are concerned about trade tensions between the US and China and a slowdown in the world's largest economy.

site_title: Pakistan's housing crisis deepens with country's financial woes
summary: Pakistan is facing a severe housing shortage, with a 10 million-unit gap that requires building 700,000 homes annually. The country needs $17 billion annually to build low-cost homes, but the government is struggling to provide subsidies and support for developers. Banks have limited liquidity for housing financing, and regulatory impediments hinder lenders' ability to foreclose on properties. The shortage affects Karachi, where over 500,000 people are homeless, and has sparked Prime Minister Imran Khan's pledge to build 5 million low-cost homes in five years.

site_title: Romania takes EU helm amid tensions with Brussels
summary: Romania is set to take over the European Union's presidency on January 1, amid tensions with Brussels. The country's left-wing government, led by Liviu Dragnea, has adopted nationalist rhetoric and proposed reforms to the judiciary, which critics say undermine the rule of law. The European Commission has called for the reforms to be scrapped, citing concerns they benefit Dragnea. Romania's presidency will coincide with key events such as Brexit and EU parliamentary elections, potentially complicating EU affairs.

site_title: China's industrial profits suffer first annual drop in 3 years
summary: China's industrial profits dropped 1.8% in November, marking the first annual decline in three years, due to slackening external and domestic demand. The decline in profits reflects slowing growth in sales and producer prices, as well as rising costs. Economists expect earnings to worsen next year, with some warning of the risk of deflation. The US-China trade dispute has pressured the manufacturing sector, prompting the government to roll out measures to juice up demand. Industrial profits have been cooling since April, and earnings growth at state-owned industrial enterprises also cooled in the 11-month period.

site_title: Most SE Asia markets end higher following Wall Street's rally
summary: Southeast Asian markets ended higher on Thursday, following a Wall Street rally and a leeway in the Sino-US trade standoff. Singapore led gains, with industrial and financial stocks rising 1.1% and 0.7%, respectively. Other markets, such as Vietnam and Indonesia, also saw gains, while Thai stocks retreated 0.5% due to late sell-offs. The rebound is attributed to investors taking cues from overnight gains on Wall Street and optimism over restarting trade talks in January.

site_title: Snoopy Time
summary: Custom watch brand Undone has released a collection featuring Charles M. Schulz's Peanuts characters, including Snoopy, Woodstock, and Charlie Brown. The Undone x Peanuts One World range features fixed designs and bespoke options, powered by Seiko's VK61 Mechanical-Quartz hybrid flyback chronograph movement. Each watch is waterproof up to 30 meters and can be customized through Undone's bespoke watch-assembly service. The collection is available for online ordering at https://www.undone.com/.

images.alt_text: Undone x Peanuts collaboration.

site_title: A Swede Sensation
summary: Stockholm, Sweden, is a city where the Scandinavian way of life, known as hygge, brings people together through simple acts like sharing cinnamon buns and coffee. Despite the bitter cold, the city's residents are calm, inclusive, and welcoming. This unique approach to life is slowly spreading globally, offering a respite from the stresses of everyday life. With limited daylight during the winter, Swedes have learned to prioritize connection over annoyance, making them one of the happiest cultures in the world.

site_title: Why Joe Biden will shape the Democrat race for 2020
summary: US President Donald Trump's tumultuous month has shifted focus to the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination battle, which could see the largest field of candidates in a generation. Former Vice President Joe Biden, 76, is the early favorite to become the Democratic nominee, with recent polls indicating he leads national polls and could unite the party around his candidacy. Biden's age may be neutralized by running against Trump, 72, and he has key advantages in fundraising and national polls. The Democratic field is fluid, but Biden's decision to run or not could significantly impact the nomination process.

site_title: Saudi Aramco sets up fuel retail unit
summary: Saudi Aramco is establishing a domestic fuel retailing subsidiary, Saudi Aramco Retail Co, to sell automotive fuels in Saudi Arabia. The new network will complement Aramco's existing global retail network, operated through joint ventures. This move is part of Aramco's expansion into downstream businesses and could help the company conduct an initial public offer of shares in the future. The IPO plans were previously suspended due to the company's valuation, but Aramco is now focusing on downstream projects to boost its value and attractiveness to international investors.

site_title: High chicken prices boost CP Indonesia shares
summary: Shares of PT Charoen Pokphand Indonesia have more than doubled in 2018, ranking No 1 on the MSCI Asean Index, due to higher chicken prices. Indonesian poultry producers have seen improved profit outlooks, with PT Malindo Feedmil and PT Japfa Comfeed Indonesia experiencing 50% share-price gains. Analysts expect CP Indonesia to book a record profit this year, with sales rising 3.6% and net income surging 79%. However, some analysts warn that higher corn prices may impact the company's financial performance in 2019.

site_title: LinkedIn co-founder says 'sorry' for funding group behind fake news in Alabama race
summary: LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman apologized for funding a group behind a "highly disturbing" effort to spread disinformation during the 2018 Alabama special election. Hoffman invested $750,000 in American Engagement Technologies, which allegedly used Facebook and Twitter to undermine Republican Roy Moore and boost Democrat Doug Jones. Hoffman expressed support for a federal investigation and echoed Jones' position, but left key facts unaddressed. He stated that he finds the tactics "highly disturbing" and that there is "no place in our democracy for manipulating facts or using falsehoods to gain political advantage."

site_title: The answer's in the cloud
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is enhancing online shopping experiences for retailers in the Asia-Pacific region. By leveraging cloud services, businesses can analyze customer data, create personalized recommendations, and deliver targeted content. The talks will run through March 1, with a "hard deadline" set by US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer.

site_title: Israel eyes 5G mobile network auction by mid-2019
summary: Israel plans to publish a tender for 5G mobile networks by mid-2019, with the goal of allocating frequencies by the end of 2019 and launching 5G between 2020 and 2023. The Communications Ministry expects the tender to cost around $529 million, which may be too steep for local operators struggling to remain profitable. Only the six main mobile operators will be eligible to bid, and companies are encouraged to form partnerships to participate. The government hopes 5G will support economic growth and development in areas such as healthcare, education, and smart cities.

site_title: Manulife US Reit worries lifted after release of proposed US tax regulations
summary: Manulife US Reit has alleviated concerns about upcoming US tax regulations, which had threatened its tax deductions and distribution per unit. The proposed regulations, released on Dec 20, have "scoped out" the Reit's specific tax structure, preserving the shareholder loan tax shield. Although a worst-case scenario under the Barbados tax changes could result in a one per cent tax expense, the Reit is exploring tax planning options to mitigate this impact. The Reit's units ended up 2.76 per cent at 74.5 US cents on Thursday, after initially facing concerns over the regulations.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes up more than 3.8% following NY rally
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index surged 3.88% or 750.56 points to close at 20,077.62, following Wall Street's best performance in nine years. The Nikkei 225 index rose, while the broader Topix index also increased. The rally was driven by investors' positive sentiment despite US tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Vietnam's economy remains outperformer as growth tops 7% mark
summary: Vietnam's economy grew 7.3% in the fourth quarter, outperforming the median estimate of 6.9% in a Bloomberg survey. The country's robust domestic demand, increased exports, and foreign investment are driving growth, which was 7.1% for the full year. Vietnam is capitalizing on US-China trade tensions to boost its profile as a manufacturing powerhouse, with trade accounting for about twice the nation's GDP. The country is poised to capture some of China's global market share in labor-intensive manufacturing, according to senior economist Trinh Nguyen.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: US and Chinese trade negotiators plan to meet in January for talks, according to Beijing. Asian shares rose on Wall Street's surge and oil rally, while concerns over US tax regulations on Manulife US Reit have dissipated. Sinopec suspended senior officials at its trading arm Unipec after losses. Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index up 1.12%. Vietnam expressed surprise over a potential Trump tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs.

site_title: Traders face new landscape with Powell at microphone after every fed meeting
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is set to hold press conferences after all eight of the central bank's meetings in 2019, starting from the next meeting on January 30. This shift is expected to increase optionality in pricing in the very short end of the curve, potentially affecting fed funds futures and overnight indexed swaps contracts. However, strategists believe the ripple effect will be minimal, overshadowed by traders' anticipation of the end of the tightening cycle and criticism of the Fed by US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down despite US market rally
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down 0.67% on Thursday, despite a US stock market rally, due to weak economic data from China. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,478.88, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.61% to 2,483.09. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.22%. The US market rally, however, lifted investor confidence, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Second Chance Q1 profit down 90% to S$218,000 on securities losses
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 90% decline in Q1 net profit to S$218,000, despite a 5.7% revenue increase to S$6.47 million. The securities segment contributed the most to the loss, mainly due to an unrealised loss of S$2.09 million on financial assets held for trading purposes. Profit from operations remained steady at S$2.5 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.12 points to 1,690.72 on Thursday, driven by a gain of 595 stocks to 221 losers. The index closed higher with a volume of 1.6 billion lots worth RM1.2 billion.

site_title: Thai anti-graft agency drops probe into 'Rolex General'
summary: Thailand's anti-graft agency dropped a probe into General Prawit Wongsuwan, the junta's second-in-command, over his luxury watch collection. The investigation found that all 22 watches, worth $1.2 million, belonged to his deceased friend, wealthy businessman Pattawat Suksriwong. The agency cited "no grounds" for the investigation, stating General Prawit had not intended to hide the truth about the watches. The decision was met with criticism from opposition parties, who accused the agency of being a "tool" for the military.

site_title: US team to visit China for talks during trade truce: report
summary: A US government delegation, led by Deputy US Trade Representative Jeffrey Gerrish, will visit China in early January for face-to-face talks on trade tensions. The talks follow a truce agreement between US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, which aims to ease trade tensions by March 1. The US team will discuss issues such as trade balance and intellectual property, with China agreeing to suspend extra tariffs on US-made cars and auto parts, and restarting purchases of soybeans from American farmers.

site_title: Sinopec suspends top officials at its trading arm: sources
summary: Sinopec has suspended two senior officials, Unipec's President Chen Bo and Communist Party secretary Zhan Qi, following losses at the company's trading arm. The suspension does not imply any wrongdoing by the two men. The move comes after Sinopec, Asia's largest refiner, suffered losses. A spokesman for Sinopec had no immediate comment. The suspension is part of a broader effort to address the company's financial issues, but details remain unclear.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up in early trade on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded in early trade on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.94% and the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 1.18%. The rally followed White House reassurances that the Federal Reserve chair will not be fired, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,070.55, up 2% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.97% to 3,070.55 on Thursday, driven by gains in financials, led by DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. The index resumed trading after a brief pause and saw 572.1 million securities worth S$309.8 million change hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 246 to 101, with Ezion Holdings and Pine Capital being among the most heavily traded stocks.

site_title: Transcorp warns of expected wider full-year loss
summary: Transcorp Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, has warned of an expected net loss after tax for the financial year ended Oct 31, 2018, citing a decline in car sales leading to lower revenue. The expected loss is higher than that of FY 2017. The company will announce its unaudited consolidated financial results by the end of December 2018. This comes after a wider loss was reported in the first half of the year, with a loss of S$2.68 million. The company advises caution in dealing with its shares.

site_title: White House mulls new year executive order to bar Huawei, ZTE purchases
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering an executive order to declare a national emergency that would bar US companies from using telecommunications equipment made by China's Huawei and ZTE, citing national security concerns. The order, which could be issued as early as January, would direct the Commerce Department to block US companies from buying equipment from foreign telecommunications makers deemed a national security risk. The move follows a defense policy bill that barred the US government from using Huawei and ZTE equipment, and comes as US wireless carriers prepare to adopt next generation 5G wireless networks.

site_title: US Commerce Department won't publish economic data during shutdown: report
summary: The US Commerce Department announced it will not publish economic data during the ongoing government shutdown. The Bureau of Economic Analysis and Census Bureau will remain closed, but the Labor Department will continue to release key data such as jobless claims and employment reports. The shutdown, entering its sixth day, is due to a dispute over border wall funding, with President Trump seeking $5 billion from taxpayers. The lack of data may impact investors and policymakers, who rely on the Commerce Department's releases.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Economic Analysis and Census Bureau will not publish economic data during the government shutdown, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, citing an agency spokesman.

site_title: Morgan Stanley fined US$10m over poor fraud monitoring
summary: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a $10 million fine to settle allegations by the US regulator, Finra, that its anti-money laundering programme failed to monitor tens of billions of dollars in transactions from 2011 to 2016. The firm's insufficient monitoring included wire and foreign currency transfers, as well as penny-stock trades. Morgan Stanley neither admitted nor denied the allegations, stating it had strengthened its controls and been recognized by Finra for its efforts. The fine resolves a matter that occurred several years ago, according to the firm's spokesman.

site_title: France's Vinci Airports to buy majority stake in London Gatwick for £2.9b
summary: France's Vinci Airports agreed to acquire a majority stake in London's Gatwick Airport for £2.9 billion, adding a major London hub to its network. The purchase is expected to be completed in the first half of 2019, with Vinci managing the majority stake and Global Infrastructure Partners managing the remaining 49.99%. The acquisition will make Gatwick the largest single airport in Vinci's global network, following operations at the airport being disrupted earlier this month due to drone sightings.

images.alt_text: France's Vinci Airports agreed to acquire a majority stake in Gatwick Airport for £2.9 billion (S$5 billion), adding a major London hub to its network.

site_title: Indonesia hikes danger level for deadly tsunami volcano
summary: Indonesia raised the danger level for the Anak Krakatoa volcano, citing increased activity and a heightened risk of another deadly tsunami. The alert level was raised to the second-highest danger warning, and a no-go zone was expanded to 5km around the volcano. The move came after a killer tsunami killed over 400 people, injured 1,495, and left 159 missing. Authorities warned residents to stay away from the coast and redirected flights away from the area, citing rough seas and pyroclastic flows.

images.alt_text: Authorities also widened a no-go zone around Anak Krakatoa to five kilometres - up from a previous two kilometres - and warned shell-shocked residents to stay away from the coast, after more than 400 were killed by Saturday night's killer wave.

site_title: No Uber or Airbnb in South Korea: Red tape, risk-aversion hobble startups
summary: South Korea's regulatory environment has hindered the growth of ride-hailing and car-sharing services, with Uber and Airbnb banned due to strict laws and risk-aversion. This has hindered Hyundai's investment in Luxi, a car-sharing firm, which was later sold after thousands of taxi drivers threatened to boycott Hyundai cars. The restrictive laws have also limited the entry of foreign companies into the market, hindering South Korea's ability to keep up with global transportation trends.

site_title: LTC extends exit offer to Jan 10
summary: LTC Corp has extended its exit offer for steel trading and property group to January 10, 5.30pm, from its original deadline of December 27. The offer remains unconditional, with the controlling Cheng family holding 88.44% of the company. A voluntary delisting resolution was passed earlier this month, paving the way for the company's de-listing after the offer is successful. The level of acceptances has not been updated.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares enjoy gains after Wall Street's surge
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.9% to 5,597.20, led by resource-based stocks, following a surge in US equities. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.5% on Monday. Wall Street saw a buying frenzy due to upbeat US data and Trump's efforts to soothe battered equities. Australia's metals and mining index rose 1.7%, while energy stocks soared 3.2%. The "Big Four" banks gained between 1.4% and 2.5%, and healthcare stocks jumped 3.4%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.689%.

site_title: US dollar holds most of its gains after Wall Street rally pushes yields higher
summary: The US dollar maintained most of its overnight gains as Wall Street stocks and Treasury yields rose, driven by easing trade tensions and strong US economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged over 1,000 points, while US 10-year yields increased 8 basis points to 2.8%. The dollar index slipped 0.2% in Asian trade, but the dollar strengthened against the yen. Investors' improving risk sentiment and easing tensions between the White House and the Federal Reserve also supported the greenback.

images.alt_text: The dollar retained most of its overnight gains on Thursday but was off its peak for the week so far amid thin volumes, as signs of easing trade tensions and strong US economic data sent Wall Street stocks and Treasury yields higher.

site_title: US won't be world's 'policeman,' Trump says during Iraq visit
summary: US President Donald Trump stated during a surprise visit to US troops in Iraq that the US cannot continue to be the "policeman of the world." He defended his decision to pull US troops out of Syria, saying there would be no delays. Trump also reiterated that the US will not intervene in global conflicts, indicating a shift away from its traditional role as a global military power.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Alliance Mineral Assets, Yongnam, Heeton, SHS Holdings
summary: Stocks to watch: Alliance Mineral Assets, Yongnam, Heeton, SHS Holdings. Alliance Mineral Assets' trading halt has turned into a suspension pending an announcement about its offtake agreements. Yongnam Holdings secured new contracts in Australia and Singapore worth S$73.4 million, expected to positively impact its financial performance.

site_title: High-flying chicken prices lift South-east Asia's top stock
summary: Shares of PT Charoen Pokphand Indonesia (CP Indonesia) have more than doubled in 2018, outperforming South-east Asian peers, due to higher chicken prices. The company is expected to book a record profit this year, with sales rising 3.6% and net income surging 79%. Analysts note that the rally may be overdone, with higher corn prices potentially affecting the company's financial performance in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: LinkedIn co-founder apologises for deception in Alabama senate race
summary: LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman has apologized for his company's role in a Russian-style social media deception campaign in the 2018 Alabama Senate race. Hoffman, who financed $100,000 of the operation, claimed he had no knowledge of the tactics and promised to exercise more care in the future. The campaign used fake social media accounts to promote a conservative write-in candidate and create the illusion of Russian support for Republican candidate Roy Moore. Hoffman joined Democratic candidates and officials in calling for investigations into the operation, which has raised concerns about the use of misinformation in US politics.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 6.79 points to 1,679.39. The index saw 81.85 million lots traded at RM31.32 million, with gainers beating losers 219 to 18.

site_title: China's industrial profits suffer first year-on-year fall in almost 3 years
summary: China's industrial firms saw their profits fall 1.8% in November to 594.8 billion yuan, marking the first year-on-year decline in almost 3 years. This contraction follows a 3.6% gain in October. Industrial profits rose 11.8% year-on-year in the first 11 months of 2018, slower than the 13.6% rise in the first 10 months. China's economy faces downward pressure due to a trade dispute with the US, slowing global growth, and a deleveraging campaign. Policymakers aim to maintain economic growth within a "reasonable range" in 2019.

site_title: Oil prices fall after jump the day before; glut, economy worries weigh
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, down 8 cents to $54.39 a barrel for Brent crude and 0.19% to $46.13 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude. The decline follows a 8% jump in prices the day before, driven by concerns over a global oil glut and a faltering economy. Despite this, analysts predict that Opec's output cuts may lead to higher prices next year, with Brent expected to reach $58-70 a barrel and WTI to reach $50-60 a barrel.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens up more than 3% after Wall Street surge
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index surged 3.54% or 684.32 points to 20,011.38, driven by Wall Street's best performance in nine years. The broader Topix index also rose 3.81% or 54.55 points. The positive momentum followed a strong opening on US markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Beyond NY resolutions
summary: A 2019 guide to living a more "woke" lifestyle, focusing on personal growth, social consciousness, and helping the world, is featured in BT Weekend magazine. The article includes advice from hotelier Surya Jhunjhnuwala on living a more gracious and diverse lifestyle, as well as a look at the hottest places to party in Singapore. The guide aims to inspire readers to make positive changes in their lives and the world around them.

site_title: JPMorgan to pay US$135m for improper handling of ADRs
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to pay a $135 million settlement to the US Securities and Exchange Commission for mishandling American depository receipts (ADRs) that represented shares of foreign companies. The bank improperly provided ADRs to brokers without clients holding shares, inflating market values and enabling abusive practices. The fine and disgorgement amount to $49.7 million and $85.4 million, respectively. This settlement marks the eighth enforcement action against a firm related to "abusive ADR pre-release practices" and follows similar settlements with Citigroup and Deutsche Bank.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday's open; STI up 1.5% to 3,054.83
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 1.5% to 3,054.83. Gainers outnumbered losers 125 to 15, with Ezion Holdings and Genting Singapore leading the gains. Major banks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, with DBS increasing 1.76%, OCBC 2.1%, and UOB 1.75%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Alleged victim of Spacey sexual assault filmed part of incident
summary: A 59-year-old Kevin Spacey is due to be formally charged on January 7 on the island of Nantucket with "indecent assault and battery on a person over 14 years of age" after an alleged 2016 incident at a seaside restaurant near Boston. The alleged victim, 18-year-old William Little, claimed Spacey sexually assaulted him after they met at the "Club Car" restaurant. Spacey could face up to five years in jail if found guilty. Little had sent a Snapchat video of the incident to his girlfriend, which police retrieved and showed him to confirm its authenticity.

site_title: Alliance Mineral Assets suspends trading pending announcement
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets has suspended trading pending an announcement, following a trading halt initially sought on December 21. The halt was related to the company's offtake agreements, including a deal with HC Starck Tantalum and Niobium to sell high-grade tantalum concentrate from the Bald Hill mine in Australia. The company had agreed to sell 20-30 dry tonnes of concentrate and secure a long-term offtake deal. The exact nature of the announcement is not specified, but investors are awaiting further information.

site_title: Federal Reserve chairman's job '100%' safe: Trump advisor
summary: President Donald Trump has no intention of firing Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, according to White House economic advisor Kevin Hassett. Hassett stated that Powell's job is "100% safe" despite Trump's criticism of the central bank. Hassett also downplayed concerns over the economic outlook, citing strong Christmas shopping and an expanding economy. The Trump administration has been under pressure due to a government shutdown and Trump's tariffs, but Hassett believes these issues will not significantly harm the economy. The White House is reportedly planning to meet with Powell in the near future.

site_title: Motor racing: Schumacher in F1's thoughts as stricken great turns 50
summary: Formula One is set to celebrate Michael Schumacher's 50th birthday on January 3, five years after a near-fatal skiing accident left him fighting brain injuries. The sport's focus will be on highlighting Schumacher's remarkable career and talents, with various exhibitions and interviews planned, including a special exhibition at the Ferrari museum in Maranello, Italy. Mercedes, the last team Schumacher drove for, will also display some of his cars, while Formula One management will dedicate a week to him on its social media platforms. Despite Schumacher's ongoing struggles, Mercedes driver Lewis Hamilton is closing in on his records, leaving a sense of sadness over the German's enduring absence from the sport.

site_title: US: Wall Street roars back to life in best session in 9 years
summary: US stocks surged in the best session in nine years, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising nearly 1,100 points, or 5%, to 22,878.45. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 5% and 5.8% respectively. The rally followed strong retail sales data and White House reassurances about Fed Chair Jay Powell's job security, driven by technical factors after days of selling. Analysts attribute the gains to oversold conditions and a bounce back from recent weakness in petroleum markets.

site_title: Beijing aims to steady home prices in 2019, boost rental supply
summary: China's housing authorities aim to stabilize land and home prices in 2019 and boost rental supply to address affordability issues. Following regulatory controls since 2016, the housing ministry will curb speculation while supporting "reasonable" housing demand. The government will prioritize affordability by increasing public rental housing supply in medium to big cities, with a multi-year redevelopment program to demolish tens of millions of cramped homes. A city-based regulatory approach will be adopted to manage property prices.

site_title: China to try Canadian citizen on drugs charges: report
summary: A Chinese court will try Canadian citizen Robert Lloyd Schellenberg on Saturday on drugs smuggling charges, amid strained relations between China and Canada. Schellenberg, who was found guilty of smuggling a large amount of drugs into China, faces severe punishment in China. The case comes as tensions between the two countries rise over the detention of two Canadian citizens and the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou at the request of the US. Canada has pressed for the release of the detained Canadians and Meng, who faces extradition to the US on fraud charges.

site_title: Workers fret at making ends meet as US government shutdown persists
summary: The US government shutdown, now in its third month, is causing financial strain for federal workers who are either unpaid or working without pay. Over 800,000 workers are affected, with many struggling to pay bills and buy holiday gifts for their families. Many are forced to use credit cards or dip into savings, with some even having to relocate to find stable employment. President Trump insists on a wall along the Mexican border before reopening the government, but lawmakers return with no deal in sight, leaving the fate of federal workers uncertain.

site_title: China to online financial info providers: Keep 'economic order'
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration has issued new regulations for domestic financial information providers, requiring them to maintain "economic order" and avoid distorting fiscal and monetary policies. The regulations, set to take effect on February 1, will condemn violators publicly and order them to rectify their errors, with criminal cases to be brought forward if necessary. The move comes as China's slowing economy has spurred calls for stimulus policies, and domestic providers of financial information are expanding rapidly, publishing sensitive market information and potentially harming financial stability.

site_title: Malaysia reviewing palm oil export taxes amid bulging stockpiles
summary: Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, is reviewing its export duty structure to boost demand and reduce stockpiles. Despite cutting export tax on crude palm oil to zero since September, imports from Indonesia have increased due to lower prices. The government aims to reduce stockpiles by encouraging domestic use of palm oil and implementing a higher biodiesel mandate in 2019. Expected production in 2019 is around 20 million tonnes, with prices supported by demand from traditional markets and the biodiesel mandate. This aims to counter the impact of Indonesia's eased palm oil levies.

site_title: Trump blasts US central bank again over rate hikes
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, blaming them for the tanking market. With stocks on track for their worst December since the Great Depression, Trump has repeatedly attacked the Fed's monetary policy. Trump has also expressed concerns about the government shutdown and its impact on the US economy. Despite Treasury Secretary Stephen Mnuchin's assurances of ample liquidity, markets remain volatile, with Asian markets experiencing a holiday rout. Trump remains confident in American companies and urged investors to stay calm.

site_title: Asian debt defaults expected to rise
summary: Asian debt defaults are expected to rise due to weakening currencies and tighter liquidity, leaving riskier borrowers with higher refinancing costs. In 2018, Asian dollar bond market defaults tripled to nine, with India and China experiencing landmark defaults. The US-China trade war is also increasing pressure on companies, and investors are setting up to capitalize on distressed debt opportunities in China and India. The region's governments face challenges navigating the increasing defaults, particularly during the 2019 elections in India and Indonesia.

site_title: Keppel O&M bags S$300m of contracts; Keppel T&T sells stakes in Thai IT firms
summary: Keppel Corp's unit Keppel O&M secured S$300m in new marine contracts, including a design and construction contract for an ice-class LNG bunker vessel by 2020. Keppel Shipyard also bagged 65 exhaust gas scrubber retrofit projects. Separately, Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) sold stakes in Thai IT firms Advanced Research Group Co and Anew Corporation for about S$8.9 million, expecting a net gain of S$5.2 million. The deals are not expected to impact Keppel Corp's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Innopac's outgoing CEO owed S$491,920 for unused leave dating back to 2008
summary: S$491,920 of unused leave, dating back to 2008, is owed to Innopac's outgoing CEO Wong Ching Yong, according to the firm's financial results. The leave was accumulated due to Mr. Wong's inability to utilize it as the sole executive director. The amount has been recorded in Innopac's books but not paid to date. Other staff members are also owed compensation for unused leave. Mr. Wong resigned last week, with a planned departure date of March 31, 2019.

site_title: Asia: Shares ride Wall Street surge, oil rally
summary: Asian shares surged on Thursday, driven by a dramatic surge on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising over 1,000 points. This helped push the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index up 0.9% and away from eight-week lows. Australia, Japan, and Singapore shares also rose, with Japan's Nikkei surging 3.7% and Singapore's Straits Times Index up 1.12%. Oil prices jumped, with US crude and Brent rising 8.7% and 8.8% respectively, while the US dollar gained 1% against the yen.

site_title: Parents scramble to keep up as TikTok videos take hold with teens
summary: Millions of teenagers, particularly girls, are flocking to TikTok, with 500 million users as of June, but parents are concerned about the app's mature content and potential risks. Critics say the platform exposes teens to caustic comments and abuse, while offering a hunting ground for predators. Despite promises from ByteDance to protect users, many parents are unaware of the risks and are removing the app from their children's devices. Experts say raising the age limit would curb TikTok's growth, but could also remove millions of users from the platform.

site_title: Japanese brokerage cuts pay of CEO, chairman over insider trading scandal
summary: Japanese brokerage SMBC Nikko Securities Inc has cut the pay of its CEO and chairman over an insider trading scandal. Yoshihiko Shimizu and Tetsuya Kubo will forfeit 20% of their salaries for two months after a former employee was arrested on suspicion of insider trading. The firm apologized for causing concern and inconvenience to customers and pledged to restore trust. This move is part of a growing trend in Japan where executives take pay cuts to show responsibility and contrition following scandals.

site_title: China still has a treasure chest of overseas real estate to sell
summary: China is expected to continue selling its overseas real estate assets in 2019, with disposal records potentially smashed due to slowing economic growth and tight capital controls. Despite a record-breaking $89 billion spent on real estate in 2016-2017, Chinese companies have reduced their spending to $12.3 billion since January. The government's push to rein in debt levels and aggressive buyers has driven asset sales, with buyers from Singapore and South Korea taking the place of Chinese investors in US and European markets.

images.alt_text: New York's famed Waldorf Astoria Hotel is one of China's many lucrative real estate assets overseas.

site_title: SMFG weighs acquiring Asia banks to use some of US$12b surplus capital
summary: SMFG aims to acquire Asian commercial banks using its planned US$12 billion surplus capital over the next five years. The goal is to expand its presence in emerging economies and build a retail banking business. CEO Takeshi Kunibe plans to acquire local lenders rather than establishing retail operations from scratch. SMFG is also exploring acquisitions in other business areas, such as asset management and investment banking. The bank's CFO, Jun Ohta, will take over the top job in April, with Kunibe becoming chairman.

site_title: Singapore market feels the jab on Boxing Day
summary: The Singapore stock market plummeted 1.3% on Boxing Day, with the Straits Times Index dropping 39.91 points to 3,011.15, due to concerns over the US economy and growing turmoil in the White House. Tech stocks were particularly hard hit, with Creative Technology and Hi-P International losing 16.2% and 5% respectively. Other sectors, including finance and property, also fell, with UOB, DBS, and OCBC losing 1.6%, 1.23%, and 1% respectively. The decline was attributed to investors losing faith in the US economy under President Trump's unpredictable leadership.

site_title: Global economy is set to feel delayed trade war pain in 2019
summary: The global economy is expected to feel the pain of a delayed trade war in 2019, despite efforts by the US and China to resolve their trade spat. Trade volumes are expected to slow to 4% in 2019, down from 4.2% in 2018, according to the International Monetary Fund. Companies are warning of ongoing disruption, with FedEx and GoPro already taking action to diversify their production. The threat of tariffs on auto imports from Europe and Japan also poses a risk to the global economy, with the US and China facing a March 1, 2019 deadline to strike a deal.

site_title: All eyes on US as dollar edges up and futures gain
summary: The US dollar edged higher on Wednesday, with US equity futures advancing as investors awaited the reopening of American markets following the Christmas break. The S&P 500 Index is on the cusp of a bear market, and President Trump's frustration with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has caused market volatility. Despite this, the greenback remained in a tight range, and other major currencies also moved in response to the uncertainty.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has seen unrecognised sales of S$0.6 billion as of Q3, driven by Singapore and Australia projects. The group is expected to drive earnings in the next three to four years. DBS Group Research upgrades Roxy's rating to "hold" from "fully valued" and lowers its target price to S$0.39. Despite attractive valuations, the sector is expected to face a property market slowdown, and limited catalysts are anticipated for the stock.

site_title: Closing the books on tech's mixed year
summary: Tech industry in 2018 saw controversies, including Congressional testimony, driverless car deaths, and global tensions. However, voice-activated smart speakers gained popularity, with 74 million users in 2019, exceeding one quarter of US adults. Despite challenges, tech continued to evolve, with AI research and innovation hubs established by major companies and organizations.

site_title: Poland's Torun gingerbread: the ancient luxury with a secret recipe
summary: Poland's Kopernik Confectionery Factory, established in 1763, has been producing its famous Torun gingerbread using a secret recipe for centuries. The factory, which has remained family-owned, has been maturing the dough in large vats for months to develop its unique flavor. Only six bakers know the exact spice mix, which includes cloves, cinnamon, ginger, and pepper. The factory produces 3,500 tonnes of gingerbread annually, with a certification ensuring its products are vegan, kosher, and non-GMO. The historic factory has been a major part of Torun's tradition since the Middle Ages, with gingerbread once being a luxury item only affordable by the elite.

site_title: Russians need certificates of sanity to sell their homes
summary: In Moscow, Russians must obtain a certificate of sanity from a psychologist to sell their homes, a measure aimed at combating rampant property fraud. The certificates are required for nearly all 140,000 transactions annually, protecting buyers from scams and weak courts. Homeowners who have no history of mental illness must undergo psychological evaluations to secure the documents, which can be a lengthy and costly process. This requirement is part of a broader effort to address corruption and bureaucracy in Russia's real estate market.

site_title: Thai farmers giddy over new medical marijuana law
summary: Thailand's National Assembly has passed a bill allowing the cultivation and use of marijuana for medical purposes, a significant step for the region. The law, which still outlaws recreational use, allows for the production, import, and export of marijuana and promises an economic bonanza for farmers. However, some fear foreign companies will dominate the market, potentially limiting research and development by Thai universities and government agencies. The Commerce Ministry has promised to revoke foreign patent applications, but critics warn that Thai people will not benefit if patents are not canceled.

site_title: Stan & Ollie, an intimate portait of comedic genius
summary: Stan & Ollie, a new feature film, explores the intimate portrait of comedic geniuses Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy, known for films like Sons of the Desert and Way Out West. The film, directed by Jon Baird, delves into the duo's unique chemistry and their struggles in the late 1940s, when they attempted a final hurrah despite declining popularity. John C. Reilly and Steve Coogan bring new life to the duo with their convincing performances, highlighting their chemistry and partnership.

images.alt_text: Actors John C Reilly (at left) and Steve Coogan during a screening of Stan & Ollie on Dec 8 at the 92nd Street Y in New York.

site_title: Singtel adds ex-Wespac CEO, Google VP to board
summary: Singtel appoints former Westpac CEO Gail Kelly and Google VP Bradley Horowitz to its board of directors, bringing the total to 11 members. Kelly will join the executive resource and compensation committee, while Horowitz will join the finance and investment committee and technology advisory panel. Singtel chairman Simon Israel said the new members bring international experience and expertise in areas such as technology, innovation, finance, and global operations, which will be valuable in the company's transformation journey.

site_title: Bouts of volatility, swings taint US economic growth
summary: The US economy, despite a slowdown in global growth, is vulnerable to policy mistakes and market accidents, increasing the risk of a downward overshoot. Recent weeks have seen a rise in volatility, with investors warned to be cautious. Global economic uncertainty, particularly in Europe, Japan, China, and oil-producing countries, has also contributed to the economic instability.

site_title: Largest floating LNG platform starts production in Australia
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has started production at its Prelude floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) facility in Australia, the world's largest floating production structure. The Prelude facility, located 475 km north-north east of Broome, has an annual LNG production capacity of 3.6 million tonnes, cementing Australia's lead as the world's biggest LNG exporter. The project, which began later and cost more than estimated, is expected to further boost exports, potentially putting pressure on the Asian market next year.

site_title: Yongnam bags deals worth S$73.4m
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured contracts worth S$73.4 million in Australia and Singapore, expected to positively impact its financial performance for the year ending Dec 31, 2018. The firm is entering the Australian market for the first time, supplying steel struts and components for infrastructural developments in Melbourne. In Singapore, Yongnam has two contracts from repeat customers for structural steelwork, with completion dates set for 2020 and 2021. The announcement led to a 0.6% increase in Yongnam shares on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore November manufacturing beats forecasts with 7.6% year-on-year growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 7.6% year-on-year in November, exceeding economists' forecasts, driven by strong performance in the biomedical sector. Excluding this sector, output grew 5.3% year-on-year.
