However, economists caution that the November performance may be due to front-loading of imports, potentially leading to a weaker manufacturing growth outlook for 2019, with projected industrial production growth of 2.5% next year.

site_title: Starbucks' expansion runs out of steam in South Africa
summary: US coffee giant Starbucks has abandoned its expansion plans in South Africa due to high operating costs and tight customer budgets. The company had initially opened 12 cafes across Johannesburg, Pretoria, and Durban, but further openings have been ruled out. High costs, estimated at US$350,000 to US$550,000 per store, and the need to control debt have led to a pause in expansion plans. The company's failure to make a profit in the South African market is attributed to the high cost of imported ingredients and materials, making it unaffordable for many consumers.

site_title: JTC launches last 4 industrial sites under confirmed and reserved lists for H2 2018
summary: JTC launches the last four industrial sites under the confirmed and reserved lists for the 2018 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) Programme. Two sites, a 20-year leasehold 1.23-hectare site at Jalan Papan and a 30-year, 2.09-ha site at Woodlands Avenue 12, are available for tender with minimum bids of S$36 million and S$36 million respectively. The remaining two sites, a 1.2-ha site at Gambas Way and a 2-ha site at Benoi Sector, are available for application with 30-year tenures. All sites are zoned for Business-2 use.

site_title: Christmas rout leaves markets contemplating tough year ahead
summary: Asian markets ended the year on a down note, with most equity markets in South-east Asia experiencing a sell-off due to US economic uncertainty and the ongoing government shutdown. Shanghai and Japanese equities, however, showed resilience. Oil prices declined, while gold prices rose amidst the uncertainty. Experts predict a tough year ahead, with Citigroup forecasting a 1,150 target for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Beware the Ghost of Trump Chaos Future
summary: US investors are reevaluating their stance on President Donald Trump's presidency, realizing that his erratic behavior and policy decisions could have significant economic implications. Despite initial optimism that Trump's populist rhetoric would translate to policy changes benefiting corporations and the wealthy, investors now see the potential for instability and chaos. Trump's recent actions, including his trade war with China, government shutdown, and potential firing of the Federal Reserve chairman, have raised concerns about the administration's ability to manage the economy. As growth slows, investors are becoming increasingly wary of the administration's ability to respond effectively to economic challenges.

site_title: Headwinds persist for South-east Asia's airlines in 2019
summary: South-east Asia's airlines face headwinds in 2019, with competition and pressure on yields expected to persist. The region's carriers are projected to report a combined net profit of US$10.4 billion, up from US$9.6 billion in 2018, driven by lower fuel costs and strong regional economic growth. However, downside risks include protectionism and the US-China trade war, and airlines will struggle to pass on higher fuel costs to consumers. Despite this, lower oil prices and easing fuel costs offer some relief, with the price of oil expected to retreat to US$65 per barrel next year.

site_title: 2 Koreas pledge to reconnect rail, road links but sanctions an issue
summary: The two Koreas held a symbolic ceremony to reconnect roads and railways, with North Korea calling for South Korea to push through joint projects despite international sanctions. The ceremony, attended by senior officials from Russia, China, and Mongolia, does not mark the start of actual work due to concerns over sanctions and denuclearization. The North has reiterated its demand for the South to lift sanctions until it gives up nuclear weapons. South Korea has set aside $620,000 for the endeavour, which is part of a series of measures aimed at improving bilateral ties.

site_title: Seoul, Tokyo need to move beyond history to grow ties
summary: Japan and South Korea are facing a critical point in their relations due to ongoing disputes over wartime forced labor. The South Korean Supreme Court upheld compensation awards of around $100,000 to victims, threatening cooperation between the two countries on East Asian security. The Japanese government has warned that the rulings "fundamentally damaged the legal foundation of Japan-South Korea relations" and may challenge the decisions in international courts. The dispute raises questions about the South Korean government's commitment to reconciliation efforts and could have consequences for regional stability and the US alliance system in East Asia.

site_title: Nissan updates governance code after arrest of former head
summary: Nissan Motor Co updated its corporate governance code a month after the arrest and indictment of former chairman Carlos Ghosn, amid a strained partnership with Renault SA. The new code clarifies policies on cross-shareholdings, examining their purpose and benefits. The updated code aims to improve transparency and oversight, following the Ghosn scandal that exposed differences between the two companies. This move is seen as a step towards restoring investor confidence and rebuilding trust in the company's governance structure.

site_title: Golden Energy secures A$150m loan facilities
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) secured up to A$150 million loan facilities from Credit Suisse to finance its acquisition of shares in Stanmore Coal. The loan is secured by a share pledge and a guarantee. Gear had previously announced a bid for a 19.9% stake in Stanmore for A$47.6 million, with plans to eventually transfer that interest to a 51% joint venture offering up to A$201.13 million for all remaining shares.

site_title: New Israeli law will enable medical cannabis export
summary: Israeli lawmakers have approved a law enabling the export of medical cannabis, expected to generate $265 million in annual revenue. The law, which passed with final approval, conditions growing cannabis on a health ministry license and requires police monitoring. The move is seen as a significant economic opportunity for the state and farmers, with eight companies already growing medical cannabis in Israel. Exportation is expected to begin within six months, with nearly two dozen countries already legalizing medical marijuana use.

site_title: BOJ divided over side effects of easy policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) policymakers are divided over the feasibility of allowing bond yields to move more flexibly around its zero per cent target, amid concerns about the growing dangers of prolonged easing. The division reflects a deepening dilemma, as the BOJ maintains a massive stimulus program despite low inflation. Some members suggest allowing bond yields to move more freely, while others warn that this could undermine the BOJ's credibility. The BOJ agreed to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy, but also noted the strain on the banking system from years of easy policy.

site_title: Appropriate US response is using monetary, fiscal policy; not protecting old industries
summary: The US economy has shifted from goods to services, with 70% of private sector employment now in services. This trend is driven by people's increasing spending on non-agricultural goods and rapid growth in productivity. The US is a global leader in services, with $798 billion in exports in 2017. However, the Trump administration's focus on old manufacturing industries is misguided, and protectionist policies like tariffs will only harm sunrise industries and exacerbate the decline of manufacturing employment. A more effective response is to provide support for vulnerable workers and facilitate the expansion of services industries, using monetary and fiscal policy to drive growth.

site_title: India's central bank sets up panel to examine its economic capital framework
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has set up an expert panel to review its economic capital framework, following government pressure and the unexpected resignation of RBI Governor Urijit Patel. The panel, headed by former RBI Governor Bimal Jalan, will also include former Deputy Governor Rakesh Mohan and other experts. This move comes after heated discussions over the revamping of the economic capital framework, which led to Patel's resignation earlier this month. The panel's review is aimed at addressing government demands, including handing over surplus reserves and easing lending curbs.

site_title: Is there any way to solve the research conundrum?
summary: Singapore's stock market faces a research conundrum, with a lack of independent research and quality listings hindering price discovery and retail investor participation. The issue is not unique to Singapore, as the global broking industry has evolved to marginalize research functions. The rise of passive investing and decreased demand from active asset managers have led to reduced research coverage and commissions. To address this, reliable independent research should be prioritized as a valuable service for retail investors, and local financial institutions should focus on providing superior service to domestic retail investors.

site_title: Heavy rain hampers tsunami rescue efforts
summary: Rescue efforts in Indonesia's tsunami-hit areas were hindered by heavy rain, making it difficult for teams to reach remote areas along the western coast of Java. The rain also posed a risk to the Anak Krakatau volcano, where a crater collapse triggered the tsunami, with authorities imposing a two-kilometre exclusion zone. The confirmed death toll stands at 430, with at least 159 people missing, and nearly 1,500 injured, with over 21,000 evacuees.

site_title: Overseas expansion key for healthcare sector in 2019 and beyond: analysts
summary: The healthcare sector in Singapore is expected to benefit from overseas expansion in 2019 and beyond, according to analysts. Companies like IHH Healthcare, Singapore Medical Group, and Raffles Medical Group are investing in regional markets, including Vietnam and China, to capitalize on growing demand for healthcare services. Analysts predict a positive outlook for the sector, with key risks including impact on medical tourism from weakening currencies and increasing competition. The sector is trading at fair valuations, with healthy valuations for hospital operators and healthcare specialists. Overseas expansion is expected to drive growth and improve prospects for the sector.

site_title: Don't blame Powell for market slump
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will likely face criticism for the stock market's recent slump, but conditions for the bubble were set by his predecessors through years of easy monetary policy. The US economy experienced overly easy monetary policy under Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen, creating the conditions for the current market downturn. The latest interest rate increase was not under Powell's watch, and experts argue that he cannot be held responsible for the market's collapse. The true blame lies with those who set the stage for the economic conditions that led to the stock market's current state.

images.alt_text: If there is one person who will undeservedly be publicly dragged over the coals by US President Donald Trump for the bursting of the stock market bubble, it surely will be Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell after Wednesday's latest interest rate increase.

site_title: Bull market that has outlasted all previous runs gets whiff of extinction
summary: The US stock market is experiencing a significant decline, with the S&P 500 falling 19.8% in three months, its worst three-month performance since 1931. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has plummeted 5,036 points, and futures on the index are trading little changed. Despite the decline, the fundamentals of the economy appear strong, with rising gross domestic product, profits, and economic data. The Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates and withdraw quantitative easing is also seen as a contributing factor. While a full-blown bear market is still possible, many experts believe the market may recover, citing past examples of market resilience.

site_title: Rusal board chairman quits as part of US sanctions waiver deal
summary: Russian aluminium company Rusal's board chairman Matthias Warnig resigned as part of a restructuring deal with the US to remove sanctions. The deal, which includes reducing controlling stakes of businessman Oleg Deripaska, is in exchange for a waiver from US sanctions. Warnig, who has known Russian President Vladimir Putin since the 1990s, stepped down after six years at the world's largest aluminium producer outside China. Rusal plans to choose a new successor and expects the restructuring to be completed after the US sanctions are lifted, allowing En+ to retain a 56.88% stake in Rusal.

site_title: Huawei ships record 200 million phones despite US crackdown
summary: Huawei shipped a record 200 million smartphones in 2018, exceeding 30% growth from the previous year, despite US crackdowns and increasing scrutiny from other national governments. The company ranks third globally, behind Samsung and Apple, and has cast the blacklisting as politically motivated. Huawei's strong growth in Europe and China has led its head of consumer business to predict the company could become the world's top smartphone maker by the end of next year.

site_title: Saudi Aramco creates fuel retail subsidiary to expand downstream
summary: Saudi Aramco is establishing a domestic fuel retailing subsidiary, Saudi Aramco Retail Co, to expand into downstream businesses. The new firm will create a network of filling stations within Saudi Arabia to sell automotive fuels, but details on the size, cost, and time-frame for the network are not provided. This move is part of Saudi Aramco's drive to diversify its business and increase its presence in the downstream market.

site_title: Reflections on 40 years of Chinese reforms
summary: China marked the 40th anniversary of its economic reforms, initiated by Deng Xiaoping in 1978. The reforms transformed China from an inward-looking agrarian society to the world's second-largest economy, saving the country from decades of stagnation and the impact of the Cultural Revolution and Great Leap Forward. Today, China has maintained a market-oriented economy while maintaining the Communist Party's primacy. The country has come a long way from the "grain coupons" and "product coupons" that people used to rely on, and has become a major global economic power.

site_title: CPTPP will keep the trade beat drumming for Singapore
summary: The Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is being closely watched for its impact on trade adoption. The agreement's success will be measured by the level of business adoption, with Singapore expected to benefit from the partnership. However, critics argue that the agreement's 500-page dossiers with preferential arrangements are largely ineffective unless businesses actually utilize them. This criticism is reminiscent of the theme in the 1980s TV satire "Yes, Minister," where administrators boasted of a hospital's efficiency despite having no patients, highlighting the need for tangible results in free trade agreements.

images.alt_text: CPTPP countries accounted for S$214 billion - a fifth - of Singapore's total goods trade last year, according to Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry.

site_title: Pacific Star Devt to take full control of Puteri Cove project for S$26m
summary: Pacific Star Development (PSD) will acquire its joint venture partner in the Puteri Cove Residences project in Malaysia for S$26 million. This move is necessary for PSD to obtain a S$70 million 2-year secured loan facility. The loan will be used for working capital and a Bangkok property project. After the transaction, PSD will be the sole shareholder of Twin Prosperity Group, which owns Puteri Cove. The loan bears an annual cash coupon of 7.5% and a payment-in-kind interest of 5%. PSD's net debt would have been lower if the deal had been completed on June 30, 2018.

site_title: Oil prices rebound but economic worries cap gains
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Wednesday, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rising 29 cents or 0.68% to $42.82 per barrel. However, concerns over the global economy, including a US-China trade dispute and higher interest rates, continued to weigh on the market. Brent crude oil futures fell 11 cents or 0.22% to $50.36 per barrel. Analysts say market confidence needs to be restored, which could be achieved through an equity market rebound or deeper production cuts from major oil exporters, including Opec.

site_title: Kuroda further waters down pledge to hit inflation target quickly
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has adjusted his pledge to hit Japan's 2% inflation target, saying it will be achieved "step by step" due to global risks, including China's slowing growth and trade frictions. This change in language underscores the rising hurdle for meeting the BOJ's price goal, as fears of a global slowdown cast doubt on the central bank's view that robust exports will boost growth and help fire up inflation. Kuroda also warned of the rising costs of prolonged monetary easing, such as near-zero rates that could hurt financial institutions' profits.

site_title: Putin says latest test of hypersonic warhead successful
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin announced the successful test of a hypersonic glide vehicle, called Avangard, which can carry conventional or nuclear weapons and maneuver past defenses. The test, conducted in Kamchatka, was witnessed by Putin and officials, and deployment is expected to begin next year. The Avangard was touted as a strategic weapon to counter US missile defenses, with Putin describing it as heading towards its target like a meteorite.

site_title: Ofo plight a warning to China's tech investors
summary: Ofo, a Chinese bike-sharing startup, is facing bankruptcy after millions of users demand refunds for deposits. The company's founder has admitted to considering bankruptcy, warning China's tech investors about the risks of investing in loss-making businesses like bike sharing, ride hailing, and food delivery. Ofo's rapid expansion and failure to turn popularity into profit led to its downfall, with costly battles for market share and spiraling costs. The company's demise serves as a cautionary tale for investors, highlighting the challenges of scaling a business in a highly competitive market.

images.alt_text: The firm has pulled back from markets such as Israel, Germany and the United States, and has been forced to sell assets, including some bikes for as little as US$2.

site_title: Emerging nations will take longer to outpace developed economies: CEBR
summary: Emerging nations, including China, India, and Brazil, will take longer to surpass developed economies, according to the Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR). China is expected to overtake the US as the world's largest economy in 2032, two years later than previously predicted. Other emerging countries, such as Brazil and India, will also experience delayed growth, with Brazil overtaking Italy in 2020 and India possibly overtaking Britain and France in 2019 or 2020. The CEBR also projects a bumpy growth route for the global economy due to a trade war between the US and China.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after four session slide
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by technology and retail shares, after a four-session decline. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.30%, the S&P 500 gained 0.51%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 1.05%. The benchmark S&P 500 is now close to bear market territory, but traders are brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Japan's MUFG promotes core bank unit head as CEO in management reshuffle
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) has promoted Kanetsugu Mike, head of its core commercial banking unit, as its next president and CEO, effective April. Mike, 62, will continue to lead the commercial banking unit, while current CEO Nobuyuki Hirano will become chairman. The move aims to expand MUFG's overseas operations, following a successful tenure under Hirano, who led the company since 2013 and expanded its tie-up with Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Russia warns US against interfering in Saudi royal succession
summary: Russia warned the US against interfering in Saudi Arabia's royal succession, supporting Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman amid pressure over Jamal Khashoggi's killing. Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister Mikhail Bogdanov stated that the Saudi people and leadership should decide the royal succession, rejecting US interference. The US has blamed the crown prince for Khashoggi's murder, while Russia accepts the Saudi account. Russia has strengthened ties with Saudi Arabia, cooperating on oil production and with President Putin set to visit next year.

site_title: Finnish town may be world's happiest place
summary: A small Finnish town, Kauniainen, may be the world's happiest place, according to a survey that found its residents to be the most satisfied in Finland. Despite Finland being named the world's happiest country by the UN, Kauniainen's residents were more satisfied, with low crime rates, high-quality education, and affordable services like universal healthcare and childcare. The town's low inequality and strong sense of solidarity contribute to its residents' contentment. With a high proportion of high-earners and subsidized services, Kauniainen offers residents many opportunities for personal growth and development, making it a unique example of a happy community.

site_title: Shutdown cuts Christmas vacation short for Federal employees
summary: The US government shutdown has cut short Christmas vacation for approximately 400,000 essential federal employees. They must return to work on Wednesday without pay, as the shutdown has no impact on vacation time. The shutdown, the third this year, is due to a dispute over border wall funding. Lawmakers have passed a bill to retroactively pay workers once a spending deal is reached, but the shutdown could last into the new year, affecting about half of the 800,000 federal workers.

site_title: Big discounts fail to draw UK shoppers to post-Christmas sales
summary: UK post-Christmas sales saw a 4.2% decline in shoppers compared to the previous year, with out-of-town stores and shopping centers experiencing a 6.7% drop. Traditional town and city shopping streets saw a 2.8% drop. Despite heavy discounting, shoppers were deterred by the trend of eating and drinking on high streets, benefiting from more venues. International tourists, driven by the weaker pound, boosted footfall in London's shopping districts, with forecasts suggesting $63 million would be spent in the area by the end of the day.

site_title: Thai farmers giddy over new medical marijuana law
summary: Thai farmers welcomed a new law allowing the cultivation and use of marijuana for medical purposes, a significant step for the region. The National Assembly passed a bill Tuesday, legalising the use of marijuana and kratom for research and medical use. The move promises an economic bonanza, but also raises concerns that foreign companies could reap the rewards. The law allows for the production, import, and export of marijuana, marking an Asian first in the use of marijuana for medical purposes.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 2-month low on US political uncertainties; won flat
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1.31% to a near two-month low of 2,028.01, amid US political uncertainties and a weakening economy. The index hit a 16.7% decline so far this year and a 1.22% drop in the past 30 days. The won remained flat against the US dollar, while bond yields fell. Investors are concerned about the partial US government shutdown and President Trump's comments on the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Home price gains in 20 US cities slow for a seventh month
summary: Home prices in 20 US cities rose 5% from a year earlier in October, extending a seventh consecutive month of slowing gains, according to S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data. This marks the longest streak since 2014, indicating waning demand amid higher mortgage rates and elevated property values. Economists had forecast a 4.9% gain. The data suggests a broad slowdown in the housing market, with sales and building also showing recent signs of weakness.

site_title: Brigitte Bardot seeks Christmas 'miracle' for animals
summary: French actress and animal rights activist Brigitte Bardot has written a public letter to President Emmanuel Macron, urging him to implement a Christmas "miracle" by installing closed circuit TV in abattoirs and banning hunting. Bardot claims the government has shown a "shameful attitude" towards animal protection, calling France a "recreational facility for the extermination of animals." The 84-year-old activist is seeking a change in policy to improve animal welfare.

images.alt_text: Iconic former French film star and animal rights activist Brigitte Bardot has asked President Emmanuel Macron for a Christmas "miracle", with closed circuit TV in abattoirs and a curb to hunting.

site_title: Gaw Capital Partners said to be buying Robinson 77 for about S$710m
summary: Gaw Capital Partners, a Hong Kong-based private equity firm, is acquiring Robinson 77 in Singapore for approximately S$710 million. The price works out to about S$2,300 per square foot on a net lettable area of 307,585 sq ft. The seller, a CLSA Real Estate-managed fund, completed a major refurbishment of the 35-storey building in 2017. Analysts expect the acquisition to be a yield play, as the property boasts a 90-metre-long frontage, 137 carpark lots, and proximity to four MRT stations.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect the group's acquisition of Robinson 77 to be pretty much a yield play for now, given the substantial asset enhancement works done.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: West Knighton Limited, a special purpose vehicle indirectly owned by Cityneon group chief executive Ron Tan and Hong Kong entrepreneur Johnson Ko Chun Shun, has extended the closing deadline for its buyout offer for Cityneon Holdings to January 9. The offeror now controls 98.92% of Cityneon shares, allowing it to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares and delist the company. Meanwhile, JEP Holdings subscribed for an additional 2.2 million shares in its unit JEP Precision Engineering for S$11.6 million, and Heeton Holdings disposed of a 40% stake in its unit Prospere Glory for S$20 each.

site_title: World's largest floating LNG platform starts production in Australia
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has begun production at its Prelude floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) facility in Australia, the world's largest floating production structure. The facility, located 475 kilometers north-north east of Broome, has an annual LNG production capacity of 3.6 million tonnes. Shell, which owns 67.5% of the project, expects exports to start by early next year, with condensates likely to start first. The start-up of Prelude is expected to further cement Australia's lead as the world's biggest LNG exporter, following its recent takeover of Qatar as the top LNG exporter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after Christmas selloff
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, rebounding from a 5% drop on Christmas Day. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.89% to 19,327.06, its first positive finish in six sessions. The yen's appreciation helped boost exporter shares, with Toyota and Nintendo rising 1.10% and 1.24% respectively. Despite no clear sign of a US recession, investors remain cautious ahead of Wall Street's reopening. Analysts expect US stocks to track higher as financial markets regain calm.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.3% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.3% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,011.15 points. The market saw 263 losers and 109 gainers, with about 490.8 million shares traded. Key stocks such as Ezion, Keppel Corp, and UOB declined by 2.6%, 1.6%, and 1.6% respectively.

site_title: No winner for Christmas Mega Millions, jackpot grows to US$348m
summary: A US$321 million Mega Millions jackpot went unclaimed on Christmas Day, growing to $348 million for the next drawing on Friday. No one matched the winning numbers, and it's the fifth time a Christmas Day drawing has failed to produce a winner. The odds of winning the jackpot are 1 in 302.6 million, while the chance of winning any prize, including a $2 ticket, is 1 in 24.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.22 points to 1,672.60. The index saw 1.4 billion lots traded worth RM966.8 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 567 to 208, indicating a bearish trend.

site_title: US$5.6 trillion Asia stock loss has traders on edge of their seats
summary: Asia's stock markets have suffered a significant loss of $5.6 trillion in equity value this year, with traders bracing for volatile days ahead. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average experienced choppy trading, with the Nikkei closing 0.9% higher despite entering a bear market on Christmas Day. Investors remain cautious amid concerns over the US bull market's end, following President Trump's comments on dismissing the Fed Chairman.

site_title: Heeton cuts stake in subsidiary Prospere Glory to 60%
summary: Heeton Holdings has cut its stake in subsidiary Prospere Glory to 60% after disposing of 40% of its shares. The real estate firm sold 20% of Prospere Glory's shareholding interest to two companies, KSH Investments and Ho Lee Properties, for S$20 each. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on Heeton's earnings and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday trading at 3,011.49, down 1.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday at 3,011.49, down 1.3% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index fell 39.57 points, with 232 losers outweighing 85 gainers. The most actively traded counter, Ezion, was flat, while Keppel Corp and Singtel fell 2.6% and 1.7%, respectively. Trading volume was 237.7 million shares worth S$260.3 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore manufacturing saw a 7.6% increase in November, surpassing estimates, with a 2.8% month-on-month growth driven by the biomedical sector. Keppel secured S$300m in marine contracts and Singtel appointed new board members, including Gail Kelly and Bradley Horowitz. The Singapore shares closed 1.3% lower on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: ON a seasonally adjusted month-on-month basis, output rose 2.8 per cent in November, pulled up by the biomedical sector - without which growth would have been flat.

site_title: Airlines are catering to their smallest customers: children
summary: Airlines are catering to their youngest passengers, offering new amenities such as toys, child-friendly toiletry kits, meals, and entertainment options. Emirates introduced a "Kids Kit" with travel-themed items, while Qatar Airways offers an activity pack and Qantas provides an activity book with puzzles. Turkish Airlines provides a backpack amenity kit with child-sized essentials. These offerings aim to keep children occupied and happy during long flights, ultimately pleasing parents and increasing the airline's appeal.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 15.31 points to 1,668.51 at 9:01am on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 56.61 million lots worth RM18 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 192 to 30.

site_title: Singtel adds ex-Westpac chief Gail Kelly, Google exec Bradley Horowitz to board
summary: Singtel has appointed two new board members, former Westpac CEO Gail Kelly and Google executive Bradley Horowitz, effective December 26. Kelly brings experience in finance and global operations, while Horowitz has expertise in technology and innovation. Singtel chairman Simon Israel stated that the new additions will be invaluable in navigating the company's transformation journey in a fast-changing landscape. With the additions, Singtel's board now consists of 11 members.

site_title: Yongnam Holdings secures contracts worth S$73.4m
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Yongnam Holdings has secured contracts worth S$73.4 million in Australia and Singapore. The structural steel and specialist civil engineering firm has entered the Australian market with several contracts, including a S$47 million deal for Melbourne infrastructural developments. In Singapore, Yongnam has two contracts for structural steelwork projects, expected to be completed by 2020 and 2021. The deals are expected to positively impact the firm's financial performance for the year ending Dec 31, 2018.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Nissan updates governance code to address cross-shareholding
summary: Nissan Motor Co updated its corporate governance code, clarifying its policy on cross-shareholdings, amid tensions with partner Renault SA following the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn. The new code requires the board to examine the purpose and benefits of cross-shareholdings, and consider selling shares if they are deemed inappropriate. Nissan shares rose 3.3% in response, while Renault asked Nissan to call a shareholder meeting to discuss corporate governance issues. The two companies have differed on how to address Ghosn's arrest, with Nissan sacking him immediately and Renault naming a deputy CEO.

site_title: Asia: Most markets decline in line with global equity rout
summary: Southeast Asian stock markets declined on Dec 26, 2018, following a global equity rout triggered by US political concerns. Singapore's markets fell the most, while local trading volumes were subdued due to the holiday season. Investors fear-mongered over US President Trump's potential actions, including sacking the Federal Reserve Chairman. Global equity markets experienced a tailspin, with US equities falling on Christmas Eve.

site_title: German industry views Brexit, Trump as biggest risks to economy
summary: Germany's leading industry groups view Brexit and US President Donald Trump's 'America First' policies as the biggest risks to the country's economy. The economy is expected to post its weakest growth rate in years, but domestic demand remains strong. Industry leaders warn that a no-deal Brexit would create massive uncertainties for trade and business, while escalating international trade disputes could derail the economic upswing. They call for the government to lower corporate taxes and invest in digital infrastructure to support companies. A growth rate of around 1.5% is predicted for 2019.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda blames stock rout on heightening global uncertainty
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda attributed recent stock market instability to growing global economic uncertainties, citing protectionism and slowing growth in China. Despite acknowledging it's taking longer than expected to achieve a 2% inflation target, Kuroda expressed confidence in Japan's economy's resilience, citing solid US economic growth and companies' efforts to boost profitability. The BOJ must balance policy benefits and costs, particularly considering the rising costs of prolonged monetary easing, under the yield curve control policy.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda blamed recent instability in stock markets on growing global economic uncertainties, but said the world's third-largest economy was resilient enough to withstand any external shocks.

site_title: SHS units obtain extension for Bangladesh power plant, divest Vietnam plant
summary: SHS Holdings has received an extension for a 50 MW solar power plant in Bangladesh, with the new commercial operations date set for October 31, 2019. The extension avoids US$912,500 in liquidated damages, and SHS Holdings will provide updates on the project's progress. Separately, the company has divested a solar power plant in Vietnam and signed a power purchase agreement for the electricity produced by the plant. The divestment is expected to result in a gain of about US$1.1 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks weighed down by US equity rout, oil prices
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.43% on Wednesday due to the US equity rout and low oil prices. The Straits Times Index fell to 3,007.41 points. Financials, tech stocks, and oil-linked counters were under pressure. Investors are seeking shelter in gold, with prices near US$1,255 levels. The US dollar weakened against most Asian currencies, including the Singapore dollar, amid US political uncertainty.

site_title: Starbucks' expansion runs out of steam in South Africa
summary: Starbucks' expansion plans in South Africa have been put on hold due to high operating costs and tight customer budgets. The company had aimed to open 45 stores by 2020, but now plans to pause further openings. High costs, including importing ingredients and materials, have made it difficult for Starbucks to make a profit in the country. The South African coffee market is also highly competitive, with local chains and independent outlets offering similar products at lower prices.

site_title: Japanese brokerage cuts CEO, chairman pay over insider trading scandal
summary: Japanese brokerage SMBC Nikko Securities Inc has cut CEO Yoshihiko Shimizu and chairman Tetsuya Kubo's pay by 20% for two months after a former employee was arrested on suspicion of insider trading. The move is a gesture of contrition and responsibility, widely used in Japan to show accountability without resigning. The firm has pledged to restore trust following the incident, which allegedly involved insider trading tips. This is the latest example of executives taking pay cuts in Japan following scandals.

site_title: Keppel bags S$300m of marine contracts; Keppel T&T sells stakes in Thai IT firms
summary: Keppel Corp's unit Keppel Offshore & Marine secured S$300m in new marine contracts, including a LNG bunker vessel and a floating production storage and offloading vessel. Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation sold stakes in Thai IT firms Advanced Research Group Co and Anew Corporation Limited for S$8.8 million. The deals are expected to result in a net gain of S$5.2 million in Keppel's profit and loss account.

site_title: Parents scramble to keep up as TikTok videos take hold with teens
summary: Millions of teenagers are flocking to TikTok, the most downloaded app on Apple's App Store, with 500 million users as of June. The app, owned by China's ByteDance, allows users to share short videos, but critics say it exposes young girls to caustic comments and potential abuse. Parents are concerned about the app's popularity among young girls, who are often bombarded with disturbing content. Analysts say the app's low age limit of 12 allows a "greater assortment of dangerous characters" to join, but raising the age limit could curb growth.

site_title: Beijing to help banks replenish capital through various channels
summary: The Financial Stability and Development Committee under the State Council announced plans to help Chinese banks replenish capital through various channels to issue perpetual bonds. Many Chinese banks face pressure to write off bad loans and meet stringent capital rules, but they have limited funding channels due to a bearish stock market. The goal is to enable banks to issue perpetual bonds as soon as possible, allowing them to raise capital and meet regulatory requirements. This move aims to support the struggling economy amid a prolonged Sino-US trade war.

site_title: Malaysia reviewing palm oil export taxes for competitiveness: minister
summary: Malaysia is reviewing its palm oil export duty structure to ensure market competitiveness, according to Primary Industries Minister Teresa Kok. This move aims to boost demand and reduce the country's stockpiles, which are at their highest in nearly 18 years. The review comes as palm oil producers in Southeast Asia face slow exports due to waning demand and higher import taxes.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources secures A$150m loan facilities to aid Stanmore Coal bid
summary: Golden Energy and Resources secured A$150 million loan facilities from Credit Suisse to finance its acquisition of Stanmore Coal shares. The loan is secured by shares in PT Golden Energy Mines Tbk and a guarantee agreement. This follows Gear's initial bid of A$47.6 million for a 19.9% stake in Stanmore, with plans to eventually own a 51% joint venture.

site_title: Japan announces IWC withdrawal, will resume commercial whaling
summary: Japan is withdrawing from the International Whaling Commission (IWC) and will resume commercial whaling in July 2020, a move expected to spark international criticism. The decision comes after Japan failed to convince the IWC to allow it to resume commercial whaling earlier this year. The government's decision was made to allow Japan to catch up to its historical whaling quota, which it claims is necessary for food security and research purposes. The move is likely to be met with opposition from conservation groups and other countries.

site_title: From wacky to well meaning, 7 upbeat stories of improving lives in 2018
summary: In 2018, various efforts aimed at improving lives worldwide received attention. A Ugandan man, Louis Lakor, now helps ex-child soldiers acquire skills to reintegrate into society. A new puppet, Lily, was introduced on Sesame Street to address homelessness. A Barbie doll championing women's rights was released, while in India, a million slum dwellers gained homeownership through a land rights program. Kenyan women are becoming their own advocates in court, and a women-run train station in India improved services. A Caribbean island resort recovered from Hurricane Irma by restoring natural habitats. These stories offer a contrast to the year's more somber headlines.

site_title: Buyout offer for Cityneon extended to Jan 9
summary: A buyout offer for Cityneon Holdings has been extended to January 9, allowing the offeror, West Knighton Limited, to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares. The offeror, indirectly owned by Cityneon CEO Ron Tan and Hong Kong investor Johnson Ko, currently holds a 97.73% stake in the company. Dissenting shareholders will receive a letter on the acquisition process. The offer was initially set to close on December 26.

site_title: Ghosn's ex-aide leaves jail after court grants bail
summary: Greg Kelly, a Nissan Motor Co director and former aide to Carlos Ghosn, was granted bail and released from a Tokyo detention center after spending over a month in jail. Kelly, who faces allegations of helping Ghosn under-report his compensation by tens of millions of dollars, was set free with a 70 million yen (S$869,000) bail. Kelly will remain in Japan, with conditions including a ban on leaving the country and avoiding contact with those involved in the allegations. Ghosn remains in jail on more serious allegations, with his detention set to continue until January 1.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing up 7.6% in November, beating estimates
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 7.6% year-on-year in November, beating economist estimates, with the biomedical sector driving the growth. Excluding the biomedical sector, output rose 5.3%. Key sectors that contributed to the growth include transport engineering, which rose 11.3%, and electronics, which turned around after two consecutive months of decline. Chemicals output also grew 3.4%, while general manufacturing and precision engineering saw declines.

site_title: What your palate can expect in 2019
summary: In 2019, Americans can expect a quiet, restorative year with a focus on healthy eating and reduced waste. Key trends include the rise of lesser-known lettuce varieties, sour and funky flavors, cheese tea, and salad robots. The year will also see an emphasis on gut health, low-carb diets, and plant-based main courses. Lighter wines and spirits-free cocktails will be popular, and restaurants will prioritize reducing packaging waste. Laboratory-grown proteins and vegan alternatives will also enter the mainstream, while the role of immigrants in American food culture will be highlighted.

site_title: US oil prices rebound after tumbling to lowest since June 2017 on economy fears
summary: US oil prices rebounded 35 cents, or 0.82%, to $42.88 per barrel, after tumbling to their lowest since June 2017 due to global economic concerns. Despite mixed trading, US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose from a 6.7% drop in the previous session. Broader financial markets remain under pressure due to worries about a global economic slowdown, higher US interest rates, and the US-China trade dispute. Opec's supply cuts, led by Russia, aim to reassure markets but concerns persist unless deeper cuts are implemented.

site_title: Pacific Star Development to take full control of Puteri Cove project for S$26m
summary: Pacific Star Development (PSD) is buying out its joint venture partner, Max Treasure Co, in the Puteri Cove Residences project in Malaysia for S$26 million. This deal will allow PSD to obtain a S$70 million loan facility to fund its working capital and a property development project in Bangkok. As a result, PSD will become the sole shareholder of Twin Prosperity, the holding company of the Puteri Cove project, and will have a higher net tangible asset per share. The loan facility bears an annual cash coupon of 7.5% and is secured by PSD's assets.

site_title: JTC launches last 4 industrial sites under confirmed, reserved lists for 2nd-half year
summary: JTC launches four industrial sites for the second half of 2018 Industrial Government Land Sales Programme, with two sites available for tender and two for application. The tender sites are a 20-year leasehold parcel at Jalan Papan and a 30-year, 2.09 ha plot at Woodlands Avenue 12, while the application sites are a 1.2 ha parcel at Gambas Way and a 2.0 ha parcel at Benoi Sector. All sites are zoned for Business-2 use and carry varying lease terms.

site_title: Two Koreas to pledge road, rail links on divided peninsula
summary: A South Korean delegation departed for North Korea to attend a ceremony for reconnecting roads and railways across the divided peninsula, despite stalled denuclearisation talks. The event, agreed upon by President Moon Jae In and North's leader Kim Jong Un in September, aims to express a commitment to the projects, which will depend on progress on the North's denuclearisation and sanctions. The ceremony is attended by officials from Russia, China, and Mongolia, and marks a step towards reconnecting the two Koreas, which remain technically at war.

site_title: Aspen to seek mandate for share buybacks
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings plans to propose and seek shareholder approval for a share buyback mandate, aiming to manage dilutive impact of share-based incentive schemes and mitigate market volatility. The move will help offset short-term speculation and bolster shareholders' confidence. Aspen's shareholders will vote on the mandate at a general meeting. The company plans to use the share buyback to reduce the number of outstanding shares and minimize the impact on its two existing schemes.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Wednesday's open; STI down 1.43% to 3,007.41
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.43% to 3,007.41 at Wednesday's open, following a Christmas Eve plunge on Wall Street. The index had a heavy trading day with 31.4 million securities worth S$53.6 million changing hands. Key losers included Ezion Holdings, Singtel, DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and Keppel Corp, with declines ranging from 1.4% to 2.4%. The decline was attributed to the global market's weakness.

site_title: South Korea central bank sets open-ended inflation target of 2.0%
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, set an open-ended annual inflation target of 2.0% effective from 2019, unchanged from the previous target. The bank removed the three-year time limit, reviewing the target every two years. It will maintain an accommodative monetary policy stance in 2019 without specifying near-term rate changes. The decision aims to address reduced volatility in consumer prices.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank on Wednesday set an open-ended annual inflation target of 2.0 per cent, effective from 2019, unchanged from the target that expires at year-end.

site_title: Trump says partial US government shutdown to last until agreement on border wall
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the partial government shutdown will continue until his demand for border wall funding is met. He reiterated his concerns about the Federal Reserve raising interest rates too fast. The shutdown, which began on December 22, is the third this year. Trump's comments came after a video conference with US troops abroad.

images.alt_text: United States President Donald Trump on Tuesday said the partial shutdown of the federal government was going to last until his demand for funds to build a US-Mexico border wall is met.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Keppel T&T, Pacific Star, Aspen
summary: Keppel Corp secured new marine contracts worth S$300 million. Keppel T&T divested stakes in Thai companies for S$8.8 million and acquired a 4% stake in a business information service provider. Pacific Star Development bought out its joint venture partner in the Puteri Cove Residences project to secure a S$70 million loan facility. Aspen (Group) Holdings proposed a share buyback mandate to manage share dilution and mitigate market volatility.

site_title: Trump downbeat on Federal Reserve as markets nosedive
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed disappointment with the Federal Reserve, criticizing its interest rate hikes as too fast, amidst the stock market's worst December since the Great Depression. Trump also marked Christmas with a downbeat gathering at the Oval Office, where he denied any involvement in a possible firing of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and criticized Democrats for denying him funding for his southern border wall. The partial government shutdown, now in its fourth day, has no end in sight, with Trump refusing to sign a budget bill until he secures US$5 billion for the wall.

site_title: Nissan executive linked to Ghosn case released on bail
summary: Japanese authorities released Nissan executive Greg Kelly on bail, 70 million yen (S$872,000), after the Tokyo District Court approved a request by his lawyers. Kelly, 62, faces allegations of helping Carlos Ghosn under-report his compensation at Nissan for eight years. He was granted bail on condition that he would not leave Japan, make contact with anyone involved in the case, or destroy evidence. Kelly's release comes as Ghosn remains in detention, with prosecutors still investigating the period from 2015.

site_title: India's longest road-rail bridge bolsters defence on China border
summary: India has opened its longest rail-road bridge, the 4.9km Bogibeel bridge, in Assam state, bolstering its defense on the sensitive border with China. The bridge, costing $800 million, allows for faster military dispatch to neighboring Arunachal Pradesh, which borders China. It also shortens the rail journey by 750km and can bear the weight of India's heaviest battle tanks. The bridge is the second longest in India, following the 9.1km Dhola-Sadiya bridge opened in 2017.

site_title: Gold hits six-month high as stock turmoil spurs demand for haven
summary: Gold prices reached a six-month high on December 26, 2018, amid global stock turmoil, the partial US government shutdown, and concerns over the US economy. The metal rose 0.2% to $1,271.36 an ounce, its highest level since June, as investors sought a safe-haven asset. Money managers were bullish on prices, the largest in half a year, and gold-backed exchange-traded funds holdings surged. The US government shutdown and uncertainty over US interest rates contributed to the metal's rally, with prices expected to rise further this month.

site_title: Top Trump aide says government shutdown may go into New Year when new Congress convenes
summary: US President Donald Trump's budget director and chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, said the partial government shutdown may continue until January 3, when the new Congress convenes. The shutdown, sparked by Trump's demand for more funds for a border wall, has left over 400,000 employees without pay and 380,000 on temporary leave. Mulvaney attributed the impasse to Democratic opposition, claiming they are seeking to delay negotiations until after the new speaker is elected.

site_title: Hong Kong, Australia, New Zealand: Markets closed for holiday on Wed
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong, Australia, and New Zealand are closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, global markets continue to show resilience, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) edged up 0.4% on Thursday, while NTT DC Reit's public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription.

site_title: Emerging nations will take longer to outpace developed economies: Cebr
summary: Emerging nations, including China, India, and Brazil, are expected to take longer to surpass developed economies, according to a Centre for Economics and Business Research report. China is now predicted to overtake the US as the world's No. 1 economy in 2032, two years later than previously expected. Emerging economies are forecast to face a "bumpy" growth path, with a 2.99% increase in world trade growth this year, less than two-thirds of the increase in 2017. Policymakers have enough ammunition to mitigate the risk of a global recession, with a focus on fiscal action.

site_title: Indonesia rescuers scramble to reach isolated tsunami-struck towns
summary: Indonesian search and rescue teams are working to reach isolated tsunami-struck towns in western Java and south Sumatra, where over 400 people were killed. Medical workers warn of a public health crisis due to low clean water and medicine supplies. Thousands of displaced survivors are in shelters and hospitals, with many left homeless by the killer wave. Helicopters have been dispatched to drop supplies into hard-to-reach communities. The disaster agency is racing against time to provide aid to the affected areas.

images.alt_text: Indonesian search and rescue teams on Wednesday plucked stranded residents from remote islands and pushed into isolated communities still desperate for aid in the aftermath of a volcano-triggered tsunami that killed more than 400.

site_title: Whiff of extinction blows in bull market that outlived them all
summary: The US bull market, which has lasted 10 years and outlasted all its predecessors, is on the verge of collapse. The S&P 500 has plummeted 19.8% in three months, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average is poised for its worst December since 1931. Despite strong fundamentals, including rising GDP and profits, investors are turning on the market due to concerns about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The market's prolonged rally has also been criticized for favoring the wealthy and ignoring stagnant wages. While a recovery is possible, the fundamentals suggest a prolonged bear market may be underway.

site_title: Eight killed in China as hijacked bus crashes into pedestrians
summary: Eight people were killed and 22 injured in a hijacked bus crash into pedestrians in Longyan, Fujian province, China on Tuesday. A 48-year-old local man, surnamed Qiu, hijacked the bus after a quarrel with a local official and attacked a female passenger before detaining a policeman. This incident is part of a recent spate of violent attacks in China, including a car accident that killed five people and a man who drove into a crowd and attacked onlookers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded 1.45% or 277.75 points to 19,433.49, following a 5% drop on Tuesday, as the yen's rise took a breather. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index rose 1.37% and 1.37% respectively. The rebound comes after a 20-month low on US economy worries.

site_title: Thailand names Ministry of Justice's Ruenvadee Suwanmongkol as capital market regulator chief
summary: Thailand appointed Ruenvadee Suwanmongkol as secretary general of the Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC), marking the first time a woman will lead the capital market regulator. Ruenvadee, 54, previously worked at the Ministry of Justice and has a law degree from Harvard University and an MBA from the University of California at Berkeley. Her appointment is set to begin on May 1, following a cabinet approval by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha.

images.alt_text: Thailand named Ruenvadee Suwanmongkol as secretary general of the Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC), appointing a woman to run the market regulator for the first time.

site_title: Singapore goes underground to boost land use
summary: Singapore plans to unveil an Underground Master Plan in 2019, featuring data centers, utility plants, bus depots, and other facilities to address the city-state's space crunch. With a growing population of 6.9 million by 2030, Singapore aims to make better use of its underground space to free up surface land for housing, offices, and greenery. The plan uses 3D technology to visualize space and aims to alleviate the monotony of underground spaces. The initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to integrate the underground cityscape and keep its cities liveable, as the world's population is expected to reach 70% urban by 2050.

site_title: Britain bans puppy and kitten sales by pet shops
summary: Britain has banned the sale of puppies and kittens by pet shops in a bid to combat animal exploitation and abuse. The ban, set to take effect next year, will require buyers to either deal directly with the breeder or adopt from an animal re-homing centre. The measure, dubbed Lucy's Law, aims to end welfare conditions found in puppy farming and improve animal welfare. The ban is supported by 95% of the public and is expected to affect high-volume, low-welfare breeders.

site_title: Satellites to safety apps: 10 new uses of technology to help people in 2018
summary: In 2018, governments and companies employed technology to help people globally. New uses included drone-delivered vaccines, satellites tracking forced labor, and safety apps mapping harassment hotspots. Other innovations included apps identifying crop-munching pests, mosquito-fighting drones, satellite mapping of slums, and blockchain systems to combat human trafficking. Additionally, virtual reality training programs and mobile phones detecting counterfeit seeds were launched to combat issues such as harassment, labor exploitation, and food insecurity.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc rise as investors seek safe havens
summary: The Japanese yen and Swiss franc rose on Monday as investors sought safe-havens due to fragile sentiment in financial markets amid US political instability and fears of a global economic slowdown. Trading volumes were thin, and stocks experienced their worst quarterly performance since 2008. The dollar index lost 0.2% to 96.76, while the yen and Swiss franc gained 0.1% each on the dollar. This move was driven by the US Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates and concerns over higher borrowing costs hurting corporate profits and the US economy.

site_title: HK exchange rejects CNMC Goldmine's dual listing application
summary: HONG KONG'S STOCK EXCHANGE has rejected CNMC Goldmine's application for a dual listing on its mainboard, citing the company's inability to meet the minimum market capitalisation requirement of HK$500 million. CNMC's current market capitalisation is less than HK$500 million, and its share price has been declining. The listing committee also noted that the proposed dual listing would not create meaningful liquidity for the company's shares in Hong Kong. CNMC's board has accepted the outcome and will re-evaluate its plans.

site_title: World steps up to study India's cash ban while Modi looks away
summary: India's 2016 currency ban, also known as demonetisation, has been studied by economists worldwide, revealing a relatively smaller decline in output than initially thought. However, the policy's long-term consequences remain unclear. Critics argue that policymakers underestimated the impact of the move, which reduced the availability of currency and exacerbated the country's vast informal economy. Despite negative economic effects, the policy still gained support in some areas, with the ruling party benefiting in unbanked districts. Economists call for deeper evaluations of the policy's effects.

site_title: Bank of Japan divided over side effects of easy policy: Oct minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers are divided on the feasibility of allowing bond yields to move more flexibly around the central bank's zero per cent target. One member suggests widening the range of bond yields or shortening the duration of the government bond yield target, while another warns that this could cast doubt on the BOJ's commitment to achieve its price target, citing low inflation. The disagreement reflects growing concerns about the demerits of prolonged easing.

site_title: China growth to slow, economy to remain strained
summary: China's economy is expected to remain strained in 2019, with growth slowing to under 6.5% due to a slump in the property market, trade war uncertainties, and a global economic slowdown. Despite this, analysts believe the government has leeway to support the economy, and growth is likely to stay above 6%. Beijing will continue to implement measures to boost infrastructure projects, loosen credit conditions, and monetary policy to keep growth above 6%.

site_title: Vocal minority of investors echo Trump's concerns over Fed fiscal tightening
summary: US President Donald Trump and a growing chorus of investors are questioning the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes, citing concerns over stifling growth and potential recession. The Fed's policy error is being echoed by analysts, with some warning that the central bank's approach is too restrictive and that monetary policy is being too tight. The S&P 500 has tumbled over 7% and the Treasury yield curve has flattened, sparking fears of an inversion that could signal recession. A growing number of investors, including those at TD Securities, Guggenheim Partners, and Deutsche Asset Management, are sounding the alarm on Fed policy, calling for careful consideration of the risks to growth and wealth.

site_title: Rescuers race to find tsunami survivors as toll expected to rise
summary: A tsunami triggered by a volcano in Indonesia's Sunda Strait killed at least 281 people, with over 1,000 injured and thousands evacuated. The disaster, which occurred on December 22, 2018, was caused by the collapse of Anak Krakatau volcano, which led to a 2-3 meter high tsunami. Experts warn of further deadly waves due to volcanic instability. Rescue efforts are ongoing, with Indonesian President Joko Widodo visiting the area and international aid agencies providing assistance.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo walking past debris by the beach at the Mutiara Carita Cottages in Carita in Banten province on Monday. The volcano-triggered tsunami killed at least 281 people.

site_title: Italy rejigs measures to spur sale of green cars
summary: Italy has approved measures to encourage the sale of green cars, offering subsidies of up to 6,000 euros for new low-emission vehicles. The country will also impose taxes on larger petrol and diesel cars, with higher rates applying to high-powered vehicles. The new rules, which come into effect March 1, aim to reduce emissions and promote sustainable transportation. The measures have been met with criticism from the car industry, with unions warning of potential job losses.

site_title: Cromwell Reit forking out 21.6m euros for 3 Paris properties
summary: Cromwell European Reit is acquiring three freehold logistics properties in France for 21.6 million euros (S$33.75 million), gaining exposure to the Greater Paris logistics market. The properties, located in Sully-sur-Loire, Villeneuve-lès-Béziers, and Parcay-Meslay, have a net initial yield of 8.5% and will increase Cromwell's portfolio valuation by 2.6%. The acquisition is part of a larger expansion plan, which includes 23 properties across five countries in Europe valued at 384.4 million euros.

site_title: The all-American muscle car will outlive the doomed sedan
summary: US car manufacturers are shifting focus away from sedans, with sales declining 21% in 2018, while muscle cars continue to hold on. The Dodge Challenger and Charger, with average transaction prices of around $36,000, remain profitable for Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA). Despite sales down 11% this year, FCA expects to sell around 65,000 Challengers, and sales of the Ford Mustang, the top-selling muscle car, dropped only 3.6%. Manufacturers are reviving sedans by adding more powerful engines and special editions, but the future of muscle cars may be electrified, with plug-in hybrid versions taking off in the future.

site_title: Cold War not inevitable; US and Chinese leaders should not give up
summary: A debate in Washington is underway over the future of the US-China relationship, with "determinists" predicting a Cold War due to ongoing trade and security disputes. However, "pragmatists" argue that a conventional wisdom of inevitable conflict is misplaced, citing the success of engagement strategies with Japan in the 1970s and 1980s. The US and China must find ways to manage their differences, including resolving intellectual property rights and national security issues, and there is no reason for leaders to give up on trying to manage tensions peacefully.

site_title: Bottleneck at printers derails holiday book sales in US
summary: US holiday book sales have been impacted by a shortage of printed copies due to a surge in demand and a backlog at printing presses. Despite strong sales of critically acclaimed titles, many popular books, including best-sellers and literary fiction, were out of stock on Amazon during the holiday season. The shortage is attributed to shrinking and consolidation in the printing industry, global paper shortages, and a tight job market. Publishers have shifted release dates for January books due to the backlog, with some titles showing shipping dates of two to four weeks.

site_title: Lacking drivers, STI ekes out 0.16% gain
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.16% higher on Christmas Eve, reaching 3,051.06, due to a thin trading session. Investors were cautious amid US political instability, with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin convening a "Plunge Protection Team" to address market concerns. Crude oil prices continued to fall, affecting oil-linked counters such as Ezion Holdings and Rex International. The US government shutdown also weighed on investors' minds, with some predicting a prolonged shutdown.

site_title: World economy set to feel delayed trade war pain in 2019
summary: The global economy is expected to feel the delayed pain of the US-China trade war in 2019. Despite efforts to resolve the trade spat, trade volumes are forecast to slow to 4% in 2019, down from 4.2% in 2018 and 5.2% in 2017. Companies are warning of ongoing disruption, with FedEx and GoPro already taking action to mitigate the impact. The International Monetary Fund warns that trade barriers have become more pronounced, and the risk of additional tariffs on auto imports from Europe and Japan poses a significant threat to global growth.

images.alt_text: While 2018 was the year trade wars broke out, 2019 will be the year the global economy feels the pain.

site_title: May your days be merry and bright
summary: A 12-metre-tall Christmas tree, 'The Tree of ImagiNature', was unveiled at Millenia Walk in Singapore, featuring a wood and PVC design with individually spray-painted and assembled panels. The tree's inside is covered with mirrored gold stickers, creating a kaleidoscope of reflection and light, embodying the themes of imagination and warm togetherness.

site_title: Private rental market may be held up by en bloc sellers, lower supply
summary: Singapore's private residential leasing market is expected to improve in 2019, driven by easing supply and supported demand from displaced owners and citizens/PRs. The URA forecasts 10,119 private units to be completed in 2019, lower than the 12,950-unit ten-year average. Analysts predict a landlords' market, with rents likely to increase 1-3% in 2019. Expatriate demand may soften due to global economic slowdown, but this will be offset by growing demand from Singaporeans and PRs.

site_title: China's language reflects its values and culture
summary: China's language is a reflection of its values and culture, shaped by its history, geography, and social norms. The country's many dialects, which can be mutually unintelligible, have been largely replaced by Mandarin, the official language. This shift has led to a loss of regional dialects and cultural identity. Language also reflects a society's hierarchy and relationships, such as the importance of family ties in Chinese culture. The evolution of Chinese language has also been influenced by globalization and the adoption of foreign terms, with 70% of sociological terms now borrowed from Japan.

site_title: Asia's worst currency isn't stopping bond bulls from charging in
summary: Foreign investors are pouring into South Korean bonds, making them the second-best performers in emerging Asia over the past six months. This year, the nation's debt has attracted $45.6 billion from global funds, seen as a safe-haven investment amidst emerging-market asset sell-offs. The trend is expected to continue, providing more reason for bulls to buy.

site_title: Intelligent cloud: A new 'playing field' for SMEs in the digital economy?
summary: Singaporean SMEs now have a more level playing field in the digital economy due to advancements in cloud, AI, and IoT technologies. These new technologies have increased agility, scalability, and flexibility for small businesses, allowing them to compete more easily with established industry players. This shift has enabled SMEs to enter the market faster and with greater ease.

site_title: Gold rises as political uncertainty in the US breeds risk aversion
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to a six-month high of $1,263.91 per ounce as investors sought refuge from US political uncertainty and a global economic slowdown. The partial US government shutdown and speculation of a less aggressive monetary policy by the US Federal Reserve also boosted demand for the metal. Hedge funds and money managers increased their net long positions in Comex gold to a six-month high, and holdings of the SPDR Gold Trust rose 0.5%.

site_title: Who will blink first in UK's pantomime of Parliament?
summary: The UK's pantomime of Parliament is being criticized for its outdated and insensitive portrayal of characters, particularly the Dame, which mocks transgender issues. In contrast, recent MPs' pantomime centered around Brexit, which has been deemed the most boring subject of the century, has sparked laughter and high viewing figures. The UK's decision to leave the EU in 2016 led to a £39 billion payment and a draft deal allowing the UK to control its destiny, but a border issue with Northern Ireland remains unresolved. The EU and UK are now on the brink of a no-deal Brexit, with both parties facing significant consequences, and it is unclear who will blink first.

site_title: A letter from the CEO of Santa Claus Holdings to his employees
summary: Santa Claus Holdings, a centuries-old consumer conglomerate, is facing disruption in its legacy business due to changing toy consumer habits. The company has embarked on diversifying its business model through initiatives such as Santa-prise, social enterprise play centers, and igloo real estate development. However, these efforts have been hindered by logistical challenges, including the high costs of last-chimney delivery and congestion issues with the reindeer population. The company has also been affected by geopolitical tensions, supply chain disruptions, and the rise of alternative gift options. To address these challenges, Santa Claus Holdings plans to focus on defensive sectors and bolster revenue streams.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower after half-day trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 0.40% at the end of half-day trading on December 24, 2018, with the Hang Seng Index ending at 25,651.38. The markets will resume trading on Thursday, December 27.

site_title: Intellectually disabled patients to get specialist attention at Minds clinic
summary: Singapore's Minds clinic, the only medical clinic dedicated to persons with intellectual disabilities, plans to roll out eye screenings, hearing tests, and dental checks starting in January 2019. The clinic aims to identify and treat medical problems early, as patients with intellectual disabilities often struggle to articulate their issues. The initiative is a partnership with specialists and organizations, including The Singapore Association of the Deaf, and is supported by OCBC Bank, which donated S$100,000 to set up the clinic. This move aims to provide comprehensive healthcare to those who need it most.

site_title: Aquaman makes the biggest splash at box office
summary: Warner Bros' Aquaman dominated North American box office ticket sales over the weekend with $67.4 million in ticket sales, surpassing Disney's Mary Poppins Returns ($22.2 million) and Paramount's Bumblebee ($21 million).

images.alt_text: Aquaman, which stars Jason Momoa in a title role infused with new swagger by director James Wan, raked in US$67.4m in the US over the weekend.

site_title: Italian toy story: retired mechanic carves old favourites
summary: Italian toymaker Mario Collino, a retired mechanic, spends 30 years creating handmade toys and puppets from discarded objects, inspired by childhood memories shared by elderly residents in his native Piedmont region. His workshop near Cuneo produces 138 items, including spinning tops and rabbit-shaped tea towels, each with a story or fairytale in Italian or Piedmontese. His performances, free of charge, showcase his wizardry and Christian devotion to nurturing his inner child.

site_title: BOJ governor's moves could be stealth threat to 2019 stability
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's potential policy shifts could disrupt global markets, despite the BOJ already owning assets worth over Japan's GDP. Any hints of a shift could alarm investors, who have been influenced by years of central bank liquidity. The BOJ's monetary policy may exacerbate regional bank losses, leading to a possible signal of allowing 10-year government bond yields to fluctuate or raising short-term interest rates. This could impact Japanese investors, who have been seeking higher returns abroad, and affect markets such as French and Spanish government debt.

site_title: Netpoleon carves out a niche in competitive cybersecurity market
summary: Netpoleon, a Singapore-based cybersecurity value-added distributor, has carved out a niche in the competitive market by focusing on employee development and creating a nurturing work culture. The company, established in 2000, has expanded across the region and was acquired by Macnica Networks Corporation in 2017. Netpoleon offers holistic services, including technical expertise, proof-of-concept work, and training, to clients, and has successfully navigated the intense competition by investing in its employees and government grants. The company's focus on its people has given it a unique competitive edge in the cybersecurity industry.

site_title: Mnuchin's bid to calm US markets could make things worse
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin attempted to calm US markets by reassuring the financial community on Sunday that market liquidity is in good shape. However, his statement may have had the opposite effect, with some market participants questioning why liquidity has become an issue in the first place. Mnuchin's confirmation of ample liquidity could be seen as suggesting that liquidity has actually become a concern, potentially exacerbating market worries. His efforts to quash concerns may ultimately make things worse for the US stock markets.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin looked to quash big-bank worries over recent plunging stock markets and reports that US President Donald Trump might sack his Federal Reserve chief by reassuring the financial community on Sunday that market liquidity is in good shape.

site_title: AXA's Swiss employees mistakenly get double December pay
summary: AXA's 4,300 Swiss employees received double their normal December salaries due to an error between AXA and its house bank. Employees can either return the money or take it as an advance on their January paychecks. The error could have resulted in overpayments of more than 30 million Swiss francs (S$41.4 million). Despite the mistake, all employees received their December pay on time before Christmas.

site_title: Why 2019 is a big election year across the globe
summary: In 2019, numerous key elections are set to take place globally, with significant impacts on domestic politics, economics, and international relations. These include the Indian general election, European Parliament election, Israeli general election, and presidential elections in South Africa, Nigeria, and Argentina. Foreign political consultants are expected to play a major role, with US consultants already working in over half of the world's countries. The phenomenon is seen as a globalisation of politics, with the potential to promote homogenous campaigns and a repetitive political language.

images.alt_text: The Argentinian presidential election will be closely watched to see if Mr Macri, who recently secured the largest-ever loan from the IMF, at some US$57 billion, can win a second term given that his public approval ratings have sunk as Argentina's economic woes have mounted.

site_title: As WeWork keeps pushing, landlords and rivals push back
summary: WeWork, a US$42 billion office-sharing giant, is expanding into real estate ownership and disrupting the industry by building its own investment division and buying properties. Landlords and rivals are pushing back, with Blackstone Group and Tishman Speyer venturing into flexible-space offerings. WeWork's aggressive expansion threatens to limit its access to buildings, as it competes with traditional landlords and brokers. The company's valuation and credit risk are also being scrutinized by Wall Street investors, who have seen its bonds struggle since their issuance in April.

site_title: Future of transport will be shaped by multiple solutions
