summary: The future of transport will be shaped by multiple solutions, not just one, to meet the global energy and climate challenges. Shell's latest scenario work suggests a rapid transition to a lower-carbon world, with CO2 emissions falling sharply from 2020. Various options, including battery electric power, hydrogen, natural gas, and advanced biofuels, will be explored, with digitalization and autonomous vehicles also playing a key role. Collaboration among governments, companies, and policy makers is essential to meet the challenge posed by the future of transport and reduce emissions to tackle climate change and air pollution.

site_title: London's streets no longer paved with gold as miners struggle
summary: London, once a hub for gold miners, is struggling as companies from Petropavlovsk plc to Centamin plc face financial difficulties. AngloGold Ashanti Ltd's consideration of a London listing provides some festive cheer. The departure of Randgold Resources Ltd, a star performer, will leave a gap for other producers to woo investors. The combined market value of London's gold and silver miners will drop to less than half its £30 billion value six years ago, amid concerns of "value destruction" in the sector.

site_title: JD.com averts crisis as CEO cleared in rape probe
summary: JD.com, China's No 2 online retailer, avoids a major crisis after US prosecutors decide not to press charges against its CEO, Richard Liu, in connection with a rape investigation in Minneapolis. The decision frees JD.com to resume its global ambitions. The probe, which lasted months, cast doubt over JD's leadership, but Liu is now cleared. This outcome avoids the biggest crisis in JD.com's history and allows the company to continue its expansion plans.

site_title: China unveils tariff adjustments for 2019 to boost trade
summary: China has announced tariff adjustments for 2019 to boost foreign trade, removing import duties on alternatives to soymeal and fertilisers, and tariffs on iron ore exports. Import tariffs on pharmaceutical materials and temporary tariffs on manganese slag and lithium-ion battery cells will also be removed. In contrast, over 700 items will be subject to temporary tariffs, and most-favoured-nation tax rates will be imposed on some products. These adjustments aim to counter the slowing economy, which has slowed to 6.5% in the third quarter, amid a trade war with the US.

images.alt_text: China announced on Monday adjustments to some import and export tariffs for 2019, removing import duties on alternatives to soymeal for animal feeds and tariffs on fertilisers and iron ore exports, to boost foreign trade as the economy slows.

site_title: Australia's MYOB backs KKR's reduced A$1.6b buyout offer
summary: Australia's MYOB Group Ltd has backed a reduced A$1.6 billion buyout offer from private equity giant KKR & Co amid market turmoil. The company initially rejected the lower bid but now recommends it to shareholders, citing market uncertainty and the cost of a company restructure. MYOB's shares rose 15% following the decision, while KKR's latest offer price of A$3.40 is below the company's current trading price. The deal would see KKR vote in favor of any higher offer, and MYOB's chairman Justin Milne believes it's in the best interests of shareholders.

site_title: Mattis forced out 2 months early, resignation letter cause of Trump's ire
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the early departure of Defence Secretary Jim Mattis, effective February 28, amid a dispute over Mattis' resignation letter criticizing Trump's foreign policy, including surprise decisions to withdraw troops from Syria and Afghanistan. Mattis' letter, which Trump deemed "ingloriously written," was reportedly dictated to an aide before Trump read it, prompting Trump's ire. Mattis will be replaced by Deputy Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan on an acting basis starting January 1.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 13.54 points to 1,683.82. The market saw 1.3 billion lots traded worth RM875 million, with 428 gainers outnumbering losers 332.

site_title: Bows get bigger as Christmas drives sales of luxe marques
summary: Luxury car sales surge in December, driven by holiday gift-giving, with Mercedes, Lexus, BMW, Lincoln, Cadillac, and Jaguar experiencing significant sales. Dealerships are offering giant bows to make the sales more appealing, with some buying up to 60 bows per year. The bow is seen as a crucial factor in making the sale, with some dealers stating that no bow can mean no sale. December sales of these six luxury marques make up 10-14% of each brand's annual sales, with some dealers arranging surprise deliveries on Christmas Eve.

site_title: Silent Night: How a beautiful carol shone through darkness and hardship
summary: A young Catholic priest in Germany wrote the first words of "Silent Night" in 1816 amid famine and hardship. Two men with a guitar sang the new carol in a church in Oberndorf, Austria, on Christmas Eve 1818, amidst the aftermath of the Napoleonic Wars. The song's message of peace and hope shone through darkness and hardship, becoming a beloved Christmas classic.

site_title: Singtel's Optus extends partnership with fellow Australian telco Vocus
summary: Singtel's Optus has extended its partnership with Australian telco Vocus for five years, providing access to Optus's 5G network and future technologies. The agreement will help Vocus grow its mobile customer base and increase market share in enterprise and small-to-medium business segments. Optus won 47 regional 5G licenses in December, while Vocus secured 131 lots for A$263 million. The partnership puts Vocus in a stronger position to compete with other major telcos in Australia.

site_title: Michael Kum becomes Atlantic Navigation chairman after takeover
summary: Michael Kum has become the non-executive chairman of Atlantic Navigation Holdings after taking over the company through a 50.2% stake acquisition in early December. Wong Siew Cheong remains executive director and CEO. The company has also appointed Sam Chee Leong as an independent director and replaced several other directors. Trading in Atlantic Navigation's shares is suspended due to the reduced public float, but the company and its investment vehicle plan to restore the float.

site_title: China to remove some import, export tariffs including alternative feed meals
summary: China plans to remove import and export tariffs in 2019 on goods including alternative meals used in animal feed to secure supplies amid trade tensions with the US. Import tariffs on alternative meals, including rapeseed meal, cotton meal, and sunflower meal, will be removed from January 1, 2019. The move aims to boost outbound cargoes and improve animal feed supply reliability.

site_title: Canada battery maker says flow storage costs to tumble by half
summary: Canada-based battery maker CellCube Energy Storage Systems Inc. expects the cost of its vanadium redox flow battery units to halve within four years, from $300 to $150 per kilowatt hour. This decrease could boost the technology's adoption over lithium-ion units, particularly for storing intermittent wind and sun-generated power. The global energy storage market is expected to surge to 942 gigawatts by 2040, requiring approximately $620 billion in investment.

site_title: Italian toy story: retired mechanic carves old favourites
summary: Italian toymaker Mario Collino, a retired mechanic, has spent nearly 30 years creating handmade toys, puppets, and curiosities from discarded objects for old-age homes in his native Piedmont region. His 138 creations are brought to life through simple objects and storytelling, with no new or bought items. Collino's performances are free of charge, and he sees it as his Christian duty to nurture his inner child, believing "if you do not become like little children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven."

site_title: Europe: Shares dip in thin holiday trade
summary: European shares fell at the start of a holiday-shortened week, with Britain's FTSE 100 down 0.6% and France's CAC and Spain's IBEX easing 0.7 and 0.5% respectively. Worries over slowing economic growth, tighter monetary conditions, and US government shutdowns weighed on markets. European shares are down 13.5% in 2018, their worst performance since 2008, and are on track for their worst yearly performance since 2008.

images.alt_text: European shares fell at the start of a holiday-shortened week on Monday as worries over slowing economic growth and tighter monetary conditions continued to weigh.

site_title: Santa arrested in Iraq? Social media says yes, police say no
summary: Reports of Santa Claus being arrested in Iraq and Syria on Christmas Eve 2018 sparked widespread social media rumors, with many claiming he was detained by police or drafted into the Syrian army to fight the Islamic State group. However, Iraqi police denied the claims, stating that a photo of Santa was actually taken in Syria, where he was helping distribute presents to children. The incident highlighted the dangers of spreading misinformation, particularly in a country with a history of sectarian violence.

images.alt_text: Never mind who's being naughty or nice, Santa Claus himself supposedly has had bigger problems in Iraq and Syria, where he either did or did not get arrested in the run-up to his big night this year.

site_title: Euronext seeks to buy Oslo stock exchange owner for US$711m
summary: Euronext NV is seeking to acquire Oslo Bors, the owner of the Oslo stock exchange, for approximately $977.6 million. The offer, valued at 625 million euros, represents a 20.8% premium to Oslo Bors' last traded price. The acquisition is part of Euronext's strategy to diversify from share trading, focusing on seafood derivatives, oil services, and shipping. The deal has secured support from 49.6% of Oslo Bors' outstanding shares.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation decreased to 1.7% in November, below economists' expectations of 1.9%. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. In other news, Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident his daughter's suspension as Thai PM in an ethics case will be cleared.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding initial expectations. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs imposed on Canada by the Trump administration. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues. London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green finance.

site_title: The US's complicated Middle East policy mix
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced plans to withdraw 2,000 American troops from Syria within 30 days, citing a decrease in the region's oil reserves as a reason. This decision was met with surprise and criticism from Washington's foreign policy establishment, including Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis' resignation. Trump's long-held criticism of American military intervention in the Middle East and his campaign pledges to reassess the costly strategy have contributed to his decision. The move is part of a broader Realpolitik vision, aiming to create a stable balance of power in the Middle East without US ground troops, and shifts focus towards East Asia to contain rising economic and military power of China.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump said he was ordering a pull-out of the roughly 2,000 US troops in Syria because IS had been defeated, an assessment rubbished by many.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks start the week lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week lower, following a decline on Wall Street last week. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.13% to 25,462.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.38% to 2,506.74. The decline was attributed to ongoing political turbulence in Washington. Asian shares have been affected by US trade policies, despite recent rallies.

site_title: 'Crouching Tiger' star Chow Yun-fat vows to donate fortune
summary: Hong Kong actor Chow Yun-fat, 63, has vowed to donate his estimated US$715 million fortune to charity after his death, citing that wealth is temporary and should be left for others to use. The actor, known for films like "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and "Pirates of the Caribbean", has been praised for his modest lifestyle, often taking public transport and eating at street stalls. Chow's wife supports his decision, and his pledge follows the example of billionaire business figures who have signed "The Giving Pledge".

site_title: Sculptor gets laughs in New York with monuments to fake tragedies
summary: A New York sculptor, Joseph Reginella, creates monuments to fictional tragedies, including a bronze statue commemorating a giant octopus sinking the Staten Island ferry in 1963, a Wall Street bankers' stampede in 1929, and a tugboat crew's alien abduction in 1977. Reginella's sculptures, with accompanying fake documentation, aim to raise questions about the importance of verifying information. His unique art piece has gained popularity, with thousands of fans buying souvenirs and allowing him to finance new projects.

site_title: Top fund proves value investing works in China
summary: A US$442-million fund in China has returned 159% over 5 years by focusing on bargain stocks in the onshore market. The Bank of Communications Schroder Alpha Core Mixed Fund, managed by He Shuai, has outperformed the CSI 300 Index and all its peers, relying on proprietary research to identify sustainable business growth and earnings models. Despite market volatility and swings in speculative money, the fund has held up well, with only a 0.2% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index over the same period.

site_title: Tyrone Thomas, a Citigroup loan sales head, dies at 42
summary: Citigroup Inc. announced the death of Tyrone Thomas, 42, a 15-year veteran and head of North American loan sales, who had been battling brain cancer. Thomas was a founding member of the bank's underrepresented minority senior advisory committee and received a degree in accounting and finance from the State University of New York at Buffalo. Colleagues praised his strong character, infectious laugh, and ability to facilitate positive change. He is survived by his wife and two children.

site_title: Australia's MYOB recommends KKR's lower buyout offer
summary: MYOB Group Ltd has recommended US private equity giant KKR's A$1.8 billion buyout offer for the Australian accounting software maker. KKR initially proposed A$3.40 per share, which was later reduced from A$3.77. MYOB initially rejected the new price but accepted the revised offer. The deal is expected to provide financial stability for the struggling Australian company.

site_title: Far from Washington, the routine symbiosis of the border plays out in Texas and Mexico
summary: US Customs and Border Protection officers on the Hidalgo-Reynosa International Bridge in Texas and Mexico continued their duties despite the partial government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018. Most crossers were unaware of the shutdown, focusing on spending time with family for Christmas. Officers joked about not being paid, but continued their daily duties, including deporting immigrants. Immigration courts were closed, but the Citizenship and Immigration Services agency is scheduled to reopen on December 26. The shutdown has raised concerns about the impact on border security and the effectiveness of the deportation process.

site_title: Praise for English fizz provokes splutters in Champagne
summary: England's record hot summer and limited rainfall have created ideal conditions for high-quality sparkling wine production, threatening the traditional Champagne industry. Vineyards in southeastern England, particularly in Kent, are producing exceptional wines, with some rivaling Champagne in quality. The UK's shift in attitudes towards English sparkling wines has led to a surge in awards and recognition, including the first time English sparkling wines won more gold medals than those from Champagne in the Sommelier Wine Awards. As climate change continues to impact the industry, English producers are capitalizing on their advantages, with some Champagne makers even starting to plant in England.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks closed higher in Monday's half-day trading session, with the Straits Times Index up 0.16% to 3,051.06. The market saw 602.2 million securities traded worth S$461.6 million. Financials led the gains, with DBS Group Holdings up 0.5%, while Ezion Holdings fell 2.3%. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 4.90 points to 1,665.38, with losers outnumbering gainers 195 to 121. Volume reached 218.2 million lots worth RM93.5 million.

site_title: UAE: Opec will hold extra meeting if output cuts 'not enough'
summary: The Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is prepared to hold an emergency meeting if the current 1.2 million barrel-per-day oil output cut does not balance the market next year. UAE Energy Minister Suhail al-Mazrouei stated that producers will extend the agreement if necessary, citing the need to meet market demands. The meeting aims to determine the optimal output level to stabilize the market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CNMC Goldmine, Cromwell E-Reit, Boustead Projects, First Reit
summary: CNMC Goldmine's application for a dual listing on Hong Kong's mainboard was rejected due to inability to meet minimum market capitalisation and liquidity requirements. Cromwell European Reit acquired three logistics properties in France for €21.6 million. Meanwhile, Boustead Projects and First Reit are also on watch for potential developments.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks wobble on US govt shutdown, dim trade talk outlook
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index declined 8.41 points or 0.41% on Monday due to concerns over the US government shutdown and potential delay of Sino-US trade negotiations. The won fell 0.42% against the dollar, while bond yields rose. Aides of US President Donald Trump said the shutdown could be extended to January, and a trade adviser stated it would be difficult to reach an agreement with China unless Beijing overhauls its trade and industrial practices.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.7% to 3,025.23
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 0.7% to 3,025.23. Losers outnumbered gainers 102 to 41 on 37 million shares worth S$81.3 million. Key decliners included Singtel (-1.36%) and Ezion Holdings (-4.55%). Financials, including DBS (-0.68%), UOB (-0.90%), and OCBC (-0.63%), also fell.

site_title: Singtel's Optus extends partnership with fellow Australia telco Vocus Group
summary: Singtel's Optus has extended its five-year partnership with Vocus Group, granting Vocus access to Optus' 5G network and future technologies. The partnership aims to boost Vocus' mobile customer base and market share in enterprise and small-to-medium business segments. Vocus' CEO Kevin Russell stated that the partnership provides security and flexibility to offer attractive mobile propositions. This move strengthens Optus' presence in Australia's telecommunications market, where Telstra and TPG Telecom also operate.

site_title: Bottleneck at printers has derailed some holiday book sales
summary: A surge in holiday book sales has led to a bottleneck at printers, causing stock shortages of popular titles, including critically acclaimed novels and nonfiction books. Despite a 5% rise in unit sales at independent bookstores, publishers struggle to keep up with demand, resulting in delayed shipping dates of two to four weeks. Titles such as "Fear," "The President Is Missing," and "Becoming" have reached the million-copy mark, but their sales have been hindered by printing issues. The shortage has affected Amazon and other retailers, disappointing readers who had been eagerly anticipating these titles.

images.alt_text: This year has been, much to everyone's surprise, a blockbuster for the publishing industry. Despite the relentless news cycle, readers have bought books in droves. Hardcover sales are up, and unit sales at independent bookstores have risen 5 per cent.

site_title: Poland's Torun gingerbread: the ancient luxury with a secret recipe
summary: In Poland's historic city of Torun, the Kopernik Confectionery Factory has been producing its famous gingerbread since 1763, using a jealously-guarded secret spice mix that has remained unchanged for centuries. The factory's bakers age the dough for months, then bake it in large quantities, producing 3,500 tonnes of gingerbread annually. The unique flavor of Torun gingerbread is attributed to a combination of spices, including cloves, cinnamon, ginger, and pepper, which are carefully balanced to create a chewy and meaty texture. The factory's secret recipe has been protected by its owners, who have refused foreign investment to preserve their prized tradition.

site_title: Mnuchin bid to calm markets risks making bad situation worse
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin attempted to calm market concerns by reassuring the financial community that liquidity is in good shape, citing a phone call with major bank CEOs. However, this move raised questions about the existence of systemic issues, with some market-watchers interpreting it as a sign of deeper concerns. Mnuchin's actions came after a chaotic weekend of plunging markets and reports of President Trump considering firing Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, sparking fears of a fresh financial crisis.

site_title: Dublin boom sparks housing crisis, long-term rental woes for residents
summary: Dublin's housing crisis is driving long-term rental woes for residents, with 42-year-old Greek security guard Aris forced to share a 30-square-meter studio flat with two others due to skyrocketing prices. The city's tech hub and Airbnb's popularity are exacerbating the issue, with only 1,258 long-term rentals available in Dublin, compared to 1,419 short-term lets. The crisis has led to weekly protests, with campaigners demanding affordable housing and calling it a human right. The Irish government has proposed limits on letting with Airbnb and increased construction of new homes to address the shortage.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Tokyo closed on December 24, 2018, for a public holiday. In contrast, Singapore's stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data on July 11, 2025. Asian traders continued to extend their rally despite US President Trump's new threats, with mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares upward. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth extols goodwill and respect in Christmas message
summary: Queen Elizabeth emphasized the importance of peace and goodwill in her Christmas message, stating that the message of Jesus is "never out of date" and needs to be heeded as much as ever. The 92-year-old monarch also spoke of family and friendship, reflecting on the significance of these values in her long reign. Unlike her usual avoidance of public comments on contentious issues, the message does not mention recent controversies, instead focusing on the importance of respecting others, even with deeply held differences.

site_title: Singapore core inflation slips to 1.7% in November, below economists' estimates
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to 1.7% in November, below economists' expectations of 1.9%. Headline inflation also decreased to 0.3%, mainly due to a steeper fall in private road transport costs. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintain their outlook, expecting core inflation to rise modestly in coming months and headline inflation to pick up to 1-2% in 2019.

site_title: 6.4-magnitude earthquake hits off coast of Tonga: USGS
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Tonga, with the epicenter 85km north of the capital Nuku'alofa, at a moderate depth of 100km. No tsunami warning was issued, and there were no immediate reports of damage. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center stated there was no tsunami threat, with residents describing the quake as a "small one."

site_title: Australian shares ease in thin pre-Christmas trade; NZ up
summary: Australian shares eased 0.1% on Monday to 5,461.5 due to a decline in financials, particularly insurers, while MYOB Group shares surged 14.5% after recommending a takeover offer from US private equity firm KKR & Co. The market closed early for the Christmas holidays. New Zealand's benchmark index rose marginally to 8,700.78, driven by gains in Fisher & Paykel Healthcare and NZX Ltd.

site_title: Top Trump official calls bankers, will convene 'Plunge Protection Team'
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin convened calls with CEOs of the six largest US banks amid a Wall Street rout, citing concerns over slowing economic growth. This comes as the S&P 500 index is on pace for its biggest percentage decline in December since the Great Depression. Mnuchin also plans to convene the "Plunge Protection Team" to address market volatility.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to buy 3 logistics properties in France for 21.6m euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit is acquiring three freehold logistics properties in France for 21.6 million euros, expanding its presence in the Greater Paris logistics market. The deal includes properties in Sully-sur-Loire, Villeneuve-lès-Béziers, and Parcay-Meslay, with net initial yields of 8.5%. The acquisition is expected to increase the portfolio valuation by 2.6% and is financed with debt and equity from Cromwell E-Reit's 224.1 million euro rights issue. The properties are fully let to Inteva Products, Atac, and DHL, with ongoing negotiations for a French retailer.

site_title: Trump's key trade adviser uses aggressive tactics to shake up WTO
summary: US Ambassador to the World Trade Organization Dennis Shea has been using aggressive tactics to challenge China's non-market economy, which he says is incompatible with WTO norms. Shea's approach has led to a shift in the international trade landscape, with the US pushing for WTO reform and leaders agreeing to push for reform. China denies any wrongdoing, but Shea's efforts have borne fruit, with investors pulling back and the global economy at risk of losing steam and jobs. The US has set in motion measures that could paralyze the WTO's ability to arbitrate disputes by next year.

site_title: Indonesia searches for survivors after volcano triggers tsunami, kills 281
summary: A tsunami triggered by a massive underwater landslide on Indonesia's Anak Krakatau volcano killed 281 people, injured 1,000, and displaced nearly 12,000 coastal residents. The disaster, which occurred on December 22, 2018, was caused by the collapse of part of the volcano's southwest side, resulting in a 2-3 meter high tsunami. The government has extended a high-tide warning until Wednesday, and aid has been trickling in to the worst-affected area on Java's west coast. The disaster has raised concerns about Indonesia's preparedness for natural disasters, with the Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysical Agency saying it had no warning system for volcanoes and underwater landslides.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's meteorological agency confirmed the collapse of part of Anak Krakatau, a volcano midway between Java and Sumatra, caused a tsunami 2-3 metres  high that hit the rim of the Sunda Strait late on Saturday.

site_title: Nasa spacecraft hurtles toward historic New Year's flyby
summary: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft is set to make a historic New Year's Day flyby of Ultima Thule, the most distant planetary object ever studied, at a distance of 3,500km. The flyby will provide unprecedented insights into the object's shape, geology, and composition, with the spacecraft snapping hundreds of pictures to reveal its features. The flyby requires precise navigation and is a significant milestone in planetary science, offering a glimpse into the early solar system's formation.

site_title: US denounces discounts for wealthy nations for UN peacekeeping
summary: The US has denounced discounts for wealthy nations in UN peacekeeping assessments, stating they are "without justification" and should be eliminated. The US will pay no more than 25% of the assessed amount, while nearly half of member states receive an 80% discount. Despite efforts to persuade several countries to reduce their discounts, the US failed to reach a deal to cover the $220 million annual budget black hole left by Washington's downsizing of its peacekeeping contributions. The UN operating budget and peacekeeping budget will remain unchanged until 2021.

site_title: Elon Musk says Tesla to pay customers for missed tax credits
summary: Elon Musk announced that Tesla will reimburse customers who miss out on the US$7,500 tax credit due to delivery delays. The tax credit phases out after the first 200,000 electric vehicles sold by an automaker, with a reduction every six months. Musk stated that Tesla will cover the tax credit difference if customers made good faith efforts to receive their cars by the end of 2018. This move aims to address customer complaints about delayed deliveries and lack of communication.

site_title: O&M, property veteran Michael Kum becomes Atlantic Navigation's chairman
summary: Michael Kum, a property veteran, has become the non-executive chairman of Atlantic Navigation Holdings after acquiring a 50.2% stake in the company. Kum's investment vehicle, Saeed Investment, placed shares to him earlier in December. Wong Siew Cheong has been redesignated as an executive director, while Sam Chee Leong has been appointed as an independent director. Several other directors have also resigned, including Tong Choo Cherng, Andrew Waite, and Eu Lee Koon. The company's shares are currently suspended due to a public float below the minimum required by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Satellites to safety apps: 10 new uses of technology to help people in 2018
summary: In 2018, governments and companies utilized technology to address various global issues. Drone-delivered vaccines were used to immunize a baby in Vanuatu, while satellites helped combat forced labor in Thailand's fishing industry. Apps like AgriPredict and Safecity aided farmers and women in reporting harassment and crop invasions. Mosquito-drones were used to combat the Zika outbreak, and drones mapped India's slums to deliver essential services. Additionally, a machine converted plastic to fuel, and blockchain technology was used to track human trafficking, with Moldova becoming the first country to trial this method.

site_title: 'Damaged' drone found near Gatwick Airport; arrested couple are freed without charge
summary: A couple from Crawley, near Gatwick Airport, was arrested and released without charge over the disruption of flights at the airport. The couple, who were detained for approximately 35 hours, cooperated fully with police inquiries into the illegal use of drones that caused three days of chaos. A "damaged" drone was found near the airport and is being forensically examined for digital data and human DNA. The airport offered a £50,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible. The couple's release was confirmed by Detective Chief Superintendent Jason Tingley.

site_title: Another tsunami could hit Indonesia, experts warn
summary: Experts warn another tsunami could strike Indonesia, following a wave triggered by a volcanic eruption on Saturday that killed over 200 people. The tsunami was caused by an underwater collapse of Anak Krakatoa volcano, which is close to densely populated zones. The region is prone to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions due to its location on the Pacific Ocean's "Ring of Fire". Experts fear more tsunamis could occur due to the volcano's active phase, and warn that sonar surveys are needed to map the seafloor around the volcano to mitigate the risk.

site_title: Christmas delight at Gardens by the Bay
summary: Gardens by the Bay's Christmas Wonderland is underway, featuring a large Santa's Grotto with a moving German light installation. The event, now in its fifth year, runs until December 26.

site_title: Trump ends the Mattis era at the Pentagon two months early
summary: US President Donald Trump directed Defense Secretary James Mattis to depart by January 1, two months earlier than planned, and will replace him with Patrick Shanahan, the Pentagon's second-ranking official. Mattis' resignation was announced after a scathing letter criticizing Trump's approach to alliances and strategic rivals. Shanahan, a former Boeing executive, will serve as acting defense secretary until a permanent replacement is nominated and confirmed by the Senate. The move follows criticism over Trump's sudden change of course on Syria and Afghanistan, and Mattis' differences with the president over American leadership and alliances.

site_title: India cuts tax rates on some goods to appeal to traders, middle class
summary: India reduced tax rates on over 20 goods, including televisions and movie tickets, to appeal to traders and the middle class amid voter frustration over the nationwide goods and services tax (GST) implementation. The GST council, led by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, lowered tax rates on six items to 18% and one item to 5%. The move aims to reduce job losses in small businesses and increase consumer spending. This is part of the government's plan to cut tax rates on over 190 items, with only luxury goods remaining at 28%.

site_title: Nissan director's wife says Christmas Day release a possibility
summary: Dee Kelly, wife of Nissan board director Greg Kelly, says there's a possibility her husband will be released from a Tokyo jail on Christmas Day. Several US government officials have supported efforts to arrange for his return to Tennessee. Kelly may be able to communicate with his family soon, according to a video released through a lawyer. Dee Kelly also accused Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa of leading a "power grab" and wrongfully accusing her husband and Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn.

images.alt_text: The wife of Greg Kelly, the jailed Nissan Motor board director, said there's a chance he'll be released Christmas Day.

site_title: 'Tumultuous' challenges for KL but buffers likely
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to face a "tumultuous" start to 2019, with rising interest rates, trade shocks, and fiscal slippage posing challenges. Despite this, the country's natural resources, competitive manufacturing, and services sectors may provide a buffer. Economists predict a 4.8% growth in 2018 and 4.2-4.7% growth in 2019, driven by weaker global demand for the tech sector. The Malaysian government's efforts to control public debt and fiscal position may also help cushion the economy.

site_title: Oil, populist leaders and the dollar: Guide to emerging market risks in 2019
summary: Emerging markets are recovering from a 2019 rout that wiped $5 trillion off stocks since January, but risks persist. Rising US interest rates, a stronger dollar, and trade tensions with China could weigh on markets. Populist leaders in Latin America, such as Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro and Mexico's Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, may face challenges in implementing reforms. The US Federal Reserve's decision to increase interest rates and the European Central Bank's end of asset purchases could also impact emerging markets. Additionally, the ongoing US-China trade war and the decline in oil prices pose risks to developing economies.

images.alt_text: Rising rates in the US, a stronger US dollar, Beijing and Washington's trade war, lower oil prices and the emergence of populist leaders in Latin America's two biggest economies could all weigh on markets.

site_title: Fund managers see value in Asia bonds for 2019 after bad year
summary: Asian dollar bond market finishes its worst year since 2013, with some fund managers seeing value in the sector due to strong fundamentals and policy maker support in 2019. Average yield premiums on Asian US currency high-yield bonds rose to the highest since March 2016. Investors expect low single-digit positive returns for Asian IG bonds, with Asian HY outperforming IG, and some see opportunities in Chinese property bonds, Indonesian high yield, and quality Indonesian corporates. However, concerns remain over increased protectionism and elections in Indonesia and India.

site_title: JD.com averts a crisis as billionaire CEO cleared in rape probe
summary: JD.com's billionaire CEO, Richard Liu, has been cleared in a rape probe in Minneapolis, allowing the Chinese online retailer to resume its global ambitions. Liu was arrested in August and faced potential charges that wiped out about $15 billion of market value. US prosecutors decided not to press charges, freeing Liu to resume pursuing JD.com's global goals. The company's stock gained 5.9% following the news, still below pre-arrest levels. Liu's control over the company's voting rights had cast doubt on its leadership, but the clearance should help JD.com move forward.

site_title: London's streets no longer paved with gold as miners struggle
summary: London, once a hub for gold miners, is struggling to regain its status as companies like Randgold Resources, Petropavlovsk, and Acacia Mining face financial difficulties. The combined market value of London-listed gold and silver miners is expected to drop to less than half its value six years ago after Randgold delists. Despite this, there is still investor appetite for gold stocks, with AngloGold Ashanti, the world's third-largest gold producer, considering a London listing. Analysts say the right company and size are key to attracting investors, and opportunities remain for other producers to woo investors.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Murat Lutem, Ambassador of the Republic of Turkey in Singapore
summary: Turkish Ambassador to Singapore Murat Lutem sat down for an interview on Money FM's "The Hot Seat" podcast. The conversation covered various international topics, including the ongoing trade tensions between the US and Vietnam, the impact of US tariffs on the Asian garment industry, and China's slowing GDP growth. Lutem also discussed Turkey's relations with Southeast Asia and the significance of the US-China trade relationship. The ambassador emphasized the importance of maintaining economic stability and cooperation in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange rejects CNMC Goldmine's dual listing application
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange rejected CNMC Goldmine's dual listing application due to the company's inability to meet the minimum market capitalization requirement of HK$500 million. As of December 14, CNMC's market capitalization was approximately HK$458 million. The exchange also noted that the company's share price has been declining and that the proposed dual listing would not create "meaningful liquidity" for its shares in Hong Kong. CNMC's board has accepted the outcome and will re-evaluate its plans for the proposed listing.

site_title: Wall St quietly shelves its bitcoin dreams
summary: Wall Street's interest in Bitcoin has slowed down as the value of the virtual coins collapses. Established firms like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Citigroup have made little progress in developing a trading infrastructure, with some even cancelling plans. Despite this, industry experts believe that institutions are building infrastructure to enable institutional trading, and some see the bear market as an opportunity for them to build foundations without rushing into the market.

site_title: China still has a treasure chest of overseas real estate to sell
summary: China's overseas real estate assets, including the 245 Park Ave skyscraper in Manhattan, the Waldorf Astoria Hotel, and Chicago's Vista Tower, remain in Chinese hands despite the country's record-breaking property buying spree reversal in 2018. Economic growth slowdown and efforts to keep capital outflows in check may lead to another surge in disposal records in 2019. China's tight control on capital outflows is expected to remain a key theme for Beijing, with potential consequences for the country's real estate market.

site_title: France's 'yellow vests' target borders ahead of Christmas
summary: France saw a significant decline in "yellow vest" protests on the eve of Christmas, with 38,600 participants, down from 66,000 the previous Saturday. The number of protesters has been trending downwards since the movement's peak in November. The protests, which began as a response to fuel tax hikes, have since morphed into a demonstration against President Emmanuel Macron's policies. Despite a "real slowdown," some protesters continued to take part, driven by hatred of institutions, with 220 people detained nationwide.

images.alt_text: Protestors lighting flares in the colours of the French flag during a "Yellow Vest" anti-government protest on Saturday in Bordeaux, south-western France, as part of a nationwide day of demonstrations.

site_title: Semiconductor outlook remains bright despite electronics downcycle : EDB
summary: Singapore's semiconductor sector remains optimistic despite the global electronics downcycle, according to EDB director Pee Beng Kong. Investments made in 2017 and 2018 are expected to continue ramping up, with the sector growing at a 5% CAGR in electronics and 8% CAGR in semiconductors between 2008 and 2017. The long-term outlook is bright due to the increasing importance of semiconductors in rising technologies like autonomous vehicles and fintech. The EDB aims to support investments in new growth markets like automotive, industrial, and AI, with a goal of these sectors accounting for half of Singapore's semiconductor sector by 2030.

site_title: Trump privately discussed firing Federal Reserve chairman Powell: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump has privately discussed firing Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, a move that could disrupt financial markets. Despite public criticism of the Fed's interest rate hikes, Trump is unlikely to fire Powell, with his top adviser Larry Kudlow stating it's not possible. Trump's attempts to dismiss Powell would be unprecedented and on shaky legal ground, potentially destabilizing global markets.

site_title: Investor appetite stays muted for Christmas
summary: Investors in Singapore and Asia are expected to have a quiet trading week due to concerns over slowing economic growth, government shutdowns, and trade tensions. The US stock market has been declining, with the Nasdaq entering a bear market. In Singapore, technology stocks are likely to be weighed down, with the Straits Times Index's technology sector delivering negative returns year to date. The upcoming Christmas holiday will also contribute to thin trading. Key data releases this week include the November consumer price index in Singapore and industrial production figures.

site_title: Ensign sees big potential in Asia cybersecurity
summary: Ensign InfoSecurity, a joint venture between Temasek and StarHub, aims to capitalize on Asia's growing cybersecurity market. The company's interim CEO, Yeoh Keat Chuan, emphasizes the need for greater awareness and investment in cybersecurity in Singapore. Asia's mean time to detection for cyber breaches is significantly higher than the US and Europe, with 498 days in 2017. Ensign plans to bring in a permanent CEO who understands the Asian market and is focused on the continent. The company is working on incidence response and partnering with global capabilities to address the evolving threat landscape.

site_title: Oil weighed down by slowing growth, doubts about cartel
summary: Oil prices have plummeted nearly 40% since October 2018, with current levels below those in January 2017 when Opec+ first implemented output cuts. The main factors behind this decline are doubts about the group's ability to trim output and a negative global outlook, which could lead to a sharp rebound if concerns ease. Despite a recent Russian-brokered deal to cut 1.2 million barrels a day, traders are skeptical, and production is expected to fall in Venezuela and Iran. US production has also risen unexpectedly, contributing to the bearish sentiment.

site_title: Amid all the bad news, gold continues to glitter
summary: Despite tumultuous global events, including the UK's Brexit uncertainty and economic concerns, gold prices have continued to rise. The European Central Bank lowered economic growth projections, and Italian budget deficit woes and French protests further added to the negative news. However, gold prices fell slightly due to US interest rate hikes. The article highlights the resilience of gold prices amidst bad news, suggesting it remains a popular safe-haven asset.

site_title: From Meghan to Michelle: 10 celebrities who used their star power for good in 2018
summary: In 2018, celebrities used their star power to address global challenges. Meghan Markle, a new member of the British royal family, highlighted women's rights and collaborated with survivors of the Grenfell Tower fire to produce a community cookbook. Other notable examples include Michelle Williams advocating for women's rights, Priyanka Chopra promoting education, and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson supporting conservation efforts. These efforts demonstrate how celebrities can make a positive impact on the world, inspiring others to follow in their footsteps.

site_title: Behind the myth of China's great technology grab
summary: China's efforts to acquire leading-edge technology have been overstated, according to a case study of the Chinese auto industry. Despite partnering with BMW for 15 years, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd. has failed to acquire advanced technology, with BMW controlling the joint venture and producing most vehicles locally. BMW's strategy of gradually introducing technology to China, rather than forcing it, has allowed the company to maintain control and protect its intellectual property. This contradicts China's claims of widespread forced technology transfers, and highlights the nation's ham-fisted approach to innovation.

site_title: US shale producers hit the brakes on 2019 spending
summary: US shale producers are scaling back spending and drilling plans due to a 40% drop in crude prices, mounting fears of oversupply. Several major shale companies, including Centennial Resource Development, Diamondback Energy, and Parsley Energy, have cancelled drilling rig additions for 2019, citing market weakness. The move is expected to slow North American production growth in 2019, with shale prices near break-even levels and US crude futures below $50 a barrel.

site_title: Tough year for Treasuries ends with US$131 billion auction blitz
summary: US Treasury auctions will close out 2018 with a record-breaking $131 billion in sales, including the largest two-, five- and seven-year securities since 2010. The auctions come amid a partial government shutdown and questions about the Federal Reserve's future under Chairman Trump. Despite a recent recovery, 2018 was a downbeat year for US government debt, with yields rising 76 basis points for two-year bonds and 38 basis points for 10-year bonds. The Bloomberg Barclays US Treasury Total Return index is on track for its worst performance since 2013.

site_title: Forget eggnog, Ghanaians sip local drinks at Christmas
summary: Ghanaians are shifting away from traditional eggnog and opting for locally made drinks such as Kokroko, pito, and palm wine during the Christmas season. These traditional beverages are being given a new twist or resurrected, becoming a staple during the festive period. This shift is a result of the cultural and social significance of these drinks in Ghanaian society.

site_title: 'Cut away': Dual nationals feel cast adrift in Japan
summary: Dual nationals in Japan face difficulties when passing through immigration, with some being forced to hide their foreign passports to avoid losing their Japanese nationality. An estimated million citizens are affected, with Yuki Shiraishi, a Japanese-Swiss dual national, experiencing shame and embarrassment upon immigration. This issue highlights the complexities of Japan's nationality laws, which often lead to individuals being forced to choose between their dual citizenship and their Japanese nationality.

site_title: No sex assault charges for Chinese tech billionaire: US prosecutor
summary: Chinese tech billionaire Richard Liu, founder of JD.com, will not face criminal charges over a rape accusation in Minnesota. An investigation found "profound evidentiary problems" and Liu maintained the alleged sex was consensual. Liu was arrested in August while studying at the University of Minnesota. The case was marked by complicated conversations in Mandarin between Liu and the alleged victim, which investigators reviewed. The Hennepin County Attorney's office declined to bring charges to avoid re-victimizing the 21-year-old woman.

site_title: Why the FTC is taking a new look at Facebook privacy
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is re-examining Facebook's data-sharing practices amid concerns over the social media company's handling of user information. The FTC, which previously imposed a consent decree on Facebook in 2011, is investigating whether the company violated its terms by failing to prevent the unauthorized sharing of user data with third parties, including Cambridge Analytica. The FTC's investigation follows a series of news reports that have questioned Facebook's data-sharing practices, including the use of user data for advertising purposes.

site_title: For this Christmas, all they want is from Amazon
summary: Amazon dominates the holiday shopping season, with its share of online sales increasing by almost 50% to about half of all digital sales. The company's two-decade-long focus on rapid delivery has built trust among customers, who prefer Amazon's near-instant gratification. Amazon's logistical advantage, including its Prime membership and over 110 fulfillment centers, allows it to outpace competitors like Walmart and Target. While traditional retailers are catching up with same-day and one-day shipping, Amazon remains the leader in e-commerce, with over 250,000 warehouse employees and dozens of its own planes.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending December 23, 2018, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk ships. Capesize rates collapsed on the West Australia/China route, with business concluded at under $6.00, while North Atlantic rates showed resilience. Panamax rates remained steady, with minerals into India and Indonesian rounds busy. Supramax activity slowed as the festive season progressed, with period interest and FFA values softening. Handysize rates fell, with little transatlantic cargo evident. Tanker rates also declined, with VLCC rates shedding 3-4 points and Suezmax rates climbing 35 points.

site_title: With no deal, US government shutdown likely to drag on past Christmas
summary: A partial US government shutdown is likely to last through Christmas after the Senate adjourned without reaching a deal on President Donald Trump's demand for more funds for a border wall. Financing for about a quarter of federal government programmes, including Homeland Security, Justice, and Agriculture, expired at midnight, leaving over 400,000 federal employees without pay and 380,000 on temporary leave. The shutdown has raised concerns about the economy and bipartisan cooperation, with Democrats vowing to pass legislation to reopen the government when they take control of the House in January.

site_title: May hopes to seal Brexit deal, stay as PM until 2021: The Sunday Times
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's allies are reportedly planning to keep her in power until autumn 2021, allowing her to carry out two more Cabinet reshuffles and potentially secure a Brexit deal. This plan, discussed with leading party figures, aims to promote a new generation of ministers under 50. May's supporters believe a shift in Commons arithmetic has improved support for her withdrawal agreement, with a significant number of lawmakers now prepared to back it.

site_title: Prudential hosts kids, elderly and families at Marina Bay Carnival
summary: Prudential Singapore hosted over 100 children, elderly, and families from various community centers at a special preview of the Marina Bay Carnival. This is the second year Prudential sponsors the event, which features 50 thrill rides and games. The insurer aims to spread holiday cheer and bring people together through its community partners. Last year's event saw similar attendance, and Prudential's gesture was described as "generous" by the head of The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The carnival will run from Dec 22 to Mar 24 next year.

images.alt_text: Mr Blackburn and Yeoh El Lynn, head, Community Investment, with children from The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, Prudential's community partners, enjoying an afternoon of rides and games at the opening of the Prudential Marina Bay Carnival 2018.

site_title: Amid regional declines, S$27m in buybacks & 32 director acquisitions filed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 7.0% for the year 2018, amid regional market declines. Over the last five trading sessions, the STI fell 1.9%. Twenty stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$26.8 million. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included 32 acquisitions and one disposal. Key transactions included Q & M Dental Group's Ng Chin Siau increasing his stake to 53.26%, UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' Wee Ee Chao increasing his stake to 27.97%, and Oxley Holdings' Ching Chiat Kwong acquiring 349,100 shares for S$99,735.

site_title: Heeton sees significant revenue share from hospitality
summary: Heeton Holdings has seen significant revenue growth from its hospitality segment, with a 31% increase in revenue from 2016 to 2017. The company plans to expand its hospitality business further, including a new hotel-cum-resort in Bhutan, and has partnered with other investors to acquire new properties. Despite a 13% decline in its share price this year, CEO Eric Teng believes the company's fundamentals remain strong and plans to continue developing properties, including commercial and residential projects.

site_title: The highs and lows of Trump's year
summary: US President Donald Trump's 2018 has been marked by near-constant turmoil, with the government, military, and markets experiencing significant fluctuations. Trump has become increasingly reliant on his own instincts, cutting off from others' opinions. Recent events include Vietnam's surprise reaction to Trump's tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry's concern over higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth expected to slow. Additionally, Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the global equity index, while Thailand's Thaksin remains confident in his daughter's clearance in an ethics case.

site_title: India's no-frills hotel giant eyes Western dominance
summary: Oyo Rooms, India's largest hotel firm by number of rooms, is targeting European expansion after its success in Asia, with its app-based model offering affordable, no-frills accommodation. Founded in 2013, the company has received $5 billion in funding from international venture capitalists and has established itself as a major player in China. Oyo teams up with budget hotel owners to connect them with tourists, offering services like hot water and free Wi-Fi at rates below mid-range hotels. The company plans to expand into the broader European region, potentially unsettling major hotel chains like Marriott International.

site_title: Tsunami kills more than 200 in Indonesia
summary: A tsunami triggered by an underwater landslide caused by the eruption of Indonesia's Anak Krakatau volcano killed at least 222 people and injured hundreds on Java and Sumatra islands. The disaster struck late Saturday, catching residents off guard, with waves of 2-3 meters washing ashore without warning. The death toll has risen, with 843 injured and 28 missing. Authorities warned residents to stay away from beaches and a high-tide warning remains in place until Dec 25. The eruption of Krakatau in 1883 killed over 36,000 people, and the current disaster is the latest in a series of tragedies to strike Indonesia this year.

site_title: Canadian dollar hits 19-month low as risk aversion offsets GDP gain
summary: The Canadian dollar hit a 19-month low against the US dollar, trading at 1.3598 at 2100 GMT, due to risk aversion and declining oil prices. Despite data showing stronger-than-expected growth in the domestic economy, the loonie fell 1.6% for the week, its largest drop since June. Oil prices dropped 0.6% to $45.59 a barrel, offsetting the country's export-driven economy. Speculators cut their bearish bets on the Canadian dollar for the second straight week, but the Bank of Canada may remain cautious due to the recent slump in oil prices.

site_title: As manufacturing slows, diverse factors may drive 2019 growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector continues to cool, with economists expecting 2019 growth to range from 1.5 to 3.5% due to weaker external demand and potential monetary tightening. However, other sectors such as services, construction, and fintech may help offset the slowdown. The government's upcoming Merdeka Generation healthcare package and possible fiscal expansion could also boost growth. Despite tensions between the US and China, most economists agree that Singapore's economy is resilient and has room for further Monetary Authority of Singapore tightening if core inflation continues to creep up.

images.alt_text: Economists see potential in both old and new sectors, with strong fundamentals and policy buffers helping the country navigate the challenges of a global slowdown.

site_title: Trump says he hopes govt shutdown 'will not last long'
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed hope that the government shutdown, caused by a border wall funding dispute, will not last long. In a video post, Trump stated, "The shutdown hopefully will not last long." This comes amid a dispute over funding for his border wall project.

site_title: Ghosn's detention extended over Christmas and New Year
summary: Tokyo's Tokyo District Court extended former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn's detention through January 1, dashing hopes of his release for Christmas. Ghosn, facing allegations of financial misconduct, breach of trust, and under-reporting his salary, is being held on suspicion of hiding half of his income and under-reporting his pay to avoid criticism. Prosecutors can apply for a further 10-day extension, and Ghosn's lawyer has described his treatment as "well" despite complaints of cold and a limited menu.

site_title: Zimbabwe's economic crisis wipes out Christmas cheer
summary: Zimbabwe's economic crisis has led to steep price hikes and long queues for necessities like bread and cooking oil, wiping out Christmas cheer. Despite a promise of a revived economy by President Emmerson Mnangagwa, the country's economy continues to struggle. Shortages and price increases have left many unable to afford basic items, a stark contrast to the country's previous economic state.

site_title: Japan emperor draws huge birthday crowd before abdication next year
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito celebrated his 85th birthday with a large crowd of 82,850 well-wishers at Tokyo's Imperial Palace, the largest attendance during his three-decade reign. The event comes ahead of his abdication on April 30, passing the throne to Crown Prince Naruhito. Emperor Akihito addressed the crowd, referencing Japan's natural disasters and World War II, while also thanking his successor for standing by the Japanese people. His symbolic reign has contributed to a broader consciousness of Japan's wartime past, contrasting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's more assertive stance.

site_title: US: Third straight rout end worst weak for Dow, Nasdaq since 2008 crisis
summary: US stocks ended their worst week in a decade, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing nearly 7% and the Nasdaq suffering its worst week since the 2008 financial crisis. The tech-rich Nasdaq entered a bear market amid trade war concerns and a possible US government shutdown. Investors are anxious over rising interest rates, decelerating global growth, and Brexit uncertainty. The US-China trade dispute and White House advisor Peter Navarro's hardline comments on trade talks with China further fueled market volatility.

site_title: Canada, US call for 'immediate release' of two Canadians held by China
summary: Canada and the US have called for the immediate release of two Canadians detained by China in retaliation for the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou. The two Canadians, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, were detained on December 10 following Canada's arrest of Meng. The EU has also backed Canada in the dispute, citing concerns about legitimate research and business practices in China. China has accused the Canadians of "harm to national security" and has denied them access to lawyers, sparking international pressure for their release.

site_title: New Banksy artwork brings crowds to town in Wales
summary: A new Banksy artwork has appeared in Port Talbot, Wales, featuring a child playing in the snow, but with ash falling instead of snowflakes, symbolizing the town's industrial heritage and pollution. The artwork, claimed by Banksy, has drawn large crowds and caused a stir, with the local authority bringing in traffic wardens to manage the area. The image is seen as a strong social statement, with some interpreting it as a commentary on Port Talbot's steel plant and its environmental impact.

site_title: Jim Rogers, Duke Energy executive who promoted clean energy, dies at 71
summary: Former Duke Energy CEO Jim Rogers, a prominent advocate for clean energy and addressing climate change through federal policy, died at 71. Rogers, a lawyer by training, became CEO in 2006 and promoted a cap-and-trade approach to reduce carbon emissions. Despite criticism from environmental groups, Duke Energy invested over $4 billion in wind and solar projects under his leadership. Rogers also wrote a book on pragmatic solutions to lift the world's poorest people out of poverty, and believed in global warming, but favored a gradual transition away from coal.

site_title: Lereno Bio-Chem sets EGM to vote on Knit Textile acquisition in RTO deal
summary: Lereno Bio-Chem will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on January 18, 2019, to vote on its acquisition of Knit Textile and Apparel for S$26.4 million. Shareholders will also vote on allotting new shares to fund the acquisition, as well as other resolutions including a share consolidation and name change to KTMG Limited. This is the company's third reverse takeover attempt.

site_title: US shoppers fight back against porch thieves
summary: US shoppers are fighting back against porch thieves, a growing threat during the holiday season. Residents are using ingenuity, technology, and community spirit to protect packages from being stolen from doorsteps. Some are employing fake packages with GPS devices, while others are using cameras and alarm systems to deter thieves. A former NASA engineer has even built a fake gift parcel box that sprays glitter and "fart spray" when opened, capturing the thieves' reactions on camera. Authorities are also taking action, with some launching "Operation Porch Pirate" to crack down on the crime.

site_title: US stocks in for rough 2019 start in absence of positive drivers
summary: US stocks experienced their worst holiday-season performance since the Great Depression in 2018, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling over 6% in its biggest weekly drop in 10 years. The Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates despite global economic stress and the government shutdown in Washington was a major factor. Strategists predict a near-term bounce but a sustained recovery is unlikely, with the Fed expected to deliver only two more hikes. The stock market's volatility was reminiscent of the 2008 global financial crisis, and the defensive utility sector was one of the few investments to finish the year with significant gains.

site_title: Fashion designer Raf Simons to leave Calvin Klein
summary: Belgian fashion designer Raf Simons is leaving Calvin Klein, effective immediately, after less than two years with the company. The decision comes after PVH, Calvin Klein's parent company, decided on a new brand direction that differs from Simons' creative vision. Simons' departure follows speculation about his potential exit, which was fueled by declining sales and PVH's allocation of blame to him. Despite his contract expiring in less than six months, Simons' immediate departure will not be followed by a replacement, according to PVH.

site_title: US government partially shuts as Congress, Trump fail to reach deal
summary: The US government began a partial shutdown on December 22, 2018, after Congress failed to pass a federal spending bill, amid President Donald Trump's demand for $5 billion to build a border wall with Mexico. The shutdown, the third of the year, affected about 25% of the government, including NASA, Commerce, and Homeland Security departments, while leaving about three-quarters of the government fully funded until September 2019. The shutdown began at midnight on December 21, with 800,000 federal employees either furloughed or forced to work without pay.

images.alt_text: A 'stop' traffic sign stands in front of the US Capitol illuminated at night in Washington, D.C., on Friday, December 21, 2018. The US government began a Christmas shutdown early Saturday, after Congress adjourned without passing a federal spending bill or addressing President Donald Trump's demand for money to build a border wall.

site_title: Ailing firms find new lease of life in real estate
summary: Ailing firms in Singapore are diversifying into real estate to boost their fortunes. Companies like A-Smart Holdings, MS Holdings, and Katrina Group have announced plans to acquire land or own real estate, shifting away from their core businesses. This trend is seen as a way for struggling companies to find a new lease on life and increase their value. The diversification into real estate is expected to provide a stable source of income and potentially improve their financial performance.

site_title: Boeing heads for expected 2018 plane order victory over Airbus
summary: Boeing is expected to win the majority of 2018 aircraft orders over Airbus, with 690 net airplane orders compared to Airbus' 380 total orders minus cancellations. Boeing secured deals from Nigeria's Green Africa Airways for 50 737 MAX 8 jets valued at $11.7 billion and Saudi Arabia's flyadeal for 30 737 MAX jets with options for 20 more worth up to $5.9 billion. The 737 MAX 8 is Boeing's fastest-selling airplane, with over 4,800 orders worldwide, and analysts say Airbus is unlikely to recover lost ground before the year-end.

site_title: Tee International unit buys Arrow Waste Management for S$100,000
summary: Tee International's subsidiary, Tee Infrastructure, has acquired a full stake in Arrow Waste Management for S$100,000. The proposed acquisition, expected to be completed by Jan 31, 2019, was signed on Friday. Details of the deal are limited due to the transaction's low value. Tee International stated that the sale shares have been transferred to Tee Infrastructure. The acquisition marks a significant move for Tee International, which has been reported as a loss-making company.

site_title: First Reit manager says Surabaya hospital not affected by sinkhole
summary: BOWSPRIT Capital, manager of First Reit, stated that Siloam Hospitals Surabaya operations were unaffected by the December 18 road subsidence incident. The Reit had previously sold a portion of the land to a subsidiary of its sponsor, Lippo Karawaci, for a new hospital development. The hospital operator assured that patients are in safe condition, and operations are continuing normally. Repairs and investigations are ongoing, with First Reit monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: China national charged with stealing trade secrets: US Justice Dept
summary: A Chinese national, Hongjin Tan, has been charged with stealing trade secrets from US-based petroleum company Phillips 66. Tan, who worked as a staff scientist, allegedly downloaded hundreds of files related to a product worth over $1 billion. He planned to use the information to benefit a Chinese company that had offered him a job. Tan was arrested in Oklahoma and will appear in court on Wednesday. Phillips 66 cooperated with the FBI in the probe, which found Tan had an employment agreement with a Chinese company and accessed files related to marketing the trade secret in lithium-based battery systems.

site_title: London's Gatwick airport reopens again, police make two arrests
summary: London's Gatwick Airport reopened after a 36-hour disruption caused by a mystery saboteur using drones, affecting over 100,000 Christmas travelers. Sussex police made two arrests in connection with the incident. The airport initially reported 700 planes would take off on Friday, but delays and cancellations were still expected. The disruption was the largest at Gatwick since a 2010 Icelandic volcanic ash cloud.

images.alt_text: Passengers wait at a departure hall of the Gatwick airport, after it reopened, in Sussex, southeast, England, December 21, 2018.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE rises slightly thanks to mining stocks
summary: The UK's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% on Friday, recouping losses from the week, driven by gains in mining stocks such as Anglo American and Rio Tinto due to higher copper prices. Despite this, UK indices are on track for their worst quarter since 2011 and worst year since 2008, amid concerns over global growth, Brexit, and rising US borrowing costs.

site_title: Seniors enjoy a festive afternoon of fun and games
summary: TSMP Law Corporation organized a Christmas party for around 200 residents at St Theresa's Home in Singapore on December 17, 2018. The event included games, art, and a buffet lunch, with staff members from TSMP participating in activities with residents. The party aimed to bring joy to the elderly during the festive season and fulfill their desire to participate in festivities. This event is part of TSMP's Handprint community outreach programme, which focuses on supporting at-risk children and youth, foreign migrant workers, and the elderly.

images.alt_text: TSMP staff and St Theresa's Home residents create artwork using strings and pegs.
Santa visits the wards to chat with residents and hand out goodie bags.

site_title: Spiegel apologises in cover story on faked news scandal
summary: German news weekly Der Spiegel has published a 23-page report on how one of its award-winning reporters, Claas Relotius, faked stories for years, damaging media credibility. Relotius, 33, resigned after admitting to making up stories and inventing protagonists in over a dozen articles. The magazine apologized for the mistake, promising to boost credibility again, and called the scandal the "worst thing that can happen to an editorial team." The US embassy in Berlin expressed concern, calling for an independent investigation into the fabricated stories, which focused on US policies and American people.

site_title: No Christmas miracle expected as US government shutdown looms
summary: US President Donald Trump has indicated that a partial government shutdown is likely at midnight, with hundreds of thousands of federal employees potentially facing paychecks without pay. Trump rejected a funding bill that would have kept the government operational until February, citing his demand for $5 billion for a border wall. Democrats have refused to budge, and a bill passed by Republicans in the House is stalled in the Senate, with a shutdown now considered almost inevitable.

site_title: Not plugged in?: Why we are so slow to adopt electric cars, and what lies ahead
summary: Singapore's adoption of electric cars remains slow, with only 0.08% of registered private cars being pure electric, despite efforts by manufacturers and the government to promote the technology. The city-state's lack of charging infrastructure, high upfront costs, and limited incentives are major barriers to adoption. However, the government has revamped its carbon emission-based vehicle scheme and introduced electric car-sharing schemes, such as BlueSG, which has seen steady growth in demand. Manufacturers like Audi, Mercedes-Benz, and BMW are committed to electrification, with plans to release all-electric models by 2021 and 2022. As battery technology improves and charging infrastructure expands, experts predict a gradual increase in adoption, with some models offering significant cost savings and environmental benefits.

site_title: Crude hovers at multi-month lows with market in doldrums
summary: Oil prices plummeted to multi-month lows, falling 10% in the week, as global oversupply kept buyers away ahead of holidays. Crude prices dropped 32 cents to $54.03 a barrel, with US light crude oil down 4 cents at $45.84 a barrel. Planned OPEC production cuts, set to kick in next month, are expected to be ineffective due to growing global inventories and sustained oversupply, driven by the US shale industry's emergence as the world's largest crude producer.

site_title: Salmonella outbreak linked to raw turkey leaves over 200 sick across US
summary: A salmonella outbreak linked to raw turkey has affected over 200 people in the US, with 84 hospitalized, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The outbreak, which began in October, has resulted in one death in California. The CDC has issued a second voluntary recall on raw turkey products, bringing the total number of documented cases to 216 in 38 states and the District of Columbia.

site_title: Medtech stocks hurt by overall market slide
summary: Medtech stocks in Singapore, represented by five listed companies, have seen an average one-year total return of minus 10%, mirroring the overall market's decline. Despite this, the sector's prospects remain promising, with the global market for cancer diagnostics estimated to reach US$169 billion by 2030. Newly listed Biolidics, a cancer diagnostic firm, has seen its shares slump 28.6% from its listing price, closing at S$0.20. The company plans to use IPO funds to expand clinical services and advance pipeline products.

site_title: Goldman Sachs CEO defends bank in 1MDB scandal
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon defended the bank's handling of the 1MDB scandal, stating that the criticism was unfair and that the bank's culture and processes were strong at the time. The bank helped issue $6.5 billion in bonds for the scandal-plagued Malaysian fund, but Malaysia accuses the bank and its former employees of misappropriating $2.7 billion. Solomon acknowledged that the bank conducted due diligence but was unaware of the scheme orchestrated by individuals and foreign officials. The bank is working with authorities to bring the culprits to justice.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Venture Corp and Ascendas Reit received positive analyst reviews. Venture Corp is expected to see a V-shaped recovery in Q4 2018 due to new product introductions, and its revenue is likely to rise in Q4 2018. The company is also less exposed to trade war issues. Ascendas Reit's industrial segment is expected to benefit from favorable demand-supply dynamics, and the company's portfolio is diversified with recent UK acquisitions. Analysts recommend buying both stocks, with target prices of S$19.00 for Venture Corp and S$2.90 for Ascendas Reit.

site_title: China's builders are hurting: Beijing may feel the pain
summary: China's construction industry is facing significant challenges, with builders expressing caution due to high material costs, tougher regulations, and limited access to credit. Private builders, which account for 90% of the sector, are hesitant to take on new projects, citing increased risks and lower profits. The industry's woes come as China's infrastructure and property sector, a key driver of the economy, is in flux. The government has responded by relaxing restrictions and offering financing support, but industry insiders believe pressures will last for at least another year.

site_title: JFK and Marilyn Monroe "tryst" house on sale for US$5m
summary: A 6,700-square-foot Spanish-style estate in Rancho Mirage, California, once owned by Bing Crosby, is on sale for $5 million. The property, which includes a master suite and four en-suite bedrooms, is believed to be the site of a rumored tryst between former US President John F. Kennedy and actress Marilyn Monroe. The home, nicknamed the "JFK Wing," has been on and off the market since 2010 and features a 1,400 sq ft master suite, a swimming pool, and fire pit.

site_title: Mexico says it won't deport refugees as it seeks details on US plan
summary: Mexico's government has agreed to accept some non-Mexican migrants sent by the US to wait in Mexico while their asylum claims are processed, but will not deport people seeking refuge. Mexico's foreign minister Marcelo Ebrard said the country wants more details on the US plan and will set out its position on Monday. The US plan uses a section of the Immigration and Nationality Act to return migrants to Mexico, but some experts argue this exemption could apply to many asylum-seekers. Mexico will provide work visas to migrants and has not agreed to become a "safe third country" for asylum seekers.

site_title: Brazil prosecutors charge 42 people in alleged Petrobras bribery scheme
summary: Brazilian prosecutors have charged 42 people in connection with an alleged bribery scheme involving a construction contract for state-run oil firm Petrobras in the state of Bahia. The charges, part of the "Car Wash" probe, involve former Petrobras officials, executives from builder Odebrecht SA, and engineering conglomerate OAS. The bribes, totaling 67.2 million reais, allegedly occurred between 2009 and 2016 and involved senior Petrobras and Petros officials, as well as the leftist Workers Party. The charges include corruption, money laundering, and criminal organization.
