site_title: Finance firms' loans hitting records on relaxed SME lending rules
summary: Singapore's finance companies have seen record loan growth due to relaxed rules on lending to small and medium enterprises (SMEs). Hong Leong Finance (HLF) and Sing Investments & Finance (SIF) have hit all-time highs in loan books, with HLF's loans rising 5% to S$10.3 billion, the highest in its 57 years. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) relaxed rules allowing finance companies to offer unsecured loans to SMEs, providing more flexibility in funding solutions. This has led to increased demand for cash flow financing, with many SMEs restructuring and investing in capabilities to strengthen their business.

site_title: M&G Real Estate buys into Sydney, Brisbane industrial portfolio
summary: M&G Real Estate has partnered with Australian real estate group Dexus to acquire a portfolio of industrial properties in Sydney and Brisbane. The AU$2.37 billion deal marks M&G's third Australian acquisition this year, with the portfolio comprising fully occupied prime industrial locations. The partnership aims to capitalize on increasing demand for logistics assets near cities, driven by retailers' growing omni-channel presence. M&G will become a 50% joint venture partner with Dexus once the deal is complete, increasing its Australian exposure to AU$2.37 billion.

site_title: Boustead unit to build Razer's SEA headquarters in Singapore
summary: Razer, a gaming company, will build its South-east Asia headquarters in Singapore with Boustead Projects' joint-venture firm, Snakepit-BP. The 19,300 sqm facility will be located in the one-north precinct and is expected to be completed by 2020. Boustead Projects' orderbook backlog increased to S$548 million following the project. Razer CEO Tan Min-Liang stated that the move supports Singapore's efforts to develop a top location for technological innovation and attract technology talent.

site_title: US government to shut down in fight over Trump's wall
summary: The US government was set to partially shut down at midnight on December 22, 2018, after Republican senators failed to approve $5 billion for a border wall, a key demand of President Donald Trump. The shutdown was the result of a disagreement between Trump and Democrats, who oppose the wall. Trump had previously said he would be "proud" to shut down the government to get the funding, but ultimately rejected a short-term funding bill that included $1.6 billion for border security measures. The shutdown would affect about a quarter of the federal government's programs, including some essential services, and would leave thousands of workers without pay.

images.alt_text: The US Capitol is seen ahead of a possible government shutdown, in Washington, DC, December 21, 2018. The US government was to begin a partial shutdown at midnight on Friday after Republican senators failed to muster the votes needed to approve US$5 billion that President Donald Trump wants for a border wall fiercely opposed by Democrats.

site_title: HSBC gets nod to sell Malaysia insurance unit stake to FWD
summary: HSBC Holdings' Asia-Pacific insurance unit has received regulatory approval to sell its 49% stake in Malaysia's HSBC Amanah Takaful Malaysia Bhd to FWD Group, owned by tycoon Richard Li. The deal, expected to be completed in the first half of next year, will allow HSBC to exit the takaful manufacturing business and focus on banking operations in Malaysia. The financial details of the transaction were not disclosed.

site_title: DKSH to buy Auric's distribution business in Singapore, Malaysia for 160m Swiss francs
summary: DKSH, a business expansion company, has agreed to acquire Auric Pacific's distribution business in Singapore and Malaysia for 160 million Swiss francs. Auric Pacific, an investment holding firm, will focus on acquiring and growing consumer brands. The acquisition is expected to be immediately earnings accretive and will increase DKSH's exposure to the high-margin food service business. The existing management team will join DKSH, and the transaction is subject to regulatory approvals, with completion expected in the first half of 2019.

site_title: Supreme Court deals Trump another immigration setback
summary: The Supreme Court rejected President Donald Trump's attempt to implement an asylum ban on Central Americans, upholding a block placed by the San Francisco federal appeals court. The ban aimed to automatically reject asylum requests from migrants crossing the US-Mexico border from Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador. Four Supreme Court justices supported lifting the lower court's stay, but the court made no comment. The ruling may not significantly impact migrants, who can still request asylum after crossing the border, and the Trump administration plans to push back illegal immigrants into Mexico while their requests are being processed.

images.alt_text: The Supreme Court dealt President Donald Trump's attempt to crack down on illegal immigration a blow Friday when it rejected a White House bid to implement his asylum ban on Central Americans.

site_title: Safety and service quality are tops for 2019, says Grab's head of regional operations
summary: Grab, the Southeast Asian ride-hailing giant, plans to invest "tens of millions of dollars" in safety features and service quality in 2019. The company aims to enhance driver verification, reduce crime, and improve the overall user experience. Grab is also expanding its Super App service, including a new pet service and point-to-point transport, and will work on improving map accuracy. The company expects to double its revenue to $2 billion next year and is focusing on growth in its food delivery business. Despite increased competition from Gojek and other rivals, Grab remains confident in its ability to operate safely and effectively.

site_title: Federal Reserve could rethink rate hikes as Trump trade wars drag on economy
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering reevaluating interest rate hikes amid concerns about the US economy's slowdown due to President Trump's trade wars. A senior Fed official stated that the central bank is "listening to the fears about the risks" and will reassess its policy stance. New data shows falling exports, slower consumer spending, and business investment, putting economic growth in the second half of the year at risk. The Fed had previously forecast strong growth, but now appears to be taking a more cautious approach.

images.alt_text: The US central bank sent a strong signal on Friday that it would be willing to reconsider expected interest rate hikes amid new data showing President Donald Trump's multi-front trade wars are dragging on the economy and shaking up investors.

site_title: Small wonder from Sonos
summary: The Sonos Beam, a compact soundbar, offers impressive sound quality despite its small size, punching above its weight. It features four full-range woofers, three passive radiators, and one tweeter, powered by five Class-D digital amplifiers. The soundbar performs well in jazz and pop music, but lacks low-end oomph in electronic dance music. It excels in movies, handling fast action scenes with clarity. However, it suffers from sibilance at the high end. At around $700, it competes with other soundbars like Bose's Soundbar 500 and Yamaha's YAS-207, but its compact size limits its soundstage. Despite this, the Sonos Beam is an exceptional choice for those with space constraints.

site_title: Hwa Hong takes 71% stake in £18.5m acquisition of London office block
summary: Hwa Hong acquired a 71.39% stake in Garrett Property Holdings for a nominal value of £71.39, gaining control of a £18.5m London office block. The property has a total lettable floor area of 17,500 sq ft, fully leased until 2029 with annual gross rental income of £610,000. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to Hwa Hong's earnings per share, allowing it to expand its London commercial property portfolio and seek value-add opportunities.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation suspends trading after free float falls below 10%
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings suspended trading after a share subscription caused its free float to fall below 10% due to the issuance of 263 million shares to Saeed Investment for US$26 million. The company has US$4.3 million remaining from the proceeds, which it will use for general working capital. The suspension is under Singapore Exchange rules, allowing for three months or longer to restore the free float to at least 10%.

site_title: Because you're worth it: understanding luxury retail
summary: The luxury retail industry's unique characteristics include a demand curve that is not downward-sloping, with prices often increasing to maintain exclusivity and social status. Luxury brands maintain control over the value chain and distribution channels to ensure consistent quality and customer service. To invest in this sector, investors should analyze a company's profile, demand, pricing strategies, sales performance, branding, and ESG factors. A thorough understanding of these elements can help investors recognize the name, assess the company's profitability and cash position, and make informed decisions.

site_title: Liew Mun Leong launches new Sunday Emails
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat launched a new book by Surbana Jurong chairman Liew Mun Leong, titled "Sunday Emails from a Chairman," which aims to nurture future leaders. The book, the fifth volume in Liew's series, offers practical lessons and perspectives on management, leadership, and other topics. Heng praised Liew's books for their relevance and impact, noting they have reached a wider readership in Singapore and beyond. The book's royalties will be donated to charity, following a similar practice with previous volumes.

site_title: 'Dead skunk' stench from marijuana farms outrages Californians
summary: California residents are suing to ban cannabis operations from their neighborhoods due to the overwhelming stench from marijuana farms. Despite the state's 2016 legalization of recreational cannabis, the potent odor from thousands of flowering plants has become a major issue, with many residents complaining of nausea and discomfort. The problem is particularly severe in Sonoma County, where residents are banding together to sue cannabis growers and demand odor-control measures.

site_title: Global banks chasing Asia techs' transaction business as trade tensions continue
summary: Global banks, including HSBC and Citi-group, are increasing efforts to sell day-to-day banking services to Asia's fast-growing tech firms, amid growing competition for traditional transaction banking. The services, which include trade financing, cash management, and facilitating payments, have become attractive due to the trade tensions between the US and China. Tech firms, such as e-commerce companies and ride-hailing services, are driving growth in this segment, with revenues from technology clients surging 20% for Citi this year.

images.alt_text: In June, HSBC closed a S$500 million, five-year asset-backed syndicated loan for ride-hailing service Grab.

site_title: Signs piling up for slowdown in 2019: WTO chief economist
summary: The World Trade Organization's chief economist, Robert Koopman, warns of a slowdown in global trade growth in 2019, citing weakening leading indicators. The WTO's forecast for global trade growth this year is 3.9%, but it may be downgraded to 3.7% in 2019. Concerns about trade tensions and slowing economic growth are surfacing in major economies, including the US, China, and the EU. Koopman notes that the uncertainty from trade conflicts could weigh on businesses and consumer sentiment, potentially leading to a downturn in investment and spending.

images.alt_text: "When you look at leading indicators, they continue to weaken. It's almost like a death from a thousand cuts," says Robert Koopman. "There's not any one big change in those leading indicators but, boy, they are starting to add up."

site_title: The social trends shaping business in 2019
summary: Key consumer communications trends shaping business in 2019 include video, stories, and messaging, driven by accelerated technology adoption and the rise of mobile devices. The Asia-Pacific region leads in video consumption, with smartphones dominating views. The multi-screen consumer trend is also prominent, with simultaneous use of second-screen devices increasing. Stories have become increasingly popular, with over 1 billion shared daily, and messaging has become a preferred method for businesses to engage with customers, offering a direct line for guidance, expertise, and streamlined shopping experiences.

site_title: Deutsche, Credit Agricole, Credit Suisse charged by EU over alleged bond cartel
summary: The European Commission has charged Deutsche Bank, Credit Agricole, Credit Suisse, and another bank with allegedly participating in a bond trading cartel. The investigation focused on traders' online chatrooms, and if found guilty, the banks could face fines up to 10% of their global turnover. This case is the latest in a series of penalties for rigging financial benchmarks, with Deutsche Bank having paid over $3 billion to resolve interest rate benchmark investigations. The banks' reputations have been damaged, and investors may face claims if collusion is proven.

site_title: Reits
summary:

Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. In Asia, Goldman Sachs acquired a Seoul hotel and retail portfolio, while New World sold China property assets after a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at its Singapore office post-bankruptcy. These developments reflect shifting market trends and investor sentiments.

site_title: China pledges to step up tax cuts, keep liquidity ample
summary: China has pledged to step up tax cuts and maintain ample liquidity in 2019 to support economic growth, aiming to keep growth within a "reasonable range". The country will maintain pro-active fiscal and monetary policies, focusing on efficiency and job creation. The government will also strengthen counter-cyclical adjustments and make policy fine-tuning in a pre-emptive manner to curb risks and financial market volatility.

site_title: Forget drones. Amazon's Jeff Bezos needs lots of delivery guys
summary: Amazon is expanding its network of independent delivery drivers, a move to keep pace with growing demand during peak seasons. The company is partnering with aspiring entrepreneurs, offering them $300,000 a year in exchange for a $10,000 upfront investment. This model allows Amazon to exert less control over drivers while maintaining a steady stream of packages. The company is copying FedEx's approach, but faces challenges in recruiting and retaining drivers, who earn around $150 per eight-hour shift. Amazon's goal is to find a way to add drivers without breaking the bank, as it seeks to reduce costs and maintain its competitive edge in the e-commerce market.

site_title: An investment strategy that consistently underperforms
summary: A popular investment strategy consistently underperforms the market, and many investors unknowingly follow it. When a stock becomes the largest in the market, it's actually a sell signal, as it tends to underperform the overall market. Over the past 40 years, the largest company in the market has outperformed the overall market only briefly, and consistently underperforming has been the norm. A good rule of thumb is to sell when a stock becomes the largest in the market, and consider eliminating the top decile largest companies from your portfolio to potentially double your gains.

site_title: Guangzhou relaxes curbs on commercial property to revive real estate sales
summary: Guangzhou, China, has relaxed curbs on commercial property sales to revive real estate sales. The city's Housing and Urban-Rural Construction Committee announced that developers who built on land sold before March 2017 can now sell commercial property to all buyers, including individuals. This policy change took effect on Thursday, following a similar move by Heze city to curb real estate flipping. The easing of restrictions aims to boost the city's property market, which has been impacted by government efforts to control soaring house prices.

site_title: DKSH to buy Auric Pacific's distribution business in Singapore, Malaysia for 160m Swiss francs
summary: DKSH has agreed to acquire Auric Pacific's consumer goods distribution business in Singapore and Malaysia for 160 million Swiss francs. The deal aims to increase DKSH's exposure to the high-margin food service business and expand its presence in the consumer goods industry in Asia. Auric Pacific's distribution business, which serves over 4,400 customers, generates around 185 million francs in net sales and 14 million francs in operating profit. The acquisition is expected to be immediately earnings accretive, with the existing management team joining DKSH. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and expected to be completed in the first half of 2019.

site_title: The dividend investor's naughty and nice list
summary: This article discusses the performance of various sectors in Singapore's dividend market for 2018. The sectors that performed well include Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits), banks, hotels, and food retailers. CapitaLand Mall Trust, Mapletree Commercial Trust, and DBS Group delivered notable returns, while Carlsberg Brewery Malaysia and Heineken Malaysia stood out for their high dividend growth. The article emphasizes that for income investors, reliability of the income stream is more important than capital appreciation, and encourages investors to focus on dividend yields and reinvesting dividends to grow their income effortlessly.

site_title: Triple P Capital buys insurance IT solutions provider Contemi
summary: Triple P Capital, a Singapore-based private equity impact investing fund, has acquired Contemi Group, an insurance IT solutions provider, for US$5 million. Contemi operates in Asia and Scandinavia, and the acquisition aims to capitalize on the rapid growth and innovation in the IT market for insurance. The company plans to turn its core policy system into an open source project in 2019, a trend seen in modern insurers adopting open source solutions. Contemi's foothold in Asia's emerging markets, particularly Vietnam, is seen as attractive by the fund.

site_title: GovTech, CSA to partner 'ethical hackers' to uncover weaknesses in public systems, websites
summary: The Government Technology Agency (GovTech) and Cyber Security Agency (CSA) of Singapore partnered with HackerOne, a cybersecurity research platform, to launch a Government Bug Bounty Programme (GBBP). The program invites "white hat" hackers to uncover vulnerabilities in government ICT systems and websites, with rewards ranging from US$250 to US$10,000. The program aims to identify cyber blind spots and benchmark the government's defenses against skilled global hackers. The findings will be shared in March 2019, and the program will be expanded to include more systems and websites in the future.

The development includes an onsen spa, restaurants, and concierge services, with prices starting from approximately US$500,000. Setsu Niseko is due for completion in December 2021.

site_title: Life after Ferrari and Maserati for Hong Seh Motors
summary: Hong Seh Motors, formerly an authorized distributor for Ferrari and Maserati in Singapore, has celebrated its 50th anniversary after branching out to become a boutique car parallel importer. The company now specializes in luxury, sports, and exotic models, including Alfa Romeo, Mercedes-Benz, and Tesla. With a 40,000 square foot maintenance facility, Hong Seh Motors also offers services in sourcing, restoring, and importing classic cars. The company has recently expanded into electric cars, announcing the sale and leasing of Tesla models in Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices tumble to lowest in more than a year as equities sell off
summary: Oil prices plummeted 5% on Thursday, reaching their lowest level in over a year, due to concerns about oversupply and a US interest rate hike. Brent crude futures fell to $54.35 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures fell to $45.88 a barrel. Global stock markets declined after the US Federal Reserve raised rates, leading to a drop in oil prices. Despite OPEC's plans to curb output, production remains high, and market skepticism persists.

site_title: The bumpy road to electric cars
summary: Singapore's slow adoption of electric cars is attributed to production problems, consumer-unfriendly prices, and basic infrastructural needs. Despite the benefits of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and addressing global inequality, the country has been slow to warm to electric vehicles. To move ahead, businesses must prioritize sustainability and become part of the solution, not the problem. The United Nations Development Programme's head, Achim Steiner, emphasizes the need for collective action to address climate change and promote a clean, green future.

site_title: Business opportunities in a world of trade disruption
summary: The US-China trade war continues to pose a challenge to businesses worldwide, with over half of Singapore-based businesses feeling a moderate to significant impact from recent US trade actions. The Trump administration's trade policies are unlikely to change, with potential targets for trade sanctions including Russia, Iran, and North Korea. Despite this, countries like Japan, the EU, and Mexico are pursuing high-pressure free trade agreements. The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) offers benefits such as tariff elimination, while the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) has the potential to bring huge trade opportunities to the region if outstanding differences are resolved.

site_title: Noble completes debt restructuring, transfers assets to new entity
summary: NOBLE Group has completed debt restructuring and transferred substantially all its assets to a new entity, New Noble. New Noble has access to US$800 million of debt facilities, allowing it to continue its commodity trading operations. The restructuring aims to restructure the company's debt and maintain its core business.

site_title: Storytelling has power to fight hate
summary: Steven Spielberg has expanded the USC Shoah Foundation's archive with prerecorded video conversations using playback technology, allowing visitors to converse with 16 survivors of genocide. The goal is to fight hate, which Spielberg says has become commonplace globally. The foundation, founded by Spielberg in 1994, has collected over 51,000 testimonies from Holocaust survivors and now includes modern testimonies about genocide. The organization aims to counter hate through education and storytelling, and has produced films and documentaries, including a re-release of Spielberg's "Schindler's List."

site_title: Apple risks iPhone ban in Germany after court case loss
summary: A German court ruled in favor of Qualcomm in a patent dispute against Apple, potentially leading to a ban on iPhone sales in Germany. The ruling affects iPhone models 7plus, 7, 8, 8plus, and X. This marks the second major win for Qualcomm in a month, following a Chinese court's prohibition on iPhone sales over a separate patent dispute. The ruling could have significant implications for Apple's European market presence.

site_title: KL moves timely reminder of the importance of food security for Singapore
summary: Singapore's reliance on imported food, particularly eggs from Malaysia, has raised concerns about its food security. A Malaysian ban on fish and shrimp exports may impact Singapore's supply, but the country's importers are prepared to tap other sources. Despite topping the Global Food Security Index, Singapore's vulnerabilities to climate-related risks and high reliance on imports (90% of food) remain. Efforts to boost agricultural capacity, including an agri-tech hub, are underway, but Singapore's food security remains a concern, particularly in the face of climate change and potential supply disruptions.

site_title: Passengers at London Gatwick face days of delays after drones stop flights
summary: Passengers at London Gatwick airport are facing disruptions through to Friday due to drone sightings that forced the airport to shut its runway. Two drones were spotted near the airfield on Wednesday, causing thousands of Christmas travelers to experience delays. Authorities halted flights at 2200 GMT on Wednesday, with over 20 police units searching for the drone operators. The airport, which handled around 115,000 passengers on Thursday, is expected to continue to be affected by the disruptions. Flights are expected to resume once the drones are found and the airfield is deemed safe.

images.alt_text: Gatwick officials advised passengers to check before travelling to the airport and have warned that the knock-on effects from the airport closure would last for some time.

site_title: US dollar drops to one-month low
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-month low of 96.258 against its rivals due to growing concerns about a US economic slowdown. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and potential future hikes are fueling expectations of a recession. The US bond yield curve flattened, and repatriation investments from US companies are slowing down, contributing to the dollar's decline. Other currencies, such as the euro and sterling, rose against the dollar, while Sweden's krona jumped 1.5% after the central bank raised interest rates for the first time in over seven years.

site_title: Americans have grown fatter, shorter since 1999: US data
summary: US health data reveals that Americans have grown fatter and shorter over the past 20 years. Average weight, waist circumference, and body mass index (BMI) in adults have increased, with men adding 3.62kg to their average weight from 1999-2000 to 2015-2016. Men's average waist size has also increased, while women's waists have grown 6cm. American men are now slightly shorter, averaging 1.754m, and women's average height has decreased by one-tenth of an inch. BMI has risen for both men and women, with significant increases in men.

site_title: US Congress will not pass bill on self-driving cars in 2018: senators
summary: US Congress will not vote on a bill to speed up the introduction of self-driving cars before adjourning for the year, according to key senators. A proposal to extend a $7,500 tax credit for electric vehicles was also not attached to a funding bill. Republican Senator John Thune and Democrat Senator Gary Peters vowed to try again next year, warning the US may fall behind countries like China and South Korea in developing self-driving technology. The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers called the bill's failure a setback for the development of potentially life-saving technologies.

site_title: Skoda Karoq review: A 'Roq star
summary: The Skoda Karoq is a highly praised vehicle that offers excellent value for its price, starting at S$112,900. Despite not being designed for off-roading, it excels in hauling families around and provides a smooth ride and agile handling. The 1.5-litre turbo engine and 7-speed automatic transmission deliver refinement and performance, while the VarioFlex seating system offers versatility and cargo space. The Karoq's balance of price, features, and performance makes it a standout in its class, justifying its "Roq star" status.

site_title: Pacific Radiance wins some, loses others in restructuring efforts
summary: Pacific Radiance, a debt-ridden offshore and marine group, has received firm commitments from certain investors for a US$85 million (S$116 million) equity injection, but other investors have reduced their investments. The company continues to seek additional investors to meet its investment requirements. Pacific Radiance also explores debt-restructuring efforts, executing a binding term sheet with unnamed parties to acquire a vessel-owning and logistics services provider for US$180 million. The deal is contingent on board and shareholder approval, following a voluntary trading suspension since late February.

site_title: US Senate okays stopgap spending bill but denies more funds for Trump's wall
summary: The US Senate approved a stopgap spending bill to avert a government shutdown, excluding $5 billion for President Trump's border wall. The bill, which will fund government operations through February 8, needs to pass the House of Representatives and be signed by the president by Friday. The measure is seen as a defeat for Trump, who had pushed for the wall funding. Democrats and Republicans have clashed over immigration, and the bill's passage signals a temporary break in the impasse.

site_title: Frasers Property Australia to acquire Melbourne housing estate for A$202.5m
summary: Frasers Property Australia has agreed to acquire The Grove housing estate in Melbourne for A$202.5 million. The partially completed project, covering 167 hectares, will yield 1,780 residential lots. The acquisition is under deferred payment terms, with settlement to occur in stages over three years. Frasers Property will deliver on the existing masterplan, featuring over 2,600 homes, a town centre, and community facilities. The company will formally take over sales and marketing functions on February 11, 2019.

site_title: BMW 330i review: Still a mighty 3
summary: BMW's new 7th-generation 3 Series is a resurgent model that combines impressive performance with advanced technology, making it a formidable competitor in the "small executive sedan" segment. The 330i variant features a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine, Driver Assistant Plus system for semi-autonomous driving, and Intelligent Personal Assistant for voice control. The car boasts a futuristic cabin, precise steering, and excellent chassis, making it a blast to drive. With its refined comfort and advanced tech, the 3 Series is poised to lead its class and reclaim its position as a top contender in the market.

site_title: Is this the end for Europe?
summary: France and Germany, two EU anchors, face internal problems, threatening the EU project. Rising anxieties among rural and suburban working-class populations, largely white, have led to protests and riots, such as in Paris and Rome. The EU's core challenge is balancing economic growth, redistribution, and free-flowing borders while addressing the decline of middle-skilled jobs and stagnant incomes. French President Emmanuel Macron's top-down approach has produced a backlash, and his failure could bring the end of Europe.

images.alt_text: Mr Macron's royalist, top-down approach produced a vicious backlash for weeks now from protesters who felt left behind and neglected as a result of his policies.

site_title: The US$48 billion sell-off that sent Japanese stocks into bear territory
summary: US$48 billion sell-off hits Japanese stocks, sending them into a bear market. The benchmark Topix index declined 2.5% on Thursday, marking a 21% drop from its January high. UBS Wealth Management's Toru Ibayashi warns of a "cold winter" for traders, citing the worst foreign investor exodus in three decades. The sell-off is attributed to the massive outflow of US funds, which may exacerbate the market's decline.

site_title: Perennial-led JV wins tender for Yunnan development with 341.5m yuan bid
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' 45% owned joint venture, Perennial HC Holdings, won a tender to develop two plots of land in Yunnan, China, for 341.5 million yuan (S$67.6 million). The Kunming South HSR Integrated Development will feature a general hospital, eldercare apartments, and commercial spaces, with a 40-year tenure and 627,600 sqm GFA. The development aligns with Perennial's strategy to acquire HSR healthcare and commercial integrated developments in China, with its CEO stating that it will strengthen the company's presence in Southwest China.

site_title: Woodlands industrial site up for tender
summary: JTC has accepted an application to sell a 20,937.7 sqm industrial site at Woodlands Avenue 12 for S$36 million, with a 30-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 2.5. The site will be released for public tender on Dec 26, with a six-week tender period, following a successful application under the Reserve List system. The site is zoned for "Business 2" development or heavier industrial use.

site_title: The great American tax heist turns 1 amid wrong calls
summary: US President Donald Trump's corporate tax cut, signed into law last year, has failed to deliver promised economic growth, contradicting predictions from over 100 economists who supported the bill. The Tax Policy Center, a neutral scorekeeper, had warned of a more realistic outcome, but its predictions were largely ignored by proponents of the tax cuts. Now, economists must re-examine their flawed forecasts, as investment has not increased as predicted, and the US economy has not seen the expected growth.

site_title: A Christmas Past
summary: Christmas in Singapore has evolved significantly since the 1970s, from a simple cardboard tree in People's Park Complex to an extravagant display of lights and decorations. In the 1980s, buildings and hotels began to decorate for the season, with pine-scented sprays on plastic trees. Today, the Orchard Road Business Association partners with Disney to create a festive atmosphere, featuring a wide range of colors and images. This transformation reflects the country's shift towards a more secular and commercialized celebration of Christmas.

site_title: Tokyo District Court will not extend Ghosn's detention
summary: A Tokyo District Court refused to extend the detention of Nissan's ousted chairman Carlos Ghosn, potentially leading to his release from prison. Ghosn faces charges of understating his income over a five-year period, with prosecutors also re-arresting him for the same alleged crime. The court's decision is seen as a change in its approach to detention, and Ghosn's lawyers believe it could have a significant impact on Japanese justice practice.

site_title: South Koreans sue govt over wartime labour at Japanese firms
summary: South Korea has sued its government over wartime labor compensation for Japanese firms, seeking 100 million won (S$122,000) each for over 1,100 former forced laborers. The lawsuit claims the government received funds from Japan as compensation, despite having not paid the victims. The move adds to three previous lawsuits by a total of 283 victims and their families, who are seeking reparations for their experiences during Japan's colonization of the Korean peninsula during World War II.

site_title: Real estate hurts Dubai bourse, all major Gulf markets slide
summary: Dubai's stock market fell 1.1% on Thursday, with real estate shares leading the decline. The index is down 25% for the year, making it the worst-performing market in the Middle East. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and sliding oil prices contributed to the downturn. Other Gulf markets also fell, with Saudi Arabia's index down 0.6%, Qatar's index down 0.8%, and the Abu Dhabi index down 0.4%. The decline is attributed to a weak real estate market, forcing construction firms to cut jobs and halt expansion plans.

site_title: Asia's central banks have almost no reasons to hike rates in 2019
summary: Asia's central banks are unlikely to hike interest rates in 2019 due to a depressed growth outlook and subdued inflation, which diminishes the argument for rate hikes. The US Federal Reserve's slower pace of rate hikes and weakening exchange rates in Asia also contribute to this trend. As a result, economies such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and India may experience more inflows into their bonds and relief for smaller-sized, low-margin borrowers. The International Monetary Fund expects Asia's economic growth to slow to 5.4% in 2019.

site_title: Oil falls as Fed hike threatens growth and fear of glut persists
summary: US oil prices fell to near $47 a barrel after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, sparking fears of economic growth and a supply glut. Inventories at a key US storage hub rose to the highest level since January, adding to speculation that Opec's production cuts will be undermined by shale supplies. The Fed's decision failed to quell concerns, and oil prices are expected to hover in the $40 range due to market uncertainties.

site_title: Shell quietly enters Japanese market
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc has set up a small desk to trade electricity in Japan, marking its entry into the country's market. The company is in an "experimental" phase, learning to buy and sell power and identify industrial customers. Shell sees opportunities to balance the grid when there are supply-demand mismatches driven by intermittent wind and solar power. Japan, which has deregulated its electricity market since 2016, has seen spot trading surge, with nearly 30% of electricity purchased through the exchange in November.

images.alt_text: ONE of the largest energy companies is quietly testing the waters of what is perhaps the world's richest electricity market yet to be tapped by foreign investors.

site_title: SGX IPO value for 2018 plunges to second lowest since 2008: PwC
summary: Singapore's IPO market saw a sharp decline in 2018, raising S$730 million from 15 listings, the second-lowest in the last decade. This follows a significant drop from 2017's S$4.7 billion from 20 listings. Despite this, global IPO proceeds increased to US$160.6 billion in the first nine months of 2018, driven by robust activity in the Americas and Hong Kong. PwC predicts that the IPO pipeline remains optimistic in 2019, with sectors like real estate, healthcare, and food and beverage expected to see increased fundraising activities.

site_title: British ministers split over what to do next if PM May's Brexit deal fails
summary: British ministers are divided over the government's next steps if Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal fails. Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd suggests a "plausible argument" for a second referendum, while House of Commons leader Andrea Leadsom proposes a "managed no deal" with bilateral arrangements. The government is seeking assurances from EU leaders on the Irish backstop, and some ministers threaten to quit if the no-deal option becomes official policy.

site_title: NTUC Enterprise gets competition panel's nod to buy Kopitiam
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has given the green light for NTUC Enterprise's proposed acquisition of food centre operator Kopitiam, stating it will not lead to a substantial lessening of competition. The acquisition, valued at an undisclosed amount, will bring Kopitiam under NTUC Enterprise's umbrella. The CCCS found that the combined market share in overlapping areas will be below 20% and that there are at least five other competing operators remaining post-merger. The acquisition is expected to be completed in January 2019, with NTUC Foodfare and Kopitiam continuing to operate separately.

images.alt_text: NTUC Foodfare and Kopitiam will continue to operate separately, with their respective management teams and employees remaining in place. Business will continue as usual and Kopitiam Loyalty Card users can go on using their Kopitiam Card at all Kopitiam outlets.

site_title: House of Horrors
summary: Netflix's 2018 series "The Haunting Of Hill House" is considered one of the most complex and compelling TV horror series of the year, earning critical acclaim for its storytelling and character development. The show's blend of horror and heartbreak makes it a standout, with even minor characters having their own unique stories to tell. Its success has contributed to the growing respect for the horror genre in TV and film.

site_title: Productivity up, more jobseekers helped: public sector report
summary: Singapore's public sector has reported improved productivity, with real value-added per hour worked increasing to 4.5% in 2017 from 1.4% in 2013. More jobseekers have also secured jobs, with over 25,000 participants benefiting from the Adapt and Grow initiative in 2017. The government has also simplified business processes, such as the LicenceOne portal, and invested in digital solutions for small and medium enterprises. Additionally, healthcare expenditure has more than doubled, and the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme has provided over S$5.5 billion to lower-wage Singaporeans since 2007.

site_title: Saudi Arabia wants to sell 120 billion riyals of bonds in 2019
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to issue around 120 billion riyals ($43.7 billion) in international bonds in 2019 to help finance its deficit. The kingdom aims to tap international markets, including the US and Europe, in the first half of the year. Despite the murder of Jamal Khashoggi, Finance Minister Mohammed Al-Jadaan said foreign investment has not been affected. The budget for 2019 projects revenues of 975 billion riyals, with 662 billion riyals coming from oil, defying analysts' expectations due to falling crude prices.

site_title: Trump tariff war with China sends US retailers on buying binge
summary: US retailers are stockpiling inventory from China ahead of potential tariffs, leading to a record 13.6% surge in imports at major US retail container ports in October, with 2.04 million containers. The buying binge is driven by retailers seeking to avoid higher tariffs that may kick in next year, and could result in heavy discounts for shoppers next year. The surge in imports has driven up transportation and warehousing costs, adding pressure to quarterly results for retailers.

site_title: Queen of Hearts
summary: Bohemian Rhapsody, a biopic about Queen's frontman Freddie Mercury, is screening at select cinemas with lyrics on screen to aid singing along. The film, which has been nominated for Best Motion Picture (Drama) and earned Rami Malek a Best Actor Golden Globe nod, is now playing at several Singapore cinemas.

site_title: Putting Your Best Face Forward
summary: Medical aesthetics treatments have become increasingly popular due to favorable attitudes towards procedures that improve physical appearance. Non-surgical facial aesthetic procedures have seen a 44% increase in demand over the past five years, with trends expected to continue in 2019. Combination treatments that address various layers of the facial tissues are predicted to be the main trend next year, incorporating treatments like botulinum toxins, fillers, and Ultherapy. Patients seek natural-looking results and are willing to invest in preventative measures, such as collagen building procedures like Ultherapy, to minimize the effects of aging.

site_title: Break out the bubblies for dinner tonight
summary: Champagne is often misunderstood as the only type of sparkling wine, but in reality, it refers specifically to sparkling wine from the Champagne region in northern France. Properly used, champagne has incredible food-friendliness due to its high acidity and diverse styles, making it suitable for a wide range of cuisines. Unlike other sparkling wines, champagne is considered a luxury item, and its high quality is worth the splurge for special occasions. Recognizing the distinction between champagne and other sparkling wines can help appreciate the unique qualities of each.

site_title: US home sales rise unexpectedly in Nov
summary: US existing home sales rose 1.9% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.32 million units in November, but fell 7% from a year ago, marking the largest annual drop since May 2011. Sales have declined 2.3% in the first 11 months of this year, constrained by higher mortgage rates and land/labor shortages. The median existing house price increased 4.2% to $257,700, but wage growth outpaces inflation, sidelining some first-time homebuyers.

site_title: Antitrust agencies say Siemens, Alstom concessions fall short
summary: Britain's CMA competition watchdog and its counterparts in four European countries have teamed up to say Siemens and Alstom's plan to create a Franco-German rail champion "falls far short" of addressing concerns. The companies proposed selling high-speed train technologies and signalling assets, but regulators are waiting for comments from rivals and customers. European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager is now reviewing the proposal.

site_title: Ringing in the new year - and new fears
summary: US stocks face a potentially volatile 2019 due to the looming 90-day deadline for a comprehensive trade deal with China, rising interest rates, and uncertainty over Brexit and possibly 'Quitaly'. Rising tariffs, trade wars, and economic slowdowns are expected to negatively impact US growth, leading to a possible recession. Despite the US economy's resilience in 2018, strategists warn that the global selloff may hit the New York Stock Exchange with a vengeance in 2019, as consumer confidence and economic activity are expected to decline.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp's unit DC Reit Holdings acquired 77.6% of I12 Katong shopping mall for S$56.6 million. AsiaPhos received another rejection from Chinese authorities to renew mining rights for a mine in Sichuan province. Goodland Group bought industrial properties on Kim Chuan Drive for S$18.9 million to redevelop them. TT International's debt restructuring scheme won creditor approval.

site_title: Taking a more holistic approach to sustainable financing
summary: The green bond market has reached a significant milestone, with over $164 billion in issuance as of end-November 2018. European issuers dominate the market, accounting for over 50% share, while Asia Pacific accounts for around 30%. The market is evolving, with a growing distinction between green, SDG, sustainability, and social bonds. SDG bonds, which focus on the UN's 17 recognized goals, are gaining traction, with the World Bank launching the world's first "blue bond" for the Republic of Seychelles. Despite a slowdown in growth, the market is expected to continue evolving, with a focus on harmonizing taxonomies, regulatory frameworks, and state-sponsored sustainability funds.

site_title: A payment system that works for the man on the street
summary: A quiet revolution in financial services is underway, transforming payment systems globally. Central banks have started giving non-banks full access to their payment infrastructure, enabling companies like TransferWise to reduce fees and increase speed for international money transfers. Momentum is building worldwide, with countries like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Australia taking steps towards greater access to national payment rails for non-banks. The benefits include cheaper, faster, and more convenient payments for consumers, with lessons learned including the importance of zero entry fees, full independence, and cloud-based systems.

site_title: Putin says he'll take Russia into 'new economic league'
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin announced plans to take Russia into a "new economic league," aiming for a top-5 ranking by economy size. Putin stated that Russia's economy grew 1.7% in the first 10 months of the year, with unemployment down. However, his approval rating has been declining, with recent polls showing support below 50%. Putin also addressed international tensions, including the US withdrawal from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty and the ongoing conflict with Ukraine.

site_title: Aladdin's Fantasia
summary: Guy Ritchie's live-action adaptation of Aladdin, starring Will Smith as the genie, is set to be released in cinemas worldwide next summer. The Broadway musical, based on the 1992 Disney cartoon, is also coming to Singapore in July as part of its international tour, marking the first time the production has visited Asia. The stage adaptation, which debuted on Broadway in 2014, has become a major hit and is expected to bring its unique blend of music and magic to Singapore audiences.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SPH Reit has acquired an 85% stake in Figtree Grove shopping center in New South Wales, Australia for A$188.2 million. The acquisition is expected to add 1-2% to its estimated distribution per unit and make up 5.2% of its assets under management. Top Glove reported a net profit of RM110.1 million in Q1 FY2019, in-line with forecasts, but warned of potential losses from its Aspion operations.

site_title: STI slips 0.3% as Fed hikes rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the fourth time this year, causing Singapore stocks to slip 0.3% as Asian markets also suffered losses. The Straits Times Index fell to 3,050.62 after being down as much as 0.56% in the morning. Investors had anticipated a softer approach due to global growth concerns, but the Fed trimmed its 2019 rate hike projections from three to two.

site_title: Kuroda signals room to ramp up stimulus as economic risks rise
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, keeping interest rates unchanged, but Governor Haruhiko Kuroda signaled a possible increase in stimulus due to rising economic risks. The central bank reiterated its view that Japan's economy is on a solid footing, despite global economic uncertainties and slowed growth. Kuroda warned of "downside risks" to Japan's economy and stated that the BOJ could ease monetary policy further if necessary, potentially leading to a ramp-up of stimulus in 2020.

site_title: IBM manager Jetter seen in lead to become Deutsche Boerse chairman
summary: IBM manager Martin Jetter is considered the leading candidate to become Deutsche Boerse chairman after Joachim Faber's expected departure in 2020. Jetter joined the supervisory board in May and could replace Faber, who initially planned to step down at the next annual shareholder meeting but now aims to stay on for another year. No decision is imminent, with the possibility of bringing in an external candidate. Former Bundesbank director Joachim Nagel is also considered a potential successor.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.1 points lower on Thursday at 1,650.56, with a volume of two billion lots worth RM1.6 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 463 to 334.

site_title: China feels pressure as the clock ticks in trade talks
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is facing growing pressure as the 90-day deadline for a trade deal with the US approaches, with slowing economic growth and disagreements within the Communist Party complicating his strategy. Analysts say Xi's lack of a clear direction on trade and reforms has sparked dissent within the party, with some arguing that China needs to make more significant changes to its economy. Despite resuming soybean purchases and suspending tariffs, China's moves are seen as superficial and aimed at buying time, rather than implementing meaningful reforms.

site_title: German court rules Apple infringed Qualcomm patent
summary: A German court ruled that Apple Inc infringed on Qualcomm's hardware patent, affecting iPhone 7 through iPhone X models. The ruling prohibits Apple from selling some iPhone models in Germany containing a specific component. Qualcomm needs to post a $765 million bond before enforcing the order. This is Qualcomm's third major effort to secure a ban on Apple's iPhones in Germany, the US, and China due to patent infringement allegations.

site_title: Thomas Hoepker
summary: Thomas Hoepker, a renowned photojournalist, has had a six-decade-long career documenting human stories and conditions. Born in Munich, Hoepker began photography at 14 with a glass plate camera and went on to work for publications like Life and Stern, and Magnum Photos. His notable photos include a close-up of Muhammad Ali's fist and a shot of New Yorkers sitting by the Brooklyn waterfront after 9/11. Now 82, Hoepker continues to work with digital cameras and is known for his wanderlust, always ready to capture unique moments. His legacy showcases the power of photography in storytelling the human condition.

site_title: Lawsuit adds to Facebook woes on data protection
summary: The US Attorney General has filed a lawsuit against Facebook, alleging the social network deceived users about who had access to their data and how it was used. The lawsuit seeks an injunction to require Facebook to implement safeguards to monitor users' data and make it easier for users to control privacy settings, and demands restitution for consumers. The lawsuit comes amid growing concerns over Facebook's data sharing practices, including allegations that up to 87 million users had their data hijacked by Cambridge Analytica.

images.alt_text: The New York Times reported that some 150 companies - including powerful partners like Amazon, Microsoft, Netflix and Spotify - could access detailed information about Facebook users, including data about their friends.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower on Fed disappointment
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, extending losses from the previous session, after the Federal Reserve's forecast of fewer interest rate increases in 2019 fell short of investors' hopes for a more dovish monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all declined, with the Dow falling 99.54 points, or 0.43%, to 23,224.12. The disappointing Fed forecast led to a loss of investor confidence, causing stocks to drop at the open.

site_title: Israeli families in talks for potential London office tower site
summary: Israeli real estate company Brockton Everlast Inc., backed by some of Israel's richest families, is in talks to buy the Devonshire Quarter site in London's City of London for about £95 million. The four-building estate could be the location of a new office tower, marking a sign of appetite for development risk in London's office market. The negotiations are private and exclusive, with broker CBRE Group handling the sale.

site_title: Clear skies for Singapore office sector - but beware potential headwinds
summary: Singapore's office sector is expected to see a continued rise in rental values, with Grade A CBD office rentals projected to appreciate 8-10% in 2019, following a 10% increase in 2018. Strong demand from tech companies, coworking operators, and financial institutions is driving the growth, but potential headwinds from interest rate hikes, trade wars, and global economic slowdowns could dampen office demand. The lack of new Grade A office supply in 2019 is expected to tighten supply and put pressure on rents.

site_title: Keppel pays S$56.6m to buy rest of shopping mall I12 Katong it does not own
summary: Keppel Corporation's DC Reit Holdings has acquired 77.6% of the issued share capital of PRE 1, the owner of shopping mall I12 Katong, for S$56.6 million. This deal allows Keppel to take full control of the mall, which is strategically located in an affluent residential precinct. Keppel expects to record a loss of S$16.8 million from the re-measurement of its interests in the property. The company plans to enhance the mall through asset improvement works and new concept offerings.

site_title: TT Int'l new scheme of arrangement wins creditors' approval
summary: TT International's scheme of arrangement, aimed at restructuring its debt, has won creditor approval with 90% of creditors voting in favor. The plan involves selling 10 subsidiaries to Celestial Palace for S$48 million, using most proceeds to ensure secured creditors' full recovery. Unsecured creditors will receive a higher recovery compared to a liquidation scenario. The scheme will discharge existing liabilities and allow the company to pursue post-restructuring business directions as a going concern, bringing an end to a nearly eight-year debt restructuring process.

site_title: India's Infosys appoints Nilanjan Roy as CFO
summary: India's Infosys appoints Nilanjan Roy as its chief financial officer, effective March 1, 2019. Roy, previously global CFO at Bharti Airtel, will replace Jayesh Sanghrajka, who will resume his role as Deputy CFO. The appointment comes after the departure of M D Ranganath.

site_title: Mars InSight deploys French-made quake sensor on Red Planet
summary: The US space agency's Mars InSight lander has successfully deployed its French-made quake sensor, Seis, on the Martian surface. The instrument, designed to study ground motion, or marsquakes, will help scientists create a three-dimensional map of Mars' interior to understand how rocky planets formed. Deployment of Seis was a crucial step in the two-year mission, which aims to shed light on Mars' internal structure and geological history. The lander's principal investigator, Bruce Banerdt, called Seis deployment "as important as landing InSight on Mars."

site_title: Soros fund is cutting back on the bets that made its founder a billionaire
summary: Soros Fund Management, founded by billionaire George Soros, is reducing its macro wagers, shifting away from the strategy that made its founder a billionaire. The firm has cut allocations to macro investments from $3 billion to $500 million, citing fewer opportunities. The move is part of a broader shift under new chief investment officer Dawn Fitzpatrick, who has refocused the business and restructured investments. The firm's macro team lost 4-5% this year, while the overall firm is up slightly, and several macro staff members have been cut.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slump at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets plummeted at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 1.4%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 losing 1.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 retreating 1.4%. The slump follows a rout of Asian shares, mirroring big losses on Wall Street after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, sparking fears of choking economic growth. The decline is attributed to renewed slides on Wall Street and British retail sales data, as well as uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: India to spend 830 billion rupees by March on bad loan clean up
summary: India plans to infuse 830 billion rupees (S$16.2 billion) into state-run banks by March to clean up a sector saddled with bad debt and boost economic growth ahead of the 2019 federal polls. This is part of a total 1.06 trillion rupees infusion this fiscal year. The move aims to improve lending and reverse an economic slowdown, as the sector struggles with over $210 billion of stressed debt.

site_title: Crackdown on rappers 'pointless', Putin says
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that a crackdown on rappers is "pointless" and should be replaced with more delicate methods to convince young people of the importance of other values. He expressed concerns about the "propaganda" of drugs and suicide in rap music, but also acknowledged the value of protest and self-expression. Putin suggested that role models for modern youth should be heroic figures like those who survived World War II, rather than rappers who promote negative lifestyles. He also hinted that some rappers may benefit from concert cancellations.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims up; mid-Atlantic factory activity slows
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose marginally to 214,000, near a 49-year low, suggesting underlying strength in the labor market and broader economy. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the fourth time this year, but forecast fewer rate hikes next year and signaled its tightening cycle is nearing an end. Factory activity in the mid-Atlantic region slowed in December, but manufacturers hired more workers and were upbeat about business conditions over the next six months.

site_title: Retailer Casino switches on data centres in new revenue search
summary: Casino, a French supermarket retailer, has signed a deal to install data centers in its warehouses to generate revenue. The data centers will be operated by ScaleMax, a joint venture between Qarnot Computing and Casino. This move aims to diversify revenue and reduce debt levels, which have been under pressure from investors. The first data center is expected to start operating in 2019, with plans for 20 more sites by 2023, generating revenue through space rental and power sales. This business is expected to be profitable, according to Casino.

site_title: Goodland unit buys industrial properties in Tai Seng estate for S$18.9m
summary: Goodland Group's unit, Goodland Citrine, acquired industrial properties in Tai Seng estate for S$18.9 million through an option to purchase. The 1,415.3 sq m freehold properties, with a "Business 2" zoning and 2.5 plot ratio, will be redeveloped. The acquisition price is significantly lower than Goodland's last traded share price of S$0.245.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% on Thursday, closing at 3,050.62 points, with 281 losers outnumbering 125 gainers. Active traded counters included Ezion Holdings and Golden Agri-Resources, which declined 6.38% and 2% respectively.

site_title: Australia shares hit 2-year lows on Fed pressure; NZ turns up
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.3% to a two-year low, reaching 5,505.80, due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike amid slowing global growth. Oil prices fell 1.8% and metal prices dropped, with aluminium prices reaching a 16-month low. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1% as domestic economic growth slowed to a five-year low.

site_title: Pacific Radiance updates investment, debt-restructuring efforts
summary: Pacific Radiance, a debt-ridden offshore and marine group, has updated its investment and debt-restructuring efforts. Despite initial commitments from investors for a US$85 million equity injection, others have reduced their investments. The company continues to seek additional investors and explores alternatives for debt restructuring. It has executed a binding term sheet with unnamed parties to acquire a target company with assets valued at US$180 million, to be funded through the issue and allotment of shares. Pacific Radiance aims to raise a total of US$120 million through investments and debt restructuring.

site_title: Muslim Pakistan says outcry over China detention camps 'sensationalised'
summary: Pakistan defends China against international outcry over Muslim detention camps, saying the issue is being "sensationalised" by foreign media. The country's ministry of foreign affairs claims that out of 44 women from Pakistan who married Uighur men in China, six are in detention, with four convicted and three under investigation. Human rights activists say the camps are involuntary and that the region has become a police state. Pakistan and China will continue to coordinate on the matter, with the Chinese authorities offering visits to the families of the convicted women.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index plunges to 15-month low
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted to a 15-month low on Thursday, closing down 2.84% or 595.34 points to 20,392.58, amidst US Federal Reserve meeting disappointment. The broader Topix index also dropped 2.51% or 38.99 points. This marks the lowest level since September last year.

site_title: Stocks tumble on deepening fears of a fed mistake
summary: Stocks plummeted in Europe and Asia on Thursday as investors feared a Fed mistake, with over two-thirds of Stoxx Europe 600 members falling. US equity futures also declined, and the dollar weakened, while the yen jumped to its strongest level since mid-October. Analysts predict a sustained downside for markets in 2019, despite the Fed signaling a less aggressive path for rate hikes. Global stocks are set for their worst quarter since 2011, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index falling 1.4% and futures on the S&P 500 Index declining 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Stocks tumbled in Europe and Asia on Thursday while US equity futures fell as investors expressed concern about a lack of relief from the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening.

site_title: AsiaPhos gets rejected for mining rights again, five months later
summary: AsiaPhos, a mining firm, has received another rejection from Chinese authorities to renew exploration rights for two mines in Sichuan province, five months after the initial rejection. The company claims the rejection is an "unlawful expropriation of AsiaPhos' investments" and is exploring arbitration. The mines are located within protected nature reserves, and the Chinese government has not finalized the compensation amount. The company's shares have declined to S$0.011.

site_title: Hong Kong: Markets close down
summary: Hong Kong's markets closed down on Thursday, following an Asia-wide slump triggered by the Federal Reserve's fourth rate hike of the year. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.94% to 25,623.53, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.52%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.20%. The decline was attributed to the Fed's rate hike, which affected stocks across the region.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Public Sector Outcomes Review found increased productivity and more successful jobseekers. The Ministry of Finance reported improved business convenience. In financial news, stocks tumbled globally due to concerns over a potential Federal Reserve mistake. A Singapore competition panel approved the acquisition of Kopitiam by NTUC Enterprise. New Noble acquired Noble Group assets, and Frasers Property Australia purchased a Melbourne housing estate for A$202.5 million.

site_title: Noble completes debt restructuring, transfers assets to new entity
summary: NOBLE Group has completed its debt restructuring, transferring substantially all assets to new entity New Noble. New Noble has access to US$800 million debt facilities, allowing it to continue commodity trading. Shareholders hold 20% stake, while senior creditors hold 70% and management control 10%. Independent non-executive directors Wayne Porritt and Tim Isaacs have resigned, and a new board will be appointed. New Noble will not be listed due to Singapore regulators' decision and is facing an investigation into its past accounts.

images.alt_text: Noble Group said, as its restructuring took effect on Thursday, that a total US$800 million in new money debt has been made available to New Noble - the restructured entity whose planned listing on the Singapore bourse was derailed by an ongoing probe into improper accounting.

site_title: From 2020, all Singapore passport and NRIC applications must be done online
summary: Singapore's Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) plans to stop using paper forms for 15 services by 2010, including passport and NRIC applications, to support the country's Smart Nation goals. The ICA's MyICA portal, launched in June, already offers 8 services and allows users to make one consolidated payment. To assist those unfamiliar with online transactions, the ICA will provide online tutorials, multi-language video guides, and self-service kiosks at its building. The authority also plans to make special arrangements for those with medical reasons or limited internet access.

site_title: UBS appoints co-heads for Asia-Pacific wealth management business
summary: UBS has appointed Amy Lo and August Hatecke as co-heads of its Asia-Pacific wealth management business, succeeding Edmund Koh, who was recently appointed president of Asia-Pacific. Lo, head of wealth management in Greater China, and Hatecke, head of wealth management in South-east Asia, will take effect on January 1, 2019. UBS manages $521 billion in the Asia-Pacific region, the world's largest private bank by assets under management.

site_title: US Senate passes stopgap spending bill that would avert shutdown
summary: The US Senate passed a stopgap spending bill, averting a government shutdown through February 8. The measure would fund nine federal departments and punt the southern border wall impasse to the new year. The bill's passage poses a challenge for President Donald Trump, who had demanded $5 billion for the wall. The bill's fate remains uncertain, with Trump's potential signing or veto still unclear.

site_title: Indonesia's construction industry to gain from openness to BRI: Fitch
summary: Indonesia's construction industry is expected to benefit from its openness to China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), with private and foreign capital crucial in bridging the country's infrastructure gap. BRI projects account for 20% of Indonesia's infrastructure projects, with new projects worth up to $60 billion offered to Chinese investors. Fitch Solutions forecasts the industry to average real growth of 7.2% from 2019 to 2027, driven by infrastructure development plans and China's growing involvement. The government aims to decentralize business activity and shift debt risk from the public to the private sector.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks tumble on Fed hike, 2019 rates outlook
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index plummeted 0.90% to 2,060.12, its lowest point in nearly two years, due to the US Federal Reserve's decision to maintain its policy tightening outlook for 2019. The won fell, and bond yields rose. SK Hynix and LG Innotek also slid, with Micron Technology warning of a market glut in memory chips. Tensions over a car-pooling service also led to a rally by South Korean taxi drivers protesting its impact on their livelihoods.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,045.12, down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday at 3,045.12, down 0.4% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index dropped 13.53 points. Golden Agri-Resources and Ezion Holdings led declines, falling 4% and 4.3% respectively. The market saw 590.7 million shares worth S$417.1 million traded.

site_title: Bank of England holds rate awaiting Brexit deal
summary: The Bank of England kept its main lending rate at 0.75% due to intensified Brexit uncertainties, minutes revealed. A no-deal Brexit could trigger a financial crisis, with the pound potentially plummeting 25%. The central bank maintained quantitative easing stimulus policy, citing a slowing global economy and weak business investment. Despite this, British retail sales rebounded strongly in November, beating analysts' forecasts. The BoE's monetary policy response to Brexit will depend on the effects of EU withdrawal on demand, supply, and the exchange rate.

site_title: Woodlands industrial site up for tender: JTC
summary: JTC has accepted an application to sell an industrial site at Woodlands Avenue 12 through public tender. The site, measuring 20,937.7 square meters, has a minimum committed bid price of S$36 million. Zoned for "Business-2" development or heavier industrial use, the site has a 30-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 2.5. The public tender for the site is scheduled for December 26 with a six-week tender period.

site_title: China 'resolutely opposes' new US law on Tibet
summary: China's foreign ministry has "resolutely opposed" the US law on Tibet, calling it an "internal affair" and a threat to China-US relations. The Reciprocal Access to Tibet Act, signed into law by President Trump, aims to restrict US entry for Chinese officials who restrict access to Tibet. China's Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying stated that the law would harm bilateral relations if implemented. The law seeks to promote access to Tibet for US diplomats, journalists, and citizens by denying entry to Chinese officials deemed responsible for restricting access.

site_title: BMW, Daimler mulling cooperation on key car components: sources
summary: BMW and Daimler, parent company of Mercedes-Benz, are exploring a potential partnership on key car components, including vehicle platforms, batteries, and autonomous technology. The move aims to cut costs and invest in self-driving and electric cars. The two German manufacturers have already collaborated on components purchasing and digital-mapping, and are considering further cooperation on mobility operations. Any partnership would be restricted to non-brand-specific technology and its timing is unclear. The move reflects the industry's shift towards cost-cutting and technology-sharing to stay competitive.

site_title: At Jesus's birthplace, an app is born to ease crowds
summary: A new app is being developed to manage crowds at the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, where Jesus is believed to have been born, due to the expected surge in tourists this Christmas. The app, set to be introduced early next year, will allow visitors to reserve a spot in advance, ensuring a regular flow of tourists and reducing wait times. The app will be available in English and will provide information about the church, including details of specific prayers, celebrations, and masses.

site_title: Ghosn 'may be released' after Japan court rejects detention request
summary: A Japanese court rejected prosecutors' request to extend the detention of former Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn, who was arrested for financial misconduct. Ghosn may be released as early as Friday due to his detention period expiring. He faces charges of under-reporting his pay by $44 million and is also under investigation for other financial misconduct claims. Ghosn and his former right-hand man, Greg Kelly, have denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: Weinstein back in court seeking dismissal of sex assault case
summary: Harvey Weinstein, accused of multiple sex assaults, is seeking to have his case dismissed due to alleged police misconduct. His defense attorney, Ben Brafman, claims that one investigator's actions have "irreparably tainted" the case, including failing to disclose witness testimony and deleting text messages. Prosecutors want to continue the case, despite Brafman's motion, and argue that the detective's conduct only affected one accuser. A judge's decision could be a game-changer for Weinstein, who faces life in prison if convicted.

site_title: Asia: Markets slump after Fed hikes rates
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday, mirroring Wall Street's losses after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the fourth time this year. Despite the Fed's dovish tone, investors were spooked by Chairman Jerome Powell's statement that the bank won't shift course on reducing its balance sheet. The Dow hit its lowest level of 2018, and Asian markets followed, with Tokyo, Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Seoul all falling. The Fed now projects only two interest rate increases, trimming its forecast for US growth and inflation, but concerns over global growth and trade tensions persist.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday, STI at 3,057.61
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,057.61. Losers outnumbered gainers 77 to 41, with about 40.8 million shares worth S$72.6 million traded. Ezion fell 2.1%, while DBS dropped 0.8%. ComfortDelGro gained 1.9%.

site_title: New Zealand top court lets Kim Dotcom appeal US extradition
summary: New Zealand's Supreme Court has allowed Megaupload founder Kim Dotcom to appeal his extradition to the US on fraud and online piracy charges. The decision, made by a panel of five judges, rejects an argument by US lawyers that they didn't have jurisdiction to hear Dotcom's appeals. Dotcom faces up to 20 years in prison in the US if extradited, and this ruling gives him one last chance to overturn a court ruling in his favor. A date for the appeal hearing has yet to be set.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's top court will hear Megaupload founder Kim Dotcom's final appeal against extradition to the United States on fraud and online piracy charges, judges said Thursday.

site_title: Singapore competition panel gives nod to acquisition of Kopitiam by NTUC Enterprise
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has approved NTUC Enterprise's acquisition of Kopitiam, a homegrown food centre operator, without finding it to infringe on competition. The deal, expected to be completed in January 2019, will not lead to a substantial lessening of competition in the relevant markets. The merged entity will face sufficient competition, with many stalls operated by third-party food vendors within their premises, and will be regulated by the National Environment Agency (NEA).

site_title: Angry South Korean taxi drivers rally against carpooling service
summary: Tens of thousands of South Korean taxi drivers held a rally to protest against a carpooling service, Kakao Mobility, which they claim would destroy their jobs and threaten their livelihoods. The service was postponed after a taxi driver's suicide protest against the plans. Drivers say they already suffer from low income and long hours, and a proposed compromise has yet to be agreed upon with the government. The ruling party has established a task force to resolve the dispute, but a solution remains elusive.

site_title: Frasers Property Australia to buy Melbourne housing estate for A$202.5m
summary: Frasers Property Australia has agreed to acquire The Grove housing estate in Melbourne for A$202.5 million under deferred payment terms. The estate, which covers 167 hectares, has about 850 lots sold and will yield 1,780 residential lots upon completion. Frasers Property will deliver on the existing masterplan vision, which includes over 2,600 homes and various community facilities. The acquisition is part of Frasers Property's major presence in Victoria, with over 7,500 land lots and homes currently under development.

site_title: China's Guangzhou city relaxes curbs on commercial property
summary: China's Guangzhou city has relaxed restrictions on commercial property, easing curbs that prevented individuals from buying commercial property. The move is part of efforts to revive flagging real estate sales, which have weighed on economic growth. Guangzhou's restrictions, introduced in March last year, were designed to cool the property market. The easing of these curbs is seen as a positive sign for the city's real estate market, which has been struggling.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars sideswiped by Federal Reserve, mixed domestic data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced significant losses due to the US Federal Reserve's less dovish stance on future rate hikes. The kiwi dollar fell 1.2% to US$0.6753, while the Aussie dollar found support from a solid jobs report. Data showed the New Zealand economy slowed by more than expected in the third quarter.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 21.25 points to 1,634.41 at 9am on Thursday, with volume reaching 35.1 million lots worth RM17.46 million. Losers outpaced gainers 125 to 38, marking a lower opening for the day.

site_title: The Place Holdings deputy CIO leaving due to family commitments
summary: The Place Holdings announced that its deputy CIO Teo Sheng Yue, 38, is resigning "due to family commitments and to pursue other interests and career opportunities" and will leave on Dec 31, 2018. This change in reason for his departure was made after an initial statement citing "personal reasons". The exact nature of his future plans is not disclosed.

site_title: Indonesia keeps rates unchanged
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 6.00% in its final policy review of 2018, as expected.
