The decision comes as the rupiah faces pressure due to US monetary tightening, the Sino-US trade war, and a widening current account deficit. The bank also maintained its other main rates, including the deposit facility and lending facility rates, at 5.25% and 6.75% respectively. The decision was made hours after the Federal Reserve raised US interest rates for the fourth time this year.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday, as expected, though it reasserted it will defend the exchange rate of the rupiah when needed.

site_title: China bike-sharing firm Ofo faces "immense" cash crunch, CEO vows to battle on
summary: Chinese bike-sharing firm Ofo is facing "immense" cash flow problems due to a costly battle with rival Mobike, which has eroded its ability to make payments to suppliers. The firm's CEO, Dai Wei, has considered dissolving the company and applying for bankruptcy, but vows to battle on. Millions of users have applied for a return of deposits paid to use the platform, adding to the firm's financial woes. Despite financial struggles, Dai remains determined to keep the company afloat, stating that he has thought of "countless times" about ways to resolve the issues.

site_title: Trump orders full withdrawal of US troops from Syria
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a full withdrawal of US troops from Syria, citing the defeat of ISIS. The move, finalized on Tuesday, will leave US-backed Kurdish fighters vulnerable to Turkish attack. The decision has been met with criticism from lawmakers, who warn it could embolden Ankara and put the Kurds at risk. The withdrawal has significant geopolitical implications, potentially allowing Russia and Iran to increase their influence in the region.

site_title: China keeps short-term borrowing rates steady after Fed hike
summary: China's central bank maintained its short-term borrowing rates steady at 2.55% and 2.7% on Thursday, defying the US Federal Reserve's decision to raise its benchmark rate earlier. The move follows the bank's announcement of a new lending tool, the Targeted Medium-Term Lending Facility, aimed at stimulating lending to smaller firms. The decision aims to support China's economic growth amid slowing GDP growth and rising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indonesia central bank intervenes to defend rupiah: official
summary: Bank Indonesia intervened in the rupiah market to defend the currency after it fell 0.4% to 14,490 per dollar following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and signal for two more increases in 2019. Head of monetary management Nanang Hendarsah said the decline was a "knee jerk reaction" and that the central bank is ready to stabilize the sovereign bond market in case yields jump.

site_title: Academic stalked in Hong Kong hits out at China
summary: An Australian academic, Kevin Carrico, was followed by a state-owned Hong Kong newspaper, Wen Wei Po, for a week during a visit. The paper accused him of stirring "pro-independence" sentiment and holding secret meetings, and published a front-page "expose". Carrico has vowed not to be bullied and suspects Beijing may be behind the intimidation. He was a lecturer in Chinese Studies at Macquarie University.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down in early trade on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, following US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.19% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.20%. The decline follows losses on Wall Street.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Fed rate signals
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, tracking falls on Wall Street due to the US Federal Reserve's signals on additional rate hikes next year. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.90%, and the Topix index fell 0.68%. The disappointing news from the Fed led to a decline in Asian markets, with Tokyo's benchmark index falling to 20,799.70.

site_title: Singapore Public Sector Outcomes Review finds productivity up with more successful jobseekers
summary: Singapore's Public Sector Outcomes Review found productivity increased to 4.5% in 2017, with real value-added per hour worked rising from 1.4% in 2013. Household incomes rose by 20% in real terms since 2013. Industry transformation maps were launched, with over 285,000 Singaporeans using SkillsFuture Credit, and 25,000 jobseekers securing jobs through the Adapt and Grow initiative. Doing business became easier with LicenceOne and Business Grants Portal, and over 1,000 SMEs adopted digital solutions under the SMEs Go Digital initiative.

images.alt_text: Productivity is up, more jobseekers are landing jobs, and businesses now enjoy more convenience, said the Ministry of Finance in the latest Singapore Public Sector Outcomes Review on Thursday. The stock-take of the public sector's work, released every two years, rounded up figures in areas such as the economy and welfare spending.

site_title: 5 ways Facebook shared your data
summary: Facebook shared user data with major tech companies, including Yahoo, Netflix, and Spotify, without disclosing the extent of the partnerships. The deals, part of Facebook's "instant personalisation" program, granted companies access to user names, profile photos, and public information. In some cases, Facebook also shared private messages and contact details. The partnerships helped Facebook draw new users and increase advertising revenue. Internal Facebook documents revealed that some companies, including Yahoo, continued to access user data years after the partnerships ended, with unclear uses for the information.

site_title: Shares in SoftBank mobile unit open more than 7% down
summary: Shares in SoftBank's mobile unit plummeted 7.6% on their second trading day, down 8.3% from the IPO price of 1,500 yen, making it 22% below the offering price. The company raised $23.5 billion in its initial public offering, the largest in Japan and the second-largest globally. Analysts attribute the underperformance to a weaker market, concerns over government intervention, and technical glitches. CEO Ken Miyauchi acknowledged the stock's poor start but expressed optimism about the company's future prospects.

site_title: New Zealand's economic growth slides to 5-year low, stokes central bank rate cut talk
summary: New Zealand's economic growth slid to a 5-year low in the third quarter, with a 0.3% quarterly growth rate, missing expectations of 0.6% and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's forecast of 0.7%. The manufacturing sector contracted sharply, contributing to the slowdown. The central bank may consider a rate cut in 2019, with ANZ forecasting a 25-basis-point cut in November and further cuts in 2020. The low growth and business confidence have raised concerns about the country's growth outlook and inflation.

site_title: US: Stocks fall further after Fed rate hike
summary: US stocks fell sharply on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve lifted interest rates, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.3% at 23,364.27. The Fed pledged a cautious approach to additional rate hikes next year, citing a "certain degree of uncertainty" in the global economy. The announcement followed a news conference with Fed Chair Jerome Powell, which contributed to the decline in stocks.

site_title: There's more than one reason traders may have disliked the Fed's message
summary: The Federal Reserve defied pressure to refrain from raising interest rates, sparking a risk-off response in markets. Stocks dropped and Treasuries rallied after the central bank trimmed its rate projections and maintained a generally upbeat view of the economy. Investors expressed concerns over the Fed's message, including its handling of market strains, insufficient downgrade of rate projections, and unwinding of quantitative easing. The Fed's decision was seen as a mixed signal, with Chairman Jerome Powell stating that the economy's broad changes are what matter, rather than individual market strains.

images.alt_text: Traders seemed to agree that they didn't like what they heard from the Federal Reserve at its final meeting for the year on Wednesday, but exactly what caused most offense in markets was less clear.

site_title: Federal judge deals setback to Trump's asylum restrictions
summary: A US federal judge declared President Donald Trump's asylum restrictions "unlawful" and "arbitrary," ruling that domestic and gang violence victims can seek asylum. The decision, made by Judge Emmet Sullivan, blocks a 2017 policy that denied asylum to victims of domestic violence or gang violence. The judge stated that the asylum statute provides redress for all misfortune, contradicting the Trump administration's claim that it does not. The ruling suspends deportation orders for 12 Central American asylum seekers and orders their return to the US.

site_title: Denmark urges no clemency as bankers in Danske scandal are detained
summary: Denmark's government is urging no clemency for bankers detained in the Danske Bank money laundering scandal, with Danish Business Minister Rasmus Jarlov stating it's essential to ensure economic crimes come at a cost. 10 former Danske Bank employees were detained in Estonia on suspicion of helping criminals from the former Soviet Union launder money. The bank is under investigation by the US Justice Department and faces significant fines. The case has led to a tightening of anti-money laundering laws in Denmark and Estonia, and prosecutors believe there are more suspects to be identified.

site_title: Argentina puts 65-million-year-old dinosaur replica on display
summary: Argentine paleontologists unveiled a 65-million-year-old plesiosaur replica in a Buenos Aires museum. The fossil, discovered in 2009 in Lake Argentino, is the most complete found in Argentina. The 9m-long plesiosaur had 1.3m-long fins and lived in seas that covered Patagonia before the Andes existed. After four tons of rocks were removed, the fossil was extracted and put on display, a result of years of work by paleontologists Fernando Novas and Marcelo Isasi.

images.alt_text: Argentine paleontologists unveiled on Wednesday the replica of a 65-million-year-old skeleton of a plesiosaur marine reptile found in a Patagonian lake in 2009.

site_title: Renault, Nissan executives sought other ways to pay Ghosn, documents show
summary: Renault and Nissan executives explored ways to pay Carlos Ghosn, the alliance chairman, undisclosed income through shared finances. Documents show that Renault executives were involved in discussions, with Mouna Sepehri and Thierry Bollore working on a 2010 plan to create a new source of compensation for Ghosn through the Renault-Nissan BV Dutch holding. The plan was abandoned, and a second attempt in 2017 to pay Ghosn undisclosed bonuses via a Dutch service company was also scrapped. Ghosn denies the allegations and remains in custody, with US representatives declining to comment.

site_title: Big Pharma returning to US price hikes in January after pause
summary: Nearly 30 pharmaceutical companies, including Novartis and Bayer, plan to raise US prices of their medicines in January, reversing a temporary halt due to pressure from the Trump administration. The hikes, which will affect over $20 billion in Novartis' revenue, are expected to pose a new challenge to President Trump's pledge to lower prescription medication costs. Despite a proposed slew of policies to lower prices, the measures are unlikely to provide short-term relief to consumers, and the US remains the world's most expensive pharmaceutical market.

images.alt_text: Novartis AG and Bayer AG are among nearly 30 drugmakers that have taken steps to raise the US prices of their medicines in January, ending a self-declared halt to increases made by a pharma industry under pressure from the Trump administration, according to documents seen by Reuters.

site_title: Brazil high court suspends order that could free Lula
summary: Brazil's chief judge Jose Antonio Dias Toffoli suspended an order by Justice Marco Aurelio Mello that could have freed former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva from prison. Mello's provisional order, which applied to non-violent prisoners with confirmed convictions, was stayed after public prosecutors objected. Lula is serving time for graft and is awaiting final appeals. The decision maintains Lula's imprisonment, at least temporarily.

site_title: Corruption-scarred Indonesian football grapples with new match-fix scandal
summary: Indonesian football is embroiled in a new match-fixing scandal, with a senior official caught trying to bribe a coach. A three-year ban and fine have been handed down to the official, but analysts say more needs to be done to tackle the endemic corruption and match-fixing in the sport. The Football Association of Indonesia (PSSI) has promised a crackdown, but critics argue that lip service is not enough, and perpetrators feel impunity due to lack of law enforcement.

site_title: QT Vascular, partners invest S$1.23m in erectile dysfunction startup's series B round
summary: QT Vascular has invested S$1.23 million in a series B funding round for erectile dysfunction medtech firm Sano V, receiving 83,135 Series B preferred shares. This investment brings QT Vascular's effective voting interest to 4.1% in Sano V. The company also has a call option to purchase all shares if Sano V achieves a successful six-month follow-up study, with a valuation equivalent to 2.5 times the company's current valuation. The funds will be used for Sano V's first-in-man study and working capital.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Christina Teo, founder, she1k
summary: Singapore-based entrepreneur Christina Teo, founder of the invitation-only network she1k, discusses her platform and angel investing on the Money FM podcast. Launched last month, she1k connects C-suite females in the corporate world, aiming to foster mentorship and support. Teo shares her vision for the network, which seeks to empower women in business and drive economic growth.

site_title: Oil rebounds from rout on signs of strong product demand
summary: Oil prices rose 1.74% on Wednesday, rebounding from a sharp decline, as strong demand for refined products was reported. US crude inventories fell 497,000 barrels, while distillate stockpiles decreased by 4.2 million barrels. Heating oil futures gained nearly 3% to $1.8054 a gallon, driven by profit-taking and short-covering. However, sentiment remains negative due to weakening demand and oversupply concerns.

site_title: Perennial-led JV wins tender for Yunnan development with 341.5m yuan bid
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' 45% owned joint venture, Perennial HC Holdings, won a tender to develop two plots of land next to the Kunming South High Speed Railway in Yunnan, China, for 341.5 million yuan (about S$67.6 million). The 40-year development will feature a general hospital, eldercare apartments, and commercial spaces, and is expected to have a total GFA of about 627,600 square meters. The investment will be funded via equity capital calls from shareholders, with no material impact on Perennial's current financial year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: QT Vascular, Perennial, Keppel Corp, BH Global
summary: QT Vascular agreed to invest S$1.23 million in research and development firm Sano V through a share subscription. Perennial Real Estate Holdings won a tender to develop two plots of land in China at S$67.6 million. Keppel Corporation secured a residential site in the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City for S$214 million. BH Global won two contracts totaling S$7.6 million. The Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) closed 0.4% higher on Thursday amid investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Smaller soy exporters on the rise amid global demand boom
summary: Global soybean exports have doubled within the last decade, driven by rapid demand growth worldwide. Brazil and the US remain the top exporters, but smaller countries such as Paraguay, Canada, and Argentina have also increased their export markets. As global demand continues to rise, smaller soy exporters are on the rise, providing alternative sources of soybeans. This shift is driven by the growing importance of soybean exports in the global market.

site_title: UK to prioritise high-skilled migrants post-Brexit, business groups sceptical
summary: The UK government has announced its post-Brexit immigration policy, prioritizing skilled workers and treating EU and non-EU citizens alike. The system will prioritize skilled workers, requiring sponsorship and a minimum salary threshold, but will not cap the number of skilled workers. A temporary worker scheme will allow EU nationals and workers from low-risk countries to come to Britain without a job offer for up to 12 months. Business groups have expressed skepticism, warning that the plans could be a "sucker punch" for many firms, and criticizing the government for not giving businesses enough time to adapt.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise cautiously before Federal Reserve meeting
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, lifting the Stoxx 600 index after four consecutive losses due to slowing economic growth concerns. Market participants expect the US Federal Reserve to signal a dovish stance towards monetary policy, potentially indicating fewer rate hikes for 2019. This speculation lifted gains in most sectors, including mining and healthcare.

site_title: What made 2018 stand out
summary: A 2018 recap by BT Weekend magazine highlights key trends and notable figures in food, design, arts, and more. The year saw dominant food trends and notable chefs, groundbreaking retail concepts, and award-winning design and architecture. Acclaimed photojournalist Thomas Hoepker shares insights into his career and the golden age of photojournalism. The article also provides last-minute Christmas shopping ideas, entertainment, and lifestyle suggestions.

site_title: China detains third Canadian as Huawei spat simmers
summary: China has detained a third Canadian national, following the arrests of former diplomat Michael Kovrig and business consultant Michael Spavor, amid a tense diplomatic spat with Ottawa over the arrest of Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emphasized that the latest detention does not seem linked to the previous cases, but suspicions are mounting that China is holding Canadians in retaliation. The US has branded the arrests "unacceptable," while China claims Canada and the US overstepped their authority.

site_title: US housing starts in Nov up but single-family segment still weak
summary: US housing starts rebounded in November, driven by a surge in multi-family projects, but single-family home construction fell to a 11/2-year low. This weakness in the single-family segment may indicate a slowdown in the overall economy. The report also showed housing starts fell in October instead of rising as previously reported, contradicting earlier data. The mixed signals from the housing market may flag a broader economic slowdown.

site_title: Federal Reserve raises lending rate; signals slower pace ahead
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate for the fourth time this year, signaling a slower pace of rate increases next year. The move, announced by Chairman Jerome Powell, aims to slow the economy amid inflation concerns. The decision, which sent Wall Street tumbling, contradicts President Donald Trump's claims that rate hikes would be "foolish." Powell stated that political considerations played no role in the decision, citing the central bank's commitment to monetary policy independence. The rate hike is expected to have a cooling effect on the economy.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve raised the benchmark interest rate on Wednesday, a move sure to anger President Donald Trump, but it also sent a clear signal it expects to slow its rate increases next year.

site_title: Keppel Corp secures 10.97-ha residential site in Tianjin Eco-City
summary: Keppel Corp's subsidiary Keppel Land China secured a 10.97-hectare residential site in Tianjin Eco-City for 1.07 billion yuan (S$214 million). The site will be developed into 572 units of residential homes, with a total development cost of over 1.90 billion yuan. The project is expected to be launched in Q4 2019, targeting upper-middle income homebuyers.

site_title: Shell takes 49 per cent stake in S'pore solar energy developer
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has taken a 49% stake in Singapore-based solar energy developer Cleantech Solar, with the possibility to increase its position after 2021. The undisclosed investment deal establishes Shell's platform in Southeast Asia and India. Cleantech Solar had received a US$50 million equity investment from climate-focused investment manager Climate Fund Managers in September 2018. The partnership aims to expand Shell's presence in the renewable energy sector.

site_title: French state railway to axe more than 2,000 jobs in 2019
summary: French state-owned railway SNCF plans to cut 2,190 jobs in 2019, despite hiring 170 people, as part of its 2019 budget plans. The move comes after France's parliament passed a law in June to overhaul the heavily indebted company. The decision follows three months of rolling strikes against the reform.

images.alt_text: France's SNCF state-owned railway is to cut 2,090 jobs next year under 2019 budget plans presented on Wednesday, union officials told Reuters.

site_title: Hong Kong's central bank raises base rate by 25 bps in lock-step with Fed
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, raised its base rate by 25 basis points to 2.75% in lock-step with the US Federal Reserve's 25 basis point increase. This move follows Hong Kong's currency peg to the US dollar. The decision aims to maintain monetary stability and keep inflation in check. The rate hike is in line with Hong Kong's formula, which is 50 basis points above the US Fed Funds Target or the average of the five-day moving averages of the overnight and one-month HIBORs.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) on Thursday raised the base rate charged through its overnight discount window by 25 basis points to 2.75 per cent.

site_title: Fragrance industry must adapt to come up smelling like roses
summary: The global perfume market is facing a decline in demand, with mid-priced ranges, including celebrity-branded products, falling out of favor among millennials. In contrast, luxury and personalized products are growing quickly. To reinvigorate sluggish demand, companies such as Revlon and Coty Inc. must adapt by making affordable scents smell more expensive. This shift towards customization, unique ingredients, and bespoke fragrances is driving growth in the luxury and artisanal segments, with companies like Estee Lauder and L'Oreal investing in personalized and natural products.

images.alt_text: Perfume bottles on display at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York. Companies offering customised fragrances and bottles may be able to sniff out the elusive scent of success.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Abterra Limited requested a copy of a report on offences submitted by its former auditors Mazars to the Ministry of Finance, citing "additional information" without specifying its relation. Figtree Holdings disposed of its 60%-owned Master Development (Jiangyin) project for $10 million in cash. Aspial Corporation's joint venture Bayfront Ventures received a Temporary Occupation Permit for its CityGate Project. Pine Capital Group signed an MOU to invest in a $3 billion Sri Lankan land project, dubbed Project Beacon.

site_title: Grab users face problem booking rides on mobile app Wednesday morning
summary: Grab users in Singapore experienced technical issues with their mobile app on Wednesday morning, resulting in a service interruption. The company posted on its Facebook page at 8:21am stating that users may experience problems with their app. The cause of the issue is not specified. Grab did not provide an estimated time for when the service would be restored.

site_title: Micron misses estimates as chip glut hurts prices
summary: Micron Technology Inc reported quarterly sales and profit forecasts below Wall Street estimates, citing a market glut of memory chips. The US chipmaker expects estimated revenue of $5.7b-$6.3b for its FYQ2, lower than analysts' $7.3b. A market glut, coupled with weakening consumer and business demand for phones and computers, is driving down chip prices. Industry output is expected to outstrip demand, further depressing prices.

site_title: Japan's November export growth slows to 0.1% on trade war concerns
summary: Japan's export growth slowed to 0.1% in November, missing economists' expectations, due to weakened shipments to the US and China amid a Sino-US trade dispute. The country's export volume fell 1.9% year-on-year, with exports to the US growing 1.6% and those to China rising 0.4%. The trade data highlights external risks for Japan's export-led economy, which may drag on growth over the coming quarters.

site_title: India's stocks are hostage to Fed rate cycle, says mutual fund giant
summary: India's stock market is heavily influenced by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cycle, according to Sankaran Naren, chief investment officer at ICICI Prudential Asset Management. Investors should expect constrained returns until the Fed makes a policy change. Naren's fund manages $60 billion and is one of the largest in India. The Fed's rate cycle is a significant factor, overshadowing domestic drivers such as oil prices and election uncertainty.

site_title: For Asean, sustainability is key to unlocking development potential
summary: Asean countries are emphasizing the importance of sustainable regional growth, with infrastructure development being a key factor. The region faces significant infrastructure gaps, with less than 60% of the population in some countries having access to electricity or piped water services. To address this, Asean is working with the World Bank Group and private sector stakeholders to identify and develop projects that can boost economic, social, and environmental connectivity. The private sector is also increasingly investing in infrastructure, particularly in Asia, with private infrastructure investments in East Asia and Pacific growing 27% in the first half of the year.

site_title: Reskilling students for a changing world
summary: The article discusses the need for education systems to adapt to the changing job market due to Industry 4.0 and digitalization. To realign education and meet labor needs, educators should focus on social awareness, self-discovery, and critical thinking. Early years' role play and vocabulary should promote a world of opportunities, and curriculums must be flexible to recognize the complexity of adult working life. Pedagogical changes are necessary to assess and address the validity of school external subject examinations and to incorporate real-life scenarios, challenges, and opportunities into the curriculum.

site_title: India court ruling on Fortis deal may be a blessing in disguise for IHH
summary: An Indian court has ruled to maintain the status quo on IHH Healthcare's buyout of Fortis Healthcare, putting on hold a mandatory open offer for up to 26% of the Indian hospital chain. This ruling may benefit IHH, as it already controls 31% of Fortis and has operational control over the company. IHH can now proceed with restructuring Fortis' debt and improving its operations, with potential savings of RM2.2 billion. Fortis' stock has also suffered, dipping 10% due to the uncertainty, but analysts remain optimistic about IHH's long-term prospects for the deal.

site_title: Companies cite trade war as main risk to six-month outlook: survey
summary: Asian companies remain cautiously optimistic about the fourth quarter due to uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade dispute. The Thomson Reuters/INSEAD Asian Business Sentiment Index edged up to 63, above a three-year low of 58. Companies await potential breakthroughs in the trade dispute, which poses a significant risk to their six-month outlook. The survey of 84 firms suggests that the ongoing trade tensions will continue to impact business confidence and investment decisions.

site_title: Passive investing may mask risks of looming financial crisis: poll
summary: A majority of institutional investors (2/3) expect a global financial crisis to occur in 1-5 years, citing passive investments as a major risk factor. They believe passive investments have artificially suppressed volatility, distorted relative stock prices, and increased systemic risk. Most investors (more than half) also think passive investing has altered the risk-return trade-offs, contributing to the looming crisis.

site_title: Effective date for Noble's restructuring pushed back to Dec 20
summary: Noble Group's effective date for restructuring has been pushed back to December 20, from the previously slated December 19. A Bermuda court approved an officer to carry out the plan using an insolvency process, allowing Noble to avoid liquidation. The group will emerge from restructuring as soon as this week after over a year of negotiations over its $3.5 billion debt pile. Noble's market value has been significantly pared down due to accounting questions and will not be relisted as a new entity on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: China, US discuss trade ahead of meeting in January
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said China and the US are focusing on reaching a trade agreement by a March 1 deadline, as vice-ministerial level talks were held to discuss the ongoing trade dispute. The two sides plan to meet in January to negotiate a broader truce, with the goal of documenting an agreement. Mnuchin also sought to downplay concerns about President Trump's willingness to intervene on Huawei's behalf, stating that any deal would be "enforceable and verifiable." The administration is prioritizing reducing the trade deficit with China and securing structural changes in the Chinese economy.

site_title: These celebrities actually want to host the Oscars
summary: Several celebrities have expressed interest in hosting the 91st Oscars ceremony, following Kevin Hart's withdrawal due to criticism over homophobic Twitter posts. Suggested hosts include Nick Kroll and John Mulaney, Whoopi Goldberg, Ken Jeong, Busy Philipps, Rob Lowe, Patton Oswalt, Bruce Campbell, Rhea Butcher, Megan Amram, Scott Patterson, Tom Green, and others. While some have jokingly expressed interest, others have made serious pitches, with Goldberg and Jeong highlighting the opportunity for representation and diversity. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has yet to officially offer a replacement host.

site_title: Struggling in Europe and US, western toy stores find new life in China
summary: Toys "R" Us, which filed for bankruptcy in the US, is experiencing a resurgence in China, where it has a strong presence. The company's Asian partner, Fung Retailing Ltd, has secured control of its stores in China, Japan, and South-east Asia. Lego Group and FAO Schwarz are also expanding their operations in China, targeting the country's growing toy market. The Chinese government's shift in policies, including a relaxation of the one-child policy, is seen as a factor in the revival of Western toy stores, as parents become more willing to spend on brands perceived as safer.

images.alt_text: A customer resting against a display inside a Toys "R" Us Asia store in Shanghai, China. Toys "R" Us Asia plans to add as many as 50 new stores next year in China.

site_title: Thailand raises key rate after 7 years, no more hikes seen soon
summary: Thailand's central bank raised its key policy rate for the first time in over seven years, increasing the one-day repurchase rate to 1.75% by 25 basis points. The decision aims to curb financial stability risks and build policy space, despite a slowdown in external demand and concerns over global growth. The bank cut its 2018 growth forecast to 4.2% and lowered its 2019 GDP growth estimate to 4.0%. Analysts expect no further hikes in 2019, citing Thailand's benign inflation and hefty current account surplus.

site_title: Ying Li reveals take-up rates for Beijing project built amid buying curbs
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate reported take-up rates for its Beijing project, New Everbright Centre, with Phase 1 construction reaching 69.8% and Phase 2 construction at 25%. The company attributed a 27.2 million yuan increase in interest expense to underlying loans totaling 1.45 billion yuan. Ying Li also disclosed plans to repay 23.7% of the loans using existing cash, rental income, and sales proceeds from property sales.

site_title: European mining stocks: five themes for 2019
summary: European mining stocks experienced a 25% decline from their June peak in 2018 due to concerns over the US-China trade war and China's economic growth. These worries are expected to persist in 2019. Key factors include the impact of US tariffs on Chinese goods, China's economic slowdown, and the rise of solar stocks as Beijing moves to calm price wars. The sector's performance is also influenced by global oil demand and supply, with OPEC trimming oil demand for the next four years.

site_title: Citigroup facing US$180 million loss on loan to Asia fund
summary: Citigroup is facing potential losses of up to $180 million on loans to an Asian hedge fund whose foreign-exchange bets went awry. The hedge fund, managed by a unit of GF Holdings, has sparked top-level meetings and a business shakeup at Citigroup. The situation is fluid, and losses may be smaller depending on how the trades are unwound. As a result, Citigroup is reorganizing its prime brokerage business, placing it under the oversight of its prime finance and securities services unit, and making changes to its leadership.

site_title: COE prices rise for small cars, motorcycles and Open category
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices rose for small cars, motorcycles, and the Open category in the latest bidding round, ending on Wednesday. COE prices for cars up to 1,600cc rose to S$25,501, motorcycles to S$3,789, and the Open category to S$31,809. Premiums for goods vehicles and buses dropped to S$27,001. Dealers attributed the increases to reduced deregistration numbers and anticipation of the Singapore Motorshow in December. COE prices for cars above 1,600cc remained unchanged at S$31,001.

site_title: Boeing raises projection for aircraft orders from India
summary: Boeing has raised its projection for aircraft orders from India to a record high of up to 2,300 new planes worth $320 billion over the next 20 years. This represents a 9.5% increase from its previous estimate of 2,100 jets until 2036. India's growing aviation market, driven by domestic passenger traffic growth of 20% in recent years, is expected to make it the third largest commercial aviation market by the early 2020s. Boeing predicts that single-aisle planes, such as the 737 MAX, will account for 84% of global deliveries to India from 2018-2037.

site_title: HK broker Futu files confidentially for New York IPO of up to US$500m: sources
summary: Futu Securities International, a Hong Kong-based online brokerage firm backed by Tencent Holdings, has filed confidentially for a US initial public offering (IPO) of up to US$500 million, targeting a valuation of US$2.5 billion. The company plans to debut in New York in early 2019 and has hired Goldman Sachs and UBS to work on the US float. Futu's decision to list in the US is due to a faster listing pace and better comparable peers, allowing for confidential filings and easier access to US-based new investors.

site_title: SoftBank IPO's weak debut still a win for Masayoshi Son
summary: SoftBank Corp, the Japanese telecommunications business of billionaire Masayoshi Son, raised $32.3 billion in its IPO, but its stock price plummeted 14.5% to 1,282 yen, marking the biggest decline for a major IPO since 2014. Despite concerns over an impending price war, investors were attracted by the high yield, and 90% of those who bought at the offered price were individuals. The IPO was a victory for Son, who will use the funds to invest in new enterprises, including the $100 billion Vision fund.

images.alt_text: By getting individuals to buy into the offering with an attractive yield, Mr Son was able to raise funds even though future profitability remains a big question.

site_title: World stocks claw out of the doldrums after plunge of markets
summary: Global equity and crude oil markets made a tentative recovery after three days of losses, with oil prices falling almost 10% since last Thursday. World stocks plunged to 19-month lows, sparking speculation the US Federal Reserve might be done with tightening monetary policy. Investors sought safety in bonds amid mounting pessimism over world growth, but Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Best December for bonds in 7 years highlights growth risks for 2019
summary: Developed-market bonds have seen their best December performance in seven years, with a 1.16% gain, amid a global economic slowdown. The MSCI World Index of developed markets has declined 6.5% in the same period, setting a record low for the month. This sell-off in stocks and buying of bonds may signal a major decline in the global economy next year, according to investment experts. The US 10-year yield has dropped below 2.80%, while Japan's 10-year yields have fallen to 0.01%, poised to decline to zero.

site_title: With sales all year round, there'll be no Christmas cheer for UK fashion firms
summary: UK fashion retailers, including Primark and Superdry, are warning of weak sales in the run-up to Christmas due to unprecedented discounting and shopper fatigue. Online players like ASOS have also issued profit warnings, sparking concerns about weakening consumer strength globally. Retailers are expanding traditional summer and new year sales to year-round promotions to stay competitive, but this trend may be a taste of the future, with investors worried about the impact on profit margins.

site_title: Super Saturday, not Black Friday, is the biggest spending day of the year
summary: US shoppers are expected to spend an estimated $26 billion on December 22, surpassing the $24 billion spent on Black Friday, according to industry researcher Craig Johnson. This marks the final Saturday before Christmas as the biggest shopping day of the year, as retailers began their Black Friday sales on Thanksgiving Day or earlier. The shift in spending habits is attributed to the earlier start of Black Friday sales, making Super Saturday the new title for the biggest spending day of the year.

site_title: Medtech firm Biolidics' shares slump in Catalist debut
summary: Biolidics, a Singaporean medtech firm, saw its shares slump 16% on its Catalist debut, closing at S$0.235. The stock opened at S$0.265 and traded 4.88 million shares. Biolidics plans to use IPO funds to expand clinical services and advance pipeline products. The company derives revenue from its ClearCell FX1 System, which separates cancer cells from blood. CEO Ivan Lew sees great potential for growth in the cancer diagnostics industry.

site_title: Dream of augmented humans endures, despite sceptics
summary: Transhumanism, the concept of scientifically assisted human evolution, continues to be a topic of debate. Proponents believe that advancements in technology, such as brain implants and genetic modification, will lead to a future where humans can live longer and be enhanced beyond current limitations. However, skeptics argue that some problems are scientifically impossible to solve, and the movement may hit a brick wall. Despite this, the field of transhumanism is expected to continue, driven by the increasing investment in AI and digital innovation.

site_title: China's rise as a global player exposes its 'soft power deficit'
summary: China's 40-year economic reforms, spearheaded by Deng Xiaoping, have led to its rise as a global power, with a record-breaking GDP growth rate of 9.5% and lifting over 700 million people out of poverty. However, this success has also exposed a "soft power deficit," where Beijing's international attractiveness and cultural influence are seen as limited. A Pew Global Research survey found that only three of 25 countries prefer a world order with China as the leading power, and many countries have a net negative opinion about China. To address this deficit, China must enhance its international public diplomacy and demonstrate its commitment to being a responsible, peaceful global stakeholder.

site_title: Huan Hsin must delist, provide exit offer; company to appeal SGX order
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ordered electronics contract manufacturer Huan Hsin Holdings to delist due to failure to meet mainboard requirements on profitability and market capitalization. The stock will trade until January 18, 2019, and be suspended from January 21 until a mandatory exit offer is completed.

site_title: Newer strata malls fail to deliver
summary: Newer strata malls in Singapore have failed to deliver expected returns, with lower-than-expected rents, footfall, and occupancy, disappointing investors. Despite their initial promise, these malls have not yet achieved the expected financial performance, with one investor, MR Tan Meng Khiang, expressing disappointment with his 187 sq ft strata retail unit at One Dusun Residences. The disappointing performance of these malls highlights the challenges faced by the Singapore retail sector.

site_title: UK unveils proposals for immigration clampdown after Brexit
summary: The UK has unveiled proposals for an EU immigration crackdown after Brexit, introducing visas for arriving EU nationals and a new system based on skills, not nationality. Home Secretary Sajid Javid aims to bring net migration down to sustainable levels, putting EU and non-EU citizens on the same footing. The proposals, which include a potential £30,000 salary threshold, are aimed at winning over Brexit hardliners but are expected to cause anger in parts of the country that have benefited from EU immigration.

site_title: Chinese city's property policy reversal a test of central govt resolve
summary: China's city of Heze has reversed a rule to curb real estate flipping, boosting property developer shares and sparking speculation of further policy reversals. The reversal comes as China's economy slows, with new home price growth slowing in smaller cities like Heze. The move tests the central government's resolve in controlling the sector, which had vowed to stop price growth earlier this year. Analysts expect a "gradually better policy environment" in the future, while the decision may lead to more cities following suit.

site_title: Builders bruised by Dubai's real estate market woes
summary: Dubai's real estate market is experiencing a downturn, forcing construction and engineering firms to cut jobs and halt expansion plans. The residential sector is particularly affected, with many towers standing half-empty and some construction sites dormant. The oversupply of properties has led to a decline in prices, which have fallen steadily since 2014. This downturn raises risks for the wider economy, highlighting the challenges faced by the city's builders and the need for a market adjustment.

site_title: TV sitcom star, director Penny Marshall dead at 76
summary: Penny Marshall, a TV sitcom star and director of films like "Big" and "A League of Their Own," died at 76 due to complications from diabetes. Marshall was the first woman to direct a film grossing over $100 million and directed several notable films, including "Awakenings" and "A League of Their Own," which starred Tom Hanks. She was known for her instinctive directing style and treating filmmaking as a team effort. Marshall's legacy includes her seven seasons on the hit TV series "Laverne & Shirley" and her contributions to the film industry.

site_title: Before and after May: Politics of the ringgit
summary: The ringgit's value has fluctuated significantly since May, with a sharp decline in its value against the US dollar. The Malaysian currency fell to a record low in May due to a decline in oil prices and a widening trade deficit. However, the ringgit has since recovered, partly due to a surge in oil prices. The Malaysian government has taken steps to stabilize the currency, including implementing a new monetary policy. The ringgit's value is expected to continue to be influenced by global economic trends and trade policies.

site_title: JGB futures post biggest jump since BOJ policy to control yield curve
summary: Japanese government bond (JGB) prices ended in a mixed trading session, with benchmark 10-year JGB futures posting the biggest daily range since the Bank of Japan's yield curve control policy. Futures rose 0.07 point to 152.39, the highest since July 2016, amid growing concerns over the global economy. The Bank of Japan kept its buying in five- to 10-year bonds steady, despite speculation of a potential reduction. Trading was volatile due to thin conditions near the year-end, with the yield on 10-year JGBs dropping to 0.010% and then rising again.

site_title: Corbyn rapped for allegedly muttering 'stupid woman' at May
summary: British opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn faced calls to apologize after being accused of muttering "stupid woman" at Prime Minister Theresa May during a heated exchange over Brexit. Corbyn's spokesman denied he used the phrase, claiming he said "stupid people." The incident sparked uproar among Conservative MPs, with some female politicians and lawmakers weighing in, and Commons Speaker John Bercow saying Corbyn would have to apologize if true.

site_title: EU and Italy reach deal on disputed 2019 budget: commissioner
summary: The European Union and Italy reached a deal on Italy's 2019 budget, avoiding a major fine for the country. The revised spending plans fell within EU rules, and Italy agreed to back down on its universal basic income and pension increase measures. In return, the EU offered flexibility in calculating the budget due to exceptional circumstances, including infrastructure modernization. The compromise avoids an excessive deficit procedure, which could have resulted in a fine of up to 0.2% of Italy's GDP.

site_title: GIC buys two distribution centres in South Korea for US$570m
summary: GIC has acquired two distribution centers in South Korea's Greater Seoul area for US$570 million. The 35 km from Seoul, the centers, Blocks A and B of Hwaseong Dongtan Logistics Complex, are newly completed and fully leased by quality tenants with long-term leases. The acquisition aligns with GIC's strategy to own assets with long-term earning potential at reasonable prices and with due regard to risk.

images.alt_text: Blocks A and B are part of the Hwaseong Dongtan Logistics Complex, which is located 35 km from Seoul, and with good access to the Seoul-Busan Expressway, the No. 1 artery expressway in South Korea.

site_title: Musk bores tunnel to revolutionise city driving
summary: Elon Musk unveiled a 1.8km tunnel created by his Boring Company for $10 million, part of a vision to revolutionize city traffic by zipping cars at speeds up to 241km/h below congested streets. The tunnel uses specially designed equipment to drill wide enough for cars to fit on tracks, with the goal of having over 4,000 cars pass through per hour. Musk aims to slash tunnel drilling time and cost, using a prototype machine that can drill 15 times faster than conventional methods. The network, expandable and accessible to self-driving electric vehicles, could alleviate traffic congestion.

images.alt_text: A modified Tesla Model X driving into the entrance of the Boring Co's test tunnel in Hawthorne, California, on Tuesday.

site_title: With eye on China, Germany tightens foreign investment rules
summary: Germany has agreed to new rules to screen and block non-European purchases of stakes in German firms, aiming to prevent unwanted takeovers by Chinese investors in strategic areas. The move follows concerns that China's state-backed companies are gaining access to key European technologies. The decision by Chancellor Angela Merkel's Cabinet is a response to China shielding its own companies. The new rules are seen as a bid to maintain control over strategic sectors in Germany's economy.

site_title: Go beyond legislation to encourage board gender diversity
summary: Singapore's revised Code of Corporate Governance, effective January 1, 2019, aims to encourage gender diversity on company boards by requiring a board diversity policy and reporting progress. Despite an increase in female board seats from 10.3% to 11.2% in 2018, Singapore lags behind countries like Norway and France in female board representation. Stakeholders cite concerns about tokenism and meritocracy, while cultural norms limit women's ability to balance work and family responsibilities, hindering progress. Policymakers must move beyond legislation to address these issues and change normative thinking to achieve meaningful change.

site_title: Britain in Brexit limbo with 100 days to go
summary: Britain is stuck in Brexit limbo with just 100 days to go until the UK's departure from the EU. Despite a crucial vote on Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal being delayed to next month, the country remains without a divorce deal in place. This leaves uncertainty over what happens next, with total confusion among MPs and the public. The delay comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, adding to the fresh blow to Labour leader Keir Starmer's campaign.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment gets new controlling shareholder
summary: China Jinjiang Environment's controlling shareholder, Dou Zhenggang, has gifted 4 million ordinary shares to his daughter Jennifer Wei, representing 50% of China Green Energy Limited's total shares. This transaction makes Jennifer Wei a controlling shareholder of China Jinjiang Environment, holding 16.4% of shares through China Green Energy. Dou Zhenggang's firm, China Green Energy, owns 32.9% of China Jinjiang Environment, solidifying Jennifer Wei's influence in the company.

site_title: Bristol-Myers gets US$1.6b offer for French consumer health unit
summary: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co received a US$1.6 billion offer from Japanese firm Taisho Pharmaceutical Holdings Co Ltd to buy its French consumer health unit UPSA. The deal is estimated to be approximately US$0.04 dilutive to 2019 earnings. Bristol-Myers has not yet commented on the offer.

images.alt_text: UPSA's portfolio covers a wide range of therapeutic areas such as pain, cough and cold, vitamins and supplements.

site_title: Asia markets trade mixed; oil stocks under focus
summary: Asian markets traded mixed on Wednesday, with Singapore stocks gaining 0.4% and Hong Kong trading 0.2% higher, while Shanghai fell 1.05%. The US-China trade talks are set to resume in January, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin saying face-to-face meetings are unlikely. Geopolitical risk fatigue is affecting market sentiment, with strategist Dave Lafferty noting that events such as tweets, tariffs, and government shutdowns are losing their shock value. Oil stocks were under pressure due to steep falls in crude prices, which fell below the US$50 per barrel support level.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, closing at 3,058.65, with 177 gainers and 166 losers. Heavy trading in Singtel and Golden Agri-Resources led the gains, while OCBC Bank fell 0.09%. Financials, including UOB and DBS, edged higher. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Kimly, a Catalist-listed coffee shop operator, remains open to acquisitions and strategic alliances despite ongoing investigations. The company plans to develop its own brand of coffees and tea, expand to 70 coffee shops and food courts in Singapore by 2019, and consider increasing its dividend payout ratio. However, the investigation may limit potential upside, and the stock's performance may be negatively impacted.

site_title: Pennsylvania lets Uber self-driving cars back on the roads
summary: US authorities in Pennsylvania have authorized Uber to resume testing self-driving cars in Pittsburgh after a fatal crash in Arizona prompted a pause. Uber stated it received the green light, but has yet to put the cars back on the road. The ride-sharing giant has a lab devoted to the technology in Pittsburgh.

site_title: HK govt to sell cheap homes in world's least affordable city
summary: Hong Kong's government will sell 450 cheap starter homes, priced 38% below market levels, to help people get on the property ladder in the world's least affordable housing market. Eligible applicants, who earn no more than HK$37,000/month, can apply starting January. The initiative aims to accommodate a small portion of those wanting to own a home, following previous programs that saw over 260,000 applications for 4,431 flats. Despite a dip in home prices, Hong Kong's market remains unaffordable, with prices 50% higher than five years ago.

site_title: European retail storm casts a shadow over US holiday shopping
summary: A slowdown in global consumer confidence threatens the US holiday shopping season, despite a strong start. European retailers are reporting weaker sales, with some warning of profit declines, due to economic uncertainty and protests. However, US consumers are expected to continue spending, with a potential boost from lower gas prices. Retailers are seeing increased traffic at brick-and-mortar locations, particularly in the apparel sector, where athleisure clothing is driving sales growth.

images.alt_text: Super Saturday, the last before Christmas and the biggest shopping day of the US holiday season, is likely to bring in more than US$26 billion in revenue, retail consultancy Customer Growth Partners (CGP) said, up from US$24.5 billion a year ago.

site_title: Renault plans to name new director to Nissan board as tension between the two rises
summary: Renault plans to appoint a new director to Nissan's board amid rising tensions between the two companies. The move comes after Carlos Ghosn's jailing for financial crimes, with Renault seeking to exercise its rights as a shareholder to replace him. Nissan has agreed to the appointment, but Renault's head of the agency holding the French government's stake, Martin Vial, warns of a rift between the companies over governance and power. Renault aims to safeguard its influence within the car-making alliance, which it sees as crucial for its long-term interests.

site_title: US existing home sales unexpectedly rise in November
summary: US existing home sales rose 1.9% in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.32 million units, the largest annual decline in 7-1/2 years. Sales have now increased for two straight months, despite economists' forecasts of a decline. The housing market is constrained by higher mortgage rates, land and labor shortages, and tight inventory, leading to lower sales of 7.0% from last year.

site_title: BRI needs to embrace international arbitration
summary: The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) aims to transform economies with hard physical infrastructure, but its success depends on establishing an effective cross-border dispute resolution system. With 103 countries and 118 cooperation agreements signed, the initiative requires a trusted and efficient legal framework to implement and complete projects on time and without disputes. An effective dispute resolution system is critical to the success of regional economic initiatives like BRI, which connects Asia, Europe, and the Middle East.

site_title: 'I have a future without Manchester United,' says Mourinho
summary: Jose Mourinho stated he has a future without Manchester United, the first time speaking since being sacked by the club. The 20-time champion was dismissed after a 3-1 loss at Anfield, leaving them 19 points behind league leaders Liverpool. Mourinho refused to discuss his departure, saying "It's over" and that he will live his normal life until he returns to football. Former United striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was announced as Mourinho's temporary replacement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.20% to 25,865.39. In contrast, Shanghai's benchmark composite index fell 1.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 1.38%. Investors remain cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting.

site_title: COE prices rise for small cars, motorcycles and Open category
summary: COE prices in Singapore rose for three categories: small cars, motorcycles, and Open vehicles. Small car COE prices increased to $25,501, while motorcycle premiums rose to $3,789. Open vehicle COE prices climbed to $31,809, driven by dealers stocking up for the upcoming Singapore Motorshow. The price drops for cars above 1,600cc and goods vehicles were attributed to reduced deregistration numbers.

site_title: US and China spar at WTO policy forum
summary: The US and China engaged in a heated exchange at the World Trade Organization, with the US accusing China of violating trade rules and expecting impunity. The US Trade Policy Review criticized China's practices, including forcing technology transfer and dumping products on US markets. China responded by accusing the US of renouncing its leadership role in the world economy. The WTO's director described the debate as "lively," highlighting the tensions between the two global superpowers. The exchange marked a continuation of the US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Foreign investment in Saudi Arabia more than doubled in 2018: minister
summary: Foreign investment in Saudi Arabia more than doubled to 13 billion riyals ($4.74 billion) in 2018, despite global concerns following Jamal Khashoggi's murder in October. The economy and planning minister, Mohammed al-Tuwaijri, attributed the increase to the kingdom's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy. The government aims to generate 35-40 billion riyals in non-oil revenues by 2020 and create 12,000 jobs through privatisation. Unemployment is expected to decline starting in 2019, with the number of job openings exceeding 300,000-400,000 annually.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 20.35 points to 1,655.66 on Wednesday, driven by a gain of 502 to 329 gainers to losers. The stock market closed with 1.9 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion.

site_title: EU electricity reform calls end to coal subsidies
summary: The European Union agreed to reform its electricity market, including ending coal subsidies by 2025. The reform aims to create a more transparent and competitive market, with stricter limits on subsidies for powerplants emitting high levels of CO2. The move is part of the EU's efforts to accelerate the clean energy transition and reduce its reliance on coal. The reform is expected to lead to lower electricity prices, greater consumer choice, and stronger incentives for new technology. The European Parliament and member states must still formally approve the deal.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker in 1MDB saga barred for life from deal-making in Singapore
summary: Tim Leissner, a former Goldman Sachs director, has been barred for life from deal-making in Singapore due to his involvement in the 1MDB scandal. Leissner, who pleaded guilty to money laundering and violating the US Foreign Corrupt Practice Act, admitted to obtaining and retaining business from 1MDB through bribes and kickbacks. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) raised his lifetime prohibition order from 10 years, citing new evidence from US DOJ charges. Leissner is also barred from acting as a director or substantial shareholder of a capital markets services licensee in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Leissner has admitted embezzling funds from 1MDB for himself and others and laundering the loot.

site_title: Italy backs down in EU budget truce
summary: Italy and the European Union reached a truce over Rome's disputed 2019 budget, with Italy agreeing to back down on its universal basic income and pension reform measures. In exchange, Brussels offered flexibility in calculating the budget and allowed for infrastructure modernization in light of exceptional circumstances. The compromise avoids opening the excessive deficit procedure, which could have resulted in major fines for Italy. The agreement marks a victory for dialogue over confrontation and brings an end to a bitter row that could have alarmed markets and sparked a debt crisis.

site_title: Pine Capital signs MOU to develop land in Sri Lanka
summary: Pine Capital Group has signed a memorandum of understanding with Sri Lanka's Provincial Council of the Eastern Province to develop a US$3 billion land project called Project Beacon, featuring luxury resorts, hotels, and a convention center. The integrated hospitality and lifestyle township aims to cater to fashion and lifestyle events. The project's development is expected to take place in the Eastern Province of Sri Lanka.

site_title: BH Global secures 2 contracts worth S$7.6m
summary: BH Global Corporation secured two contracts worth S$7.6 million, including one for cable supply to a FPSO project and another for LED lighting systems to an overseas customer. The contracts are expected to be delivered in 2019, building on the company's strength in LED lighting systems. BH Global's new LED factory in Kunshan, China, is set to commence production in 2019.

site_title: Singapore hotels get a 'Crazy Rich Asians' boost
summary: Singapore's hotel industry experienced a significant boost in 2018, with average occupancy rates reaching 87% and revenue per available room rising 4% to S$190.40. The success of "Crazy Rich Asians" and high-profile events, such as the Trump-Kim summit and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit, contributed to the growth. Analysts predict the industry will remain strong in 2019, despite potential headwinds from global economic growth and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Marina Bay Sands was among local landmarks showcased in the film Crazy Rich Asians.

site_title: Don't leave SRS funds idle, and plan to maximise retirement funds
summary: The Singapore government has increased the investment cap for Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) funds to S$200,000, starting February 1, 2019. This move aims to encourage individuals to invest their SRS funds in Singapore Savings Bonds (SSB), which offer higher returns than traditional savings accounts. The 10-year SSB pays an average 2.45% interest, compared to 1.7-1.9% for fixed deposits. The SRS complements the Central Provident Fund (CPF) and offers tax benefits, but comes with restrictions, including penalties for premature withdrawals.

site_title: USDA confirms second wave of US soy sales to China since trade detente
summary: The US Department of Agriculture confirmed a second wave of US soybean sales to China, totaling 1.199 million tonnes, following a 90-day trade truce between US President Donald Trump and China's President Xi Jinping. This brings total US soybean sales to China since the truce to 3 million tonnes, falling short of expectations. Despite a 25% tariff imposed by China on US soybeans, the sales indicate easing trade tensions and a potential deal. However, analysts say more sales are needed to meet expectations and stabilize the soybean market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A former Goldman Sachs director, Tim Leissner, has been barred for life from securities deal-making in Singapore due to his involvement in the 1MDB scandal. COE prices rose for small cars, motorcycles, and the Open category in Singapore. Institutional investors predict a global financial crisis within the next five years. Deutsche Bank is experiencing an exodus of almost 50 investment bankers in Asia since May. The stock of Huan Hsin received a delisting notice and will continue to trade until January 18, 2019.

site_title: Keppel Corp secures residential site in Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City
summary: Keppel Corp's subsidiary Keppel Land China secures a 10.97-hectare residential site in the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City for 1.07 billion yuan (S$214 million). The project will feature 392 terrace houses and 180 low-rise apartments, targeting upper-middle income homebuyers, with a total development cost exceeding 1.90 billion yuan. The site is near amenities and the Z4 rail line, enhancing connectivity to other parts of Tianjin. The project is expected to be launched in Q4 2019.

site_title: UBS Wealth has hedge fund-like playbook to combat market mayhem
summary: UBS Wealth, the world's largest private bank, is adopting a hedge fund-like playbook to combat market volatility. The bank is using exotic options trades to profit from price distortions in various markets, including the US healthcare sector, yield curve, and currency moves. This strategy involves betting on relative value trades, linking stock performance to bond landscape shifts and currency movements. The move aims to navigate a multi-speed world with tightening liquidity and uneven market performance.

images.alt_text: As Wall Street frets another annus horribilis, UBS Global Wealth is embracing a playbook beloved by hedge funds - a slew of options trades that bet, for example, on the continued outperformance of US healthcare stocks versus industrials when tensions in commerce sink equities.

site_title: UK unveils tougher Brexit immigration policy, riling business
summary: The UK has unveiled a new immigration policy to end freedom of movement from the European Union, prioritizing skilled workers regardless of nationality. The plan aims to reduce net migration to "sustainable levels," with a proposed salary threshold of £30,000. The government has faced criticism from businesses, with the Confederation of British Industry calling the rules a "sucker punch" for companies. The policy will be subject to a 12-month public consultation, and the government has denied plans to cap the number of skilled migrants.

site_title: Vietnam - The coming of age of a vibrant Tiger Cub Economy
summary: Vietnam is expected to achieve a 6.8% GDP growth in 2018, driven by an open economy, foreign direct investment, and a youthful population. The country is forecast to be the fastest-growing economy among the "Tiger Cub Economies" in the next five years. Vietnam's growth is attributed to a successful export-oriented strategy, similar to China and Asian Tiger economies. The government has set a GDP growth target of 6.6-6.8% for 2019, which is considered achievable despite the uncertain global environment.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat; Fed in focus
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday ahead of a Federal Reserve announcement, with the Dow Jones rising 17.69 points and the S&P 500 opening higher by 0.89 points. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 6.32 points. Investors are awaiting the Fed's signal on rate hikes, amid turmoil in financial markets and recession fears.

site_title: Daimler, BMW win green light for car-sharing merger
summary: Daimler and BMW have received final US regulatory approval to merge their car-sharing services Car2Go and DriveNow, creating a European giant to challenge Uber. The joint venture, owned equally by the two German carmakers, will combine 20,000 cars in 30 cities worldwide, serving over 4 million customers. The deal, announced in March, will also integrate other mobility services like electric car charging points, taxi-hailing apps, and parking space locators. The companies aim to close the transaction by January 31, 2019.

images.alt_text: German carmakers Daimler and BMW said Wednesday they had won final approval to merge their car-sharing services Car2Go and DriveNow, paving the way for the creation of a European giant to challenge the likes of Uber.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise ahead of Fed decision; shrug off global uncertainties
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and won rose ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with investors shrugging off global uncertainties. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates, but may cut future hikes and signal an earlier end to monetary tightening. Shares of Hyundai Motor, LG Chem, and Korean Air Lines gained, while hydrogen-powered car parts companies surged after the government announced a plan to expand the use of hydrogen fuel-cell cars. The won was quoted at 1,123.5 per dollar, 0.54% firmer than its previous close.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down as investors eye Fed
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on December 19, 2018, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.60% to 20,987.92, while the Topix index dropped 0.41% to 1,556.15. The Japanese mobile unit of SoftBank Group made its debut, but its performance was not mentioned. The decline was attributed to investor anticipation of the Fed's meeting.

site_title: Oil collapse hits Australian shares, but NZ up; Fed in focus
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% due to plummeting oil prices, which sank 5% on Tuesday, affecting energy stocks like Origin Energy and Santos Ltd. The Federal Reserve's interest rate meeting is expected to reset US monetary policy, with investors cautious about a possible pause in rate hikes. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.85% despite the global downturn. The Fed is expected to raise rates, but market pricing suggests a slowing or pause in the US rate-hike cycle.

site_title: Fed poised to signal pause in US rate hikes
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise the benchmark lending rate to 2.5% from 2.25% on Wednesday, accompanied by a signal that it will hold off on future increases. Despite President Donald Trump's criticism, analysts and investors are looking for confirmation that the central bank will stand on the sidelines for a time, citing signs that the US economy may have peaked. The Fed's quarterly forecasts are also expected to show only one or two rate hikes next year, down from three previously expected.

site_title: Saudi Arabia plans to privatise seven firms in 1Q
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to privatize seven state-owned companies in the first quarter of 2019 as part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to overhaul the economy and prepare for a post-oil era. The move is part of a larger plan to privatize 19 state enterprises next year. Economy and Planning Minister Mohammed Al Tuwaijri identified five sectors for privatization. This initiative aims to diversify the economy and reduce dependence on oil exports.

site_title: Firms in South-east Asia most positive about outlook: Thomson Reuters/INSEAD
summary: Firms in the Philippines, Thailand, and Malaysia are the most optimistic about the coming six months, with a business sentiment index of 63, above the previous quarter's three-year low of 58. This suggests increasing concerns about growth, but INSEAD professor Antonio Fatas notes that a crisis wouldn't be a large surprise. The overall sentiment index remains subdued, indicating uncertainty about the future.

site_title: Malaysia to charge ex-Goldman's Ng after extradition delay: source
summary: Malaysian prosecutors will charge former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng on Wednesday for his involvement in 1MDB transactions. The extradition process was delayed earlier in the day, and Ng is now set to face charges in both the US and Malaysia. Ng faces money laundering and bribery charges in the US and is also expected to be charged in Malaysia. Goldman Sachs has stated it will "vigorously contest" the charges, which the firm claims were made without a chance for its view.

site_title: Indian drug inspectors seize J&J baby powder: source
summary: Indian drug inspectors have seized samples of Johnson & Johnson's baby powder from a plant in Himachal Pradesh state, following a report that the company knew about the presence of cancer-causing asbestos in the product for decades. The samples were taken on Tuesday night, and the company has denied any wrongdoing. The move is part of an investigation into the safety of the product, which could affect millions of babies in India.

images.alt_text: Indian drug inspectors have seized samples of Johnson & Johnson's baby powder from a plant in a northern state, an industry source said on Wednesday, following a Reuters report the company knew for decades that cancer-causing asbestos lurked in the product.

site_title: Tencent-backed broker Futu confidentially files for up to US$500m US IPO: sources
summary: Hong Kong-based online brokerage firm Futu Securities International, backed by Tencent Holdings, has confidentially filed for a US initial public offering (IPO) of up to $500 million, targeting a valuation of $2.5 billion. The company plans to debut in New York in early 2019 and has hired Goldman Sachs and UBS to work on the US float. Futu's IPO comes after a 15-fold increase in its trading volume and follows other Chinese companies, such as Uber and Tencent Music Entertainment, which have raised billions in US IPOs this year.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker barred for life from dealmaking here over 1MDB saga
summary: Former Goldman Sachs director Tim Leissner has been barred for life from deal-making in Singapore due to his involvement in the 1MDB scandal. Leissner, a former chairman of Goldman Sachs Southeast Asia, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit money laundering and violating the US Foreign Corrupt Practice Act. He admitted to obtaining and retaining business from 1MDB through bribes and kickbacks to government officials. A lifetime prohibition order has also been imposed, preventing him from acting as a director or becoming a substantial shareholder in a capital markets services licensee in Singapore.

site_title: GSK, Pfizer to merge consumer healthcare units into £10b business
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and Pfizer have announced a merger of their consumer healthcare units, creating a new £10 billion business. GSK will own 68% of the joint venture, with Pfizer holding the remaining 32%. The move aims to create a category leader in pain relief, respiratory, and other areas, and will enable GSK to spin off the healthcare arm in three years. The deal follows the expiry of patents for major drugs, enabling smaller rivals to offer cheaper alternatives. The merger will strengthen GSK's pharmaceuticals business and R&D pipeline.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 winning 0.3%. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 0.36 points to 1,635.67 at 9am. The market saw 30.32 million lots traded worth RM15.72 million, with gainer-to-loser ratio at 74-67.

site_title: Huan Hsin receives delisting notice, must provide exit offer; company to appeal
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ordered electronics contract manufacturer Huan Hsin Holdings to delist due to failure to meet mainboard requirements on profitability and market capitalisation. The stock will trade until Jan 18, 2019, and be suspended from Jan 21 until a mandatory exit offer is completed. Huan Hsin plans to appeal the order, with a deadline to provide a reasonable exit offer proposal within a month. The company had been on the watch list since 2014 due to consecutive pre-tax losses and failure to maintain a minimum market capitalisation of S$40 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,057.13, up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.4% to 3,057.13. As of 1pm, losers outpaced gainers 161 to 127, with 503 million shares worth S$460 million changing hands. Active index stocks included Singtel, which rose 0.68% to S$2.98, while Nam Cheong was flat at S$0.007. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Ying Li discloses take-up rate for Beijing project built amid purchase curbs
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate disclosed take-up rates for its New Everbright Centre project in Beijing, citing purchase restrictions to control rising home prices. Phase 1, consisting of four Soho towers, had a 69.8% take-up rate, while Phase 2, with two office towers and retail podium, had a 25% take-up rate. The restrictions include limiting purchases to corporate buyers and those without household registration in Tongzhou. This move aims to rein in home prices in the area.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.03% to 3,044.54
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.03% to 3,044.54. The decline follows a global slowdown and fears over an impending trade war. Investors are approaching "extreme bearishness," with 53% of those polled expecting global growth to weaken over the next 12 months, according to the BofA Merrill Lynch survey.

site_title: GIC buys two distribution centres in South Korea for US$570m
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC buys Blocks A and B of Hwaseong Dongtan Logistics Complex in South Korea for US$570 million. The two newly completed, prime-grade distribution centers are fully leased to quality tenants with long-term leases. This investment aligns with GIC's strategy to own assets with long-term earning potential at reasonable prices, with due regard to risk. The logistics space was previously owned by K-Eco Logis Co, a subsidiary of Halla Corp.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of Federal Reserve, oil struggles to recover
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, with some markets rising and others falling. Oil prices edged up but struggled to recover from a steep loss on Tuesday due to a global supply glut and concerns over demand. The Fed is expected to hike interest rates again, with opinions split on whether it should pause its tightening policy. The US economy remains healthy, but economists are suggesting a break could be in order to maintain growth momentum.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick higher at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.18% to 25,860.68. The gains followed the previous day's big losses, as investors awaited the end of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with gains of 0.08% and 0.11%, respectively.

site_title: German government plans to relax rules to attract foreign workers
summary: Germany's government plans to relax immigration rules to attract foreign workers and replenish its aging workforce. The proposed law, expected to be approved by Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet, aims to ease restrictions on hiring non-EU workers.
