site_title: The world's keenest online hagglers help Line rule in Thailand
summary: Line Corp. is leveraging Thailand's online haggling culture to maintain its dominance as a messaging service in the country. In an unstructured e-commerce model, buyers and sellers negotiate prices via chats, mirroring offline street markets. According to Line's managing director, Ariya Banomyong, this approach is rooted in Thai behavior and allows for flexibility. This strategy enables Line to stay ahead in Thailand's e-commerce market, where no other nation uses social media for online transactions as much as Thailand.

site_title: China's Xi urges implementation of reform but offers no new measures
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged the implementation of reforms on Beijing's terms, calling for support of the state economy and development of the private sector. In a speech marking 40 years of market liberalisation, Xi reaffirmed the Communist Party's leadership and said reforms should align with the goal of improving the socialist system. However, his remarks offered no new specific measures, failing to excite investors, and attention now focuses on the Central Economic Work Conference expected later this week for policy direction.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares skid on growth woes as Fed awaited
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares declined on Tuesday as investors sought safer assets amid concerns over global growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.2% to its lowest since Dec 10, while the NZX 50 index dropped 0.65%. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision on Wednesday is expected to influence markets. The Australian central bank noted uncertainty in household consumption due to falling home prices and high debt levels, while the energy index tumbled 2.7% due to sharp oil price drops.

site_title: Beefeaters and staff at several UK royal sites to strike
summary: Beefeaters and staff at several UK royal sites, including the Tower of London and Kensington Palace, will go on strike starting Friday over a dispute about pensions. The staff and a small number of beefeaters voted "overwhelmingly" to walk out after Historic Royal Palaces (HRP) announced plans to replace final salary pensions with a cheaper defined contribution scheme. The unions claim this move will leave employees with inferior benefits. The strike will affect sites including Hampton Court Palace and the Tower of London, with picketing planned for January 8.

site_title: India's SEBI chief laments slow pace of IPOs hitting market
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) chief Ajay Tyagi expressed concerns about the slow pace of initial public offerings (IPOs) hitting the market, despite a significant amount of filings worth around 600 billion rupees. Fund raising by small-and-medium-sized companies has doubled compared to last year, driven by domestic investors. However, a debt crisis and global trade tensions have dampened investor sentiments, making it challenging for companies to come out with IPOs. Tyagi cautioned that pricing of IPOs should be done more carefully in volatile times.

site_title: Japan's super rich are getting richer under Abenomics
summary: Japan's number of super rich households has almost doubled since 2011, reaching a record high of 84,000, thanks to rising stock prices and economic expansion under Abenomics. The super rich account for 0.16% of Japan's total households, with their net financial assets exceeding 500 million yen. This increase may fuel criticism that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's policies have primarily benefited the wealthy, leaving the general populace with mixed feelings. The proportion of super rich lags other developed economies.

site_title: SoftBank alum unveils 'affectionate' companion robot in Japan
summary: Groove X, a Japanese startup founded by SoftBank alum Kaname Hayashi, unveiled the Lovot, a companion robot designed to make users happy. The robot uses AI to interact with its surroundings, resembling a penguin with cartoonish human eyes, and can become warm to the touch, go to "sleep" when cuddled, and follow users. The Lovot will compete with Sony's Aibo and is priced at 349,000 yen ($3,100) with ongoing subscription fees. Units will start shipping in late 2019, targeting the growing market for household robots in Japan.

site_title: Banyan Tree pushes into Greater China amid global expansion
summary: Banyan Tree Group has signed 26 hotel agreements for its four brands, with 17 in Chinese provinces and the rest in Asean, Oceania, and Europe. The projects are expected to become operational over the next three years, adding to the group's existing 48 hotels. This expansion marks Banyan Tree's push into Greater China amid global expansion.

site_title: PwC Singapore seeks more tax breaks in Budget 2019 to spur startup scene
summary: PwC Singapore has proposed tax breaks in Budget 2019 to spur the startup scene. The audit firm suggested a new tax exemption scheme for early-stage VC investment with a lower fund size of S$10 million. PwC also recommended liberalizing the Angel Investors Tax Deduction scheme to boost growth of tech startups. Additionally, the firm proposed making all of Singapore a free trade zone and offering tax reliefs for working mothers and medical-related insurance policies.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,055.48, down 1.9%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.9% on Tuesday, closing at 3,055.48, as losers outnumbered gainers 239 to 100. Ezion Holdings and Singtel led the decline, down 4.17% and 2.61% respectively. Local banks UOB and DBS were among the top losers. The Straits Times Index resumed trading after the market reopen.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars get reprieve as US dollar faces trouble of its own
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars saw a reprieve as the US dollar faced uncertainty over interest rates. Speculation of the Federal Reserve signaling a conditional rate hike and potential US government shutdown contributed to the decline of the US dollar. As a result, the Aussie dollar strengthened against the US dollar, while the kiwi firmed up against it. The Reserve Bank of Australia reiterated that a rate hike was likely, but downside risks to consumption and the housing market suggested no immediate move.

site_title: Japan's Q3 output gap turns negative in blow to BOJ's inflation goal
summary: Japan's economy contracted in the third quarter by the most in four years due to a strong earthquake, severe floods, and global trade friction concerns. This contraction led to a negative output gap for the first time in almost two years, making the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target more distant. The negative output gap is a sign of weakening demand, further complicating the BOJ's inflation goal. Japan's economy has been impacted by external factors, exacerbating the economic slowdown.

site_title: UK markets watchdog overhauls bank overdraft charges
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed a radical overhaul of bank overdraft charges, banning higher fees for unarranged overdrafts. Banks earned £2.4 billion from overdraft charges in 2017, with 30% coming from unarranged overdrafts. The FCA proposes a simple, single interest rate and no fixed daily or monthly charges, and a ban on fixed fees for using an overdraft facility. The proposals aim to limit the availability of free banking and protect vulnerable consumers from high fees and interest charges.

site_title: Thailand's car sales in high gear but bumps seen ahead
summary: Thailand's car sales are expected to reach 1 million units in 2018, driven by a strong economy and growing household debt, but analysts predict a slowdown ahead due to anticipated interest rate hikes. Household debt accounts for 77.5% of the country's GDP, and delinquencies are high, with 7.32% of car loans overdue. Carmakers are shifting to hybrid electric vehicle production, and the government is providing tax incentives for eco-friendly cars, but consumer confidence is low, and prospective buyers are hesitant to make purchases.

site_title: Twitter is 'toxic place for women', says Amnesty International
summary: Amnesty International has released a report stating that Twitter is a "toxic place for women", citing a study that found 7% of tweets received by prominent women in government and journalism were abusive or problematic. Women of color were 34% more likely to be targeted than white women, with black women being 84% more likely than white women to be mentioned in problematic tweets. The organization is calling on Twitter to provide data on the scale and nature of abuse and how it is being addressed.

site_title: Kuwait Oil Minister's resignation accepted by Government
summary: Kuwait's Oil Minister Bakheet Al-Rashidi has resigned amid internal disputes, accepted by the government. The resignation follows a series of delays in projects and allegations of mismanagement. Al-Rashidi survived a no-confidence vote in May but lawmakers called for his resignation. Two top executives of state-owned energy companies, Jamal Jaafar and Hatem Al-Awadhi, have also submitted their resignations. The country's oil industry has been plagued by chronic internal disputes for two decades, contributing to delays in high-profile energy projects.

site_title: Bain Capital closes new Asian fund at US$4.65b: source
summary: Bain Capital has closed its new Asia-focused fund at US$4.65 billion, exceeding its target of US$3.5 billion to US$4 billion. The firm raised US$4 billion from external investors and US$650 million from itself and related parties. This is the fourth and largest pan-Asia fund by Bain, which typically invests in consumer, financial, and technology sectors. The region's dry powder reached a record high of US$336 billion in December, with private equity firms raising US$445 billion in new funds since 2015.

site_title: Russian troll farm aimed to discourage black US voters at 2016 election: study
summary: A Russian troll farm, the Internet Research Agency (IRA), aimed to demoralize African-Americans and discourage them from voting in the 2016 US presidential election, according to a Senate report. The IRA created social media accounts targeting black Americans with divisive messages, such as "No lives matter to Hillary Clinton." The campaign also targeted liberal voters, including Latinos and the LGBTQ community, with messages pushing them to boycott the election. While the study did not directly link IRA propaganda to election results, post-election data shows a surge in white voter turnout and a decline in black turnout.

site_title: Malaysia's November inflation seen easing to 0.5% y-o-y
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to rise 0.5% in November, marginally slower than the previous month, amid lower transport prices. This marks a mild inflation rate, easing from a 0.6% rate in October. The government's decision to fix pump prices for premium petrol and the reintroduction of a narrower sales tax have softened the expected pickup in inflation. Economists expect inflation to remain benign for the rest of the year and into 2019.

site_title: China hopes for "orderly" Brexit, calls for more open EU economy
summary: China hopes for an "orderly" Brexit, calling for a more open EU economy, according to a foreign ministry policy document. China is concerned about market turmoil and losing Britain's voice for free trade within the EU. The EU and China have differing views on trade and investment, but China sees the EU as committed to integration and regional affairs. China has promised to consider a "top-notch" free trade deal with Britain post-Brexit, and is seeking to ease EU restrictions on Chinese investments and market access.

site_title: Kimly to develop own brand of coffees and teas amid probe
summary: Kimly Ltd, a Catalist-listed coffeeshop operator under investigation, plans to develop its own brand of coffees and teas. The company has convened a workgroup to study packaging and intends to launch its own brand between January and March 2019. Despite the arrest of two key executives, Kimly claims daily operations have not been affected. The company remains open to acquisitions and strategic alliances, and expects to operate 70 coffee shops and food courts in Singapore by the end of 2019.

site_title: Law firm Clifford Chance sets up innovation lab in Singapore
summary: Law firm Clifford Chance has opened its Singapore innovation lab, Create+65, to develop new legal technology solutions. The lab brings together venture capitalists, startups, and experts to tackle problem areas in the law firm's services delivery. With support from the Singapore Economic Development Board and the Singapore Academy of Law, Create+65 aims to promote innovation and collaboration in the legal sector. The lab will test solutions, secure funding, and roll out successful projects to Clifford Chance's global network. This move aims to position Singapore as a hub for technology and innovation in the legal sector.

site_title: 'No place for a mother': South Korea battles to raise birth rate
summary: South Korea's birth rate continues to decline, with the country's fertility rate falling to 0.95 in the third quarter of 2018, the first time it has dropped below 1. The low birth rate is attributed to various factors, including reluctance to employ mothers, long working hours, and limited daycare options. Many firms view mothers as unreliable and doubt their commitment to the company. The government has implemented measures to encourage marriage and childbirth, but critics argue that these measures are insufficient and do not address the underlying issues. As a result, South Korea's population is expected to start falling in 2028.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink with Wall Street on global outlook fears
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, following a sharp retreat on Wall Street due to concerns about the global economy. The US Federal Reserve's monetary tightening drive and China's stuttering economy are among the issues weighing on investor confidence. A speech by Chinese President Xi Jinping later in the day is also being closely watched for possible clues about reforms to China's economy. The central bank is expected to announce another interest rate hike, but comments from its boss Jerome Powell will be closely followed for any signs of a slower pace of increases in 2019.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 13.15 points to 1,628.47 at 9am on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 49.32 million lots worth RM13.48 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 163 to 26.

site_title: Japan to buy more stealth jets, radar to counter China, Russia
summary: Japan plans to accelerate spending on advanced stealth fighters, long-range missiles, and other equipment to counter China's military presence in the Western Pacific. The country aims to buy 45 additional Lockheed Martin F-35 stealth fighters and modify its navy's two large helicopter carriers for F-35B operations. Japan also plans to purchase two land-based Aegis Ashore air defence radars, four Boeing KC-46 refuelling planes, and nine Northrop Grumman E-2 Hawkeye early-warning planes. The country's military spending is expected to increase by 6.4% over the next five years, with a total budget of 25.5 trillion yen.

site_title: Indigenous Argentine group sues energy multinationals
summary: A group of indigenous Mapuche people in Argentine Patagonia are suing major energy multinationals, including Exxon, Total, Pan American Energy, and YPF SA, for environmental contamination due to "dangerous waste" from fracking operations. The waste, allegedly dumped in illegal waste dumps, threatens wildlife and human health. Greenpeace has accused Total and Shell of dumping highly toxic oily sludge waste, and the lawsuit claims that the waste is being tipped in illegal dumps close to populated neighborhoods.

site_title: From Jan 1, non-Malaysians and non-Singaporeans can rent HDB flats for maximum 2 years
summary: From January 1, non-Malaysian and non-Singaporean individuals can rent HDB flats in Singapore for up to 2 years, increasing from the current 1.5-year maximum tenancy period. This change applies to flat owners whose applications reach HDB on or after January 1, providing greater flexibility for non-citizen tenants with longer work or immigration passes.

site_title: Struggling TT International takes bridging loan of up to S$3m
summary: TT International, the electronics retailer, has taken a bridging loan of up to S$3 million as its restructuring process drags on. The loan is intended to tide the group through an interim period, with directors Julia Tong and Sng Sze Hiang providing a joint-and-several personal guarantee. The company's restructuring process has been difficult due to cash flow issues, and the loan is seen as a necessary step to address these challenges.

site_title: Ex-BOJ deputy governor says improving labour productivity behind Japan's low inflation
summary: Former Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Hiroshi Nakaso attributes Japan's low inflation to improved labour productivity and increased workforce participation. Labour productivity is rising steadily, while real wages are also increasing but not keeping pace with productivity growth. This improvement is a key factor in Japan's low inflation.

site_title: US eager to work with restored Sri Lanka PM
summary: The US has welcomed the restoration of Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, who was replaced in October. The State Department praised the resolution of the political crisis according to constitutional norms and the rule of law. US officials expressed eagerness to work with Wickremesinghe to advance cooperation on bilateral and regional issues, considering Sri Lanka a valued partner in the Indo-Pacific.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Kimly, Top Glove, GS Holdings, DeClout, BlackGold
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday included Kimly, which is developing its own coffee and tea brand, and Top Glove, which reported a 34.5% increase in revenue. GS Holdings signed a conditional sale and purchase agreement for a food court and coffee shop company, while DeClout sold its stake in an e-commerce platform provider. BlackGold's consultant was sentenced but won't impact the company's finances.

site_title: Goldman says former Malaysia government lied, after charges filed
summary: Goldman Sachs has accused the former Malaysian government and state fund 1MDB of lying, after Kuala Lumpur charged the bank over a massive financial scandal. The charges, filed by Malaysia's attorney-general, allege the bank and two ex-employees misappropriated $2.7 billion and bribed officials. Goldman denies wrongdoing, stating that certain individuals lied to the bank about the use of proceeds from transactions. The bank will contest the charges, seeking to avoid fines and jail terms. The scandal involves former Malaysian leader Najib Razak and contributed to his government's shock defeat at the May elections.

site_title: Qualcomm says Apple violating Chinese court order, despite new software
summary: Qualcomm claims Apple is still violating a Chinese court order to stop selling older iPhone models despite a software update. The court had previously ordered Apple to stop selling phones with certain software features. Qualcomm's general counsel stated that Apple's efforts to address the issue were "deliberate attempts to obfuscate and misdirect." Apple believes it is in compliance with the order, but Qualcomm argues that Apple is still selling phones and has not received explicit permission to do so. The dispute remains unresolved.

site_title: The music stops for HMV in Hong Kong
summary: HMV Retail, a music and movie store chain in Hong Kong, has closed its stores after a quarter century due to the rise of streaming services and declining demand for physical media. The chain's owner, HMV Digital China Group Ltd, appointed liquidators and cited stagnant sales of CDs and DVDs, as well as the popularity of Apple's AirPods, as reasons for the closure. This marks the demise of the retailer in Hong Kong, five years after its UK parent HMV Group filed for bankruptcy. Liquidators will seek new investors to restart operations.

site_title: Ethiopian Airlines reopens Moscow route after 27 years
summary: Ethiopian Airlines has resumed flights to Moscow after a 27-year gap, marking a significant addition to its European service. The airline, which operates 100% state-owned, will fly three times a week to the Russian capital. The move is seen as a positive step in strengthening relations between Ethiopia and Russia, with the two nations cooperating in sectors such as nuclear power. The resumption of flights is also expected to boost passenger flow and connect Russians with Ethiopian Airlines' global network.

site_title: Singapore business optimism wanes for Q1 2019
summary: Singapore's business confidence moderated in Q1 2019, with the Business Optimism Index easing to +7.19 percentage points, down from +9.19 in Q4 2018. Despite this, optimism remained higher than the same period last year. Expansionary outlooks were seen in selling price, new orders, and inventory levels, while sales volume, net profits, and employment levels slipped. The most optimistic sectors were services, transportation, and wholesale, with firms expecting investments in business expansion, particularly in technology. Global economic uncertainties and higher business costs were cited as major challenges.

site_title: BlackGold: Sentencing of consultant in bribery case not expected to impact group operations
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources' consultant, Johanes Kotjo, was sentenced in a bribery case, but the company expects no impact on its operations or finances. Kotjo, the uncle of BlackGold's chief investment officer, was previously described as a shareholder. The company received a query about bribery allegations related to its Riau-1 Project in August and has since requested the release of held bank accounts. BlackGold's shares closed unchanged on the day of the sentencing and have since been trading halted, but the company plans to make further announcements on the bribery case.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall Street tumbles
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, extending losses on Wall Street, as investors awaited meetings of the US and Japanese central banks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.07% or 230.76 points to 21,276.12, while the Topix index declined 1.14% or 18.19 points to 1,576.01.

site_title: J&J moves to limit impact of Reuters report on asbestos in its Baby Powder
summary: Johnson & Johnson faced backlash after a Reuters report revealed the company knew for decades that its Baby Powder contained cancer-causing asbestos. The report found that J&J knew as early as 1971 but failed to report the findings to the FDA. In response, the company repurchased $5 billion of its stock and ran a full-page ad defending its product. CEO Alex Gorsky denied the allegations in a TV interview, but a Reuters spokesman said the FDA stands by its reporting. Senator Edward Markey called for an investigation into the company's practices.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 1.2% to 3,077.03
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 37.22 points, or 1.2%, to 3,077.03. Losers outnumbered gainers 99 to 45, with Singtel falling 2.6% to S$2.98, OCBC losing 1.6% to S$11.16, and DBS dropping 1.5% to S$23.58. About 52.1 million shares worth S$107.7 million changed hands.

site_title: Canada proposes hefty redress for airline delays
summary: Canada has proposed regulations requiring airlines to compensate passengers for delayed flights, lost baggage, and bumped flights. The draft rules, subject to public consultation, would provide up to C$1,000 in compensation for delays and C$2,400 for overbooked flights. Compensation would also be required for lost or damaged baggage, including a refund of baggage fees. The regulations follow a rising number of complaints and aim to ensure airlines treat passengers with respect and live up to their commitments. The rules would apply to flights to, from, and within Canada.

site_title: New criminal charges for Goldman Sachs deepen crisis for Wall Street giant
summary: Goldman Sachs is facing a severe crisis after receiving subpoenas from New York regulators and being charged by Malaysian prosecutors for allegedly defrauding investors by raising over $6 billion for the 1Malaysia Development Berhad fund. The bank is also under investigation in the US and may incur billions of dollars in penalties. Two former Goldman bankers have been charged with criminal bribery and money laundering, and the bank's lawyers have met with federal prosecutors in settlement negotiations. A potential settlement is months away, and Goldman's reputation as a symbol of Wall Street ethics is being severely damaged.

site_title: Auctioneer behind 'Salvator Mundi' sale leaves Christie's
summary: Loic Gouzer, the auctioneer behind the record-breaking 2017 sale of Leonardo da Vinci's Salvator Mundi for $450.3 million, will step down as co-chairman of Christie's Americas postwar and contemporary art by year's end. During his seven-year tenure, Gouzer developed a reputation for taking big risks to clinch history-making sales. His departure marks a significant change at Christie's, following the sale of the da Vinci painting, which remains the most expensive work ever sold at auction, still held in a private collection.

site_title: Da Vinci design jewel still key for Tuscan silk weavers
summary: In Florence, Italy, L'Antico Setificio Fiorentino silk mill, founded in 1786, continues to produce high-quality silk fabrics using a warping machine designed by Leonardo da Vinci in the late 17th century. The workshop, owned by the Ricci family since 2010, crafts fabrics favored by the historic House of Medici and sells them for up to 1,500 euros per meter. The mill's traditional techniques and looms, some dating back to the 17th century, have produced fabrics for royalty, opera singers, and popes, and are now preserved in the workshop's historical archives.

site_title: Fed rate hikes are extremely rare when stocks are this beat up
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates for the first time since 1994, amid a brutal market, despite the S&P 500 being in a bear market. This move would be the first rate hike since 1994, and it's rare given the current market conditions. Economists say the data suggests further tightening is appropriate, but markets are warning of financial instability, leading to a divide between the economy and the market.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's hectoring aside, it's exceedingly rare the Federal Reserve raises interest rates when stocks are behaving this badly.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink at open on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.71% on Tuesday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to global economic concerns and a Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 25,903.98, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also declined. The sell-off was attributed to investor worries over the global economy and the upcoming Fed meeting, which may impact monetary policies.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares track Wall Street losses on growth concerns
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.2% to 5,592.1, tracking Wall Street losses due to concerns over slowing global economic growth and investor caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting. The benchmark is expected to raise interest rates again but may cut policy tightening guidance. Financial stocks, such as Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and National Australia Bank, dropped 2.3% and 1.4%, respectively. Gold stocks, however, rose 2% as investors sought safe-haven assets.

site_title: Czech warning over Huawei, ZTE security 'threat'
summary: The Czech National Cyber and Information Security Agency has warned against using Huawei and ZTE software and hardware due to concerns over China's laws requiring private companies to cooperate with intelligence services. This could pose a threat to state security, as these companies are primarily based in China. The warning highlights the risks of introducing foreign-made technology into key state systems, particularly in a country with a complex political environment.

site_title: Embattled Australia PM Morrison eyes tax cuts before election
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison is seeking to boost support ahead of the May general election by proposing A$9 billion in tax cuts. The move comes as his conservative coalition is trailing behind in the polls and faces a potential loss to the centre-left Labor party. The tax cuts, budgeted for in the mid-year budget, aim to shore up support and provide a significant election war chest for Morrison. The government did not specify what the tax cuts would entail, but experts attribute the smaller deficit to higher tax revenues from stronger economic growth.

site_title: US: Bloodletting resumes on Wall Street, Dow falls -2%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Monday, falling 2.2% as investors feared weakening global growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 both dropped 2.2%, with the Nasdaq falling 2.4%. This marks the second straight session of losses, as investors continue to worry about global economic trends. The tech-heavy Nasdaq has now fallen for the year, while the Dow and S&P 500 remain above their previous record highs.

site_title: CBS denies former CEO Leslie Moonves US$120m severance
summary: CBS Corp denied former CEO Leslie Moonves a $120 million severance package, citing a review of an investigation into his behavior, which found he destroyed evidence and sought to mollify accusers with job promises. The board of directors terminated his employment for cause. The decision follows a leak of a draft report, which accused Moonves of sexual harassment and assault. The move is seen as a step towards a likely legal battle between Moonves and CBS.

site_title: New Google campus accelerates tech's march into New York
summary: Google plans to create a $1 billion campus in Manhattan, positioning it to become one of the city's largest office occupants, with plans to double its workforce to over 14,000 by 2028. The move follows Amazon's recent expansion to Queens, with Apple, Facebook, LinkedIn, and Uber also expanding in the city. The influx of tech companies is reshaping New York's neighborhoods and changing its identity from a hub of finance and media to one centered on technology, with high-paying jobs and millions of square feet of commercial real estate being leased or built.

site_title: Audio-speaker maker Plastoform says impairment on receivables will not hurt it as going concern
summary: Plastoform, a loss-making audio-speaker manufacturer, has assured regulators that an impairment of HK$23.3 million (S$4.09 million) on accounts receivables will not harm its ability to operate as a going concern. The company cited efforts to recover outstanding debts and minimize costs, despite recording a net loss of HK$17.7 million in its third quarter. Plastoform plans to close its Shenzhen production facility and liquidate its subsidiary, and is exploring options to recover debts from major customers, including US-based Monster LLC.

site_title: Hyflux to hold second round of town hall meetings on Jan 18
summary: Hyflux announced its second round of town hall meetings on January 18, 2019, open to securityholders of the water treatment firm.

site_title: China mutual fund closures hit record on shadow banking purge
summary: China's mutual fund market has seen a record number of liquidations, with over 600 funds closed this year, surpassing 12 years of combined liquidations. The US$1.9 trillion market has grown five-fold since 2011, but the recent crackdown on shadow banking and an ailing stock market have contributed to the closures. More than half of the closures came from mixed allocation funds, while tougher regulation of "mini funds" has also accelerated liquidations. Analysts attribute the closures to the operational costs of maintaining funds in a down market and the exit of fund houses from smaller products.

site_title: Facebook Watch takes on YouTube with pranksters, magicians and cartoons
summary: Facebook Watch is expanding its reach with original programming and user-generated content, attracting revenue from popular creators like magician Julius Dein and prankster brothers Max, Rebeen, and Arman Jalal. Since allowing more pages to run video ads in August, the platform has seen a significant increase in revenue, with some creators earning over $500,000. Facebook aims to attract more mainstream advertisers, with over 75 million users spending at least one minute on Watch daily. The platform is also creating communities and social engagement, with content creators citing the importance of scale and diversity in attracting advertisers.

site_title: Former FBI chief lashes out at Trump, Republicans
summary: Former FBI director James Comey criticized President Donald Trump for telling "lies" and undermining the rule of law, urging Republicans to stand up to the president. Comey's comments came after Trump's anti-FBI tweets alleged the agency abused its powers in investigating former personal lawyer Michael Cohen and national security advisor Michael Flynn, both of whom have been convicted. Comey called on Republicans to speak the truth and stop remaining quiet in the face of Trump's false statements, warning that politicians must stand up for the country's values and not be swayed by fear.

site_title: Europe: Retail stress roils stocks, no Christmas boost in sight
summary: European stocks plummeted on Monday, with the Euro zone down 1%, Germany's DAX 0.8%, and Britain's FTSE 100 0.9%. Online fashion retailer ASOS issued a profit warning, citing November sales significantly behind expectations, causing its shares to drop 37.5%. Investors fear a lack of pre-Christmas spending boost, dampening market hopes for a festive recovery.

site_title: China marks 40-year economic rise as clouds gather
summary: China is celebrating the 40th anniversary of its "reform and opening up" policy, which transformed the country into an economic powerhouse. The policy, initiated by Deng Xiaoping in 1978, led to double-digit annual growth, lifted millions out of poverty, and turned China into the world's second-largest economy. However, the economic transformation has not led to significant changes in the Communist Party's control, and China now faces slowing growth, a trade war with the US, and a debt mountain. Analysts suggest the trade war could be an opportunity for China to enact further reforms.

site_title: EU agrees to cut emissions from new cars by 37% by 2030
summary: The European Union has agreed to cut carbon dioxide emissions from new cars by 37.5% by 2030, with emissions from new vans required to be 31% lower than in 2021. This decision comes after the COP24 summit in Poland, where countries were expected to increase their emission reduction targets. The agreement aims to reduce the EU's reliance on fossil fuels and meet its climate change goals.

site_title: Women are on track to earn the same as men - in 202 years
summary: The global gender gap has improved slightly, with overall disparities in politics, work, health, and education decreasing by less than 0.1% since last year. However, the economic opportunity gap remains vast, taking 202 years to close, according to the World Economic Forum's Global Gender Gap Report. The gap in artificial intelligence is also significant, with women making up only 28% of the AI workforce in Singapore, the highest percentage among 20 economies surveyed. Governments can help spur improvements with equal-pay policies and investment in parental and elder care infrastructure.

images.alt_text: The good news: The global gender gap has improved, slightly. The reality: Differences in economic opportunity, including pay between men and women, are so vast it'll take 202 years to fully bridge them, according to the World Economic Forum.

site_title: Deloitte Singapore appoints new country managing partner
summary: Deloitte Singapore has appointed Cheung Pui Yuen as its new country managing partner, effective January 1, 2019. He will succeed Philip Yuen, who holds dual roles as CEO for Deloitte in South-east Asia and country managing partner in Singapore.

site_title: France to push ahead with digital tax starting Jan 1
summary: France will introduce a digital tax on large internet and technology companies starting January 1, 2019, with an estimated annual revenue of 500 million euros. The tax will target companies with worldwide annual turnover above 750 million euros, mainly US giants such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon. France's move comes as the European Union struggles to finalize an EU-wide levy, with some member states opposing the measure. The tax aims to ensure global giants pay a fair share of taxes on their business operations in Europe.

site_title: H&M's blowout sales raise questions about inventory
summary: Hennes & Mauritz AB reported its fastest quarterly sales growth in three years, with revenue rising 12% to 56.4 billion krona. However, analysts question whether the growth was due to price cuts to clear excess inventory, as sales may be unprofitable. The company's stock fell 2.9% in early trading, despite a 27% gain in the previous three months. Favorable currency shifts contributed 50% of the growth, with sales excluding foreign-exchange movements growing 6%. The impact on earnings will be clear only with the full results on January 31.

images.alt_text: It's possible a lot of H&M's sales growth wasn't very profitable: its outlets had been selling sweaters for as little as US$9.99.

site_title: NE Line to have major renewal project next year
summary: Singapore's North East Line (NEL) will undergo a major renewal project next year, upgrading trains, tracks, and power and signalling systems. The project, costing S$117 million, aims to improve rail reliability and reduce disruptions. The project's completion will be done under the New Rail Financing Framework, with no additional cost to the government. The renewal will also include upgrading 25 trains with new air-conditioning, ventilation, and passenger information systems, benefiting 600,000 daily commuters.

site_title: Nissan meets to replace Ghosn amid rising tensions with Renault
summary: Nissan's board is meeting to discuss replacing former chairman Carlos Ghosn amid allegations of financial misconduct. The Japanese automaker faces charges of understating Ghosn's pay, and Renault is seeking more representation on the board. Ghosn remains in detention, facing charges of under-reporting his salary and other financial misconduct. The decision on his replacement is being led by an advisory committee, with a former Renault executive involved. Nissan is instead expected to announce new governance measures to address criticism.

site_title: NTUC Income appoints Morgan Stanley's Ronald Ong as board chairman
summary: NTUC Income appointed Ronald Ong, chairman and CEO for South-east Asia at Morgan Stanley, as its board chairman effective January 1, 2019. Ong replaces Stephen Lee Ching Yen and brings 20 years of experience to the role. The insurer's CEO, Ken Ng, expressed confidence in Ong's ability to accelerate digitalization and growth. Ong stated it's an honor to serve as chairman and looks forward to working with directors to build on Income's trusted value proposition as a social enterprise. Lim Boon Heng, chairman of NTUC Enterprise, praised Ong's business leadership skills.

images.alt_text: Mr Ong joined NTUC Income as a board member in August this year.

site_title: UK housebuilders are another 'brexit football' for the market
summary: UK housebuilders are considered a "Brexit football" with analysts divided on the sector's future. Despite recent recovery, the sector's share prices remain sensitive to political news and market views differ on sales volume, house prices, and profitability. UBS analysts predict a 45% upside for share prices, while Liberum Capital sees a 20% upside, while Shore Capital expects more aggressive cuts to estimates due to weakening market trends. Analysts also cut average price targets for housebuilders by 17%, citing a volatile short-term outlook.

site_title: Philippines wins its 4th Miss Universe title
summary: Philippines' Catriona Gray was crowned Miss Universe on December 17, 2018, in Bangkok, marking the country's fourth win in the international beauty pageant. Gray, a 24-year-old model, impressed with her responses to questions on inclusivity and medical marijuana, and her advocacy work in the Philippines' slums. The event, praised for its all-women panel of judges, also featured a transgender candidate, Miss Spain's Angela Ponce, who made history as the first in the competition.

site_title: All eyes on Beijing's response at a key anniversary event amid Huawei saga
summary: China has detained two Canadians, Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig, in retaliation for the arrest of Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou in Canada. Beijing claims that the International Crisis Group, where Kovrig works, is not registered as a non-governmental organization and therefore not allowed in the country. The move is seen as a predictable response from China, which views the arrest as a political kidnapping by the US. The detentions are likely to escalate tensions in the ongoing Sino-US trade war, with US President Donald Trump's comments on Meng's case further complicating relations between the two nations.

site_title: What matters most for global business in 2019?
summary: Global businesses in 2019 face a new reality as the post-war liberal consensus is replaced by intense national competition for jobs, technology, and tax revenue. Companies must adapt to diverse Internet regulations, geopolitical risks, and local threats to their operations. Avoiding distractions from geopolitical drama and focusing on material threats is crucial, as foreign companies often get sidetracked by corruption scandals and regulatory issues. Regional risks in 2019 include Indonesia's presidential elections, India's general election, and European regional developments, which will shape global trade and politics.

site_title: Chip testing firm backed by semiconductor veteran plans Catalist listing
summary: A chip testing firm backed by semiconductor veteran Ricky Lee is planning to list its shares on the Catalist board. Grand Venture Technology, which provides engineering, assembly and testing services, lodged a preliminary offer document on Dec 14. The company, controlled by Lee, is seeking to raise funds for future growth.

site_title: Making cleaning robots a reality
summary: Singapore-based company LionsBot International has become the first to mass-manufacture professional cleaning robots, LeoBot Scrub. Developed by husband and wife team Dylan Ng and Michelle Seow, along with assistant professor Mohan Rajesh Elara, the robot can vacuum and scrub to a professional standard and has interactive characteristics. The company adopted a "Robots-as-a-Service" rental-based business model, offering robots for S$1,200 per month. With two cleaning service providers already ordering 50 robots each, LionsBot aims to position Singapore as a leading source for commercial cleaning robots, with plans to expand into domestic markets.

site_title: Engineering education must also focus on social aspects
summary: Engineering education should balance technical skills with social awareness, acknowledging the complexity of real-world problems and the unintended consequences of technological innovations. Engineers must consider human and cultural factors, such as social capital, trust, and community values, alongside efficiency and resource minimization. This broader perspective is crucial in addressing ethical concerns around AI, machine learning, and big data, and in fostering a more inclusive and responsible technology sector.

site_title: Datapulse to acquire Seoul hotel for 35b won
summary: Datapulse Technology has entered into definitive agreements to acquire Hotel Aropa in Seoul, South Korea, for 35 billion won (S$42.7 million). The acquisition, expected to be completed by March 2019, aligns with the group's plan to expand its business and enhance shareholders' returns. Datapulse will fund the acquisition through internal resources and bank borrowings, and expects it to be earnings accretive.

site_title: RBNZ chief economist John McDermott to leave central bank at end Feb
summary: Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) chief economist John McDermott will leave the central bank at the end of February to take up a position at economic research institute Motu. McDermott, who served as assistant governor until November, will step down after the bank's next monetary policy decision.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) chief economist John McDermott will leave the central bank at the end of February to take up a position at an economic think tank, the RBNZ said on Tuesday.

site_title: Want to buy a London home? Brexit isn't the only thing to watch
summary: London's luxury home market is experiencing a downturn, with home values turning negative and sales dwindling. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit is often cited as the cause, but underlying factors such as a slowdown in overseas demand, tax increases, and a decline in tech industry workers' purchasing power are also contributing to the decline. The market is also seeing a record low in sales, with many properties being treated as distressed. Even estate agents are struggling, with several going into administration in recent months.

site_title: Noon Capital, Acre launch first project in Thailand
summary: Noon Capital and Acre, a private real estate investment firm, have launched the first US$25 million project of a Thailand-focused real estate fund, targeting six multi-family development projects valued at up to US$150 million. The first project will be in Phuket, with units priced at "very accessible rates" for local residents. The partnership aims to capitalize on Thailand's growing demand for mid and long-term rental residences, driven by increasing wages and tourism. Noon Capital has also started piloting blockchain on its existing projects, allowing for quicker liquidation of properties.

site_title: Foxconn not in settlement talks with Qualcomm in Apple battle
summary: Foxconn, a parent company of one of the contract manufacturers seeking $9 billion in damages from Qualcomm, is not in settlement talks with the mobile chip supplier in the Apple battle. The group of device assemblers, including Foxconn, is preparing for a trial in April, according to their lead attorney. Qualcomm secured a preliminary victory in a patent lawsuit in China, while a US judge ruled it cannot mention Apple's switch to Intel chips in its antitrust lawsuit. The dispute is part of the global legal battle between regulators, Apple, and Qualcomm over modem chip sales.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tee International is undertaking a strategic review of its subsidiary, Tee Land, to evaluate opportunities and positioning for maximum value. AF Global sold its full ownership rights to the Crowne Plaza London Kensington hotel in the UK for £84.4 million. Keppel Shipyard received a notice to proceed for early conversion works on the Gimi FLNG project, worth up to S$50 million. Tee Land, a boutique property developer, has been listed on the Singapore Exchange since 2013 and invests in residential, commercial, and industrial projects globally.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of possible revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1, citing market uncertainty. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: DBS takes 9.9% stake in Halcyon Agri's rubber trading platform
summary: DBS Bank has taken a 9.9% stake in Halcyon Agri's digital rubber trading platform, HeveaConnect, for US$1 million. The platform aims to promote price transparency and connect natural rubber stakeholders, including farmers, producers, and tyre manufacturers. HeveaConnect will also offer access to services like financing, insurance, and logistics. The investment supports Halcyon Agri's digitalisation strategy and DBS's commitment to sustainable business practices.

site_title: As China sees bankruptcies surge, bondholders may get less back
summary: China's bankruptcy filings surge, with at least five firms accepting or planning to accept bankruptcy applications since early November. This pace is comparable to the previous four years, and the country's top planning body has called for local officials to clean up debt by 2020. Bondholders may receive less back in repayment due to the increased bankruptcies, which could impact the case history of debt resolutions for investors.

site_title: Xi sees himself as champion of China's 40-year reform process
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will use the 40th anniversary of Deng Xiaoping's "Reform and Opening Up" to argue that China's economic reform process continues, despite increasing state control and US criticism. This speech marks an opportunity for Xi to solidify his reputation, following Donald Trump's election in 2016. The address is expected to address criticisms of Xi's policies, which have led to concerns about China's economic growth and relations with the US.

site_title: Bitter end for sugar as investors line up for 2019 losses
summary: Sugar futures have slumped 17% this year, marking a second consecutive annual loss, due to a global supply glut sparked by booming production. The decline is attributed to a surplus of sugar in the market, leaving investors worried about a potential price collapse in 2019.

site_title: Time is ripe for Didi to seize the wheel of a Chinese carmaker
summary: Didi Chuxing, a $56 billion Chinese ride-hailing unicorn, plans to acquire a carmaker in 2019. With valuations of Chinese automakers falling and competition from Waymo rising, Didi's founder Cheng Wei sees an opportunity to expand into car-making. The company has already partnered with local and German automakers, and its in-house team is developing "purpose-built" vehicles. Didi aims to control the algorithms and data alongside car design and manufacturing to gain an advantage in autonomous driving. The company has sufficient cash reserves, with half of its $12 billion war chest expected to be sufficient for an acquisition.

site_title: No Santa rally in sight as Christmas nears
summary: Asian markets opened with slim gains, defying expectations of a "Santa rally" before Christmas, as risk appetite took a hit from China's lacklustre economic data. Stocks in Shanghai, Tokyo, and Seoul gained less than 1%, while Hong Kong remained flat. Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.4% led by local banks, with UOB jumping 2.64%. Analysts believe the weak data could weigh on output growth, but some see it as an opportunity for bargains, with the Chinese market considered cheap.

site_title: Rising affluence in India sees higher sales of premium alcohol
summary: India's rising affluence is driving growth in the $33 billion spirits market, with sales expected to rise 10% annually. Premium alcohol sales are increasing as the country's middle class spends more on dining out and drinking. The spirit sector is projected to expand 25% to $56.07 billion by 2022, with India becoming a significant player in global consumption. Companies are taking notice, with offshore companies interested in entering the market, but some local distillers are choosing not to sell.

site_title: No security breach on online portal: CIMB Malaysia
summary: CIMB Malaysia has denied allegations of a security breach on its online portal, CIMB Clicks Malaysia, after a tech portal founder made a posting about an alleged breach. The bank attributed the slow access to the portal to a surge in customers logging in, following the posting. Additional security measures, such as longer passwords and reCaptcha, were implemented, which were prescheduled, not in response to a breach. Unauthorised transactions via debit card and PayPal were found to be unrelated to the portal.

site_title: Britain's ASOS adds to retail gloom with profit warning
summary: Britain's online fashion retailer ASOS issued a profit warning, cutting annual sales growth and profit margin forecasts due to a downturn in November trading. The company's shares plummeted 36% following the announcement, joining other British retailers in highlighting the crisis in the UK retail sector. ASOS's warning shows that even previously high-flying online-only clothing retailers are not immune to the growing retail crisis.

site_title: Top Glove posts record revenue of RM1.26b in Q1
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a 34.5% increase in revenue to RM1.26 billion in its first quarter, driven by stronger glove sales in developed and emerging markets. The company's net profit rose 4.5% to RM110.1 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.31 sen. Despite higher interest costs, Top Glove expects to maintain profitability, driven by ongoing marketing efforts and efficiency enhancements, and a promising industry outlook with glove usage projected to grow 10% annually.

site_title: Cambodia hails opening of country's largest dam despite opposition
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen opened the country's largest hydropower scheme, the Lower Sesan 2, despite environmental concerns. The $780 million project, backed by Chinese funding, is expected to displace around 5,000 people from marginalized indigenous groups. Hun Sen defended the project, citing compensation and support from the government. Environmentalists, including the UN and International Rivers, have raised concerns about the dam's impact on the Mekong River's fisheries and biodiversity, with predictions of a "costly catastrophic impact".

site_title: Retirement options get boost from Singapore Savings Bonds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced two changes to the Singapore Savings Bonds (SSB) program, allowing investors to use their Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) funds to purchase SSBs and increasing the individual cap for holding SSBs to S$200,000 from S$100,000. The changes aim to boost retirement savings and provide a flexible risk-free investment option for investors. The changes will take effect from February 1, 2019, and are expected to benefit individual investors and the overall demand for SSBs.

site_title: China's US$20b new Egypt capital project talks fall through
summary: Egypt's US$20 billion development project with Chinese builder China Fortune Land Development (CFLD) has fallen through due to disagreements on revenue sharing. Egyptian authorities wanted 40% of the project's revenue, while CFLD offered 33%. The talks, which lasted two years, ended after Egyptian officials failed to respond to the final proposal. The project's failure may impact Egypt's ability to attract foreign direct investments, but it may not deter Chinese state-owned companies from pursuing other opportunities in the country.

site_title: Ex-banker to launch fund focused on vintage string instruments
summary: A former Frankfurt banker, Christian Reister, is launching a fund focused on vintage string instruments, aiming to capitalize on their potential for appreciation, up to 8% per year. Reister's firm, Violin Assets GmbH, has sold several dozen instruments to private investors since 2014, and the market for sought-after violins and other string instruments is smaller than that for vintage cars, but lacks transparency. The fund is expected to launch in the first quarter, targeting seed investors.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NetLink NBN Trust is recommended as a buy with a target price of S$0.93 due to its business model and healthy balance sheet, which support a 100% payout of distributable cash policy. The company's virtual monopoly of residential fibre connections and scalability of fibre make it a preferred pick in the Singapore telco sector. Dairy Farm International is held with a target price of US$9.77, citing a lacklustre near-term outlook due to ongoing cost pressures and private consumption moderation in Malaysia.

site_title: Developers' November sales jump but challenges lie ahead
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged in November, with 1,198 units sold, 2.5 times the October 2018 figure. The strong sales performance came despite concerns about the impact of revised guidelines on average unit size and potential disruptions to developers' business models. The top-selling project was Parc Esta, with 348 units sold at a median price of S$1,699 psf. Analysts expect developers to meet or exceed their sales targets for the year, with some predicting 9,000 private homes sold in 2018 and 17,000-19,000 units ready for launch in 2019.

site_title: GS Holdings buys F&B operator for S$3.6 million
summary: GS Holdings, an investment holding company, has signed a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire F&B operator Hao Kou Wei for S$3.6 million. The acquisition, led by GS Holdings' executive chairman and CEO Pang Pok's spouse, Ms Ang Siew Kiock, aims to expand the group's presence in the food and beverage industry. The deal will be reviewed by an independent financial adviser and the audit committee, and shareholders will be sought approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: China's outcast steel machines find unwelcome home in S-E Asia
summary: China banned induction furnaces in 2017, but they have been smuggled to the Philippines and Indonesia, affecting domestic steelmakers and raising safety and environmental concerns. The influx of these furnaces, which eliminate 140 million tonnes of capacity, is a result of China's crackdown on polluting producers of low-quality steel. This has significant implications for the region's steel industry and environmental regulations, as these machines can produce hazardous emissions and pollutants.

site_title: Tumultuous year raises India Inc's dependence on overseas lenders
summary: India Inc's dependence on overseas lenders is increasing due to stagnant local-currency funding and rising financing costs. The downfall of IL&FS group has fueled concerns about default risks, pushing up loan costs. Companies are turning to dollar-denominated loans, with average margins 130 basis points higher than the London interbank offered rate in 2018. Despite this, some Indian companies are still able to secure loans at favorable rates, while others may struggle to access the foreign market.

site_title: Report on Russia's 2016 fake news campaign goes before US Senate
summary: A US Senate report, compiled by Oxford University and Graphika, reveals that Russia's 2016 fake news campaign used all major social media platforms to target specific voter groups and help elect Donald Trump. The campaign, led by the Internet Research Agency, used tailored content to activate conservatives and siphon support from left-leaning groups. The report, based on data from Facebook, Twitter, and Google, found that Trump was mentioned most in campaigns targeting conservatives, while efforts to confuse and discourage left-leaning voters were also prevalent. The findings corroborate previous intelligence community assessments that Russia sought to help Trump win the White House.

site_title: Singapore November exports' slide sounds caution on trade
summary: Singapore's November non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 2.6% year-over-year, marking the first monthly decline since March 2018. This drop was unexpected, with OCBC Bank's Selena Ling stating it's worse than forecasted at 0% and significantly below the market's 1.8% expectation. The surprise drop raises concerns about a cautious outlook for trade in the coming months.

site_title: Euro rebounds as US dollar dips ahead of Fed meeting
summary: The euro rebounded nearly half a percent from recent lows on Monday as the US dollar slipped ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Fed is expected to raise rates for a fourth time in 2018, with traders cautious about the dollar's potential to rise further. The euro rose to US$1.1354, while the US dollar index slipped 0.3 percent to 97.154. Investors are also watching a major speech by Chinese President Xi Jinping on Tuesday, which may impact the offshore Chinese yuan.

site_title: China advisers urge trimming 2019 growth target amid trade war
summary: China's government advisers have recommended lowering the country's 2019 growth target to 6.0-6.5 per cent due to increasing risks from the US trade dispute, which could spur a sharper slowdown in the economy. The recommendation comes amid concerns about employment and debt problems. Despite this, some advisers suggest the government should be more tolerant of weaker growth and push for reforms to boost the private sector. The central bank is expected to deliver more cuts in reserve requirement ratios to support the slowing economy.

site_title: Redrawing of boundaries, lawsuits cast doubt on credibility of Thai election
summary: Thailand is set to hold its first election since a 2014 military coup, with many questioning the credibility of the poll. The government has lifted a ban on political activity, but critics claim the junta has manipulated the electoral process to maintain power. The military-backed Palang Pracharat Party and pro-Thaksin parties are likely to compete against anti-establishment populists led by the Shinawatra family. Critics have been slapped with lawsuits, and the Election Commission is expected to finalize ballot design, potentially confusing voters. A coalition government is likely, with no party expected to control a parliamentary majority.

site_title: India holds off raising import tariffs on some US goods until Jan 31
summary: India has delayed imposing higher tariffs on select US goods until January 31, 2019, for the fourth time. The decision comes after the US imposed higher tariffs on steel and aluminum, prompting India to consider retaliatory action. India had initially planned to raise import tax on US products, including almonds and apples, but negotiations with the US are ongoing, leading to the delay. This decision defers retaliatory action against US tariffs for the fourth time.

site_title: Marijuana merchants have something to learn from Tide Pods
summary: The US marijuana industry is driving demand for specialized packaging, with companies like KushCo Holding Co. and Berry Global Group Inc. capitalizing on the growing market. Mainstream packagers like Reynolds Group Holdings are entering the space, but face challenges due to federal prohibition and concerns about association with the "drug trade." The industry is expected to reach $75 billion by 2030, creating a lucrative market for companies willing to navigate these challenges.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as retailers fall after Asos cuts outlook
summary: European shares fell 0.3% at the open, adding to Friday's losses, as retailers declined following Asos' 35% cut in sales growth outlook. Italian stocks dropped after the government reached an agreement to trim its budget deficit. The Stoxx 600 Europe Index is down 11% for the year, the worst since 2011, with investors awaiting the Federal Reserve meeting and a quiet week ahead.

site_title: Bond investors give home bias and Robert Kuok the thumbs up
summary: Singapore's bond market ended 2018 on a positive note, with the Markit SGD corporates' total-return index down only 0.16% from its all-time high. Investors have shown a preference for local bonds, particularly those issued by statutory boards and government-linked companies. The "Robert Kuok effect" has seen bonds issued by his company, Shangri-La, perform well, with its 7-year bond rising to 102.68. Foreign issuers have also fared well, with bonds from companies like Temasek Holdings and Singapore Airlines climbing to 101.24 and 100.47, respectively. Experts predict the SGD bond yield to stay in a trading range in 2019, driven by a lenient monetary stance and stable interbank liquidity conditions.

site_title: Make cultural institutions accessible so more can benefit
summary: Cultural institutions worldwide are under pressure to make themselves more accessible to the public, as they are heavily funded by the public purse yet used by only a minority. This has led to concerns about efficiency and effectiveness. In the UK, public libraries have faced closures and restrictions due to funding issues. The article highlights the need for cultural institutions to adapt to changing public needs and make themselves more inclusive.

site_title: China and US trade barbs at WTO amid reform calls
summary: The US and China traded barbs at the World Trade Organization (WTO) amid calls for reform, with US Trade Ambassador Dennis Shea accusing China of "unfair competitive practices" that harm foreign companies and workers. China's envoy Zhang Xiangchen countered that US tariffs allowed protectionism under national security concerns. The US has refused to allow new appointments to the Appellate Body, leading to a shortage of judges and potential paralysis of the WTO dispute settlement system. The US and China are working together to address concerns on the WTO's functioning.

site_title: Burger chain Jack in the Box exploring options, including a sale
summary: Jack in the Box, a US burger chain, is exploring options including a potential sale. The company has held talks with potential buyers, including private equity firms, amid declining sales and higher worker wages. Its shares rose 4% after the announcement. This comes after Bojangles Inc and Sonic were acquired by private equity firms in recent months. Jack in the Box has not set a timeline for the process and plans to proceed with a new capital structure if a transaction is not completed.

site_title: Japan's central bank to warn of rising growth risks, policy seen steady
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its ultra-easy monetary settings, keeping the short-term rate target at -0.1% and the 10-year yield target around 0%, despite rising global growth risks. The BOJ will tolerate negative long-term rates, as long as the 10-year yield remains within a range of -0.2% to 0.2%. The central bank may warn of heightening global risks, including the Sino-US trade war and slowing demand in China, but is likely to keep its view that Japan's economy will continue expanding moderately.

site_title: TranSwap takes aim at remittance business
summary: TranSwap, a Singapore-based fintech startup, has launched an API and joined the Singapore government's Networked Trade Platform to cater to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the remittance business. The company offers competitive exchange rates and same-day transfers, with a transaction fee of 0.25-1.7% depending on the currency pair. TranSwap aims to expand its services to other capital management tools for SMEs, such as trade and invoice financing, and forex hedging tools. The company currently has about 300 registered users, with 90% coming from corporate clients, and is seeking US$5-10 million in funding for growth.

site_title: Malaysia files criminal charges against Goldman, ex-staff in 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysia has filed criminal charges against Goldman Sachs and four individuals, including two former Goldman Sachs employees, in connection with the 1MDB scandal. The charges include US$2.7 billion in allegedly misappropriated funds, billions in fines, and up to 10-year jail terms. Goldman Sachs denies wrongdoing, but the US Department of Justice has previously stated that about US$4.5 billion was misappropriated from 1MDB through the bank's involvement. Prosecutors will seek fines "well in excess" of the allegedly misappropriated funds and fees received by Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Boeing boosts value for Embraer's commercial business to US$5.26b
summary: Embraer SA finalized a deal to sell 80% of its commercial aviation business to Boeing Co for $5.26 billion, a 11% increase from the original offer. The deal values the division at $5.26 billion, with Embraer expecting to receive $3 billion after closing costs. The Brazilian government has veto power over the deal, but President-elect Jair Bolsonaro has expressed support for the partnership, which also includes a joint venture with Boeing to promote the KC-390 defense plane.

site_title: Is corporate governance in Singapore on a downward trajectory?
summary: The Asian Corporate Governance Association (ACGA) released its 2018 edition of CG Watch, a report on corporate governance in 12 Asian markets. The survey, which includes a top-down market survey and a bottom-up ESG survey, found that corporate governance in Singapore is not performing well, with concerns over investor protection and minority shareholder rights. The report highlights the need for more discussion on these issues, suggesting that corporate governance in Singapore is on a downward trajectory.

images.alt_text: A series of corporate scandals have highlighted the weaknesses of Singapore's CG regime and limitations on minority shareholder rights.

site_title: Europe's borrowers brace for death of easy money
summary: Europe's corporate borrowers are bracing for a challenging 2019 due to the end of easy money and rising borrowing costs. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program will expire at year-end, leading to higher borrowing costs and reduced market participation. January, typically the busiest month for new bond sales, may be hit and miss, with issuers facing execution risk and geopolitical uncertainties, such as Brexit, contributing to market volatility. Issuers may need to accept higher borrowing costs and spreads, with some predicting a decline in corporate bond sales.

site_title: Constructing a bright future
summary: Singapore-based construction company QXY Resources has expanded its operations to become a main contractor, earning the prestigious Enterprise 50 (E50) Award in 2016, 2017, and 2018. The company prioritizes prudence and innovation, adopting existing technologies and partnering with other businesses to stay competitive. QXY has also improved productivity through initiatives such as DOKA Formwork and automated skid steer loaders, and has strengthened its commitment to workplace safety. The company plans to expand overseas and widen its service portfolio, including entering the hospitality sector and obtaining additional technical certificates to upgrade its BCA Construction Workhead.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as growth concerns linger; Fed in focus
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday due to lingering concerns about global growth, with investors waiting for the Federal Reserve's monetary policy guidance. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.47%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.35%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.35%. The US market is expected to be influenced by the Fed's guidance, which may impact the global economy and markets.

site_title: Google to spend US$1b on new campus in New York
summary: Google is investing over US$1 billion in a new 1.7 million square-foot campus in New York's Hudson Square, with plans to start moving in by 2022. This expansion mirrors investments by other US tech giants like Apple, and will create thousands of jobs. The move aims to bring Google's operations outside its home base, solidifying its presence in the US financial capital.

site_title: Miss Philippines wins 2018 Miss Universe crown
summary: Miss Philippines, Catriona Gray, won the 2018 Miss Universe crown, beating over 90 contestants from around the globe. Gray, 24, was crowned after a ceremony praised for its inclusivity, featuring its first transgender candidate, Miss Spain's Angela Ponce. However, the event was marred by controversy over comments made by Miss USA Sarah Rose Summers about Asian contestants' English-speaking abilities. Gray's victory was widely celebrated in the Philippines, with President Rodrigo Duterte praising her win for showcasing the country's beauty and elegance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish flat
summary: Hong Kong shares ended Monday marginally lower, with the Hang Seng Index declining 6.81 points to 26,087.98. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.16%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.31%. Investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve policy meeting and an economic planning conference in China later in the week.

site_title: Pound pundits believe the UK is unlikely to exit EU by March
summary: Currency strategists doubt the UK will exit the EU by the March deadline, instead focusing on potential extensions to Article 50 and eventual deals or second referendums. The market is uncertain about the pound's short-term rally, with options bets favoring selling the currency due to political uncertainty. Strategists predict a high chance of a deal (75%) and a low chance of a no-deal scenario (20%), with a 5% chance of a second referendum. The pound will remain in limbo until the Brexit outcome is clear, with intermittent rallies due to scenario gaming.

site_title: Washington is a stage, Trump is the producer
summary: A closed-door session at the White House between four politicians drew significant media attention, likening Washington to a stage and Trump as the producer. This trend of turning politics into entertainment is not new, as past presidents like John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan successfully leveraged their charm and charisma to captivate audiences. Trump's ability to draw attention and create a spectacle has become a hallmark of his presidency, blurring the lines between politics and show business.

images.alt_text: The already thin line between politics and show business is blurring with President Trump at the helm.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 20.34 points to 1,641.62, with 689 losers outweighing 179 gainers. The index saw 1.5 billion lots traded worth RM1.2 billion.

site_title: North-East Line to undergo major renewal project next year
summary: Singapore's North-East Line (NEL) MRT will undergo a major renewal project next year, upgrading trains, tracks, and power and signalling systems. The project, costing $117 million, aims to improve rail reliability and reduce disruptions. The Land Transport Authority has signed a contract to upgrade 25 first-generation trains, which will be replaced with new trains under the New Rail Financing Framework. The project will minimize disruptions to commuters, with shuttle buses to be used during shortened operating hours. The NEL, operated by SBS Transit, was opened in 2003 and has consistently exceeded its long-term maintenance target.

site_title: DeClout disposes e-commerce platform solutions provider for S$21.9m in share transfer deal
summary: DeClout, a Singaporean e-commerce platform solutions provider, has sold its full stake in Corous360 to Choo See Wee's Grand Centrex for S$21.9 million. In exchange, DeClout will receive a 12.5% shareholding in Grand Centrex. The disposal aims to sharpen DeClout's focus on its IT Infrastructure and VDC segments. The deal is expected to yield a gain of S$70,000 for DeClout, assuming completion by end-September 2018.

site_title: Britain's ASOS adds to retail gloom with profit warning
summary: Britain's ASOS cuts annual sales growth and profit margin forecasts, citing weak November trading, contributing to a growing crisis in the UK retail sector. The stock plummeted 36% after the warning, while shares in other British clothing groups also fell. ASOS lowered its sales growth forecast to 15% and EBIT margin target to 2% due to economic uncertainty and a weakening consumer confidence. The company attributed the decline to a high level of discounting and promotional activity across the market.

site_title: Good luck to the Fed on interest rates - they'll need it
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to meet to decide on interest rate increases, which may be criticized regardless of the decision. The Fed has raised interest rates eight times since 2015 to combat inflation and speculation, but some economists fear higher rates could trigger an economic slowdown. A recent study found that lenders have relaxed credit standards on over $4 trillion of corporate debt, and prices of stocks and real estate are at historic highs. The yield curve, which measures the relationship between short-term and long-term interest rates, is also inverted, a sign that economists believe could predict a recession. The Fed's decision will be crucial in balancing the need to avert inflation with the risk of killing the economic recovery.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia sued by US owners claiming engine defect caused fires
summary: Hyundai and Kia are being sued by US owners over alleged engine defects that could cause non-collision fires. A class-action lawsuit claims the automakers' "concealment of the defect" led to over 350 reported complaints to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The US authorities have started investigating recalls related to manufacturing errors in "Theta II" engines, while a criminal investigation has been opened. The customers' lawsuit argues that a defect restricts oil flow, causing engine failure and fire. Hyundai has declined to comment on the lawsuit, but stated it is cooperating with the US Department of Transportation.

site_title: Swiss Re names ReAssure CEO in advance of possible IPO
summary: Swiss Re named Mark Hodges as CEO of its British closed book business ReAssure, effective March 1. The move comes ahead of a possible initial public offering (IPO) for ReAssure, which has £45 billion in assets under management and 3.3 million policies. The company has been exploring a 2019 listing due to a 17% fall in first-half net profit. Hodges, currently CEO of Centrica's consumer division, will replace Sarwjit Sambhi, who will take over from March 1.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.2% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,114.25, driven by gains in financials. DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank led the rally, with DBS up 1.06%, UOB up 2.64%, and OCBC Bank up almost 2%. The market saw 985.3 million shares traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 207 to 174.

site_title: Israeli spacecraft gets final element before 2019 moon launch
summary: Israeli spacecraft Beresheet, named after the Hebrew word for Genesis, has received its final element before a planned 2019 moon launch. The spacecraft, designed to carry a digital time capsule, will be the first of its kind since 2013 and will make Israel the fourth country to achieve a controlled "soft" moon landing.
