Beresheet is equipped with a device to measure the moon's magnetic fields and will be launched on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, with a landing site between Apollo 15 and 17's sites.

images.alt_text: This picture shows a Space IL and Israeli Aerospace Industries spacecraft during a presentation to the media of a "time capsule", intended to travel to the moon with the spacecraft on early 2019, in Yehud, Eastern Tel Aviv, on December 17, 2018.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's November non-oil exports fell 2.6% despite a 1.8% year-on-year increase in domestic exports. In the private home market, 1,198 units were sold in November, exceeding October's 487 units. Deloitte Singapore appointed Cheung Pui Yuen as new country managing partner. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to double the individual limit on Singapore Savings Bonds to S$200,000, starting from February 1, 2019.

site_title: China, EU lambast United States for miring WTO in crisis
summary: The US has come under fire from China and the European Union for taking protectionist measures, bringing the World Trade Organization (WTO) to crisis. China and EU ambassadors criticized US tariffs on steel and aluminum, calling it protectionism under national security concerns. The US has blocked new appointments to the WTO's Appellate Body, leading to concerns about the court's ability to issue binding rulings. The US trade ambassador defended the country's approach, saying it is "one of the most open and competitive economies in the world," while China accused the US of embracing "unfair competitive practices."

site_title: Tee International 'evaluating opportunities' for Tee Land in strategic review
summary: Tee International is undertaking a strategic review of its subsidiary Tee Land to evaluate opportunities and positioning to maximize potential value for stakeholders. Tee Land, a boutique property developer, has been involved in residential, commercial, and industrial projects in Singapore and Malaysia, as well as investments in income-generating properties. There is no assurance that any transaction will materialize from the review. Tee International's share price closed 0.3 cents lower at S$0.172, while Tee Land shares did not trade on Monday.

site_title: Japan's PayPay to update app after wrongful charge complaints
summary: PayPay, a Japanese mobile payments company, is updating its app to strengthen security after multiple complaints from users about wrongful charges. Several customers reported charges on their bills that they didn't recognize, with some claiming they hadn't even installed the app. The company will make changes to the app, including addressing security concerns, such as users being able to enter credit card information multiple times without locking out after mistakes. PayPay is also recommending users contact their credit card providers directly about suspicious activity.

site_title: Financial cycle dip could tip economies into recession: BIS
summary: The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) warns that a financial cycle dip could tip economies into recession due to a burgeoning derivatives market, recent downward trend of global markets, and soaring foreign currency debt. The BIS highlights the dangers of a potential downturn in the US economy and global trade, as well as fragile European markets. Policymakers must address the "comparative weakness of the European banking sector" and the "especially weak Chinese stock market" to prevent a slump. The BIS also warns of an overstretched leveraged loan market in the US and abroad.

site_title: An education: MBAs with Chinese characteristics
summary: China's business schools, such as Renmin University's, are adapting Western business theories to suit the country's unique market-oriented economic system. The universities, which offer MBA programs, focus on managing human resources and navigating China's complex business world. Students learn from case studies of Chinese companies like Haier and Tencent, and some even study Karl Marx's work as part of the government's efforts to emphasize ideology. The programs aim to help entrepreneurs increase productivity and grow wealth, despite concerns that the party's emphasis on capitalism may contradict Marxist principles.

site_title: No respite seen for Korean chip giants as analysts slash targets
summary: South Korea's two largest memory-chip makers, SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics, are facing a tough year as analysts cut their earnings targets and price estimates. Analysts reduced SK Hynix's target by 15% to 85,000 won, citing a decline in DRAM prices and weak demand. Samsung's operating profit is expected to drop 21% in the first quarter, with its shares down 23% for the year. Despite these cuts, all brokerages maintain a "buy" rating on the stocks.

site_title: Top Glove posts record quarterly revenue on stronger glove sales
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a record quarterly revenue of RM1.26 billion, a 34.5% increase from the previous year, driven by stronger glove sales in both developed and emerging markets. The company's net profit rose 4.5% to RM110.1 million, while earnings per share edged up to 4.31 sen. However, higher interest costs and mixed raw material prices affected the profit before tax margin. The company's shares ended 0.5% lower at S$1.98.

site_title: Foxconn not in settlement talks with Qualcomm in Apple battle -attorney
summary: Foxconn, the contract manufacturer assembling Apple devices, is not in settlement talks with Qualcomm, according to the lead attorney. Foxconn is gearing up for a trial in April, seeking at least $9 billion in damages from Qualcomm over patent disputes. The conflict is part of a broader global battle between regulators, Apple, and Qualcomm, with Qualcomm securing a preliminary victory in a Chinese patent lawsuit last week.

site_title: IHH 'resolute' on lifting Fortis' fortunes despite court rule
summary: IHH Healthcare remains committed to its "transformational" buyout of Fortis Healthcare despite the Indian Supreme Court's decision to put the deal on hold due to a petition from Daiichi Sankyo. The court's ruling does not deter IHH CEO Tan See Leng, who stated in an internal memo that the company is resolute on returning Fortis to growth. The deal faces another test, but IHH's resolve remains unchanged, according to the CEO.

site_title: ADB ups lending to Philippines for infrastructure, inclusive finance
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has increased lending to the Philippines, with loan commitments reaching a record $1.3 billion in 2018 and expected to rise to $2.9 billion by 2019. The loans support the government's Build, Build, Build program and include funding for infrastructure, inclusive finance, and emergency assistance for Marawi reconstruction. The ADB will lend around $7.8 billion to the Philippines from 2018 to 2021, with more than half reserved for infrastructure projects. The loans are seen as a boost to the government's public infrastructure spending plans, aiming to reach 7.4% of GDP by 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks gain on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.62% on Monday, rebounding from a sharp decline last week, as investors bought on dips. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,506.88, while the Topix index rose 0.13%. Analysts attribute the gains to bargain-hunting, but warn that market sentiment remains vulnerable to uncertainty. The US Federal Reserve meeting, set to end on Wednesday, is a key focus, with investors watching for rate hike pace in 2019.

site_title: Senior China official urges shift toward fuel-cell vehicles
summary: China is shifting its focus towards developing hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles, following billions of dollars in subsidies for lithium-battery electric cars. Deputy Chairman Wan Gang, a former top official, argues that fuel-cell vehicles offer long driving range, short refueling time, and zero emissions, making them suitable for long-distance transport. This move could benefit proponents of fuel-cell cars, including Toyota and local Chinese makers. Wan's advocacy represents a potential boon for the technology, which could help China meet its growing transportation needs.

site_title: Edcon Hldgs seeks funding to stave off liquidation
summary: Edcon Holdings Ltd, South Africa's biggest non-food retailer, is seeking funding to stave off liquidation by asking mall owners for a 41% rent reduction in exchange for a 5% stake in the business. The company aims to secure 1.9 billion rand (S$181 million) in emergency funding from banks and the Public Investment Corp. Edcon has been struggling due to weak consumer spending and economic growth, and has previously been taken over by banks and bondholders to avoid collapse. The company is in talks with landlords and suppliers, with "significant progress" made in securing a recapitalisation plan.

site_title: Meghan Markle's father asks Queen to get his daughter back in touch
summary: Meghan Markle's father, Thomas Markle, has asked Queen Elizabeth to help resolve his estrangement from his daughter, the Duchess of Sussex. In an ITV interview, Markle expressed hope that the Queen would intercede to mend their relationship, which has been strained since Meghan's marriage to Prince Harry. Markle said he loves his daughter and wants to build a relationship with her, despite not receiving a Christmas card from her. Kensington Palace has not commented on the interview.

site_title: Semiconductor veteran Ricky Lee aims for next IPO with Grand Venture
summary: SEMICONDUCTOR industry veteran Ricky Lee is set to list Grand Venture Technology, a provider of engineering, assembly and testing services, on the Catalist board with a preliminary offer document lodged on Dec 14. Lee, 57, founded Grand Venture in 2012 and holds a 71.7% stake in the company. He previously co-founded Norelco and ETLA before the latter's acquisition by Frencken Group in 2009. The IPO aims to capitalize on Lee's experience in the semiconductor industry.

site_title: PODCAST: How to get started in robo-investing (Money Hacks, Ep 30)
summary: A podcast episode titled "How to get started in robo-investing" (Money Hacks, Ep 30) discusses the basics of robo-investing, a low-cost investment strategy using automated platforms. The episode covers key aspects such as setting up an account, choosing investment options, and managing risk. No specific conclusions or key events related to the podcast episode are found in the provided articles.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB denies security breach but customers say thousands lost to scammers
summary: Malaysia's CIMB bank denied a security breach after customers claimed thousands were hacked, with some reporting unauthorized transactions on PayPal. The bank stated that its site remains secure and transactions are protected, introducing additional security measures such as longer passwords and reCaptcha. Customers reported losing significant amounts of money, with one losing RM1,723.18 and another RM4,000, and some speculated that the breach may be due to a "buffer overflow" attack.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge higher on hopes of Fed easing rate hikes in 2019
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended slightly higher on Monday, driven by hopes of the US Federal Reserve easing rate hikes next year. The index rose 1.70 points, or 0.08%, to 2,071.08. Asian shares were positive, while China and Europe's economic indexes remained stagnant. The South Korean won inched down, and bond yields rose. Investors are seeking Christmas cheer from the US Federal Reserve's meeting this week, hoping for signs of interest rate easing.

site_title: Australian shares recover on potential budget surplus; NZ pares losses
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Monday, closing at 5,658.30, as investors welcomed the government's budget plan that forecasts a budget surplus by 2019/20. The budget deficit is expected to be slashed to A$5.2 billion from A$14.5 billion. Key performers included mining and metals stocks, with Mineral Resources rising 10.6% and BHP Group gaining 3.5%. The energy index also recovered, driven by cautious optimism over a potential trade deal between China and the US.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia sued by owners claiming engine defect caused fires
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. and Kia Motors Corp. are being sued by US drivers over alleged engine defects that could cause fires. More than 350 consumer complaints were reported to the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, with a class-action lawsuit filed in the US District Court for the Central District of California. The US auto-safety regulator is probing Hyundai and Kia's recalls related to manufacturing errors in "Theta II" engines, and a criminal investigation has been opened in New York. The automakers have recalled about 1.6 million vehicles in the US made between 2011 and 2014.

site_title: Doing good through silence, reflection and self-care is Hush Tea Bar's mission
summary: Hush Tea Bar, Singapore's first silent tea bar, aims to promote silence, self-care, and community empowerment through its unique concept. Founded by Anthea Ong, the tea bar is run by differently-abled individuals, including the deaf, and offers a Hush@Workplace Experience model for employers to integrate employee well-being and community inclusion. A recent pilot program with Accenture staff resulted in improved team culture and increased empathy among colleagues, highlighting the benefits of incorporating silence and self-care into the workplace.

images.alt_text: Accenture staff participating in a team activity at Hush Tea Bar. Hush aims to promote silence, self-care, inclusion and community empowerment in offices.

site_title: Malaysia files criminal charges against Goldman Sachs in 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysia has filed criminal charges against Goldman Sachs and two former employees in connection with the 1MDB corruption and money laundering probe. The charges, filed under securities laws, relate to the commission and abetment of false statements to misappropriate $2.7 billion from 1MDB bond proceeds. Goldman Sachs and former bankers Tim Leissner and Roger Ng, along with financier Jho Low and former 1MDB employee Jasmine Loo, are accused of making dishonest statements. The charges mark a significant development in the 1MDB probe, which has implicated several countries and individuals.

site_title: Spanish youth diaspora comes home to opportunity, insecure jobs
summary: Spain is experiencing a shift in its labor market, with talented young Spaniards returning home after seven years abroad, drawn by the country's economic recovery and job opportunities. Despite high unemployment rates, particularly among youth, companies like Banco Santander are hiring again, especially in digital fields. Returnees face challenges, including low pay and insecure jobs, but many are finding new career paths and opportunities. Experts predict that this trend will ease pressure on the social security system and boost the labor force, contributing to strong economic growth.

site_title: Hitachi to acquire ABB's power grids unit valued at US$11 billion
summary: Hitachi Ltd. agreed to acquire ABB Ltd.'s power grids division valued at US$11 billion, aiming to become a top global provider of equipment for electricity networks. ABB will return proceeds of US$7.6 billion to US$7.8 billion, and Hitachi will acquire 80.1% of the business. The sale will shrink ABB's revenue by a quarter and focus the Swiss engineering giant on robotics and automation.

images.alt_text: Hitachi Ltd. agreed to buy ABB Ltd.'s power grids division in a deal that values the entire business at US$11 billion, a plan that's aimed at turning the Japanese conglomerate into a top global provider of equipment for electricity networks.

site_title: Sri Lanka PM Wickremesinghe's reinstatement calms markets; Cabinet in focus
summary: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe was reinstated by President Maithripala Sirisena, ending a seven-week political crisis. Wickremesinghe's reinstatement calmed markets, with the rupee strengthening and bond yields dropping. The move is seen as an embarrassment for the president, and investors will monitor the relationship between Wickremesinghe and Sirisena. Wickremesinghe is expected to form a Cabinet and restore stability in the country, paving the way for a vote on account and a temporary budget.

images.alt_text: A handout photo made available by Sri Lanka's President Media Division shows Sri Lankan president Maithreepala Sirisena (R) taditionaly greeting re-appointed Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe (L) at the President Secretariat in Colombo, Sri Lanka, 16 December 2018.

site_title: It's a bitter end for sugar as investors line up for 2019 losses
summary: Brazil's sugar market is expected to continue its slump in 2019 due to a global supply glut, with futures having slumped 17% this year. Robust demand for ethanol in Brazil, the world's largest sugar grower and exporter, has been a backstop for the market, but this trend is expected to reverse as crude oil prices decline, making ethanol less attractive. As a result, cane millers may produce an additional 2-10 million metric tons of sugar in the 2019-20 season, leading to a potential record surplus and further price declines.

site_title: Miniature books aim to revolutionise reading on the go
summary: Penguin Random House is launching miniature books, dubbed "Penguin Minis," which can fit in a pocket or hand, aiming to revolutionize reading on-the-go. The inaugural set features four titles by bestselling author John Green, including "The Fault In Our Stars." Measuring 12cms by 8.2cms, the books have a hinged cover and ultra-thin paper, and are priced at S$20.87 each. The format, inspired by a Dutch patented design, has gained popularity in the Netherlands, and experts predict it will catch on in Singapore, despite concerns over price.

site_title: Indonesia Nov trade deficit reaches widest since July 2013
summary: Indonesia's trade deficit widened to US$2.05 billion in November, its largest since July 2013, due to a 3.28% decline in exports and a 11.68% increase in imports. Exports of manufactured goods dropped 7% from a year earlier, while imports reached US$16.88 billion. The country has been struggling to contain imports, with measures such as higher tariffs imposed to curb the trade gap and support the rupiah.

site_title: Qatar Fund building venture capital unit for US startups
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), is expanding its venture capital unit to invest in US startups. The fund has invested in companies such as Foursquare Labs, biotech firm Rubius Therapeutics, and Grail Inc., valuing them at over $1.3 billion. This marks a growing appetite for risk, with the fund opening an office in San Francisco to focus on the technology industry. Investments in Homology Medicines and Rubius have proven successful, with both companies going public this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,121.05, up 1.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.4% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,121.05. The market saw 164 gainers and 163 losers, with 564.7 million shares changing hands. Key gainers included Ezion Holdings, UOB, and DBS, which rose 4.08%, 2.76%, and 1.56%, respectively.

site_title: IHH 'evaluating' court's stay on Fortis bid; subscription for 31% stake in target unaffected
summary: The Indian Supreme Court has temporarily halted the acquisition of Fortis Healthcare by Malaysian IHH Healthcare Berhad, citing concerns over the sale process. Despite this, IHH's 31.1% stake in Fortis, acquired through a share subscription, remains unaffected. IHH is evaluating the order and seeking legal advice, with plans to make further announcements if necessary. The company's wholly owned subsidiary, Northern TK Venture, will not proceed with an open offer for Fortis until further orders are issued by the court and the Securities and Exchange Board of India.

site_title: Eddie Teo to take over as Council of Presidential Advisers chairman from J Y Pillay on Jan 2, 2019
summary: Eddie Teo will succeed J Y Pillay as Chairman of the Council of Presidential Advisers (CPA) on Jan 2, 2019, after a nearly 50-year public service career. Pillay, the longest-serving CPA chairman, is retiring after 14 years of advising three presidents. Teo, 71, will chair the council until June 1, 2020, and previously served as chairman of the Presidential Council for Religious Harmony.

site_title: China struggles to shed reputation as global capital of art copies
summary: China's reputation as a global capital of art copies is struggling. A 32-year-old Chinese artist created a $200 replica of Vincent Van Gogh's "The Starry Night" in one day from a cell phone image, not the original masterpiece valued at over $100 million. This incident highlights China's growing problem of art forgery, with many reproductions flooding the market. Authorities are working to crack down on the issue, but the problem persists, threatening China's reputation as a hub for authentic art.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed as sell-off eases; yuan steady
summary: Asia's stock markets opened mixed on Monday, following two weeks of losses driven by uncertain trade conditions. Treasury yields steadied, and the yen remained stable. US equity futures edged up, while Shanghai shares fluctuated. Investors will monitor the Federal Reserve meeting and Brexit developments, and the US government shutdown remains a concern. The yuan remained steady, and oil prices remained below US$52.

site_title: Want to buy a London home? Brexit isn't the only thing to watch
summary: London's property market is facing challenges despite Brexit uncertainty. Home values in the city have turned negative, with sales at a record low. The luxury market is experiencing a slowdown, with some estate agents reporting viewings are up but prices are not. Net immigration, a key driver of demand, may slow after Brexit. The tech industry, which previously fueled homebuying in London, is experiencing a downturn. Some big buyers are selling out, and construction activity is slowing. Even estate agents are struggling, with some going into administration.

site_title: Some Kotex tampons recalled after coming apart and leaving parts inside the body
summary: Kimberly-Clark has voluntarily recalled several lots of its U by Kotex Sleek Tampons due to a defect causing them to unravel, leaving pieces inside consumers' bodies. The recall affects specific lots manufactured between Oct. 7, 2016, and Oct. 16, 2018. Consumers have reported seeking medical attention and experiencing vaginal irritation and infections. Experts say most people do not have issues with tampons, but the recall highlights the importance of knowing one's body. The company urges consumers not to abandon tampons, citing the safety and reliability of reputable manufacturers.

site_title: Ukrainian arts enjoy surprise revival in conflict-riven east
summary: In eastern Ukraine, a surprise revival of Ukrainian arts has emerged amidst the conflict. Despite a four-year unofficial ban on the Ukrainian language, local youth continue to express themselves through music, singing in Ukrainian in a Russian-backed separatist stronghold. This defiance is a testament to the enduring spirit of Ukrainian culture in the face of adversity, highlighting the resilience of the Ukrainian people amidst the ongoing conflict.

images.alt_text: Ukrainians walk past a playbill of Gogol Fest in Azov Sea city of Mariupol. While prospects for a political resolution look remote, a fragile lull has allowed local residents to think of something more than survival.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.32% to 26,178.04, ahead of this week's Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.25% and 0.43%, respectively. Investors are seeking clues on interest rate hikes for next year.

site_title: NTUC Income names Morgan Stanley's Ronald Ong as board chairman
summary: NTUC Income appointed Ronald Ong, chairman and CEO for South-east Asia at Morgan Stanley, as its new board chairman, effective January 1, 2019. Ong, who joined the board in August, replaces Stephen Lee Ching Yen. Lim Boon Heng, chairman of NTUC Enterprise, expressed confidence in Ong's ability to lead the insurer to greater success. Ong said he is honored to serve as chairman and looks forward to working with the board to accelerate digitalization and growth.

site_title: Study finds chronic fatigue clues in overactive immune response
summary: Scientists studying chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) found clues in an overactive immune response. Researchers used interferon alpha to create a model of the syndrome and found that patients with hyperactive immune systems before and during treatment were more likely to develop severe fatigue. The study, led by Alice Russell of King's College London, suggests that people with exaggerated immune responses may be at risk of developing CFS. The findings offer a better understanding of the biology underlying the condition but do not provide a clear path for treatment or prevention.

images.alt_text: Sufferers are often bed-bound and unable to carry out basic daily activities like washing and feeding themselves.

site_title: MAS to double individual limit on Singapore Savings Bonds, allow purchases via SRS funds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will double the individual limit for holding Singapore Savings Bonds (SSB) to S$200,000, effective February 1, 2019. Additionally, SSB purchases will be allowed using Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) funds. This change is in response to public feedback, aiming to expand product options for SRS members and aid in retirement planning. The new individual limit applies to both cash and SRS-funded purchases.

site_title: China's outcast steel machines find unwelcome home in South-east Asia
summary: China's ban on induction furnaces in 2017 led to an influx of these machines in the Philippines and Indonesia, where domestic steelmakers face safety and environmental concerns. The two countries are ideal markets for the cheaper steel produced by these furnaces. The ban eliminated 140 million tonnes of capacity, comparable to the US and Germany's combined output. This has raised concerns about the impact on the region's steel industry and the environment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.86 points to 1,653.10. Losers outnumbered gainers 329 to 69, and volume reached 228.3 million lots worth RM98.6 million.

site_title: Deloitte Singapore appoints Cheung Pui Yuen as new country managing partner
summary: Deloitte Singapore has appointed Cheung Pui Yuen as its new country managing partner, effective January 1, 2019. Cheung, with over 29 years of public accounting experience, will succeed Philip Yuen, who will continue as CEO of Deloitte Southeast Asia and chairman of Deloitte Singapore. Cheung previously held roles as audit and assurance regional managing partner and Singapore deputy managing partner for operations.

images.alt_text: Cheung Pui Yuen, who is the Singapore deputy managing partner for operations, will assume his new role as country managing partner for the Singapore practice on Jan 1, 2019.

site_title: Australian shares edge lower as financials drag; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Monday, weighed down by losses in financials, while New Zealand shares dropped 0.5%. Financial stocks, including Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, declined 1-2.4% due to concerns over global growth and bank profitability. However, mining stocks rose, with BHP Group and Mineral Resources gaining 1.4% and 5.6% respectively. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting is expected to influence the market.

site_title: Singapore developers sell 1,198 private homes excluding ECs in November
summary: Singapore developers sold 1,198 private homes in November, more than 2.5 times the sales in October 2018 and 1.5 times the sales in November 2017. This surge in sales came with 1,341 new private homes launched in November, with top-selling projects including Parc Esta, Whistler Grand, and Kent Ridge Hill Residences. The median price for these sold units was S$1,699 psf.

site_title: Fed entering brave new policy world as rates near normal levels
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates for the fourth time in 2018, to 2.25-2.5%, as Chairman Jerome Powell charts a less certain path towards monetary policy normalization. The decision comes as the economy approaches a 10-year expansion, and economists expect the Fed to slow its rate-hiking campaign, boosting rates twice next year instead of three times previously. The move is likely to lead to more volatile financial markets, but may also reduce the target for President Trump's criticism.

site_title: China sees bankruptcies surge; bondholders may get less back
summary: China is experiencing a surge in bankruptcies, with at least five firms defaulting on publicly issued bonds since early November. Local courts have accepted or plan to accept these applications, aiming to resolve debt issues by 2020. However, bondholders may face losses, with average recovery rates for unsecured creditors potentially as low as 10-15%. China's government is encouraging a financial system where credit pricing reflects borrower risk, and bankruptcy proceedings will provide a swifter resolution for creditors, allowing them to learn how to fight for their rights via the legal system.

site_title: Police, firemen search for cause of explosion in Japan's Sapporo
summary: A building explosion in Sapporo, Japan, injured 42 people on Sunday night. The cause of the explosion is still unknown, but it may have involved propane gas tanks. Video footage showed flames and debris, with one man suffering burns to his face. Fire inspectors had previously warned that most tenants lacked evacuation gear and warning devices for electrical short circuits. The investigation is ongoing, with police and fire officials searching for the cause of the blast.

site_title: JGB yields touch over 5-month lows as growth fears keep markets on edge
summary: Japanese government bond (JGB) prices rose, with the benchmark 10-year yield falling to a 5-month low of 0.025%, as global growth concerns boosted demand for safe-haven debt. The 20-year and 30-year yields also dropped, reaching 0.540% and 0.770%, respectively. The move follows worries about slower global growth, particularly in China, which may impact policymakers and investors.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain ahead of Fed meeting; won weakens
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate meeting, with the won weakening. US consumer spending data bolstered expectations of a rate hike, despite moderating inflation. The Kospi index gained 3.34 points or 0.16% to 2,072.72, while the won fell 0.12% to 1,132.2 per US dollar. The stock market has declined 16.1% this year, but the current price-to-earnings ratio remains relatively stable.

site_title: Moroccan saffron farmers battle knockoff spices
summary: Saffron farmers in southern Morocco are battling counterfeit versions of the prized spice, threatening their business and reputation. The authentic spice, produced in the Berber city of Taliouine, is protected by a designation of origin (PDO) label, which guarantees its origin and uniqueness. Counterfeiters use chemical dyes and other plant remains to pass off poor quality saffron as top-shelf spice, selling it for significantly less. The issue is exacerbated by unregulated salesmen and middlemen, and authorities have warned buyers to only purchase from approved sellers.

site_title: Datapulse to buy Hotel Aropa in Seoul for 35b won
summary: Datapulse Technology has agreed to acquire Hotel Aropa in Seoul, South Korea, for 35 billion won (S$42.7 million). The acquisition is expected to complete by March 14, 2019, after a 10% deposit payment. The deal includes the entire land and building, as well as hotel assets, licenses, and employees. The acquisition marks a significant move by Datapulse into the hospitality sector.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.51% to 3,092.78
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.51% to 3,092.78. Financials led active index stocks, with United Overseas Bank, DBS Group Holdings, and OCBC Bank rising 0.6%, 0.1%, and 1.2% respectively. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 46, with 26.3 million securities worth S$67.3 million changing hands.

site_title: Halcyon Agri sets up online rubber trading platform with DBS taking minority stake
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation has set up a digital marketplace, HeveaConnect, for the trading of sustainably processed natural rubber, with DBS Bank taking a 9.9% stake for US$1 million. The platform aims to promote price transparency and connect stakeholders such as farmers, producers, and tyre manufacturers. HeveaConnect will also offer financing, insurance, and logistics services, and will be the exclusive platform for Halcyon's HEVEAPRO-certified TSR. The move is part of DBS's commitment to supporting sustainable business practices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on US Fed meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by investor focus on the US Federal Reserve meeting, which begins this week. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.18% to 21,413.89, while the Topix index increased 0.17% to 1,594.79. Analysts expect the meeting to influence the pace of rate hikes in 2019 and are monitoring the market's vulnerability to uncertainty. SoftBank's initial public offering on Wednesday is also expected to impact the market.

site_title: The Place Holdings appoints chairman's brother-in-law as chief operating officer
summary: THE Place Holdings appoints Meng Kuang-Yi, brother-in-law of executive chairman Ji Zenghe, as chief operating officer. Meng, 53, will oversee the group's overall operation and development. The company also announced that its deputy chief investment officer, Teo Sheng Yue, will leave on December 31, 2018, due to personal reasons.

site_title: Qatar buys Mexican oil takes from Eni
summary: Qatar Petroleum has signed a deal with Eni to buy stakes in three offshore oil blocks in Mexico, producing approximately 90,000 barrels of oil per day by 2021. The deal marks Qatar's global expansion, following its departure from Opec, and brings the company's operating countries to eight. This move is part of a larger trend of Middle Eastern producers exploring opportunities in the Americas, Africa, and the US.

site_title: Singapore's November non-oil exports fall 2.6% after October spurt
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 2.6% in November from a high base a year ago, after a 8.2% increase in October. This was a surprise to private-sector economists, who had expected a 1.8% year-on-year increase. The drop was largely due to a decline in non-monetary gold, specialised machinery, and petrochemicals.

site_title: Deep in the red: Chinese county pays price for vanity-project binge
summary: A Chinese county, Rucheng, in Hunan province, has spent 300 million yuan (S$60.5 million) on a "red tourism" project, transforming a village into an open-air museum dedicated to the Chinese Communist Party. Despite the large investment, the project has yet to produce a profit, and few tourists have visited. This is part of a trend of public spending on vanity projects in the county, which has built numerous public gardens, town squares, and office buildings in recent years, all of which have also failed to generate revenue.

images.alt_text: A man and a child ride a motorcycle on a plaza with a statue featuring the Chinese Communist Party emblem, in Shazhou village, Rucheng county, Hunan province, China. Rucheng, among China's poorest counties, and with a population of just 420,400 people, is under pressure to resolve US$1 billion in debt, following a decade of credit-fuelled vanity projects.

site_title: UK signs air service deal with Switzerland for post-Brexit flights
summary: The UK has signed an air service deal with Switzerland to ensure post-Brexit flights between the two countries. British transport minister Chris Grayling signed the agreement on Monday, amid uncertainty over Brexit. The deal aims to maintain air services despite the UK's potential exit from the EU without a deal. The UK aviation sector is expected to play a crucial role in the country's future as a global nation, with Grayling stating it will be "even more crucial."

site_title: Powerful blast at Japan restaurant injures 42
summary: A powerful blast at a restaurant in northern Japan's Sapporo city injured 42 people, starting fires that took hours to extinguish and causing several neighboring buildings to collapse. The cause of the blast remains under investigation, with police citing possible gas leaks. Several children were among the injured, and the building housing the restaurant was heavily damaged. No fatalities were reported, and no life-threatening wounds were sustained by the victims. The city government has opened a shelter for those affected, and firefighters took several hours to bring the flames under control.

site_title: US oil prices inch up, but global economic concerns weigh
summary: US oil prices rose 0.3% to $51.35 per barrel on Monday, driven by a decline in US drilling activity, but were limited by concerns about weaker economic growth globally. Opec and Russia agreed to reduce oil production by 1.2 million barrels per day, but prices remain uncertain as markets await evidence of the cuts' impact. Weakening growth in major economies, including China and Europe, also weighed on oil prices, with Chinese oil refinery throughput falling in November and French business activity contracting.

images.alt_text: US oil prices edged up on Monday amid a fall in drilling activity in the United States, but lingering concerns about weaker economic growth in major economies kept a lid on gains.

site_title: Macron government hopes yellow vest protests running out of steam
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's government hopes the recent drop in "yellow vest" protests signals the end of the crisis, but acknowledges "mistakes" were made. The protests, sparked by fuel tax hikes, have evolved into broader opposition to Macron. The government has conceded to holding referendums to decide policy and has announced a six-month consultation with civil society groups to discuss economic reforms. Macron's approval rating has slipped to 23%, with 45% of people expressing "very dissatisfied" with his leadership.

site_title: Turkey says Trump working on extraditing wanted cleric Gulen
summary: US President Donald Trump has told Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan that the US is working on extraditing Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Muslim cleric accused of orchestrating the 2016 failed Turkish coup. Gulen, who has lived in self-imposed US exile for nearly two decades, denies involvement. The development comes after Trump previously stated he was not considering extradition as part of efforts to ease pressure on Saudi Arabia over the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

site_title: Thousands protest 'slave law' in Budapest
summary: Thousands of people protested in Budapest against Hungary's new "slave law," which allows employers to demand up to 400 hours of overtime and delay payment by up to three years. The protest, attended by over 15,000, turned violent, with protesters throwing smoke grenades and police responding with tear gas. The law has sparked widespread outrage, with opposition parties and unions accusing the government of authoritarianism and steering the country towards a more repressive system. The protests have resulted in dozens of arrests and 14 police injuries, with the situation remaining tense.

images.alt_text: More than 15,000 people, according to local press reports, joined the demonstration - the first rally since Mr Orban returned to power in 2010 to bring together all opposition parties, from greens to the far right, under the same banner.

site_title: Australia government sees bigger budget surpluses ahead
summary: Australia's conservative government forecasts a budget deficit of A$5.2 billion for the fiscal year to June 2019, down from A$14.5 billion projected in May. The government expects a surplus by 2019/20 and A$30 billion in cumulative surpluses over the next four years. Prime Minister Scott Morrison's government attributes the improved numbers to a growing economy and record employment. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg predicts 3% economic growth and 5% unemployment in 2018/19, with wage growth expected to pick up to 3.5% by 2020/21.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AF Global, Datapulse, The Place Holdings, Lifebrandz, SIA Engineering
summary: Several companies saw new developments on Monday. AF Global sold its UK Crowne Plaza hotel for £84.4 million, resulting in a net gain of S$14.4 million. Datapulse Technology acquired Hotel Aropa in Seoul for 35 billion won (S$42.7 million). The Place Holdings appointed Meng Kuang-Yi as COO and announced a deputy COO's departure. Lifebrandz proposed a rights issue to raise S$2.18 million. SIA Engineering divested its stake in AMSA for A$4.5 million.

site_title: No-deal Brexit fears take heavy toll on UK housing market
summary: The UK housing market has been hit hard by Brexit fears, with asking prices falling for a second month in December, the steepest back-to-back declines since 2012. Actual selling prices also grew at their slowest annual pace in over 6.5 years in November. Average home prices rose just 0.9% to £305,522, the smallest annual increase since April 2012. London saw 19% fewer properties come to market, and fears of a no-deal Brexit have left the market uncertain.

site_title: New Mexican president allocates 464.4b pesos for state oil company to boost output next year
summary: Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador has allocated 464.6 billion pesos ($31.6 billion) for state-owned oil company Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) in 2019 to boost oil production and increase domestic fuel output. The budget includes a 26% increase in exploration and production investment, aiming to stabilize oil production at 1.847 million barrels per day. The goal is to reduce reliance on foreign fuel imports and build new refineries to increase domestic oil production.

site_title: BOJ watchers see economic risks pushing back rate-hike prospects
summary: The Bank of Japan is likely to wait until after Japan's sales tax hike next year to tighten monetary policy, as economic risks and market turbulence increase. 49 economists surveyed by Bloomberg expect no policy change at the Dec 19-20 meeting, with 88% forecasting no interest rate hike before 2019's end. Global market turbulence, a slowing global tech cycle, and the US-China trade war are major concerns. Only 6% of economists predict additional stimulus measures in 2019, and most expect the BOJ to allow 10-year bond yields to move by more than 20 basis points.

site_title: New Brexit vote would 'break faith' with British, says May
summary: Theresa May will tell parliament that a new Brexit referendum would "break faith" with British people, causing "irreparable damage" to politics. The move comes as the UK faces a deadlock over her EU withdrawal deal and the EU offers little in the way of concessions. May's opposition to a second referendum increases the risk of Britain leaving without a deal, potentially harming its economy.

site_title: Wickremesinghe returns as Sri Lanka PM as crisis nears end
summary: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has been sworn in for a fifth term after a political crisis that began in October when he was ousted by President Maithripala Sirisena. Wickremesinghe's reinstatement is seen as a victory for Sri Lanka's democratic institutions and the sovereignty of its citizens. The crisis was sparked by disagreements over policy matters and the president's refusal to accept no-confidence votes against Sirisena's preferred candidate, Mahinda Rajapaksa. Wickremesinghe's return is expected to end the crisis and bring stability to the country, with promises to improve the economy and standard of living for Sri Lankans.

site_title: North Korea warns US sanctions may "block path to denuclearisation"
summary: North Korea has warned the US that sanctions may block the path to denuclearization on the Korean peninsula, amid recent US sanctions on three senior North Korean officials. The US imposed the sanctions over human rights abuses, which North Korea considers a "deliberate provocation." The North Korean statement praises President Trump's efforts to improve relations but warns that increased pressure will lead to "the greatest miscalculation" and "block the path to denuclearization forever." The warning comes days after the US and North Korea's historic summit in Singapore, where a vaguely-worded denuclearization statement was signed.

site_title: AF Global sells London hotel for £84.4m
summary: AF Global has sold its full ownership rights to the Crowne Plaza London Kensington hotel for £84.4 million (S$146 million) in cash, representing a net gain of S$14.4 million. The sale was made to a selected buyer following a competitive bid process and will contribute to a 20% increase in the company's net asset value (NAV) at the end of the third quarter of 2018.

site_title: Lion Air and Boeing are heading into a US$22b feud
summary: A dispute is escalating between Lion Air, an Indonesian airline, and Boeing over the crash of a Lion Air 737 Max that killed 189 people in Indonesia. Lion Air's owner, Rusdi Kirana, has threatened to cancel a $22 billion order for Boeing planes due to what he sees as the manufacturer's unfair reaction to the crash. Boeing has denied the allegations, stating that Lion Air is a valued customer and is working closely with regulatory authorities to investigate the accident. The dispute highlights concerns about the safety of the 737 Max and the reliability of Boeing's bestselling plane.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's plans for solar energy have yet to see light of day
summary: Saudi Arabia's ambitious plans for renewable energy, including solar power, have yet to materialize. Despite announcing billions of dollars in investments and ambitious targets, construction has yet to begin on projects aimed at generating 10% of the country's electricity from solar and wind plants by 2023. The lack of progress has raised concerns about the kingdom's commitment to reducing its reliance on oil exports and mitigating climate change.

site_title: Emily Blunt puts spoonful of British class into Mary Poppins
summary: Emily Blunt brings her British class to the role of Mary Poppins in the Disney sequel, mirroring Julie Andrews' iconic performance. Blunt, known for her stiff upper lip, navigates the character's talking umbrella with ease. The film, which reimagines the classic, offers a fresh take on the beloved children's story.

site_title: Canada says China has granted consular access to second detainee
summary: Canada's foreign ministry announced that consular access was granted to Michael Spavor, the second of two men detained by China. Canadian Ambassador John McCallum met with Spavor, following the detention of Michael Kovrig. The detentions came after Canada arrested a senior Chinese executive on a US extradition request. Details of the detentions remain scarce, but the Canadian government is seeking the release of both men.

images.alt_text: Canadian Ambassador John McCallum met Michael Spavor, the statement said. Mr Spavor and Michael Kovrig were both picked up after Canada arrested a senior Chinese executive on a US extradition request.

site_title: China's US$20b new Egypt capital project talks fall through
summary: Talks between Egypt and Chinese builder CFLD for a US$20 billion development in the new administrative capital have ended due to disagreements on revenue sharing. Egyptian officials stated that the project's proposal was met with silence, effectively ending negotiations. The development, which spans 15,000 acres, was intended to be built over 25 years. The collapse of the talks marks a significant setback for the project, which had been in the works for two years.

site_title: Renault seeks Nissan shareholder meeting as Ghosn crisis deepens
summary: Renault is seeking a shareholder meeting with Nissan as the carmaker's standoff with Japanese alliance partner deepens amid the Carlos Ghosn pay scandal. Renault's deputy CEO, Thierry Bollore, requested the meeting in a letter, citing risks to Renault and the industrial alliance. Ghosn was arrested in Japan for alleged financial misconduct, and Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa has called for changes to weaken Renault's control. Renault owns 43.4% of Nissan, and a shareholder meeting would allow for governance discussions and disclosure.

images.alt_text: Renault requested a full Nissan shareholder meeting, a source close to the company said - appearing to escalate the carmaker's standoff with its Japanese alliance partner in the wake of the pay scandal engulfing Chairman and CEO Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: Calls for unified Parliament and referendum to avoid hard, no-deal Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal is expected to fail in Parliament, with calls for unity and a potential referendum gaining momentum. The deal's failure is attributed to unworkable promises made by Brexit right-wing politicians, leading to economic uncertainty and potential recession. The UK faces the prospect of sliding towards a national crisis unless a deal is agreed quickly, with corporate investment plans paused for two and a half years. A second referendum is also being proposed, with 68% of voters believing Jeremy Corbyn's Labour Party would not secure a better Brexit deal.

site_title: Shareholders call on ExxonMobil to set greenhouse gas reduction targets
summary: Institutional investors in ExxonMobil Corp, including the New York State Common Retirement Fund and the Church Commissioners of England, are calling on the oil company to set greenhouse gas reduction targets. The investors, who have previously pressured Exxon on environmental issues, want Exxon to disclose short, medium, and long-term targets to reduce emissions from operations and product use. This comes after other major energy firms, such as Royal Dutch Shell, have set similar targets. The investors plan to file a shareholder resolution for a potential vote at Exxon's 2019 shareholder meeting.

images.alt_text: A number of institutional investors in ExxonMobil Corp have said they will file a shareholder resolution which calls on the world's largest oil company to set targets for lowering its greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Coco Ichibanya opens its first European outlet in London
summary: Coco Ichibanya, a Japanese curry chain with over 1,100 restaurants globally, has opened its first European outlet in London's Covent Garden. The restaurant offers unique curry options with toppings such as fried chicken dumpling and bubble-fried salmon, and diners can choose from a range of heat levels. Indian chef Vivek Singh, who owns four UK restaurants, visited Coco Ichibanya and praised its cheese cubes in the Crazy Hot katsu chicken and cheese curry, but noted that Japanese curry lacks complexity and depth compared to Indian cuisine.

site_title: Cuba forecasts slow growth in 2019 as economic woes continue
summary: Cuba forecasts a slow 1% economic growth in 2019, the same pace as 2018, due to ongoing economic woes. The country's economy is hindered by Venezuela's economic collapse, declining export earnings, bad weather, and US sanctions. Cuba's economy minister, Alejandro Gil Fernandez, announced austerity measures will continue, including cuts in energy and fuel for state companies. Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel emphasized the need for domestic reforms and better ties with foreign investors to improve the economy.

site_title: Trade war: Small signs of progress in US-China talks
summary: US-China trade talks show signs of progress, with a 90-day tariff truce holding and no new threats from President Trump. This has lifted investor confidence, reversing 2018 losses on Wall Street. The absence of new threats has also calmed markets, despite recent tensions. The resolution of the trade dispute is seen as crucial to avoiding further global economic damage, with hundreds of billions of dollars in trade at stake. The outcome of the talks will be closely watched by investors and policymakers worldwide.

site_title: US companies woo workers to rural areas
summary: US companies are actively recruiting workers to fill skilled and unskilled positions in rural areas, addressing a significant workforce shortage. Alexandria Industries, a Minnesota-based component manufacturing company, is leading this effort through the "Not So Heavy Metal" tour, targeting middle and high school students. The initiative aims to introduce the public to manufacturing and attract workers to rural areas, where companies face challenges in filling job openings. This trend is expected to have a positive impact on rural economies and manufacturing sectors.

site_title: SIA Engineering Company to sell Australian unit for A$4.5m
summary: SIA Engineering Company announced it is selling its entire stake in Australian subsidiary Aircraft Maintenance Services Australia (AMSA) for A$4.5 million (S$4.5 million) to aircraft leasing company Heston Services Limited. The divestment is part of SIAEC's strategy to streamline operations and focus on high-growth areas. The sale is expected to result in a gain of about S$5.5 million for SIAEC and is not expected to impact its net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: SGX, CapBridge eye growth-stage companies
summary: Singapore Exchange-backed CapBridge has developed a licensed private stock exchange, 1exchange (1X), to facilitate deals between companies and investors on a single platform. The private exchange aims to give growth-stage companies greater access to investors, with a focus on companies with over $5 million in revenue. 1X allows for primary and secondary trading of private companies' securities, with companies not required to do a primary capital raise first. The exchange has seen significant interest from family-owned firms, which can use 1X for succession planning and liquidity.

site_title: Western tourists trickle into Saudi Arabia as it tries to open up
summary: Saudi Arabia has welcomed its first Western tourists since introducing a new visa system, with thousands visiting the historic Diriyah district for a Formula E motor sports tournament and concerts. The new "sharek" visa allows foreigners to visit for specific events, with around 1,000 receiving the permit. The move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to diversify the economy away from oil and increase tourism, with plans to lift spending to $46.6 billion by 2020. Despite concerns over human rights, many tourists expressed a desire to experience Saudi culture and see beyond the country's restrictive policies.

site_title: Uber welcomes, unions criticise UK plan to maintain flexible gig economy
summary: The UK government's response to a review into workplace rights has been welcomed by Uber, but unions have criticized the plans to preserve the gig economy business models. The plans would not require gig economy companies to provide workers with minimum wage and workplace rights, despite court losses by Uber and Addison Lee. The review aims to address concerns over workers' rights in the gig economy, with Uber and other companies set to continue operating under flexible models. The decision has been met with criticism from unions, who argue that workers are not receiving fair compensation.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies welcomed on Monday the British government's response to a review into workplace rights, which looks set to preserve the business models of gig economy companies, but unions rubbished the business ministry's plans.

site_title: 5G: A revolution not without its risks
summary: A recent diplomatic dispute over Huawei's 5G equipment highlights the technology's risks. 5G, set to be rolled out in 2020, promises faster data transmission and enables the Internet of Things and self-driving vehicles. However, it also poses concerns over security and potential risks. The technology's transition from telephony to objects is underway, with Asia and the US expected to be among the first to adopt it. As 5G becomes increasingly prevalent, experts are urging caution and careful consideration of its implications.

site_title: A cheery outlook for liquor sales as India drinks more premium spirits
summary: India's spirits market is expected to grow 10% annually due to the rising affluence of the middle class. The industry is projected to reach $55.9 billion by 2022, with premiumization driving growth. Radico Khaitan, a leading distiller, attributes the trend to a cultural change as the middle class emerges, with vodka consumption expected to triple over the next decade. The company aims to become debt-free by reducing debt to $3.7 billion and plans to have no working capital debt in the next year and a half.

images.alt_text: The rising affluence of India's middle class will drive growth of as much as 10 per cent a year in the US$33 billion spirits market, according to one of the nation's oldest distillers.

site_title: Free public transportation isn't for everyone
summary: Luxembourg is set to make all public transportation free by 2020, becoming the first nation to do so, in an effort to reduce congestion. However, experts argue that the problem lies not with public transport prices, but with the underpricing of driving. While cities like Dunkirk and Tallinn have seen increases in public transport ridership, the effect on congestion remains unclear. A better approach to reducing congestion may be to increase the cost of driving, but this is unpopular and difficult to implement. Investing in public transport improvements, such as park-and-ride lots and service extensions, may be a more effective way to address the issue.

site_title: SGD bond market may see more retail, infrastructure deals in 2019
summary: Singapore's SGD bond market is expected to see more retail and infrastructure deals in 2019, following a positive second half of 2018. Despite a 12% decrease in new issuances to S$21.8 billion, the market has seen higher inflows into fund managers and a strong reception for Temasek's maiden retail bond. The government is also considering providing guarantees for long-term borrowings by statutory boards and government-owned companies to fund infrastructure spending via the bond market. Volatility is expected to persist, but bankers are optimistic about the market's potential for growth in 2019.

site_title: Boeing opens first 737 plant in China amid trade war
summary: Boeing has opened its first 737 completion plant in China, a strategic investment to build a sales lead over Airbus in the country's rapidly growing aviation market. The US-based company has invested $33 million in a joint venture with state-owned Commercial Aircraft Corp of China to produce the plant, which will install interiors and paint liveries. The plant's inaugural ceremony was overshadowed by US-China trade tensions, but Boeing remains optimistic about the long-term prospects in China. The company aims to deliver 100 planes per year at the facility, which will help alleviate pressure on its Seattle-area 737 production site.

site_title: Disarray in Europe and US leaves a hole where 'the West' was
summary: A leadership vacuum in Europe and the US has created an opportunity for Russia's Putin and China's Xi Jinping to maneuver. Former NATO secretary-general Anders Fogh Rasmussen says the West's failure to respond to Russia's actions in the Sea of Azov has given Putin room to act. The lack of a shared Western vision on key issues has led to divisions, with the US and Europe disagreeing on how to deal with Iran and other global challenges. As the West's influence wanes, nations are charting their own paths, bringing opportunities for transformation but also raising concerns about the future of the Western alliance.

site_title: The best place to put money? Your mattress
summary: Financial markets are experiencing a downturn, with stocks, commodities, and bonds all performing poorly due to rising trade tensions and interest rates. The US economy remains strong, with low unemployment and steady growth, but the turmoil in financial markets is already affecting consumer spending and borrowing rates. Investors are becoming increasingly pessimistic, but experts say it's rare for all asset classes to perform poorly in a year. A study by JPMorgan Chase found that "2018 has delivered losses on almost every asset class and investing style."

site_title: Nations hammer out climate pact rules, but it's less than hoped for
summary: Nations agreed on a rulebook to implement the Paris climate treaty, but it falls short of ambitions to limit global temperature rises to well below 2°C. The deal, reached after marathon UN talks, aims to deliver the Paris goals, but world's most vulnerable countries expressed disappointment. Nearly 200 states finalized the common rulebook, designed to deliver the Paris goals, after marathon UN talks.

site_title: Huawei losing allies in Europe over growing security concerns
summary: The US push for European governments to block Huawei from telecom networks is gaining momentum, with key allies distancing themselves from the Chinese technology giant. France, UK, and Germany are reconsidering their relationships with Huawei due to concerns over Beijing's potential use of the company's equipment for spying. Huawei is facing significant reputational damage and is likely to lose share in the European market over the next three years, with the European Union considering stricter regulations and vetting of suppliers.

site_title: A painful 2019 forecast for emerging markets
summary: Analysts predict emerging markets will continue to be hurt by slower global growth and the Federal Reserve's tightening, with a multi-year process for adapting to less generous dollar liquidity conditions. Singapore-based strategist Jason Daw at Societe Generale believes the modest currency rally since September is temporary and expects a prolonged decline in developing-nation currencies. Daw attributes this to the ongoing impact of the 2019 forecast, which highlighted the potential for emerging markets to struggle.

site_title: China confronts its eternal dilemma
summary: China's top leaders will meet in Beijing to set economic policy objectives for 2019, amid concerns the country's economy is slowing. The central question is whether to prioritize growth over debt reduction, with some analysts predicting a stimulus package worth up to 10% of GDP. However, this may come at the cost of increasing the public deficit and potentially storing up bigger problems for the future. The government faces an uncomfortable position, weighing the need for near-term growth against the need to slow debt growth.

site_title: Commodities investors seek a return to fundamentals in 2019
summary: Commodities investors expect a return to fundamentals in 2019, driven by a subsiding US-China trade war and potential output cuts by Opec and its allies. Analysts at Goldman Sachs predict a recovery in commodities, citing strong demand growth and low inventories, which could boost prices. A decision by China to pump up its economy with stimulus measures could further support prices, particularly for copper and zinc. Gold prices are also expected to rise, driven by higher demand for defensive assets and central bank buying.

site_title: What's a growth stock here depends on who you ask
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) lacks high-growth tech stocks, making it challenging to define a growth stock. Analysts offer varying definitions, including companies like ComfortDelGro, Thai Beverage, and Raffles Medical Group, which expand through acquisitions. Phillip Capital expects growth for Y Ventures and Shopper360. Mohamed Nasser Ismail, head of capital market development at SGX, believes Catalist-listed firms represent high-growth stocks, as they can make time-sensitive acquisitions with shareholder approval. The Catalist platform enables companies to scale technology quickly, aiding their growth.

site_title: Hotel investors continue to bet on high-end segment
summary: Luxury hotel investors remain confident, with over $21 billion worth of high-end hotels changing hands in the 12 months through November, a 44% increase from the previous year. The expectation of a scarcity of high-end assets has driven room rate increases. LVMH's $2.6 billion deal to buy Belmond's trophy properties, such as the Hotel Cipriani and Copacabana Palace, reflects this confidence. Investors and brand operators are betting on the luxury segment, with Hyatt's acquisition of Two Roads Hospitality and Hilton's upcoming luxury brand launch.

site_title: Top Democrat Schiff adds calls for probe of Trump, Deutsche Bank links
summary: House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff calls for a probe into Deutsche Bank's ties with President Donald Trump's real estate business, citing the bank's payment of hundreds of millions of dollars in fines for laundering Russian money. Schiff questions the coincidence of Deutsche Bank being the only bank willing to do business with Trump Organization, and suggests it could be a form of "compromise." Schiff's comments come after Senate Democrats Elizabeth Warren and Chris Van Hollen also called for a Banking Committee investigation into Deutsche Bank's compliance with US money-laundering regulations.

images.alt_text: Representative Adam Schiff of California said on NBC's Meet the Press Sunday that any type of compromise needs to be investigated.

site_title: All eyes on Fed, Trump and US-China trade talks
summary: US markets await the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike forecast, with expectations of one hike in 2019, down from previous projections of three. The Fed's statement will also be scrutinized for clues on the policy path. Meanwhile, US President Donald Trump is facing a government shutdown deadline over border wall funding, but markets remain unperturbed due to previous similar threats. Trade tensions between the US and China appear to be easing, but investors remain cautious. Singapore's non-oil domestic exports for November are expected to contract, while China prepares for its annual Central Economic Work Conference.

site_title: S$24 million in buybacks; Medinex makes debuts on Catalist
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Straits Times Index declined 5.8% for the year, while the Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225 Index gained 0.8% and 0.9% respectively. Seventeen stocks conducted share buybacks, totaling S$24.3 million. Medinex, a Singapore-based medical services provider, debuted on SGX Catalist on Dec 7, raising S$5.32 million. Directors and substantial shareholders made various transactions, including UOB-Kay Hian Holdings chairman Wee Ee Chao increasing his stake to 27.93%, and Oxley Holdings executive chairman Ching Chiat Kwong acquiring 1.354 million shares. Other transactions involved companies such as LHT Holdings, Hong Lai Huat Group, and Thai Beverage PCL.

site_title: Solar companies say Trump's trade war recently 'took a toll' on them
summary: US solar companies report a 15% decline in new solar array installations between July and September 2018 due to President Trump's 30% tariff on foreign solar panels. The Solar Energy Industries Association blames the tariff for a slowdown in large-scale solar projects, resulting in $8 billion in lost investments and 9,000 job losses. Despite this, the industry still expects to grow, with solar installations projected to pick up in the final months of the year.

site_title: US sets new March 2 date for China tariff increases amid talks
summary: The US Trade Representative's office has changed the scheduled date of a tariff rate increase on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods from January 1, 2019, to March 2, 2019. The change was made amid ongoing talks between the US and China on trade and intellectual property. The new tariff rate will be 25% from 10%, but it does not affect the 25% tariff already in place on $50 billion worth of Chinese technology items. The US and China are pursuing negotiations with the goal of eliminating the acts and practices covered in the US investigation.

site_title: Shenzhen gets set for next-gen transformation
summary: Shenzhen, a 13 million-person city in China, is undergoing a transformation from a manufacturing hub to a high-tech innovator. The city, where China's reforms were first implemented 40 years ago, is now home to tech firms, startups, and corporations such as Huawei and Tencent. Talented individuals from abroad, including those from Silicon Valley, are flocking to Shenzhen to create innovative products. The city's government sets clear plans for innovation, providing a supportive environment for companies to develop and secure funding. Shenzhen's evolution from a manufacturing center to a hub for creativity and innovation is seen as a significant step forward for China's economic growth.

site_title: French luxury dynasty battle in court over Mona Lisa of Ferraris
summary: A French luxury leather dynasty is battling in court over the ownership of a vintage Ferrari 250 GTO, valued at tens of millions of euros, dubbed the "Mona Lisa of Ferraris." The car was given to the current owner, Patrick Bardinon, by his father in 1978 after a racing accident. However, his brother and sister claim he sold it for a record 38 million euros to a Taiwanese collector, sparking a bitter dispute over the car's rightful owner. The case was adjourned for a ruling on March 7 after Patrick Bardinon became ill in court.

site_title: Tech startups can save healthcare billions by getting patients to their medical appointments
summary: Tech startups are addressing a critical need in healthcare by providing non-emergency medical transportation, saving the industry billions in lost revenue. As the US population ages, demand for specialized transportation is increasing, with 30% of patients skipping doctor appointments due to transportation issues. Startups like RoundTrip, Circulation, and Kaizen Health have created online portals that connect patients with skilled drivers, reducing no-show rates and increasing access to care. These platforms aim to provide a more efficient and reliable transportation solution, especially for vulnerable populations such as the elderly, recovering addicts, and those with cognitive problems.

images.alt_text: RoundTrip staff have created an online portal that complies with federal regulations and makes it easy to find, book and track customised rides for patients. No-shows are reported to cost the healthcare industry as much as US$150 billion in lost revenue annually.

site_title: US dollar net longs fall
summary: US dollar net longs decreased to $28.48 billion in the week ending Dec. 11, a drop after a nearly two-year high. Speculators reduced their bets on a strong dollar, following a dovish Federal Reserve outlook. This shift in positioning is attributed to growing bearishness in the dollar, driven by concerns over inflation, the US-China trade saga, and potential rate hike pauses. The decline in net long positions signals a shift in investor sentiment, with some analysts predicting the dollar's reign as king of FX may be numbered.

site_title: More humans working alongside robots
summary: The use of robotics and artificial intelligence (AI) is being hailed as the fourth industrial revolution, with experts predicting significant growth potential in productivity and competitiveness. Companies are increasingly turning to AI to bolster productivity and stay relevant, with automation penetrating every sector of the economy. While some jobs may be displaced, new ones are expected to be created, with 54% of new jobs requiring new skills. Experts, including Amazon and Universal Robots, argue that automation can create more jobs, with Amazon adding 130,000 jobs globally since its acquisition of Kiva, and Universal Robots increasing productivity and hiring more workers.

site_title: UK govt to stop use of illicit money in property purchases by foreigners
summary: The UK government plans to introduce a new tool to combat foreign investment linked to corruption and crime, requiring wealthy individuals to prove they used legitimate income to purchase property. The "unexplained wealth orders" will be issued to those with ties to foreign public officials or suspected links to crime, and if unable to prove legitimacy, the property may be seized. This move aims to address concerns of foreign money fueling London's housing market, with prices driven beyond reach for local residents, and facilitating illicit conduct overseas.

site_title: Billionaire newly-weds to move into swanky home
summary: Billionaire newlyweds Isha Ambani and Anand Piramal are moving into a 50,000 square foot mansion in South Mumbai, despite Isha's father Mukesh Ambani's 400,000 square foot residence being eight times larger. The mansion, Gulita, was purchased by the Piramals for $62 million in 2012 and features a stunning glass facade and multiple steel structures. The lavish wedding, attended by high-profile guests including former US secretaries of state, was followed by widespread media attention in India, where many live in poverty, sparking debate about wealth and influence.

site_title: Apple will update iPhones in China to avoid a ban on sales
summary: Apple plans to update its iPhones in China to resolve a dispute with chip supplier Qualcomm, which has threatened to ban sales of older iPhone models due to patent infringement. A Chinese court ruled Apple must stop selling seven older iPhone models, but Apple has continued to sell them by updating their software. The update will change the iPhones' software to avoid infringing on Qualcomm patents. The move comes after Qualcomm asked the court to enforce its injunction and Apple faces potential bans on sales of its newest iPhones.

images.alt_text: Apple said it would update the software of iPhones in China to try to resolve a legal dispute that threatens to stop the company from selling older iPhones in the country.

site_title: Nissan probe into Ghosn puts scrutiny on 'CEO fund' and Dutch unit
summary: Nissan is investigating former chairman Carlos Ghosn's use of a "CEO Reserve" fund, which was allegedly used to pay for personal expenses, including family residences. Investigators are also looking into whether capital from subsidiaries was used for these purposes and whether payments were split to avoid detection. This probe is part of a broader examination of alleged financial misconduct. The investigation into Ghosn's use of the fund is separate from a separate probe into Nissan's Dutch unit.

site_title: Gold dips to one-week low as US dollar bounces on strong data
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-week low, dropping 0.4% to $1,237.60 per ounce, as the US dollar rose to a 19-month high following robust US economic data ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting. The strong dollar, which is expected to rise again if the Fed raises interest rates next week, has weighed on gold prices. Analysts say the focus will be on the Fed's outlook for 2019, which could limit gold price gains.

site_title: US Fed expected to hike rates; focus to shift to policy statement, new forecasts
summary: US stocks fell last week amid a trade war escalation and Brexit deal collapse, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average entering correction territory. Strategists predict the US Federal Reserve will hike interest rates, but the focus will be on the policy statement, new forecasts, and Chair's press conference. The Fed may signal a dovish hike, potentially boosting stock prices, but some economists doubt this will reassure markets. Consumer confidence may be impacted by the volatility, particularly for high-end consumers.

images.alt_text: Strategists said that the US Federal Reserve might yet save investors in domestic stocks from a red Christmas as it releases its latest policy statement this Wednesday.

site_title: Social enterprise accused of failing to pay freelancers, others
summary: A Singaporean startup, Imaginem, is accused of owing freelancers and a public relations firm over S$20,000 for months. The Ministry of Manpower has received a complaint and is following up with the company. Freelancers face challenges in enforcing payment due to unclear business models and limited property seizure options. The case highlights the risks gig workers and small firms face in chasing fees from fledging companies. A tribunal has ordered Imaginem to pay outstanding fees, but the process can be costly and time-consuming, often resulting in forgoing payment.

site_title: The bubble's losing air. Get ready for a crisis
summary: The "everything bubble" is deflating, posing a significant threat to the global economy. Weakening credit markets and rising borrowing costs in emerging markets, combined with trade conflicts and sanctions, are contributing factors. The slow deflation of the bubble should not underestimate the severity of the fallout. Investors are underestimating the impact of these risks, which include non-financial risks such as political instability and Brexit. This deflation could lead to a crisis, highlighting the need for policymakers to take action to mitigate its effects.

site_title: Obamacare thrown out by judge, raising insurance uncertainty
summary: A Texas federal judge struck down Obamacare, ruling the Affordable Care Act unconstitutional after Congress repealed a key provision, the tax penalty for not buying insurance. The decision, made just before the end of the 2019 open enrollment period, casts uncertainty on insurance coverage for millions. The ruling is expected to be appealed to the Supreme Court, with California and other Democratic states planning to file an appeal. The decision threatens to throw millions off health insurance rolls and reverse Medicaid expansion and tax credits.

images.alt_text: Obamacare was struck down by a Texas federal judge in a ruling that casts uncertainty on insurance coverage for millions of US residents.

site_title: Retail sales show US consumer keeping foot on growth pedal
summary: US retail sales rose 0.2% in November, beating forecasts, driven by consumer spending and lower fuel prices. The control group subset showed a 0.9% gain, the most in a year, indicating a strong underlying demand. This growth will help offset stagnant manufacturing output, which missed forecasts, and a slowing global economy. Analysts raised their GDP growth estimates, but a gauge of recession expectations increased to 20% from 15%. The retail sales gain also supports the case for further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: US Fed to hike again but hints at pause in 2019
