summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates this week, but policymakers are signaling a potential slowdown in 2019 due to waning growth, a trade war, and tame inflation. Economists have cut forecasts for the number of rate hikes next year to one or two from four, with some Fed officials arguing they should signal they are close to the end of the tightening cycle. The Fed's decision will depend on economic data, and a pause in rate hikes could be a cautious approach to address uncertainty in the global economy.

site_title: As Brexit muddles along, Trump roots for a full break
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed support for a full break from the European Union, contrasting with Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal, which he deemed "a great deal for the EU". Trump's views are seen as a shift from his predecessor Barack Obama, who warned Britain would be at the "back of the queue" for a US trade deal if it left the EU. Trump's "America First" policy and desire to strengthen the US-Britain special relationship are driving his support for a hard Brexit, which could lead to a trade deal between the two countries.

site_title: Andrew Frierson, pioneering black opera singer, dies at 94
summary: Andrew Frierson, a pioneering black opera singer, died at 94. He made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall in 1948 and performed with the New York City Opera for six seasons. Frierson also sang at the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, accompanying Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech. His legacy as one of the first generation of black opera singers to gain recognition is cemented.

site_title: Oceans of garbage prompt war on plastics
summary: Environmentalists say the world is waking up to tackle plastic pollution at its source, following images of turtles smothered by plastic bags, garbage-filled beaches, and floating trash in oceans. The Ocean Conservancy's chief scientist, George Leonard, states that plastic is gaining attention, with stories on social media bringing plastic pollution into the spotlight. This growing awareness is prompting a global response to address the issue, as the world moves towards a zero-waste future.

site_title: Noble Group restructuring gets green light in Bermuda court
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, has secured approval from a Bermuda court to complete its restructuring deal. The court appointed a provisional liquidator to oversee the plan, which aims to avoid liquidation and allow Noble to emerge from its debt pile of US$3.5 billion. The decision comes after a Singaporean investigation blocked Noble's preferred plan for a consensual debt deal. The restructuring process, which could take effect as early as next week, represents a "light at the end of the tunnel" for Noble and its creditors.

site_title: China jails boss of 100b yuan pyramid scheme for inciting protests
summary: A Chinese court has sentenced the founder of a 100 billion yuan pyramid scheme, Zhang Tianming, to 17 years in jail for inciting protests and disturbing social order. Zhang's company, Shan Xin Hui, had promised investors high returns on projects to help the poor, but instead paid out early members using funds from new joiners. The scheme involved nearly 6 million people and over 100 billion yuan. Zhang and nine other executives received prison sentences ranging from 10 to 18 months. The scheme was shut down after a rare street protest in Beijing last year.

site_title: Has technology been made too easy to use?
summary: Mark Zuckerberg introduced a "frictionless" design for Facebook seven years ago, allowing apps to post directly to users' feeds without permission. This trend has become an obsession in the tech industry, with many companies aiming to eliminate complexity and difficulty from their products. However, critics argue that this has led to problems such as the spread of misinformation on social media, as users are no longer prompted to verify information before sharing it. The frictionless design has had unintended consequences, raising questions about the trade-off between ease of use and responsible online behavior.

site_title: China's home-price growth eases amid lacklustre buyer demand
summary: China's home-price growth slowed to 0.98% in November, down from 1.02% in October, marking the fifth straight month of gains above 1%. New-home prices rose despite slower sales growth and deeper discounts offered by developers. Analysts believe the property market may be nearing a correction, with mortgage rates breaking a 22-month rising streak and expectations of further easing sending a major builder's index up 10% since November. This may signal a more favorable stance from the government regarding property market curbs.

site_title: Bean there, done that
summary: Mr Bean, a Singapore-based soya bean chain, is expanding its menu with creative new items and plans to aggressively franchise overseas through its online-to-offline sales strategy. The company is doubling down on research and development, introducing items such as soya granola bars, and is also exploring the e-market space with online sales through e-commerce platforms. To tackle manpower challenges, Mr Bean is investing in training its workforce, including senior citizens, and is open to letting professionals run the business in the future. The company aims to maintain its growth momentum in the coming year, with plans to open more stores in Singapore and abroad.

site_title: Oil drops 2% on Wall St losses, weak China data
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Friday, led by falling US stock markets and weak economic data from China, which pointed to lower fuel demand. Brent crude futures fell to $60.28 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $51.20 a barrel. Global benchmark Brent posted a weekly loss of 2.3%, while WTI declined nearly 2.7%. Concerns about an oversupplied market led to a 1.2 million barrel per day output reduction agreement among OPEC and other oil producers.

site_title: LifeBrandz to undertake rights issue at S$0.007/share
summary: LifeBrandz is proposing a rights issue of up to 325.9 million new shares at S$0.007 each, representing a 46.2% discount to its last closing price. The issue aims to finance the expansion of its food and beverage business, including opening new Hashida Sushi restaurants in San Francisco and Asia. The rights issue will raise S$2.18 million, and if fully subscribed, will increase the company's share capital to 977.6 million shares.

site_title: Rupiah sovereign bonds beckon
summary: Indonesia offers a vast population and low penetration of financial services, creating a captive demand for economic growth. However, the rupiah's volatility, particularly against foreign currencies, makes it challenging for foreign investors to take a long-term stance. Despite a 16% return in local currency over the past two years, investors are cautious until the country's foreign reserves and current account improve, indicating structural stability. With a young demographic and low banking penetration, Indonesia's sovereign bonds may beckon investors seeking a stable investment opportunity.

site_title: Facebook says bug opened access to private photos
summary: Facebook announced a bug that allowed outsiders to access private photos of 6.8 million users, potentially affecting 1,500 third-party apps that accessed the photos from September 13 to September 25. The company has fixed the issue and notified affected developers, but the incident raises questions about whether Facebook violated a 2011 consent decree with the Federal Trade Commission. The incident is under investigation by the Irish Data Protection Commission, which could lead to a fine of up to $1.63 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares on track for worst quarter since 2011
summary: European shares closed lower for a second day, with the euro zone Stoxx 600 index down 0.72% and on track for a 9.5% loss in the quarter. Weak data from China and a summit in Brussels where EU leaders told Theresa May they wouldn't renegotiate the Brexit agreement contributed to the decline. The European Central Bank also cut forecasts for economic growth and inflation. The Stoxx 600 index has not seen a quarterly loss this bad since 2011, amid concerns about global growth and US-China trade talks.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for last week's tanker and dry bulk market reveals a positive end to the week after an uncertain start. Rates recovered for West Australia/China, with some gains reaching the high $8.00s, and rumors of $9.00 for prompt positions. In the Panamax market, news of fresh concluded sales into China boosted sentiment, with improving rates in the North. The Supramax market showed strong gains, with China buying US soybeans supporting the market. The Handysize market recorded a similar level as in December 2017, with rates improving in the East Coast South America market.

site_title: SingPost names Vincent Phang as new Singapore chief
summary: SingPost has appointed Vincent Phang as its new CEO and Singapore head, effective April 1, 2019. In this role, he will oversee postal services, parcels, and logistics for the Singapore business.

site_title: Pricier than gold, and in your engine
summary: Palladium, a rare and expensive metal, has surpassed gold as the most valuable precious metal, with prices reaching a record high of $1,255.12 an ounce. The metal's surge is attributed to increased demand for catalytic converters in vehicles, driven by antipollution legislation and global trade negotiations. Despite a tight supply, experts predict palladium will remain in high demand, with demand expected to outstrip supply by 1.2 million ounces in 2018. The price spike is also influenced by strikes in South Africa and Russia, which have impacted platinum mining and reduced palladium production.

site_title: SIA Engineering divesting Australian subsidiary for A$4.5m
summary: SIA Engineering Company is divesting its Australian subsidiary, Aircraft Maintenance Services Australia (AMSA), for A$4.5 million in cash to Heston Services Limited. AMSA provides line maintenance services in major Australian airports, but has a negative net tangible asset value of A$1.1 million. This decision comes after SIA Engineering's audited financial statements for 2018 showed a negative net tangible asset value. The divestment aims to reduce costs and improve the company's financial performance.

site_title: The cost of Trump's tariffs on technology? US$1b a month
summary: US companies paid an additional $1 billion in tariffs on technology products imported from China in October, a 7-fold increase from the previous year, due to the Trump administration's new duties. The tariffs, imposed since July, cover goods like printed circuit boards, computer servers, and vacuum cleaners. A new round of talks between the US and China has raised hopes for a lasting truce, with the US agreeing to delay raising tariffs on $200 billion of imports. The talks aim to reach a deal on "structural changes" to China's economy by March 1.

site_title: Seriously, Prada, what were you thinking?
summary: Prada apologized and dismantled a display at its New York Soho boutique featuring a charm resembling a Golliwog, a 19th-century blackface character, and the title character from Little Black Sambo, a children's book with racist connotations. The display sparked public complaints, leading to the removal of the offending charm and a company-wide apology. This incident highlights the ongoing issue of racist imagery in the fashion industry, with similar incidents reported in the past. The incident serves as a reminder of the need for greater sensitivity and awareness in branding and advertising.

site_title: France set for more 'yellow vest' protests despite Macron concessions
summary: Thousands of "yellow vest" protesters are expected to take to the streets in France on Saturday, a month after the start of their protest movement. President Emmanuel Macron's recent tax and wage concessions have failed to quell the unrest, with the nation split 50-50 on whether protests should continue. The demonstrations have resulted in violent clashes, roadblocks, and massive traffic jams, damaging France's image and Macron's government. The movement's leaders have urged protesters to turn out, particularly in Paris, to pressure the government into further concessions, despite Macron's call for calm and order.

site_title: Merry Grinchmas, ethically speaking
summary: A satirical article discusses the challenges of making ethical consumer choices in the global marketplace. It highlights the difficulties in tracking down responsible purchasing decisions, citing examples of misleading labeling and hidden supply chain risks. The article questions who should bear the costs of ethical behavior, whether consumers, shareholders, or corporations. It concludes that a simple, minimalist lifestyle may be the most effective way to assuage conscience, but acknowledges the temptation of consumerism and the hypocrisy of those who practice it.

site_title: Developer sees India cash crunch toppling weaker peers
summary: India's largest listed property developer expects smaller peers to go bankrupt due to a cash crunch. Weaker balance sheets will struggle to access the bond markets amid investor caution over default risks. Larger developers are paring assets to get through the crisis, while smaller ones are seeking partnerships with larger companies. This may make it harder for developers to repay $4.9 billion of debt due in 2019.

site_title: China's economy slows sharply, in challenge for Xi
summary: China's economy has slowed sharply, with weak growth in monthly retail sales and industrial production, sparking concerns for top leader Xi Jinping. The slowdown, the worst since the global financial crisis a decade ago, may be attributed to a prolonged downturn rather than the US trade war. Xi faces a diplomatic balancing act, detaining Canadian nationals in apparent retaliation, while easing environmental controls to boost business confidence. The US, however, senses an advantage, with President Trump tweeting that China's economy is growing slower due to the trade war.

images.alt_text: China's consumers and businesses are losing confidence. Car sales have plunged. The housing market is stumbling. Some factories are letting workers off for the big Lunar New Year holiday two months early.

site_title: New real estate sectors reflect changing lifestyles in Asia
summary: In Asia, the growing demand for real estate reflects changing lifestyles, with over 700 million citizens aged 15-24 and a rapidly aging population by 2050. New sectors like student housing, co-living, and senior living are emerging, offering higher yields and diversification opportunities for investors. In Singapore, the aged care sector is growing rapidly, while co-living is becoming a hub for millennials due to rising property prices and transient expatriate populations. The living sectors are expected to outperform traditional residential investments due to efficient use of space and superior building management, with estimated returns ranging from 8-14%.

site_title: T-Mobile, Sprint see Huawei shun clinching US deal: sources
summary: US wireless carriers T-Mobile and Sprint expect their merger deal to be approved by the US Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) as early as next week after their foreign owners, Deutsche Telekom and SoftBank, agreed to stop using Huawei equipment. The US government has been pressuring Deutsche Telekom and SoftBank to remove Huawei from their networks due to concerns over national security. This move is seen as a significant step towards clearing the $26 billion merger deal, which has been delayed by the Huawei controversy.

site_title: Duck & Hippo founder sets another record price for shophouse

AHTC scored amber ratings in estate maintenance and corporate governance, with specific issues identified, including delayed expense recording and non-compliance with Town Councils Financial Rules. The ministry is reviewing the Town Council Management Report to better reflect residents' experience, with updates to estate cleanliness and maintenance indicators.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 1% to 3,081.18
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 1% to 3,081.18 as of 9:04am. The most actively traded stocks were Ezion Holdings and Golden Agri-Resources, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB also experiencing declines. Losers outnumbered gainers 77 to 31, with about 46 million shares worth S$74 million changing hands.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Delong, Lorenzo
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include SingPost, which announced Vincent Phang as its new CEO, replacing Woo Keng Leong, effective April 1, 2019. Mapletree Industrial Trust plans to buy a mixed-use property for S$268.3 million, funded by debt. No financial decision has been made yet.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won sag as tech shares fall amid global uncertainties
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1.44% to 2,065.38, as tech shares declined amid global uncertainties. The European Central Bank forecast a slowdown in the euro zone, and South Korean bond yields dropped. China investigated a Canadian businessman on suspicion of harming national security, amid an escalating diplomatic row. ECB President Mario Draghi stated the balance of risk is moving to the downside due to geopolitical and financial uncertainties.

site_title: Australian shares fall, set for first drop in four; NZ down too
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Friday, tracking losses in US indexes, as cautious optimism over US-China trade relations dissipated. The S&P/ASX 200 index slid 0.5% and the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.5% for the first time in three sessions. Global economic and social worries continue, with the trade war between the US and China remaining a key risk. Australian shares have lost about 9% this quarter, on track for their steepest quarterly drop since 2011.

site_title: EU gives May assurances on Brexit, but cold comfort
summary: European Union leaders have assured Prime Minister Theresa May that the Brexit treaty she agreed to last month should not bind Britain forever to EU rules. The EU leaders, meeting in Brussels, pledged to work speedily on a subsequent agreement to establish alternative arrangements by December 31, 2020, to avoid the "Irish backstop" clause. However, it is unclear if this assurance will be enough to win parliamentary approval for the deal, with many diplomats expecting further high-stakes talks in the new year.

site_title: SilkAir to boost services to Cairns to daily flights from June 2019
summary: SilkAir, the regional arm of Singapore Airlines, will increase its flights to Cairns, Australia, from five to daily, starting June 2, 2019. The additional flights will be operated on Tuesdays and Sundays with Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft, boosting visitor numbers to 10,200 over two years and supporting up to 240 jobs. This move follows significant demand growth, supported by the state's Attracting Aviation Investment Fund.

site_title: China's year of adversity costs stock investors US$2 trillion
summary: China's stock market has lost US$2 trillion in value in 2018 due to a series of misfortunes, including a national vaccine scandal, decline in consumer spending, and the Trump administration's crackdown on Chinese tech. The CSI 300 Index is on track to drop 10% or more, one of the broadest sell-offs since the global financial crisis. Key sectors affected include technology, consumer, and education, with some companies experiencing declines of up to 58% this year. The losses are attributed to slowing economic growth, record corporate defaults, and China's strained relationship with the US on trade.

site_title: Japan business confidence unchanged in December quarter: BOJ
summary: Japan's business confidence among major manufacturers remained unchanged in the December quarter, staying at 19, following a decline for three consecutive surveys. The impact of natural disasters such as earthquakes and typhoons has receded, but concerns over the US-China trade dispute continue to weigh on corporate confidence. The index for non-manufacturers rose to 24 from 22 in the previous quarter, indicating a slight improvement in overall sentiment. Economists expect corporate confidence to remain cautious in the short term.

images.alt_text: Confidence among Japan's biggest manufacturers was unchanged this quarter after slipping for three consecutive surveys, central bank data showed on Friday.

site_title: Art Pages
summary: Phaidon, a premier publisher, is releasing a collection of 10 Contemporary Artists Series books featuring artists such as Ai Weiwei, Frank Stella, and Jannis Kounellis. The collection, priced at S$375, includes interviews, essays, and photographs of the artists' work. The bundle is available for shipping to Singapore and includes titles on Sterling Ruby, Yin Xiuzhen, and others.

images.alt_text: Ai Weiwei, Frank Stella and Jannis Kounellis.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal to join Federer in 2019 Laver Cup
summary: Tennis star Rafael Nadal will join forces with Roger Federer for the third edition of the Laver Cup in Geneva next year. The team event pits Europe against the World, with Nadal and Federer, two of the greatest players in men's tennis, forming Team Europe. This will be their third team-up, following their successful doubles match at the 2017 Laver Cup in Prague. Team Europe's non-playing captain Bjorn Borg sees this as a boost for the competition, citing the duo's unbeatable combination as a key factor in their potential to win the Laver Cup for the third consecutive year.

site_title: LVMH close to US$2.6b deal to buy Belmond: WSJ
summary: LVMH is close to acquiring Belmond Ltd in a deal valued at approximately US$2.6 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. The French luxury-goods company is expected to pay US$25 per share in cash, representing a 42% premium over Belmond's closing price. A deal could be announced as early as Friday.

site_title: Facebook teaches New Yorkers about privacy at 'pop-up' kiosk
summary: Facebook held a pop-up kiosk in New York's midtown holiday market to educate users about privacy and data protection. The event, a first for the US, aimed to address concerns following revelations about data manipulation and leaks. Facebook employees provided advice on adjusting privacy settings and explained data collection and targeted advertising. The move follows similar events in London and comes amid boycotts and investigations worldwide, including the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

site_title: Brazil airline Avianca Brasil in talks for cash boost since before bankruptcy filing
summary: Brazilian airline Avianca Brasil is in talks for a cash injection since before filing for bankruptcy, according to controlling shareholder German Efromovich. The airline faces debts to lessors and suppliers of $100 million and $125 million, respectively, after losing planes in disputes. A judge granted bankruptcy protection on Thursday, and negotiations are underway to secure a loan. Efromovich praised a new decree allowing a 20% foreign investment ceiling in Brazilian airlines, which may aid the airline's financial struggles.

images.alt_text: Brazil's fourth-largest airline, Avianca Brasil, has been in talks for a much-needed cash injection since before it filed for bankruptcy on Monday, German Efromovich, whose family controls the carrier, told Reuters.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Roxy-Pacific to 'hold' on strong property sales
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Roxy-Pacific Holdings to 'hold' citing strong property sales despite recent cooling measures. Analysts lowered the target price to S$0.39, considering potential headwinds from new property measures have been priced in. The group's shares traded below their historical average, indicating analysts believe the market has already factored in potential challenges. However, DBS remains cautious on the stock and sector due to an expected property market slowdown.

site_title: Aquaculture tech startup Umitron snags US$2m funding for Peru project
summary: Umitron, a Singapore-Japan aquaculture tech startup, has secured US$2 million funding from IDB Lab to improve productivity in Peru's Lake Titicaca trout farming industry. The project aims to increase economic and environmental sustainability through AI-driven feeding technology. Umitron's AI feeding technology has the potential to reduce worker safety risks and harmful algae blooms. The project is part of Umitron's long-term plans to develop technology for Latin American aquaculture producers, with the goal of implementing data-driven aquaculture feeding technology across the region.

site_title: SingPost names Singapore chief, reports seasonal parcel surge
summary: SingPost has announced Vincent Phang as its new CEO, effective April 1, 2019, replacing Woo Keng Leong. Phang, 45, will oversee postal services, parcels, and logistics in Singapore. The company reported a surge in parcel volumes during the year-end peak season, with 580,000 parcels delivered locally in November, a 24% increase compared to non-peak months. To cope with the volume, SingPost increased staff and extended courier hours.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Post (SingPost) announced on Friday that Vincent Phang will be the new CEO of postal services as well as its Singapore head, with effect from April 1, 2019.
Singapore Post (SingPost) announced on Friday that Vincent Phang will be the new CEO of postal services as well as its Singapore head, with effect from April 1, 2019.

site_title: Janet Jackson gets Rock Hall of Fame place on Brit-heavy list
summary: Janet Jackson, 52, was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as part of a record-breaking British lineup, alongside Stevie Nicks and five British bands: Def Leppard, Roxy Music, Radiohead, The Cure, and The Zombies. This marks the largest British presence in the hall's 33-year history. Janet Jackson, the younger sister of the late Michael Jackson, finally earned her place in music history after years of anticipation.

site_title: Starbucks sales growth to be steady despite UberEats deal, plans for China expansion
summary: Starbucks forecasts steady same-store sales growth between 3% and 4% annually, despite partnering with UberEats for delivery and expanding in China, where it plans to nearly double its outlets to 6,000 stores over four years. The company's shares fell 3% after the announcement. Despite these efforts, Starbucks faces severe competition from smaller coffee chains offering exotic coffees and fresh food, and its global same-store sales growth is expected to be in line with a forecast of 3% to 5% this year.

site_title: China Taisan judicial managers can't obtain key records, seek time to report financials
summary: China Taisan judicial managers BDO are seeking an extension to report the fabric maker's financials due to difficulties in obtaining key records. They have been in preliminary discussions with potential investors. The Singapore Exchange has given BDO two months to announce financial results for fiscal 2018. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority is reviewing an application to extend the deadline for convening the annual general meeting and laying 2017 financial statements. BDO was initially appointed as interim judicial managers in July.

site_title: US mortgage activity hits 2-month high as interest rates fall
summary: US mortgage applications surged 1.6% in the latest week, driven by declining interest rates, which fell to their lowest levels since September. The Mortgage Bankers Association reported a 1.8% increase in refinancing applications. This marks the strongest reading since October and comes amid worries about slowing economic growth and trade tensions. The 30-year conforming mortgage rate dropped 8 basis points to 4.96%, its lowest level since September. This increase in loan requests and refinancing applications suggests a potential boost to the housing market.

site_title: Grab gets US$150m investment from Yamaha
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing service, has received a US$150 million investment from Yamaha Motor Co. The collaboration aims to expand Grab's reach in South-east Asia, particularly in Indonesia, where it will compete with local startup Go-Jek. This investment follows Toyota's US$1 billion investment and Hyundai's US$250 million investment earlier this year. The partnership will enable Grab drivers to buy motorbikes and leverage Yamaha's technology in future product development, with a focus on autonomous robo-taxis to reduce individual car ownership.

site_title: Kicks For Autobots
summary: Puma and Hasbro have collaborated on an exclusive Transformers capsule collection, featuring tracksuits, tees, and accessories for adults and kids, as well as two limited-edition sneakers inspired by Optimus Prime and Bumblebee. The shoes, designed in the colors of the Autobots, take on the RS-X silhouette and will be available at PUMA Select MBS and Footlocker starting December 14, priced from S$35 to S$195. The collection is set to drop in time for the opening of the Bumblebee spin-off movie.

site_title: New Audi CEO says headwinds will only intensify after turbulent 2018
summary: Audi's new CEO, Bram Schot, warns that the company faces intensified headwinds in 2019 after a tumultuous 2018, marked by the arrest of former CEO Rupert Stadler in the diesel-emissions scandal. Schot calls for a cultural change and image polishing, emphasizing the need for transformation and employee collaboration. The company's financial muscle is crucial to support parent company Volkswagen's investments in electric vehicles and digital offerings. Audi's global deliveries slumped 17% last month, and the company's operating profit margin fell to 6.5% in the first nine months of 2018.

site_title: US: Wall Street grinds out split finish as volatility persists
summary: US stocks ended the day with a split finish, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% and the S&P 500 closing essentially flat. The Nasdaq fell 0.4% for its first negative close in four days. Shares in General Motors sank 1.6% after President Trump criticized the company's plans to cut jobs. In contrast, General Electric rose 7.2% after an analyst upgrade, and Procter & Gamble jumped 2.6% following a Bank of America upgrade. The major indices remain negative for the year due to volatility and concerns over economic growth.

site_title: Personally Yours
summary: Consultant Jennifer Zheng has started an online store, Au Clair De La Plume by J.Z, offering personalized calligraphy-penned gifts on various products, including tumblers, makeup pouches, and tote bags. The items are made from color-fast materials and have been well-received, particularly during Christmas. Zheng's unique touch adds a personal element to gifts, making them stand out from mass-produced products. Her store is available at auclairdelaplumebyjz.com.

site_title: Irish parliament votes to legalise abortion
summary: The Irish parliament passed legislation allowing abortions for the first time, permitting terminations up to 12 weeks of pregnancy or in cases of risk to the pregnant woman's life or health. The law also allows terminations in cases of foetal abnormality leading to the death of the foetus. The move was hailed as a "historic moment" by Prime Minister Leo Varadkar, following a landmark referendum earlier this year.

site_title: US prosecutors probing Trump inauguration spending: WSJ
summary: US federal prosecutors are investigating whether President Donald Trump's inaugural committee misspent some of the record $107 million it raised from donors. The investigation, led by the Manhattan US attorney's office, is examining potential exchanges of money for policy concessions. Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani denied the president's involvement, while the White House said the inauguration had nothing to do with Trump or his wife, Melania. The probe stems from materials seized in a separate investigation into former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen's dealings, including hush payments to women claiming to have had affairs with Trump.

site_title: Europe: Shares end 2 days of gains as ECB, Brexit sap confidence
summary: European shares fell on Thursday, snapping a two-day rally, as concerns about euro-zone growth and the UK's Brexit weighed on investors. The ECB trimmed its growth forecasts, and the UK's Prime Minister Theresa May survived a leadership challenge, increasing the chances of a soft Brexit. Despite this, the outcome of the final deal remains uncertain, prolonging market uncertainty. The Stoxx 600 benchmark index fell 0.2%, while German and French bourses declined, offsetting positive signs in the US-China trade war.

site_title: Australian regulator casts doubt on telco mega-merger, shares slammed
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has expressed concerns that a proposed A$15 billion telco mega-merger between Vodafone and TPG Telecom may harm competition, leading to higher prices and less innovative plans. The ACCC stopped short of blocking the deal but warned that removing two major players from competing in each other's markets could lead to negative outcomes. Shares in TPG and Hutchison fell 17% and 21%, respectively, amid investor concerns. A final decision is set for March 28, 2019.

site_title: Developers use 'try before you buy' tactic to induce luxury home buyers
summary: Developers are adopting a "try before you buy" approach to attract high-end home buyers, offering luxury trial stays at various price points. These stays, often lasting four nights, can cost up to $2,000 per night and may include amenities like cultural tours, luaus, and spa treatments. The goal is to give potential buyers a sense of the property's quality and location, increasing the likelihood of a sale. According to Montage International, more than half of those who take a trial stay become buyers, while developers charge hefty fees to ensure prospects are legitimate.

site_title: Too early to tell if Opec+ cuts will succeed: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) says it's too early to determine if OPEC's production cuts will succeed in balancing global oil markets. Despite a 1.2 million barrel-per-day reduction, oil prices remain near $60 a barrel, and traders speculate that the cutbacks may not be deep enough to curb a potential surplus. The IEA forecasts a surplus of 1.5 million barrels a day in 2019, with supply from Russia and Canada also expected to decline. The agency notes that the cuts may be sufficient in the first half of 2019, but may need to be doubled in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: Beware rogue public Wi-Fi hotspots
summary: The Money FM podcast "Mind Your Business" warns listeners to beware of rogue public Wi-Fi hotspots that can trick them into connecting to fake networks. Hackers can easily pose as legitimate hotspots, putting users' personal data and devices at risk. Experts advise using virtual private networks (VPNs) and being cautious when using public Wi-Fi, as even seemingly secure networks can be compromised. By taking these precautions, individuals can safeguard themselves from cyber threats when using public Wi-Fi hotspots.

site_title: The Greek banking tragedy and how to end it
summary: Greece's banking system faces significant challenges, with nearly half of all loans being non-performing and return on equity being negative due to high costs and a depressed economy. European supervisors have turned a blind eye to the issues, despite a tailored stress test in the spring. The Greek authorities have proposed two plans to address the problem, but lack coordination, which may deter investors. Meanwhile, individual banks are taking their own steps, with Eurobank announcing a merger and a significant reduction in bad loans, but a unified solution remains elusive.

site_title: By George!
summary: A 90-minute narrated show-cum-orchestral concert, "Faith & Freedom: The Music of George Michael", will be held in Singapore on Dec 14-15, celebrating the late singer's works. The show features Matt Allen as George Michael, accompanied by other vocal talents, and includes hits from Wham! and solo works like "Faith", "Fastlove", and "Freedom". Tickets are available from S$45 to S$125.

images.alt_text: Faith & Freedom plays.

site_title: Fire up your winter cocktails with the amazing amari
summary: As winter approaches, bartenders are incorporating European-style liqueurs, known as amari, into their cocktails. Amari add structure and backbone to drinks, and are being paired with brown spirits like dark rum, bourbon, and Scotch to create autumn and winter-themed cocktails. Bartenders are experimenting with amari in classic drinks, such as the Manhattan and Negroni, and are also using it to create unique winter drinks, like the Sleigh Ride and Ugly Sweater Weather.

site_title: EU court backs cities' complaint on emissions, scraps higher NOx limits
summary: The European Union court ruled in favor of cities Paris, Brussels, and Madrid, upholding their complaint against an EU rule change on vehicle emissions. The court found the Commission's 2016 regulation exceeded its powers and broke EU human rights laws. The court partially overturned the regulation, only annulling the part setting excessively high NOx emission limits for new vehicles. The Commission was given a year to make amendments, and the court dismissed a claim for damages brought by the city of Paris. The ruling allows cities to impose their own local restrictions to curb air pollution.

site_title: Ex-OCBC dealer allegedly made unlawful trades that caused losses
summary: A former OCBC bank dealer, Lu Chor Sheng, has been accused of committing 47 offences, including making unauthorized foreign exchange trades that caused losses to clients. Lu, 40, was a treasury adviser at OCBC before allegedly making the trades over two years. The offences include breaches of the Computer Misuse Act, cheating by personation, and acquiring benefits of criminal conduct. Lu's case is under investigation.

site_title: Euro's gains held back by caution over ECB meeting
summary: The euro struggled to gain traction after the European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its monetary policy stance, ending its bond purchase scheme and keeping interest rates on hold. ECB President Mario Draghi's news conference will be closely watched for signals on economic growth and inflation expectations. Despite a cautious tone from the ECB, the euro initially traded up 0.1% but later remained unchanged. Traders are concerned about a potential interest rate rise in late 2019, weighing on the euro's performance.

site_title: Bag This
summary: Dol's Pond, a new global online auction platform for luxury and collectible bags, has launched by serial entrepreneur Dolores Au. The platform promises low commissions and exclusive listings, bringing together bag collectors worldwide to bid for iconic bags. Bags are authenticated by expert Nisha Goshawk, who brings 11 years of luxury bags reselling experience. The website features product filtering, bidding alerts, and a forum to enhance the bidding experience.

site_title: No happy new year for central banks fretting on 2019 outlook
summary: Central bankers expressed concerns about the global economy's outlook for 2019, citing deteriorating growth risks. The European Central Bank halted its stimulus program, while Swiss and Norwegian authorities warned of potential damage. China's central bank chief stated the economy faces headwinds. The Federal Reserve is set to reassess its policy decisions after Chairman Jerome Powell hinted at less aggressive interest-rate hikes. The risks of a US recession are also being closely monitored, with Pimco warning of "flashing orange" signals. The uncertain outlook has led to a reevaluation of the global economic landscape.

images.alt_text: Central bankers' concerns about the coming year were on display on Thursday as they warned the global economy could be entering a period of great uncertainty.

site_title: Most unforgettable wines of 2018
summary: A list of 12 unforgettable wines from 2018, including Stefan Vetter Sylvaner Rosenrain, Comando G Sierra de Gredos Tumba del Rey Moro Valle de Alto Alberche, and Chateau Lafite Rothschild Pauillac, 1868. The wines, selected for their unique characteristics and stories, range from Germany's Silvaner to California's Cabernet Sauvignon and include a 150-year-old Lafite and a 1846 Madeira.

site_title: Apple suppliers may move iPhone production if tariffs hit 25%
summary: Apple suppliers may shift iPhone production to other countries if the US imposes a 25% tariff on the devices. Suppliers currently believe they can maintain production in China at a 10% tariff level, but will consider relocating if tariffs increase. Apple is assessing its supply chain as the US and China negotiate a trade deal, which could impact the company's earnings if tariffs escalate.

site_title: Markets in Cambodia cheer first bond issue
summary: Cambodia's financial markets welcomed the first corporate bond issue by a microfinance institution, Hattha Kaksekar, on December 6, lifting hopes for local firms to raise funds through bonds. The three-year, $29.8 million bond drew buyers from local and international investors, with the funds intended for extending loans to farmers and small business owners. The successful listing follows NagaCorp's debut in offshore bonds in May, and the Cambodian government is expected to push for more companies to issue bonds in 2019, with a goal of establishing a firmly established bond market by next year.

site_title: Quarz urges Sunningdale Tech to return cash to shareholders
summary: Sunningdale Tech's shares surged 4.29% after activist fund Quarz Capital Management urged the company to return at least 60% of its 2019 core net income as dividends.

site_title: Shopper360 hires group CEO to drive growth and strategic offerings
summary: Shopper360 hires Matthew Ho as group CEO, effective Jan 9, 2019, to drive growth and strategic offerings. Ho, former Facebook Malaysia client partner, replaces Chew Sue Ann as executive chair and group managing director. The move comes after at least eight key management or board changes since Shopper360's listing in 2017, with the company reviewing mergers and acquisitions opportunities to strengthen its digital offering.

site_title: 2 US senators seek probe of Deutsche's compliance history
summary: US Senators Elizabeth Warren and Chris Van Hollen are seeking a Banking Committee investigation into Deutsche Bank's compliance history, specifically its correspondent banking operations and vulnerabilities to money laundering. They aim to assess the bank's adherence to US safeguards against such activities. The probe is seen as a response to concerns about Deutsche's handling of money laundering risks, which have been raised by Wall Street critics.

site_title: The rise of co-living, in BT Weekend
summary: Co-living operators in Singapore are banking on demand for short-term rent and "community spirit" to fuel their business model, offering amenities such as utilities, WiFi, and housekeeping. The scene has grown, with co-living spaces providing a communal atmosphere rather than just a room. Landlords are attracted to the model's potential for higher occupancy rates and lower maintenance costs. As the industry continues to expand, it is seen as a viable option for those seeking flexible and affordable housing.

site_title: ECB ends long-running QE stimulus programme
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has ended its 2.6 trillion-euro bond-buying program, also known as quantitative easing (QE), after almost four years. The move comes as the eurozone economy shows signs of vulnerability, with growth slowing and inflation concerns rising. The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, acknowledged that risks to growth remain "broadly balanced" but noted that downside elements are becoming more prominent. The bank's growth forecast for 2019 has been cut to 1.7%, while inflation projections have been tweaked downward to 1.6%. The decision marks a shift in the ECB's policy stance, which will remain accommodative for at least the summer of 2019.

site_title: Slowdown in Asia next year before H2 recovery: Nomura
summary: Nomura economists predict a "year of two halves" for Asia in 2019, with a slowdown in the first half due to private debt buildup, property market corrections, and global quantitative tightening, followed by a recovery in the second half. They expect low inflation, interest rate easing, and accelerated growth slowdown. Key countries' forecasts include China's growth slowdown, Indonesia and the Philippines' acceleration, and Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand's slowdown due to structural constraints and trade war vulnerabilities.

site_title: Markets rise amid mixed signals on trade war
summary: Markets rose globally, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) climbing 0.36% to close at 3,111.08, despite mixed signals on the trade war front. China resumed buying American soybeans, and China revised its Made in China 2025 industrial policy, potentially easing tensions with the US. However, tensions with Canada and China remain, and analysts warn that the positive effects of easing trade tensions may be short-lived due to global economic growth concerns and other geopolitical risk factors.

site_title: A Smarter Watch
summary: Montblanc's new smartwatch, the Summit 2, boasts improved design and features over its predecessor, with a compact 42mm steel or titanium case, water-resistance up to 50 meters, and the latest Wear OS by Google. The watch powers with a Snapdragon Wear 3100 chipset and integrates Google Assistant, allowing for personalized services, notifications, and quick responses. Exclusive features include "Timeshifter" for minimizing jet lag and the Montblanc Running Coach app for fitness tracking. Available in various styles and finishes, the Summit 2 is priced from S$1495.

images.alt_text: Montblanc's new smartwatch is the ultimate wearable built for work, leisure, fitness or travel.
Inspired by the design codes of Montblanc's 1858 collection, Summit 2 offers several design expressions from classic elegance to feminine allure.
With the built-in watch face configurator, over 1000 watch face combinations are possible.
It has a new 42mm case designed for both men and women and includes the new Qualcomm Snapdragon Wear 3100 chipset.
It includes the new Timeshifter app watch face - an effective way to reduce jet lag.

site_title: DIY Christmas Decor
summary:
News Summary:

DIY Christmas Decor experts offer tips for decorating homes with a personal touch. A fresh centerpiece, such as a cypress leaf wreath, can be made in 15 minutes with basic equipment. Alternatively, a dried wreath can last years with minimal maintenance. Table setting expert Jill St John Jeremiah suggests formal or informal settings, with or without a centerpiece, and personalized name cards. Meanwhile, decorating a Christmas tree can be achieved with lights, string garlands, and ornaments, with a tree topper adding a finishing touch.

site_title: Inside Huawei's secret headquarters, China is shaping the future
summary: Huawei's secret headquarters in Shenzhen, China, is developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence, cloud-computing, and chip technology crucial to China's national priorities and the company's future. Despite US trade restrictions and Meng Wanzhou's arrest, Huawei continues to invest heavily in next-generation technology, aiming to replicate its success in networking and telecom gear. The company's chip design unit, HiSilicon, is on pace for $7.6 billion in sales this year, and its cloud business is expanding globally, with plans to double its enterprise sales every two years. Huawei sees itself as a leader in the global tech industry, with ties to China's blue-chip firms and government.

site_title: The Fed's latest worry - financial markets
summary: The Federal Reserve is monitoring financial markets closely due to concerns about overborrowing, shaky mortgages, and inflated stock and home prices. The latest "Financial Stability Report" and a speech by Fed governor Lael Brainard highlight a mixed picture in business borrowing, with some loans to weak borrowers, but overall credit quality appears strong. Consumer debt has reduced, with households focusing on strong credit. The Fed faces a dilemma when deciding on interest rates, as raising rates might trigger an economic slump, while keeping rates low might encourage further risky lending.

site_title: Nissan-Renault alliance faces a leadership crisis
summary: Carlos Ghosn's arrest and subsequent removal from Nissan and Renault leadership has left the Franco-Japanese auto alliance in a crisis. The alliance, which accounted for 10.6 million autos in sales last year, lacks a clear leader, with Nissan and Renault having no plan to preserve the arrangement. Ghosn's removal and Nissan's decision to investigate him without giving Renault a heads-up have raised concerns about the alliance's survival. A Nissan board meeting is scheduled to appoint a replacement, with a shareholders meeting to vote to remove Ghosn from the board expected soon.

site_title: Holiday Homes
summary: Two families in Singapore share their unique Christmas traditions. Lynette Wong, a mother of three, decorates her home with a classic scheme, featuring a Noble fir tree and handmade ornaments, while also cooking a traditional Christmas meal. In contrast, Mexican expatriate Maricruz Camez celebrates Christmas with her family in Mexico, spending three weeks with her loved ones and decorating her apartment with a nativity scene and traditional colors. Both families prioritize spending time together and honoring the true meaning of Christmas.

site_title: Time for China to live up to its pledges on climate change
summary: China is under pressure to live up to its climate change pledges as the world grapples with the threat of global warming. Despite efforts to reduce air pollution, China's carbon emissions are expected to rise by nearly 5% by the end of 2019, making it the world's second-largest emitter. To address this, China must expand its carbon emissions trading system, maximize its renewable energy capacity, and phase out fossil fuels. The country has pledged to decrease its use of coal and increase non-fossil fuel sources of energy to 20% by 2030, but experts say more needs to be done to meet the Paris climate agreement goals.

site_title: Top Sri Lanka court rules against president's snap election plan
summary: Sri Lanka's top court ruled against President Maithripala Sirisena's plan to dissolve parliament and call a new national vote, extending a political crisis since October. The court deemed the move unconstitutional and voided Mr. Sirisena's order for parliamentary elections on January 5. The decision puts pressure on Mr. Sirisena to reinstate Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, who was sacked by the president on October 26. The ruling also paves the way for Mr. Wickremesinghe's possible return as prime minister, despite Mr. Sirisena's refusal to reappoint him.

site_title: SMEs seek flexibility in foreign labour policy for O&M sector
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the offshore and marine (O&M) sector are facing difficulties in tapping into ship repair and conversion services due to the foreign worker (FW) policy, which limits the number of foreign workers allowed per local employee. The Marine Shipyard sector is restricted to a 77.8% FW dependency ratio ceiling, resulting in a maximum of 3.5 foreign workers per local hire. This policy hinders SMEs' ability to ride the cyclical shipbuilding industry and access yards for higher foreign worker ratios, limiting their growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: The large number of ships transiting through Singapore creates demand for ship repair, conversion and upgrading services here, offering industry players some buffer against cyclical shipbuilding activity.

site_title: Nissan plans to boost external board seats: source
summary: Nissan plans to boost the number of external board members to improve governance following Carlos Ghosn's arrest for financial misconduct. The company will also set up a committee to oversee compensation. Currently, Nissan has three external board members, but the number is expected to increase. This move aims to add more independent voices to the board and better represent the interests of regular shareholders.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lorenzo International's independent auditors issued a disclaimer of opinion on its financial statements for the year ended March 31, 2018, due to three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. The company reported pre-tax losses of S$10.4 million for the year, exceeding the earlier unaudited figure of S$9.2 million. Lorenzo is currently on the minimum trading price watch-list. Delong Holdings delayed the construction of its mega steel plant in Indonesia, now expected to be fully operational in June 2019, citing supplier and labor issues. Mapletree Industrial Trust plans to acquire 18 Tai Seng for S$268.3 million.

site_title: Pandora selloff hits US$7b in its worst year since 2011
summary: Pandora's shares plummeted 12% on Wednesday, marking its worst day and bringing a year-to-date loss of nearly US$7 billion. This is the company's worst year since 2011. The decline comes after a warning from brokerage Carnegie that the fourth quarter and 2019 would be "tough."

site_title: Brexit worries push UK house price gauge to six-year low
summary: UK house prices hit a six-year low in November due to Brexit uncertainty, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey. The house price balance fell to -11 from -10 in October, its lowest since 2012. Economists predicted the balance would remain at -10. London and south-east England saw the most acute price falls, with worries about Brexit's impact on the capital's financial services sector. The survey showed a lack of new listings and a prolonged sales process, but stable price expectations over the next 12 months.

site_title: Manhattan rents drop in November after 2 months of increases
summary: Manhattan apartment renters experienced a decrease in leasing costs in November, following two months of increases. The median face rent dropped 1.3% from the previous year to $3,318, according to a joint report by Miller Samuel and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. This marks a break in the trend, which saw rents rise for two consecutive months. The decrease is attributed to the decrease in demand and increased competition in the rental market.

site_title: Sharp Shooter
summary: Magnum Photos introduces its first online course, The Art of Street Photography, with 10 in-depth video lessons. World-class photographers Mark Power and Peter van Agtmael share their knowledge and experience on acquiring the mindset for street photography, framing, and editing. The course, available for US$99, also includes extra material from workbooks containing interviews, tips, and tricks. This online course aims to teach aspiring street photographers the skills needed to capture the minutiae of daily life and create meaningful images.

site_title: Sweet Dreams Of Christmas
summary: Singapore's top chefs participated in a weekend dessert-making challenge, creating festive treats with luxurious ingredients like gold flakes, white truffles, and cacao pods. The challenge, featured alongside acclaimed photographer Edmond Ho, showcased the chefs' creativity and skills. The event aimed to kick off the Christmas feasting season with visually stunning desserts.

site_title: FSL Trust subsidiaries to buy two product tankers for US$97.6m
summary: FSL Trust plans to buy two 114,000 deadweight tonnes Tier III LR2 product tankers for US$97.6 million, with deliveries expected in November 2020 and January 2021. The acquisition will be financed through a combination of net proceeds, potential vessel sales, and bank financing, with the bank financing expected to be made available in late 2020 and early 2021. The new vessels are expected to be more efficient and fuel-efficient, attracting better charter rates and potentially securing better returns for FSL Trust.

site_title: Effective corporate giving: Striving for better, always
summary: Corporate giving in Singapore has gained significant traction, with 64% of companies involved in philanthropy and integrating it into their core business function. To sustain this momentum, a robust system requiring a mindset shift towards striving to do better and a skilful orchestration of strategies are needed. Effective corporate giving involves empowering communities, listening to their needs, and taking ownership while being sensitive to nuances. A collaborative approach, such as the Dementia Friends app, and a change of ethos towards seeing at-risk communities as part of the solutions can also make a lasting impact.

site_title: Q3 labour market improves but hiring may be slowing: MOM
summary: Singapore's labour market improved in the third quarter, with more people employed and fewer job losses. However, overall unemployment rose slightly to 2.1%, and hiring momentum may slow due to global uncertainties. The seasonally adjusted ratio of vacancies to unemployed people decreased to 1.05 in September, while the long-term unemployment rate for residents fell to 0.6%. Despite this, higher-skilled sectors saw good employment growth, and the ministry cautioned that job opportunities remain in certain sectors.

site_title: Boeing's 737 deliveries rise in November
summary: Boeing delivered 61 737 single-aisle aircraft in November, up from 50 a year earlier, suggesting progress in overcoming supplier problems. Total deliveries for the first 11 months of 2018 rose to 704 from 680 in the same period a year earlier, with the company expecting to deliver 810-815 planes in 2018. Boeing's deliveries are closely watched by investors and analysts for cues on cash flow and efficiency, with Airbus delivering 673 aircraft up to November. The company's deliveries could be impacted by potential cancellations of Boeing 737 MAX orders from Indonesia's Lion Air following a crash.

site_title: China's rich rush to shelter US$1t from new taxes
summary: Wealthy Chinese individuals are rushing to establish offshore trusts before China's new tax reforms take effect on January 1, aiming to minimize their tax burden. The Bank of Singapore has seen a 35% surge in Chinese clients interested in offshore trusts since the second half of 2018. China's estimated personal wealth swelled to $21 trillion last year, with overseas holdings expected to reach $1 trillion this year. The reforms aim to reduce tax burden on lower- and middle-income individuals by increasing taxes on the rich.

site_title: Raising the stakes at Bacchanalia
summary: Bacchanalia, a newly refurbished Hong Kong Street restaurant, aims to reach two Michelin-starred territory under the guidance of 27-year-old chef Vianney Massot, a former Robuchon protégé. The restaurant offers a unique set lunch menu, with prices comparable to two-starred Les Amis, but the quality and consistency of the food fall short, with some dishes lacking originality and others being overpriced. Despite its ambitions, Bacchanalia's value perception and service are questionable, but the chef's determination and well-execution of classic dishes earn it a 7-star rating, leaving room for improvement.

site_title: A Toast to Christmas
summary: Four bartenders present festive cocktails for Christmas: Apple Pie Punch by Rusty Cerven, inspired by apple pie and featuring Six Saints Rum; Christmas Symphony B by Jesse Vida, a gin sour variation with mulled wine spices; Feliz Navidad B by Gabriel Carlos, a tequila-based cocktail with hibiscus and lime juice; and Rumtopf Fizz by Andrew Loudon, a German-inspired dessert drink with rum-infused fruit and soda water.
