Christmas Symphony
Feliz Navidad
Rumtopf Fizz

site_title: Madrid temporarily bans most polluting vehicles
summary: Madrid has temporarily banned vehicles made before 2000 and diesel vehicles before 2006 from driving in the city centre and surrounding M-30 ring road until Thursday. The move aims to reduce air pollution levels, which have been exacerbated by a lack of wind. The ban is part of Madrid's anti-pollution protocol, which was activated in October, and follows a separate traffic restriction scheme launched in the historic city centre. The ban affects 17% of Madrid's vehicles and comes as the city battles high pollution levels, earning it the nickname "la boina" or "the beret".

site_title: Silkroad Nickel secures S$400m long-term contract to supply nickel ore
summary: Silkroad Nickel, a subsidiary of Indonesian nickel mining group, has signed a long-term contract worth S$400m to supply 15 million tonnes of nickel ore to PT Transon Bumindo Resources over 5-8 years. The contract includes a minimum annual delivery of 1.5 million tonnes, starting in March 2020. The agreement is expected to give the group impetus to ramp up production and explore new areas.

site_title: UK court rules Scotland partly overstepped powers over Brexit bill
summary: The UK Supreme Court ruled that Scotland's devolved parliament partially overstepped its constitutional powers when passing a Brexit bill to maintain regional powers after the UK leaves the EU. The court found that while the bill was not entirely outside the Scottish parliament's competence, some parts were. The ruling has heightened tensions between the UK government and Scotland, which have been strained by Brexit disagreements. Both sides claim victory, with Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon saying the ruling vindicates her government's approach, and the UK's Scotland minister David Mundell stating it brings much-needed legal clarity.

site_title: Benchmarks for surgical fees raise transparency; help keep lid on costs
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has published fee benchmarks for common surgical procedures in the private sector, aiming to increase transparency and control healthcare costs. The benchmarks are part of efforts to contain rising medical inflation, with inpatient costs driving the price escalation. The move follows a 2016 report that found private hospitals were charging patients 2-2.4 times more than public hospitals, with some medical professionals over-charging by "inflating certain components of the bill". The benchmarks are expected to help patients discuss treatment options and costs with doctors, while insurers and the government will use them to assess claims and plan design.

site_title: Actors' guild fete box-office hits
summary: The Screen Actors Guild (SAG) nominations for the 2019 Oscars have been announced, with each nominated film being a big box-office hit. Notably, Regina King's Oscar chances have been hurt by her SAG snub, potentially paving the way for Amy Adams to win her first Oscar. The nominations also saw some surprises, including Emily Blunt's inclusion in the Best Supporting Actress category for A Quiet Place, and Sam Elliott's comeback in the Best Supporting Actor category. The top five nominees in each category are expected to be strong Oscar contenders, with A Star Is Born, Black Panther, and BlacKkKlansman likely to make a strong showing in the Best Cast category.

site_title: Huawei troubles spell opportunity for Samsung as 5G nears
summary: Samsung sees growing security concerns surrounding Huawei as an opportunity to challenge the Chinese company's dominance in the 5G market. Despite Huawei's efforts to expand its smartphone business, the company's 5G products are being blocked in various countries due to concerns of espionage. Samsung is investing in 5G technology and plans to release 5G-capable handsets, with the goal of reviving slowing sales and gaining market share. The company is working to overcome technical challenges, such as heat and antenna module placement, to bring its 5G devices to market.

site_title: GAM stock drops 30% on loss forecast of 925m Swiss francs
summary: GAM Holding, a Swiss asset manager, reported a record 30% decline in shares after forecasting a 925 million-franc ($1.28 billion) loss for the year due to goodwill charges and a decline in assets under management. The company also cut 10% of jobs and held informal talks with potential buyers. The loss erases eight years of earnings, and interim chief David Jacob aims to stabilize the business and move beyond the turmoil triggered by the suspension of bond manager Tim Haywood in July.

site_title: Oei calls for EGM on Raffles Edu rights issue
summary: Singaporean tycoon Oei Hong Leong is calling for a shareholders' meeting to vote on terminating the proposed S$27.4 million rights issue at Raffles Education Corporation, which is primarily meant to repay loans owed to chairman and CEO Chew Hua Seng. Oei, who holds a 10% stake in the company, claims that the issue is unnecessary and wants the company to confirm that no further action will be taken until the meeting is held. This is the latest dispute between Oei and Chew, who has sued Oei for S$15 million.

images.alt_text: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong wants Raffles Education Corporation to hold a shareholders' meeting to vote on terminating the over-S$27 million rights issue meant primarily to repay loans owed to chairman and chief executive Chew Hua Seng.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific in the black in Q2 on one-off expenses a year ago
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$8.4 million for Q2 2018, reversing a loss of US$2.8 million due to one-off expenses related to its underperforming vegetable business. Turnover fell 11% to US$556.3 million, mainly due to the divestiture of Sager Creek vegetable business and lower US sales. The group faces headwinds due to shifting consumer demographics and preferences, and plans to focus on on-trend business segments, rationalize non-profitable businesses, and invest in operational efficiency.

site_title: Eurokars Group buys 23 Leng Kee Rd for S$33m
summary: Eurokars Group, a Singapore-based car agency, has acquired 23 Leng Kee Road for S$33 million, further expanding its property ownership in the prime motor belt. The group already operates a Mazda showroom and service center from the building, which it will continue to use. The acquisition, which includes a 99-year leasehold site, is expected to boost the group's dominance in the area. Eurokars Group is the largest privately-owned car agency in Singapore, representing brands such as Mazda, Porsche, and Rolls-Royce.

site_title: Auditors, audit committees should aim to raise their game
summary: Auditors and audit committees should further enhance their reporting standards to provide more meaningful disclosures to investors. The Enhanced Auditor Reporting Standards, implemented in 2016, has shifted the focus from boilerplate statements to more detailed information about the audit process and key issues. The expanded requirements aim to breed greater trust and confidence in the integrity of financial statements. However, it remains unclear if the increased transparency has been achieved, with the audit profession still facing challenges in elevating trust among stakeholders.

site_title: Gifts for Every Style
summary: Luxury brands introduce personalized gift options for the holiday season. Longchamp Le Pliage Cuir backpacks can be customized with 12 motifs and 24 color options. Louis Vuitton offers personalization services for its Run Away sneakers and ready-to-wear items, with completion taking 8 weeks. Bottega Veneta provides complimentary embossing and stamping services for its iconic intrecciato styles, available within 24 hours. Coach Create allows customers to design their own bags and accessories through various categories, offering a range of customization options.

site_title: Grab secures US$150 million investment from Yamaha
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing service, has secured a US$150 million investment from Yamaha Motor Co. The motorcycle maker will collaborate with Grab on motorcycle-ride services in South-east Asia, focusing on Indonesia. This investment follows Toyota's US$1 billion investment in Grab and Hyundai's US$250 million investment, as the company intensifies its push against local contender Go-Jek. The partnership aims to make it easier for Grab drivers to buy motorbikes and leverage Grab's ride-hailing know-how for future product development.

site_title: China turns up gas heat in 3.29m more homes
summary: China has added 3.29 million households to gas heating, exceeding last year's increase, amid efforts to curb pollution. The new gas users will require 4.53 billion cubic meters of gas, but analysts warn that industrial supplies may be cut to meet demand. The move follows Beijing's push for cleaner fuels and comes after last year's fuel shortage left people freezing in their homes.

site_title: Michael Tay
summary: Singapore diplomat Michael Tay, 59, is a Renaissance man who has helped put the country on the global arts scene. As a former Ambassador to Russia, he commissioned a symphony by Russian composer Vladimir Martynov, which debuted in Moscow in 2005 and was later performed in Singapore. Tay now leads the Foundation for the Arts and Social Enterprise, which showcases local artists and musicians through initiatives like SingJazz, an annual music festival. He aims to promote Singapore as a model of development through music, with plans for a commissioning series featuring local and international musicians over 10 years.

site_title: Acra investigating China Environment
summary: China Environment, a Singapore-listed company, is being investigated by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) for possible offences under the Companies Act. The company announced the investigation in a filing with the Singapore Exchange, stating that its directors will cooperate fully with the inquiry. The investigation requires the attendance of the directors for an interview to provide information on the case. The outcome of the investigation is yet to be determined.

site_title: Japan confirms economy in 2nd best stretch of post-war growth
summary: Japan's economy has experienced its second-best stretch of post-war growth, with the government attributing this to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus measures. However, the outlook remains uncertain due to Sino-US trade frictions, slowing global demand, and volatile markets. Despite this, the economy's performance is seen as a positive indicator for the export-reliant economy.

images.alt_text: There are signs that Japan's economic growth could be peaking.

site_title: Housing demand could still fuel 2019 growth in Singapore
summary: Singapore's housing market could support the country's growth in 2019 despite curbs, according to bank analysts. Standard Chartered expects a 2.6% economic growth, while ANZ predicts a 3% growth, citing a robust housing market and a potential shift in investment flows to Asean due to the US-China trade war. The analysts also note that Singapore's labor market has been improving, leading to higher inflationary pressure. However, a correction in housing markets is expected to have a minimal impact on financial stability.

site_title: China's WuXi AppTec ends flat on HK debut
summary: China's WuXi AppTec, a medical tech platform, listed in Hong Kong, ending flat on its first day of trading after raising US$1 billion, valuing the firm at US$10.2 billion. This follows a subdued debut in Hong Kong this year, with trade tensions impacting investors. WuXi AppTec, listed in Shanghai, joins a list of last major stock offerings in the Asian financial hub.

site_title: Huawei US$2b security pledge followed walkout by British official
summary: Huawei has pledged $2 billion to improve security in its products following a walkout by a British official from a meeting with the company over perceived security concerns. The move comes as the Chinese company faces intense scrutiny from Western governments over allegations of Chinese state spying. Huawei has denied these allegations, and the company's relationship with British authorities remains strained despite its security pledge. The UK's National Cyber Security Centre had previously criticized Huawei's slow response to security concerns, leading to increased tensions.

images.alt_text: Huawei's relations with British authorities hit a low last month when a top official walked out of a meeting with the Chinese company over its perceived failure to fix security holes in its products

site_title: Go Green And Prosper
summary: LOOP, an eco-friendly festival, is taking place at Esplanade Park's The Incubator until December 31. The event features over 100 local craftspeople, food and drink vendors, and workshops showcasing sustainable products, such as upcycled furniture and fruit waste conversions. Attendees can also learn about environmental consciousness and participate in initiatives like metal straw usage and bamboo spoon gift-giving. For more information, visit www.facebook.com/loopsingapore.

images.alt_text: LOOP.

site_title: May's Brexit deal could fail unless EU leaders lend support
summary: Theresa May's Brexit deal may fail unless EU leaders provide support, as her no-confidence vote victory has weakened her position. Despite 63% of MPs voting to keep her as leader, 117 rebel MPs and the DUP are opposed to her deal, citing concerns over the "backstop" insurance that would keep the UK in the EU's customs union. EU leaders have indicated they won't renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, and MPs are pushing for a time limit or alternative solutions, including a second referendum, that could lead to a "no deal" Brexit.

site_title: Lazada CEO, co-founder Poignant expects 'watershed' year in 2019
summary: Lazada has appointed Pierre Poignant as its new CEO, replacing Lucy Peng, as part of succession planning. Poignant, 39, has overseen logistics development since the company's launch in 2012 and will lead the company's entry into new growth pillars. He expressed confidence in Lazada's trajectory, calling 2019 a "watershed" year, following Alibaba's US$2 billion investment in the company. Poignant will manage operations in six countries and continue to utilize Alibaba's technological capabilities and logistics network.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open on trade optimism
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, led by technology shares, amid optimism over trade talks between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.20% to 24,575.86, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 0.29% and 0.52%, respectively, reaching fresh records. The positive sentiment was fueled by signs of progress in the trade dispute, boosting market sentiment and investor confidence.

site_title: Singapore acts to stop unilateral third-party arbitration amid spat
summary: Singapore has filed a UN declaration under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (Unclos) to prevent unilateral third-party arbitration in maritime boundary disputes. The move comes amid a dispute with Malaysia over territorial waters off Tuas, where Malaysia has unilaterally gazetted extended port limits. Singapore is prepared to settle disputes through international third-party arbitration on mutually agreed terms, and has informed Malaysia of the declaration. This follows Malaysia's move in October, which encroached into Singapore's territorial waters, prompting Singapore to extend its own port limits and demand Malaysia withdraw its vessels.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: First Real Estate Investment Trust (FREIT) is planning to rebalance its portfolio, with up to 50% of assets outside Indonesia within 3-5 years. FREIT may acquire OUE Lippo Healthcare's Japanese nursing home portfolio in 2019 and potentially raise equity through a rights issuance to fund acquisitions. Meanwhile, UOB Kay Hian Research downgrades FREIT to "hold" and lowers its fair value to S$1.05 due to risks and increased debt.

site_title: Court rules against Sri Lanka president, impeachment edges closer
summary: Sri Lanka's Supreme Court ruled against President Maithripala Sirisena, declaring his dissolution of parliament last month as unconstitutional. The decision paves the way for potential impeachment proceedings against Sirisena, who broke the law by dissolving parliament nearly two years ahead of schedule. The court's unanimous verdict also restored parliament, allowing the opposition-led legislature to pass a no-confidence motion against the disputed prime minister, Mahinda Rajapakse.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore took steps to prevent unilateral third-party arbitration in a maritime boundary dispute with Malaysia, favoring negotiations. Unemployment in Singapore rose slightly, and hiring showed signs of slowing. Activist fund Quarz urged Sunningdale Tech to return more cash to shareholders. Singapore-based energy-saving firm Barghest Building Performance secured a $45m investment from KKR & Co.

site_title: Singapore energy-saving firm wins S$45m KKR investment
summary: KKR has invested S$45 million in Singapore-based energy-saving firm Barghest Building Performance (BBP) as part of its first impact investment globally. BBP plans to use the funds to grow its regional business, invest in new technology, and hire more staff. The company aims to help companies in Asia reduce electricity consumption by digitizing air-conditioning systems, with the potential to cut energy consumption by up to 40%. This deal adds to KKR's significant investments in Southeast Asia, including S$500 million in luxury retailer V3 Group and S$200 million in real estate portal PropertyGuru.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on hopes for US-China trade ties
summary: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.99% and the Topix index 0.62%, as worries over a US-China trade war receded. The benchmark indices closed at 21,816.19 and 1,616.65, respectively.

site_title: Snow Place Like Helsinki
summary: Helsinki, Finland is a holiday destination with a unique blend of winter activities and relaxation. The city features snow-covered landscapes, saunas, and pools, including the wind- and solar-powered Löyly sauna facility. The Helsinki Christmas Market in Senate Square offers a variety of treats, including Finnish cuisine, mulled wine, and handicrafts. Visitors can also explore the Uutela Nature Trail, lit up by hundreds of candles. Helsinki's festive atmosphere is available until December 22.

site_title: Charity helping single Japanese mothers wins award
summary: A Japanese charity, Little Ones, has won a World Habitat Award for its efforts to provide subsidized housing to single mothers. Since 2008, the organization has converted over 300 abandoned homes into homes for single mothers in Tokyo, Osaka, and Chiba, addressing the stigma and challenges faced by these women. Japan's single-mother households have increased to 712,000, with many living in poverty due to limited economic opportunities and social stigma, despite the country being one of the world's wealthiest nations.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.36% to 3,111.08, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. About 891.4 million securities worth S$893.1 million changed hands, with gains and losses evenly matched. Key movers included Genting Singapore (up 1.5%), DBS Group Holdings (up 0.9%), and Singtel (flat at S$3.08). Investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed.

site_title: Sanofi loses Lantus patent claims against Mylan
summary: Sanofi's patent claims against Mylan's generic versions of its diabetes drug Lantus and Lantus SoloSTAR disposable injection pen were rejected by the US Patent and Trademark Office. This allows Mylan to launch its own versions of the medications, which are being reviewed by the US Food and Drug Administration. The rejection comes as Sanofi is heavily reliant on Lantus, its leading product, with sales of 4.62 billion euros in 2017. Sanofi's Paris-listed shares fell 1% following the news.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims near 49-year low; import prices fall
summary: US jobless claims fell to a 49-year low of 206,000 in the latest week, easing concerns about a slowdown in the labor market. Import prices dropped 1.6% in November, the largest decline in over three years, as a strong dollar weighed on prices. The data bolsters expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike at its upcoming meeting and suggests inflation will remain tame through the first half of 2019, with economists predicting fewer rate hikes next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rallied for the second consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.29% to 26,524.35, driven by optimism over China-US trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.23% and 1.11%, respectively. The gains come as investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors raid Samsung Biologics office in accounting probe
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Samsung Biologics' office in Seoul as part of a probe into alleged accounting fraud. The company denied the allegations, and the financial regulator had filed a complaint last month. The raid occurred outside of Seoul, and the prosecutors' office declined to comment. This move follows claims that Samsung Biologics intentionally breached accounting rules.

site_title: ECB still sees balanced economic outlook, but downside risk more prominent
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its assessment of a "broadly balanced" economic outlook, but acknowledged downside risks are becoming more prominent. Growth in the euro zone has slowed more than expected, with uncertainties related to geopolitics, protectionism, and emerging markets. The ECB's decision to end its asset purchase scheme was seen as a cautious response, as a formal downward shift in the balance of risk assessment would have led to policy changes. The assessment is reviewed quarterly, with the next review due in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: "The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook can still be assessed as broadly balanced," ECB President Mario Draghi told a news conference on Thursday.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust proposes to buy Tai Seng property for S$268.3m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) proposes to buy a mixed-use property at 18 Tai Seng St for S$268.3 million, expanding its Hi-Tech Buildings segment. The 9-storey property has a 30-year lease and a committed occupancy rate of 94.3%. MIT has debt headroom to fund the acquisition entirely by debt, and the purchase is subject to unitholder approval. The acquisition will increase MIT's total assets under management to S$4.7 billion, with High-Tech Buildings accounting for 42.7% of its portfolio.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 12.73 points to 1,676.00. Volume reached 1.5 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 397 to 371.

site_title: Anti-junta film 'Ten Years Thailand' aims to fire political debate
summary: A new Thai film series, "Ten Years Thailand," premiered in Bangkok, aiming to spark debate on the country's future under military rule. The omnibus film features four dark satires on censorship, mob mentality, and free expression, created by prominent Thai directors. The film series, inspired by the "Occupy" protests in Hong Kong, explores the country's potential bleak future, with themes of army rule and cultural conformity. The creators hope to encourage critical thinking and inspire action among the population, which remains divided between pro-junta elites and pro-democracy supporters.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain on Sino-US trade war thaw
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.62% to 2,095.55, driven by a thaw in Sino-US trade tensions. Chinese state-owned companies purchased over 1.5 million tonnes of US soybeans, easing US concerns. South Korean bond yields dropped, and the won gained 0.45% against the US dollar. Several Korean companies, including Samsung and Hyundai, received orders worth billions of won, boosting their shares.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day stretch.

site_title: End to crisis-fighting era as ECB shuts off stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) ended its asset purchase programme in December 2018, marking the end of a three-year crisis-fighting era. The ECB had bought 2.6 trillion euros of government and corporate debt to ward off deflation. This move will likely reduce economic stimulus, leading to a shift in monetary policy. The decision comes as the eurozone faces economic uncertainty and potential slowdowns in growth.

images.alt_text: A chapter of eurozone history came to a close Thursday when the European Central Bank withdrew a key element of its support for the economy even as clouds gather.

site_title: Furniture seller Lorenzo's auditors issue disclaimer of opinion on financials
summary: Lorenzo International's auditors issued a disclaimer of opinion on the furniture seller's financial statements for the year ended Mar 31, citing material uncertainties on the group's ability to continue as a going concern. Pre-tax losses were reported at S$10.4 million, exceeding the earlier-reported S$9.2 million loss. The company is under the minimum trading price watch-list by the SGX, and auditors noted material discrepancies in financial statements, including an over-recognition of revenue and related trade receivables.

site_title: SG fund VisVires New Protein invests in Israeli shrimp virus tech startup ViAqua
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm VisVires New Protein has invested in Israeli aquaculture startup ViAqua, which develops a product to prevent and treat viral epidemics in shrimp. ViAqua's technology inhibits specific viral gene expressions, targeting the deadly White Spot Syndrome Virus. The investment aims to elevate the shrimp aquaculture industry's efficiency and quality. ViAqua plans to continue research and development before bringing the product to market, with existing investors including Nutreco, Trendlines, and the Technion Institute of Technology.

site_title: Ghana Gandhi statue removed after student protest
summary: A statue of Mahatma Gandhi, an Indian independence leader, has been removed from the University of Ghana in Accra after student protests citing passages written by Gandhi as racist against black Africans. The statue, unveiled two years ago, was the subject of a petition calling for its removal due to its perceived racist connotations. The university's decision was seen as a victory for "black dignity and self-respect." Similar protests have been ongoing at universities in Africa and beyond, questioning the enduring symbols of colonial past. The removal is considered a step towards reevaluating historical icons.

site_title: Egypt arrests two over nude tourists on pyramid
summary: Egyptian authorities arrested a camel driver and a woman accused of helping two Danish tourists, including photographer Andreas Hvid, scale the Great Pyramid of Giza at night for a video and naked photograph. The incident sparked outrage in the country, with climbing pyramids forbidden in Egypt. Hvid acknowledged his role and will be put on trial, while the woman also faces charges. The video, which has garnered 4.5 million views on YouTube, has sparked public outcry, with many criticizing the desecration of the 4,500-year-old ancient structure.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,108.61, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,108.61, driven by gains in DBS Group Holdings and Genting Singapore. Gainers outnumbered losers 158 to 130, with 427.7 million securities worth S$414.4 million changing hands. The rally follows a 0.4% gain on Wednesday, as investors remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank to shun Huawei in favour of Ericsson, Nokia equipment: Nikkei
summary: SoftBank Group Corp plans to replace 4G network equipment from Huawei with Nokia and Ericsson equipment, amid heightened scrutiny of Chinese tech firms due to concerns over ties to the Chinese government. The move comes as SoftBank prepares to list its telecoms unit in Tokyo and follows Japan's policy document on maintaining cybersecurity during procurement. This decision is likely to be time-consuming and expensive, and adds to Huawei's woes, including the recent arrest of its CFO.

site_title: Oops. Samsung retreats from 'fake' Supreme streetwear brand
summary: Samsung Electronics Co has retreated from a collaboration with Supreme Italia, a disputed version of the streetwear label, after drawing criticism from consumers. The tie-up was announced at a smartphone launch in China, but it was revealed that the real Supreme was not involved. Samsung expressed regret and said it was reconsidering the alliance, citing concerns caused by the announcement. This is the latest black eye for the world's largest smartphone maker, which has faced increased competition from Chinese rivals.

site_title: Shopper360 hires group CEO to drive strategy growth and development
summary: Shopper360, a Catalist-listed marketing services company, has hired Matthew Ho as its new group CEO, effective January 9, 2019. Ho will drive the group's growth and development, including strategic offerings, while allowing the executive chairwoman and group managing director Chew Sue Ann to focus on her role. The new appointment follows several leadership changes since the company's listing in 2017, and Shopper360 is reviewing mergers and acquisitions opportunities to strengthen its digital offering.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher after May wins vote
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Thursday after British Prime Minister Theresa May won a no-confidence vote, providing investor relief. The European Central Bank is forecast to end its "quantitative easing" stimulus, boosting sentiment. More conciliatory noises from China and the US on trade also contributed to the rally. Meanwhile, the US stock market edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

images.alt_text: European stocks rose Thursday at the open on investor relief after British Prime Minister Theresa May won a no-confidence vote.

site_title: Australia shares eke out third session of gains; NZ up
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% higher, their third straight day of gains, as China took steps to ease trade tensions with the US, including its first major purchase of US soya beans in six months. The metals and mining index rose 1.3%, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto also gaining. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6%, while Australia's consumer sentiment for December rose 0.1%. The moves followed constructive developments in US-China trade relations, which boosted market sentiment.

site_title: BlackRock euro-bond head snubs US colleagues' tips on hedging
summary: BlackRock's head of euro fixed-income, Michael Krautzberger, is ignoring US colleagues' recommendations to hedge against dollar market fluctuations due to high hedging costs, now around 4% for euro investors. European investors are instead opting for euro-bond yields, which are rising as the European Central Bank winds down stimulus measures. Krautzberger favors investment-grade corporate notes maturing in 5-7 years, citing low leverage and solid earnings, as a more attractive option. This shift is driven by the surging cost of dollar hedging and the European Central Bank's stimulus measures.

site_title: Singapore energy-saving firm wins S$45m KKR investment
summary: KKR & Co has invested up to S$45 million in Barghest Building Performance (BBP), a Singapore-based energy-saving firm, as part of its first impact investment globally. BBP aims to reduce electricity consumption in Asia's commercial and industrial buildings through its digitized air-conditioning systems. The investment will help the company grow its business, invest in new technology, and hire more staff. This deal adds to KKR's significant investments in South-east Asia, with the firm announcing over US$900 million in investments this year.

site_title: Singapore acts to prevent unilateral third-party arbitration amid maritime boundary dispute with Malaysia
summary: Singapore has filed a declaration under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) to prevent unilateral third-party arbitration on maritime boundary disputes with Malaysia. The declaration, filed on Dec 12, comes amid a dispute over territorial waters off Tuas. Singapore believes disputes are best settled through negotiations, and if not, it's prepared to take them to an international third-party dispute settlement procedure on terms mutually agreed to by the parties. This move follows Malaysia's unilateral gazetting of extended port limits for Johor Baru Port, which encroached into Singapore's territorial waters.

site_title: Ministers push Theresa May to test different Brexits before Christmas
summary: Pro-European ministers in Theresa May's Cabinet are urging her to test different Brexit outcomes before Christmas to secure a compromise. Six ministers want to hold informal votes in Parliament to gauge support for various Brexit options, which could lead to a second referendum. The plan aims to show that no one has a majority for a specific Brexit outcome, making Mrs. May's deal more acceptable. However, the plan's consequences are uncertain, and May has expressed concerns about its potential impact.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.15 points, or 0.43%, to 1,671.11 on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume was 61.1 million lots worth RM29.8 million, with 124 gainers outnumbering 47 losers.

site_title: Trump gets win as Xi makes good on pledge to buy US soybeans
summary: China resumed buying US soybeans, purchasing 1.5-2 million metric tons over the past 24 hours, in a move to ease tensions with the US. The purchases, mainly from the Pacific Northwest, are expected to occur in the first quarter and will help reduce stockpile pressures for US soybean farmers. This is the first significant purchase since the two countries began imposing tariffs. The move is seen as a positive step for US farmers, but its impact on the soybean market is uncertain, with some traders concerned that the imports are likely to be made by state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Singapore labour market strengthened in Q3 but hiring shows signs of slowing
summary: Singapore's labour market strengthened in Q3 with more people employed and fewer job losses, but hiring signs slowed amid global uncertainties. Unemployment rose slightly, and re-entry rates for retrenched workers decreased to 62% from 64% in the previous quarter. Lower re-entry rates were seen across all age groups.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.88% in the opening minutes of Thursday, tracking a positive lead from Wall Street due to hopes for China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,417.89, while the Shanghai Composite Index was slightly lower. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.19%. The rally comes despite uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Second person questioned in China after envoy arrest, says Canada
summary: A second Canadian, Michael Spavor, has been questioned by Chinese authorities, amid heightened tensions between the two countries. Spavor, a Canadian businessman, was questioned after contacting the Canadian government, and his whereabouts are currently unknown. The arrest of a former Canadian diplomat, Michael Kovrig, in Beijing and the detention of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou in Vancouver have strained relations. Canada is working to determine Spavor's whereabouts and has raised concerns with Chinese authorities.

site_title: Asian shares, sterling up on pause in Brexit, trade fears
summary: Asian shares rose on Thursday as investors breathed a sigh of relief after British Prime Minister Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote, boosting sterling and euro. China appeared to be meeting US demands to open its markets, with state-owned companies buying US soybeans. However, the risk of a chaotic Brexit exit in March and the European Central Bank's decision to end its bond purchase scheme remain uncertain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.09%, while the US dollar index edged down to 97.02, as trade tensions eased.

site_title: Former OCBC dealer on trial for unauthorised trades which caused losses to bank
summary: Lu Chor Sheng, a former OCBC treasury adviser, is on trial for unauthorised foreign exchange trades that caused the bank to lose S$3.1 million. However, the defendant disputes the figure, claiming the losses were around S$810,000. Lu allegedly executed nearly 200 unauthorised trades between 2011 and 2013, using customer accounts to earn profits. He also set up two sole proprietorships to hide his activities and deceived clients into believing trades had been executed. Lu pleaded guilty to 42 charges earlier this year but is now disputing the amount of losses.

site_title: High-tech degrees and the price of an avocado: New York woos Amazon with data
summary: New York City provided Amazon with a 253-page proposal, including detailed data on education, real estate, and incentives, as part of its bid to host Amazon's second headquarters. The data, some of which was not publicly available, included information on the availability of machine-learning specialists, user-experience designers, and hardware engineers. The proposal showed that New York City had provided Amazon with valuable research, including data on Columbia University's outreach programs for STEM students and the city's free, full-day pre-K programs. The data helped Amazon determine the best locations for its new headquarters, ultimately choosing Long Island City and Arlington, Virginia.

images.alt_text: An avocado at Whole Foods costs US$1.25. Columbia University handed out 724 graduate degrees in computer science over the past three years. And 10 potential land parcels in Long Island City are zoned M1-4, for light manufacturing.

site_title: Japan plans tighter regulation of tech giants
summary: Japan plans to tighten regulations on tech giants like Google and Facebook, following an expert panel's call for better oversight on competition and privacy. The government will issue new regulatory principles in the next two weeks, urging better protection of consumer data and fairness in market access. This move comes as European authorities crack down on US tech giants, with Google facing a record $6.8 billion fine for alleged anti-competitive practices. Japan's decision aims to balance the benefits of tech giants with concerns over market dominance and consumer protection.

site_title: CIMB-Principal Asset Management names new Asean CEO
summary: CIMB-Principal Asset Management has appointed Juan Ignacio Eyzaguirre Baraona as its new Asean CEO, overseeing businesses in Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Singapore. He replaces Alejandro Echegorri, who will become chief investment officer for Principal International in Asia. The appointment is subject to approvals by Malaysia's Securities Commission and the Immigration Department. Eyzaguirre brings 30 years of leadership experience in asset management, banking, insurance, and pensions, aiming to strengthen long-term savings, investments, and retirement solutions across the region.

site_title: Australia shares inch up, focus on Sino-US trade talks; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,669.80, with base metals and financial stocks leading gains. The market was cautiously optimistic over progress in Sino-US trade talks, despite investors seeking concrete concessions. China's purchase of US soybeans and a boost in diversified mining giants BHP and Rio Tinto contributed to the gains. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6% to 8,794.15, with Sanford being the top performer.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4% to 3,111.07
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Thursday to 3,111.07, driven by a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty. The Straits Times Index gained 11.08 points, with gains outnumbering losses 80 to 41. Key stocks included Singtel, Wilmar International, and Alpha Energy. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australian rail workers plan strikes that could hit key coal haulage tracks
summary: Australian rail workers at Aurizon Holdings Ltd are planning strikes over pay negotiations, which could delay coal shipments from the world's largest coking coal export region. The Rail, Tram and Bus Union, representing train crews and maintenance workers, has announced 11 days of action, including four days of stoppages and seven days of overtime bans. The strikes could impact coal trains on four major railways in Queensland, potentially delaying shipments to ports on Australia's east coast. Aurizon has urged the unions to withdraw their proposed industrial action.

site_title: Gold edges lower, palladium hits record high
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,244.56 per ounce, while palladium surged to a record high of $1,262.35 per ounce, trading at a premium to the bullion. The US dollar steadied after declining from a near one-month high, and Asian shares and the pound rose as investors breathed a sigh of relief after British Prime Minister Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote. China appears to be easing its high-tech industrial development push amid talks to reduce trade tensions with the US.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.65% and the Topix index up 0.44%. Worries over a US-China trade war receded, contributing to the positive start. The rally followed a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks and a report that US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Lazada veteran Pierre Poignant replacing Lucy Peng as CEO
summary: Lazada veteran Pierre Poignant is replacing Lucy Peng as CEO, effective immediately. Poignant, a 39-year-old six-year veteran of Lazada, will take the CEO role after joining the company in 2012. Peng, a co-founder of Lazada's controlling shareholder Alibaba Group Holding, will remain executive chairman. The move comes nine months after Peng was installed as CEO to replace Maximilian Bittner.

images.alt_text: Lazada Group chief executive officer Lucy Peng will step down and cede her role to Pierre Poignant, a six-year veteran of the leading South-east Asian e-commerce operator.

site_title: SEC's US$600m crypto case ends in US$2.5m settlement
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has settled a case against AriseBank for allegedly raising funds through an unregistered initial coin offering (ICO). AriseBank claimed to have raised $600 million but ultimately agreed to pay $2.5 million in a settlement. CEO Jared Rice and co-founder Stanley Ford each agreed to pay $185,000 in penalties for their roles in perpetuating the scheme, which included false claims about partnerships with Visa and exaggerated fundraising amounts. The settlement marks a conclusion to the SEC's case, which was one of the first targeting alleged cryptocurrency misconduct.

site_title: Anchor Resources to raise S$1m through private placement of shares at S$0.023 apiece
summary: Anchor Resources plans to raise S$1 million through a private placement of 43.5 million shares at S$0.023 apiece. The placement, which represents 4.15% of total issued shares, aims to procure general working capital. Net proceeds will be approximately S$920,000 after deducting expenses of S$80,000. The shares will be issued under a general share issue mandate approved by shareholders at an annual general meeting in April.

site_title: China Environment directors to attend ACRA interview in probe
summary: China Environment directors will attend an ACRA interview as part of an investigation into possible offenses under the Companies Act. The company is being investigated after a creditor took over management of its unit Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co, amid suspicions of rental income misappropriation. The directors will cooperate fully with the investigation, and the company will provide updates if significant developments occur. Trading in China Environment stock remains suspended.

site_title: Australian dollar near 1 week highs, kiwi steady on budget forecasts
summary: The Australian dollar reached near one-week highs due to improved Sino-US trade relations and signs of progress in trade talks, boosting riskier assets. China's purchase of US soybeans and easing of its "Made in China 2025" push also contributed to the increase. The New Zealand dollar remained steady despite a government budget forecast, with the economy expected to grow near its historical average.

site_title: China meeting to set 2019 economic polices will start on Dec 19: sources
summary: China's leaders will hold their annual economic policy-setting meeting from Dec 19 to Dec 21 to address US concerns over market access before a March 1 deadline for trade talks. The meeting comes amid slower growth at home and uncertainty over trade with the US. Policymakers will need to balance extra stimulus with debt control. The meeting also coincides with the 40th anniversary of China's "Reform and Opening Up" process on Dec 18.

site_title: Former Canadian diplomat held in China a 'pawn': experts
summary: Former Canadian diplomat Michael Kovrig, held in China, may be a "pawn" in a three-nation feud between Canada, China, and the US. Kovrig was detained nine days after Chinese tech giant Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou was arrested in Vancouver on Iran sanctions-related charges. Experts say China is using Kovrig to pressure Canada, following a similar pattern seen in 2014 when Canadian aid workers were detained. Kovrig's detention has sandwiched Ottawa between Washington and Beijing as they feud over trade, cyber espionage, and other issues.

site_title: Apple suppliers are considering moving iPhone output if tariffs hit 25%
summary: Apple suppliers are considering shifting iPhone production out of China if the US imposes a 25% tariff on the devices, according to people familiar with the matter. Currently, suppliers can maintain production at a 10% tariff level. Apple's manufacturing partners, including Hon Hai Precision Industry Co and Pegatron Corp, are largely beholden to the US company's wishes and are assessing their supply chains amid escalating trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: After Trump comment on Huawei, official says Justice Dept sticks to law enforcement
summary: US Justice Department official John Demers pushed back against President Trump's comment that he might intervene in a Huawei executive's case to secure a trade deal, stating the department is "law enforcement, not a tool of trade". Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou is fighting extradition in Canada on US claims of misleading banks about Iran-linked transactions. Trump's comment sparked concerns that US law enforcement is being used for political ends. Demers emphasized the Justice Department's commitment to upholding the law, not trade negotiations.

site_title: Nissan to boost external board seats, set up compensation committee: source
summary: Nissan plans to boost external board seats and set up a compensation committee to improve governance following Carlos Ghosn's arrest for financial misconduct. Critics have said the company lacked independent voices on the board. The company has not decided on the number of additional external board seats to add. This move comes as Nissan aims to address concerns about governance and ensure shareholder interests are protected. The setup of a compensation committee will oversee compensation packages for executives.

site_title: Activist fund Quarz urges Sunningdale Tech to return cash to shareholders
summary: Activist fund Quarz Capital Management is urging Sunningdale Tech to return more cash to shareholders, recommending at least 60% of core net income in 2019 be distributed as dividends. The proposal comes after the company's shares fell 19% following its earnings miss in April. Quarz believes Sunningdale is undervalued at a 30% discount to its tangible book value and expects stronger revenue growth next year. The activist also proposes distributing 50% of the proceeds from the disposal of a Chinese factory to shareholders.

site_title: Chinese state media urges Canada to defy US, free Huawei executive
summary: China's state media, Global Times and China Daily, urge Canada to free Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou without conditions, citing a US-Canada extradition agreement and human rights concerns. Meng was detained on Washington's request for allegedly misleading banks about transactions linked to Iran. Canada can end the crisis by releasing her unconditionally, the media said. China is holding former Canadian diplomat Michael Kovrig on suspicion of national security harm, and the US has warned against politicizing the extradition case. The US claims it will intervene if it serves national security interests.

site_title: The Fed's job just got more complicated
summary: The US Federal Reserve is insolvent, with a net worth of negative $66.5 billion due to losses in securities holdings and capital of $39.1 billion. This poses a risk to its ability to provide support to banks during a crisis. The Fed's balance sheet has been impacted by its decision to raise interest rates, which reduces the value of its bond holdings and increases its costs. To avoid public scrutiny and congressional opposition, the Fed needs to quickly rebuild its capital buffer without triggering a rapid selloff, a delicate balance it aims to achieve through a slow and steady asset sale.

site_title: Del Monte Q2 profit back in the black on one-off expenses a year ago
summary: Del Monte reported a Q2 net profit of US$8.4 million, reversing a loss of US$2.8 million from the same period last year due to one-off expenses related to its underperforming vegetable business. Turnover fell 11% to US$556.3 million, mainly due to the divestiture of the Sager Creek vegetable business and lower US sales. Earnings per share rose to 0.18 US cents from a loss of 0.32 US cents previously.

site_title: China's yuan edges up on signs of thaw in Sino-US trade relations
summary: China's yuan edged up against the US dollar on Thursday as signs of thaw in Sino-US trade relations offered support. China made its first major purchases of US soybeans and eased its "Made in China 2025" industrial development push, driving market optimism. Gains were capped by demand for the greenback, but yuan traders welcomed any signs of easing in trade tensions.

images.alt_text: China's yuan inched up against the US dollar on Thursday, as positive progress in Sino-US trade tensions continued to offer support, but gains were capped by some demand for the greenback.

site_title: Fintech startup Jumo secures US$12.5m from investment firm Odey Asset Management
summary: Fintech startup Jumo has secured US$12.5 million from London-based investment firm Odey Asset Management, bringing total funds raised to over US$103 million. The investment will be used to develop Jumo's technology platform and expand in Africa and Asia. Founded in 2014, Jumo manages a platform providing financial services to individuals and small businesses in emerging markets via mobile phones. The company has over 10 million users and originated almost US$1 billion in loans. Jumo plans to enter new Asian markets in 2019 and has a partnership with Uber to launch a vehicle finance product.

site_title: Oil ends lower on Iran comments despite Libya, Opec supply cuts
summary: Oil prices ended lower on Wednesday after Iran's Oil Minister stated divisions exist within Opec, despite Libya and Opec-led production cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $60.15 a barrel, down 5 cents, while US crude was down 50 cents at $51.15 a barrel. The market has fallen by a third since October due to global oversupply concerns, but Opec's production cuts may help stabilize prices, with analysts predicting Brent crude could remain above $60 a barrel for the next six months.

site_title: US: Wall Street gains on better signs in US-China trade talks
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday due to improved hopes for US-China trade talks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average adding 0.6% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.5%. Key indicators, including a Chinese Huawei executive's bail and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross's confirmation of potential tariff cuts, contributed to the positive sentiment. Tech shares and vulnerable equities such as Boeing and Caterpillar also gained ground, while Tencent Music jumped 7.7% in its first session after going public.

site_title: ECB worries multiply even as money-printing presses stop
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to end its 2.6 trillion euro bond purchase scheme, but will likely delay its next step in removing stimulus due to growing concerns over growth and inflation. Despite the end of quantitative easing, ECB chief Mario Draghi will emphasize that other forms of support will remain, and investors expect unchanged rates. The ECB may also consider extending its time horizon for investing cash from maturing bonds and exploring new long-term loans to banks.

site_title: S&P economists trim GDP outlook for Asean emerging markets
summary: S&P economists have trimmed their growth outlook for Asean emerging markets, expecting a 0.1-0.2 point decrease in GDP over the next three years. They cite risks from worsening trade and investment friction, currency pressure from a softening yuan, and US Federal Reserve policy tightening. These factors could put pressure on South-east Asian inflation and rates, despite potential supply chain diversions into the region due to the US-China trade war. The trimmed outlook reflects growing concerns about the economic impact of trade tensions and monetary policy changes.

site_title: FSL Trust units to buy 2 product tankers for US$97.6m
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) plans to buy two product tankers for US$97.6 million, with deliveries expected in November 2020 and January 2021. The vessels, which are Tier III LR2 product tankers, will be purchased in five staggered instalments starting from early 2019. This move is part of FSL Trust's plans to renew its fleet of vessels.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jumbo Group, Silkroad Nickel, Del Monte, OUE Lippo Healthcare, FSL Trust
summary:

OUE Lippo Healthcare is developing an international hospital in Shenzhen with China Merchants Group. FSL Trust plans to buy two product tankers for $97.6 million. These developments may impact trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Home comforts and a curfew for China's 'Princess of Huawei' on bail in Canada
summary: Meng Wanzhou, the "Princess of Huawei," has been released on $10 million bail after being arrested on a US warrant for alleged sanctions-breaking dealings with Iran. As she awaits possible extradition to the US, she is required to wear an electronic anklet and follow an 11pm-7am curfew. Despite her situation, Meng has been spotted enjoying home comforts, including receiving flowers at her Vancouver home and ordering pizza for reporters. Her case has divided the local Chinese-Canadian community, with some expressing support for her and others advocating for the rule of law.

images.alt_text: Accused of sanctions busting and forced to abide by a curfew and wear an ankle bracelet as she awaits possible extradition to the United States, China's "Princess of Huawei" could be said to have fallen spectacularly from grace.

site_title: Trump's ex-lawyer Michael Cohen sentenced to 3 years in prison on campaign charge
summary: US District Judge William Pauley sentenced Michael Cohen, Donald Trump's former personal lawyer, to 3 years in prison for financial crimes and orchestrating hush payments to women before the 2016 election. Cohen, who pleaded guilty to charges including tax evasion, bank fraud, and campaign finance violations, implicated Trump in the payments. The sentence was a reduction from the recommended 4-5 years under federal guidelines. Cohen also forfeited $500,000 and paid restitution of nearly $1.4 million. The sentence caps a stunning about-face by a lawyer who once said he would "take a bullet" for Trump.

site_title: China's Zhoushan to go after Singapore marine hub's top billing
summary: China's Zhoushan port is planning to challenge Singapore's dominance in the multi-billion dollar shipping fuel industry, capitalizing on its proximity to major ports and Beijing's support. With annual marine fuel sales of 3.6 million tonnes, Zhoushan aims to rise to 30 million tonnes by 2030, targeting Singapore's market share. The port's location and Chinese government backing may give it an edge, particularly with upcoming International Maritime Organization (IMO) rules capping sulphur content in shipping fuel. However, Singapore's efficiency, transparency, and strict standards may remain a challenge for Zhoushan.

site_title: Uber CEO, Temasek invest in urban farming startup
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi and Temasek have invested $90 million in Bowery Farming Inc, a two-year-old urban farming startup that uses robotics to cultivate crops indoors. The company plans to use the funding to expand its operations, including opening new farms in the US and internationally, and hiring more employees. Bowery's indoor farms are 100 times more productive than equivalent plots of arable land, and the company aims to address global food shortages by providing fresher produce. This investment validates the scope of the problem and the opportunity in indoor agriculture.

site_title: Ageing Japan: Dementia puts financial assets of the elderly at risk
summary: Japan is facing a growing concern of dementia affecting the elderly, with over 5 million cases diagnosed, projected to increase to 7 million by 2030. This condition puts trillions of yen worth of financial assets at risk, as patients struggle with everyday tasks and may make impulsive financial decisions. Experts warn of the risk of financial abuse, with some cases involving large sums withdrawn without a clear understanding. To address this issue, some financial institutions are implementing measures such as low-cost financial guardian services and technology-based warning systems for suspicious transactions.

site_title: Europe: Trade, Italy hopes lift stocks to best day in 8 months
summary: European shares rose 1.8% on Wednesday, their biggest gain in 8 months, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and potential Italian budget compromise. The euro zone stock benchmark rose despite global economic growth slowdown concerns. Italian banks gained 3%, led by Intesa Sanpaolo, as Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte met with EU officials. Deutsche Bank rose 5.8% after a report suggested a possible merger with Commerzbank. The rally was also fueled by sectors such as materials, autos, and tech, which rose over 2%.

site_title: UK's May survives, weakened and with an exit date
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote by her own MPs, but acknowledged her time in office is limited. May, who has been criticized for her handling of Brexit, defended her deal and warned that ousting her could derail the process. She won the vote 117-200, but the numbers against her will be uncomfortable. May has promised to secure assurances from EU leaders and return the Brexit deal to MPs by January 21, but those leaders have repeatedly said they have little more to offer.

site_title: Google's digital dragnet exposed in Congress hearing
summary: Google's digital dragnet was exposed during a congressional hearing, with CEO Sundar Pichai facing questions about the company's data collection practices. Lawmakers expressed concern over the volume of user data Google and other internet companies collect, with some calling for legislation to give consumers control over their data. The hearing comes as Democrats prepare to take control of the House next month, and may lead to regulations limiting Google's online advertising businesses. Representative David Cicilline said the US needs clear regulations to ensure data belongs to consumers and can be granted consent to third-party access.

site_title: Neste invests 1.4b euros, builds new Singapore plant
summary: Neste, a Finnish energy giant, has announced a 1.4 billion euro investment to increase its biofuel production capacity in Singapore by 1.3 million tonnes per annum. The new plant, set to begin operations in 2022, will have a production capacity of up to 1.3 million tonnes and 100 new employees. The investment is based on growing global demand for low-carbon solutions and will increase Neste's total renewable product capacity to 4.5 million tonnes annually by 2022.

site_title: Pedro Pascal to lead cast of 'Star Wars' series
summary: Pedro Pascal, known for his roles in "Game of Thrones" and "Narcos," will lead the cast of Disney's upcoming "Star Wars" series "The Mandalorian." The live-action show, written and produced by Jon Favreau, follows Pascal's character as a lone gunfighter in the galaxy after the fall of the Empire. Other cast members announced include Gina Carano, Giancarlo Esposito, Nick Nolte, and Werner Herzog, with directors Taika Waititi, Bryce Dallas Howard, and Deborah Chow set to helm individual episodes.

site_title: Trump: 'Foolish' for US Fed to raise rates in December
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that raising interest rates by the Federal Reserve in December would be "foolish." This comes as the Fed is expected to increase rates next week. Trump's comments continue his criticism of the central bank, but no specific details or explanations were provided.

site_title: B2B payment solutions should leverage existing innovations
summary: Business-to-business (B2B) payment solutions are lagging behind retail payments due to high set-up costs and complex implementation processes. However, leveraging existing innovations such as electronic invoicing and digital wallets can reduce administrative costs by 60-90%. Regulators, banks, and technology firms are working together to boost electronic B2B payments in Asia, with measures including enhanced e-payments infrastructure, waived transaction fees, and increased cheque processing fees. A collaborative effort between businesses and regulators is necessary to make digital B2B payments a reality.

site_title: Shell appoints new Singapore chairman
summary: Shell appoints Aw Kah Peng as its new chairman in Singapore, effective January 1, replacing Goh Swee Chen after 15 years. Aw, a former Singapore Tourism Board CEO and EDB executive, joined Shell in 2012 and led the chemical intermediates business in the Asia-Pacific. Goh, who stepped down, established Shell as an employer of choice and partner in Singapore, earning the company's first Honorary Partner in Progress award from the government. Aw's appointment reflects Shell's commitment to Singapore's economic growth and social development.

images.alt_text: Ms Aw was CEO of Singapore Tourism Board and also served at the Economic Development Board.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel secures long-term ore supply contract worth over S$400m
summary: Silkroad Nickel, a subsidiary of Indonesian nickel mining group, has signed a long-term ore supply contract worth over S$400 million with PT Transon Bumindo Resources. The 5- to 8-year contract requires the delivery of 15 million tonnes of nickel ore, with a minimum annual shipment of 1.5 million tonnes. The agreement is expected to boost production and exploration efforts, with plans to acquire new concession areas. The contract's impact on the company's financials is minimal, and Silkroad Nickel is currently negotiating with a China state-owned company to increase production volume.

site_title: India's new central bank chief faces long to-do list
summary: India's new central bank governor, Shaktikanta Das, faces a long to-do list, including addressing a banking crisis, convincing investors of the institution's autonomy, and navigating tensions with the government. Das, a former economic affairs secretary, took office on Wednesday, two days after Urjit Patel's resignation amid concerns over government encroachment. The rupee dropped 0.4% against the dollar, while sovereign bonds rallied on optimism about a less hawkish monetary policy stance. Das's first test is a board meeting on Friday, where the government is expected to push for tighter supervision of the RBI.

site_title: For big tobacco and brewers, grass is greener
summary: Big tobacco and brewers are investing heavily in the marijuana industry, with Altria and Constellation Brands paying billions of dollars for stakes in Canadian cannabis companies. This influx of capital is expected to drive mainstream acceptance and create new economic opportunities. However, longtime cannabis advocates are concerned that small-time entrepreneurs may be left behind as large corporations dominate the market, potentially altering the industry's dynamics and priorities.

site_title: Malaysia charges ex-1MDB chief and Najib for audit tampering
summary: Malaysia charges former 1MDB chief Arul Kanda and former Prime Minister Najib Razak for allegedly tampering with a state audit report into the troubled state investment fund. Najib is accused of altering the report to protect himself, while Arul is accused of abetting him. They each face up to 20 years imprisonment and a fine if found guilty. The charges mark the first for Arul, who has pleaded not guilty, and follow earlier money laundering and corruption charges linked to 1MDB.

images.alt_text: The indictment is the first for former 1MDB president Arul Kanda, the highest-ranking 1MDB officer to be charged in Malaysia's revived investigation into the fund.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Video didn't kill the radio star
summary: Radio remains a dominant force across various media platforms, despite the rise of video content. According to Radiodays Asia spokesman Steve Ahern, radio's popularity has experienced a resurgence. This trend is attributed to radio's unique ability to engage listeners through live content, storytelling, and human interaction. As a result, radio continues to be the preferred medium for entertainment and information.

site_title: China's rich rush to shelter US$1t from new taxes
summary: Wealthy Chinese individuals are rushing to establish offshore trusts to shelter assets and income from new tax rules taking effect January 1, 2019. The Bank of Singapore has seen a 35% surge in Chinese clients interested in offshore trusts since 2018, with some using trusts to hold assets in tax havens like the Cayman Islands. The reforms aim to reduce tax burden on lower- and middle-income individuals by increasing taxes on the rich, and wealthy individuals are seeking to capitalize on "tax-planning opportunities" before the deadline.

site_title: Who will be Britain's next leader if May goes?
summary: British lawmakers triggered a confidence vote in Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership over Britain's planned divorce from the European Union, citing her handling of Brexit negotiations. Possible contenders to replace her include Esther McVey, Dominic Raab, Boris Johnson, and others. If May loses the confidence vote, a contest to replace her will begin, with contenders vying for the top spot.

site_title: Noble given further extension for restructuring
summary: NOBLE Group has been given a second extension for its restructuring bid, with a court-ordered administration hearing set for December 14 in Bermuda. The extension is key to its restructuring into New Noble. This follows the company's announcement on Tuesday night that it would apply for the hearing. The company has been struggling with financial issues, and this extension aims to facilitate its restructuring process.

site_title: Two German property firms to invest 1 billion euros in shared living
summary: Two German property firms, Corestate Capital Holding and Medici Living, plan to invest 1 billion euros in co-living developments in Berlin over the next three to five years. The project will feature tiny apartments with shared facilities, catering to young professionals priced out of major city housing markets. This investment is part of the growing demand for the "co-living" sector, where microflats are grouped around communal spaces such as dining areas and work spaces.

site_title: Sri Lanka parliament demands sacked PM to be reinstated
summary: Sri Lanka's parliament voted 117-0 to demand the reinstatement of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, who was sacked by President Maithripala Sirisena six weeks ago. The resolution, passed with support from Wickremesinghe's party and allies, comes as the country is on the brink of a government shutdown due to a bitter power struggle. The opposition-led parliament has blocked the prime minister's office from spending funds, and foreign investors are exiting the market due to the ongoing crisis.

site_title: Trade talk progress buoys Asian markets
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, following positive developments in US-China relations, including Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou's release on bail and China's agreement to cut tariffs on American-made cars. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) broke a six-day losing streak, closing 1.33% higher at 3,099.99, with gains outnumbering losses 239 to 143. Key indices in other markets also rose, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 climbing 2.15% and China's Shanghai Composite Index closing 0.31% higher.

site_title: Savour delightful Christmas magic
summary: A Singaporean publication features a Christmas-themed issue, showcasing local culinary talents, decorating ideas, and gift suggestions. The issue includes a dessert spread, a DIY guide to decorating the Christmas tree and wreaths, and a gift guide for various personalities. Additionally, it highlights an interview with Michael Tay, Singapore's former ambassador to Russia, and features articles on various lifestyle topics. The publication also shares decorating ideas and gift suggestions for the holiday season.

site_title: Australia growth to be hit by housing 'perfect storm'
summary: Australia's property market slump is expected to shave up to 1.2 percentage points from economic growth in 2019, with property prices predicted to drop a further 10% next year. The Reserve Bank of Australia is likely to cut interest rates in the second half of 2019 to support households. AMP Capital Investors' chief economist Shane Oliver notes that the decline in housing prices will lead to reduced demand and further price falls, potentially exacerbated by reduced immigration levels.

site_title: Analysts caught flat-footed in 2018
summary: Analysts had predicted a strong year for Asia's US dollar bond market in 2018, but the trade war and Chinese defaults led to the worst sell-off in a decade. Analysts from JPMorgan, Bank of America, UBS, BofAML, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and ANZ had forecasted varying returns, but the actual performance saw Asian investment-grade bonds lose 1.4% and high-yield bonds down 4.9%. The trade war and tightening credit conditions in China, including record defaults, contributed to the poor performance.

site_title: Consumer confidence up in Q3: Nielsen
summary: Consumer confidence in Singapore rose to its highest level since Q3 2015, reaching 98 points in the third quarter, despite being in pessimistic territory for the past three years. This increase is attributed to better economic prospects, but the index still lags behind the global level. The rise in confidence comes as the country prepares for upcoming elections.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KLW Holdings faces setback as first payment to investor Michael Chan Ewe Teik fails to materialize due to cheque dishonour. The company claims S$7.8 million from Chan, who has appealed against a bankruptcy order. Meanwhile, Cityneon Holdings is taken private after West Knighton Limited acquires 97.7% stake, and SIIC Environment wins a 54.6 million yuan wastewater treatment project in China. Jumbo Group opens its first Singapore outlet in a decade at Ion Orchard.

site_title: Singapore condo rents up 0.6% in November; HDB rents down 0.5%: SRX
summary: Singapore's private condo rents rose 0.6% in November, while HDB rents declined 0.5%. Year-over-year, private rents are up 0.3%, while HDB rents are down 1.3%. The rental market slowed for HDB properties, while private rents picked up. The number of condo and private apartments leased fell 11.2% in November, while HDB flat leasings dropped 10.1%. Experts attribute the slowdown to tenants opting for shorter lease periods and a growing demand for housing near digital tech hubs.

site_title: No signs of new property bubble in Spain, says central bank
summary: The Bank of Spain's governor, Pablo Hernandez de Cos, states there are no signs of a new property bubble in Spain, contrary to the 2008 crisis. The construction sector has shrunk to 5-6% of economic output, and mortgage lending has decreased significantly. Housing prices have risen but remain manageable, with prices still below pre-crisis levels. The central bank will continue to monitor the sector closely, indicating a stable market with no indication of over-valuation. This assessment is a positive development for Spain's economy, which has recovered from a nearly five-year slump.

site_title: Oil prices rise 1% on Opec sentiment
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Wednesday due to a stock market rebound and expectations of an Opec-led output cut for 2019, which would stabilize the supply-demand balance. Disruptions to Libyan crude exports also contributed to the increase. International Brent crude oil futures reached $60.84 per barrel, up 64 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $52.06 per barrel. Analysts warn of a global economic slowdown in 2019-20, citing rising interest rates and inflation.

site_title: KPMG issues disclaimer on Vibrant's financial statements
summary: KPMG has issued a disclaimer of opinion on Vibrant Group's financial statements for the year ended April 30, 2018, citing material uncertainties that may cast doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The auditors were unable to obtain sufficient evidence due to the destruction of Blackgold Group's accounting records and an ongoing special audit. As of April 30, Vibrant's current liabilities include S$160.3 million in loans and borrowings, which will become due if loan waivers lapse. The company's ability to pay debts depends on selling a property for at least S$220 million.

site_title: Can firms do well by doing good?
summary: Conventional business wisdom prioritizes maximizing shareholder value, but there's a growing counter-argument that firms should balance profits with social responsibility. Companies like those supporting Indonesian palm oil farmers, which contribute to haze pollution, face consumer backlash and potential business loss. This highlights the need for firms to consider wider stakeholder opinions and adopt a more balanced business model. By doing so, companies can benefit both their bottom line and society, and mitigate the negative consequences of crises. This shift in approach can lead to long-term sustainability and success.

site_title: Khaw welcomes Malaysia's move to de-escalate as two ships leave; urges complete withdrawal
summary: Malaysia has withdrawn two ships from Singapore's territorial waters, a move seen as a de-escalation of tensions between the two countries. However, one ship remains in Singapore's waters, prompting Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan to urge Malaysia to withdraw completely, citing "unnecessary risks" and potential for "accidental escalation."

site_title: Hyundai's plans seem short on substance
summary: Hyundai Motor Group unveiled plans to invest nearly $7 billion in fuel-cell vehicles over the next decade, with a target of producing half a million units. The company also appointed a new head of research and development and elevated its chief innovation officer to president. However, critics argue that Hyundai's R&D strategy is incoherent, with the company investing in both fuel cells and battery-powered electric cars, and that the investments lack substance and may not address the company's excess cash and dismal earnings.

images.alt_text: The US$7 billion South Korean auto group Hyundai is investing in fuel-cell vehicles commits it to a clean energy technology that has not got much traction in the auto world.

site_title: Economy watchers trim Singapore 2019 GDP forecasts
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to slow down, with private-sector analysts trimming their forecast for next year's GDP growth to 2.6% from 2.7%. The manufacturing sector, particularly the electronics segment, is seen as a drag, while the construction sector is forecast to finally turn positive with 1.5% growth. Trade protectionism and a slowdown in China are cited as top risks to the economy. Economists also predict a decline in non-oil domestic exports and a cooling of the finance and insurance sector.

site_title: Next EU cap on carbon dioxide still not decided
summary: EU negotiators are weighing a last-ditch attempt to reach an agreement on a tighter cap on carbon dioxide from cars by 2030, after failing to seal a deal in Strasbourg, France. EU governments and the European Parliament are at odds over a 40% vs 35% CO2 reduction target, while car-industry groups warn that the proposals would threaten jobs and consumer choice. A meeting is planned for December 19 to try to bridge the gap, with talks also focusing on an interim CO2-reduction target in 2025 and a sales quota for zero- and low-emission vehicles.

site_title: US dollar to gain still against Singapore unit into new year
summary: The US dollar is expected to continue its upward trend against the Singapore dollar in 2019, with some analysts predicting a rise above 1.40 in the first half of the year. Gradual US Fed rate hikes and moderating US growth in China and Asia due to the US-China trade conflict are key drivers of the US dollar's strength. However, uncertainty over the number of rate hikes and moderating US growth may cloud the greenback's prospects for the later part of next year, with some forecasts suggesting a decline to 1.30 by the end of 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
