summary: Malaysia's shares rose on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 10.64 points to 1,663.27. The market saw 1.9 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion traded, with 394 gainers outpacing 371 losers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers have upgraded their forecasts for Japfa Ltd, citing a rebound in PT Japfa Tbk and animal protein divisions. Maybank Kim Eng Research raised FY18E/FY19E/FY20E core profit estimates by 23%, 9%, and 9%, respectively, and target price to S$0.99. UOB Kay Hian Research maintained a "hold" rating for Sunningdale Tech, citing a potential boost to cash flow from the sale of a Chinese property.

site_title: Red tape, funding problems hamper Lion Air black box search
summary: Bureaucratic delays and funding issues have hindered the search for the Lion Air cockpit voice recorder, potentially complicating the investigation into the October 29 crash that killed 189 people. Weeks of delays may make it challenging to explain the cause of the disaster. In a rare test of global norms, investigators are turning to the airline to foot the bill for the probe's independence.

site_title: Tencent Music sets U$1.1b IPO at bottom of price range as markets gyrate
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group raised $1.1 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), pricing its shares at $13, at the bottom of its marketed range due to global market turbulence. The Chinese music-streaming service, backed by Tencent Holdings, debuted at a valuation of $21.3 billion, falling short of Spotify's $23.3 billion valuation. Analysts attribute the lower pricing to market skepticism about music streaming platforms and weak general market sentiment.

site_title: Thailand's Feb 24 election marks big step on return to democracy
summary: Thailand's February 24, 2019, general election marks a significant step towards returning to democracy after nearly eight years of military rule. The election pits the populist movement backed by former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra against the military and royalist establishment. The country's return to democracy is crucial, given its role as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) chair in 2019. The government aims to ensure a smooth election, as a disputed outcome could lead to violence and delay the formation of a government, potentially plunging the nation into chaos.

site_title: Canada court grants Huawei CFO bail
summary: A Canadian court granted bail to Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, 46, who faces US extradition for allegedly misleading banks about Iran-linked transactions. The bail, worth C$10 million, requires her to remain in Canada, be subject to electronic monitoring, and reappear in court on February 6. The decision may help ease tensions with China, which had threatened severe consequences if Meng was not released immediately. Huawei expressed confidence in the Canadian and US legal systems reaching a "just conclusion."

site_title: Singapore online printer Gogoprint buys Indonesia print startup
summary: Singapore-based Gogoprint acquired Indonesian printing startup Prinzio to boost business growth in Indonesia. Prinzio has worked with clients such as Google and Tokopedia, and its founder will join Gogoprint as co-founder. Gogoprint plans to invest in Prinzio's sales and marketing efforts to expand market share. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to tap into Indonesia's largest printing market, with steady growth expected in 2019.

site_title: Iconic Bangkok hotel calls time after slide in luxury room rates
summary: A Bangkok luxury hotel, Dusit Thani, will close next month for a $1.1 billion redevelopment, reducing its rooms by about half. The hotel, which has been a landmark since the 1970s, will transform into office, retail, and residential space due to intense competition in the city. The redevelopment is part of a joint venture with Central Pattana and aims to expand overseas revenue, with plans to purchase hotels in Europe. The move is seen as a necessary step to compete with other luxury hotels in the city, where rooms can sell for as low as 3,200 baht per night.

site_title: Credit Suisse to buy back stock, raise dividend
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG plans to buy back up to $4.14 billion of shares in the next two years and increase the dividend by at least 5% annually. The move comes as the bank aims to deliver on its pledge to boost payouts to investors despite a 37% slump in its stock this year. Under CEO Tidjane Thiam, the bank has pivoted to wealth management, slashing jobs and tapping shareholders for billions of francs of funding. Credit Suisse expects to pay out at least 50% of earnings to shareholders in 2019 and 2020.

site_title: US dollar rises for third day ahead of expected hike
summary: The US dollar rose for a third consecutive day ahead of a widely expected interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve next week. The dollar has gained nearly 6% against a basket of currencies this year, but market expectations suggest a more cautious view from the Fed. Sterling was the biggest gainer, rising 0.4% after Prime Minister Theresa May vowed to fight a challenge to her leadership. Market sentiment remains cautious, with investors expecting a wait-and-watch mode from the Fed on future rate rises.

site_title: Paul Singer's Elliott pounces on world's second largest distiller
summary: Billionaire investor Paul Singer's Elliott Management Corp has built a stake in Pernod Ricard SA, the world's second-largest distiller, with a 2.5% holding. The activist investment firm aims to boost returns and improve governance at the company, citing inadequate corporate governance and poor performance. Pernod Ricard's shares rose 4.3% in Paris trading after the announcement, and Elliott plans to push for a more diverse and international board, as well as a potential sale of the company if steps don't produce higher margins.

site_title: Cracks forming in global economy as trade tensions take centrestage
summary: The global economy is experiencing cracks as trade tensions between the US and China take center stage. Despite the International Monetary Fund's forecast of 3.7% global growth, the US slowdown and China's potential economic contraction threaten to undercut growth, hamper investment, and spur inflation. The US trade conflict with China could cut 0.8 percentage points off global growth, and businesses, farmers, and ranchers are already feeling the pain. The US economy is expected to see a slowdown from 2.9% growth to 2.5% next year, while China's economy is forecast to slow by a half point.

site_title: Accrelist calls off deal with blockchain service provider
summary: Accrelist, a Singapore-based corporate accretion services provider, has called off its proposed acquisition of a 10% stake in blockchain service provider AmazingTech Pte Ltd. The deal was meant to be valued at S$1 million, but parties were unable to reach a consensus on resolving difficulties and the period for completion had lapsed. The termination is not expected to have a material adverse impact on Accrelist's financial performance for the 2019 financial year. The acquisition agreements have been mutually terminated by Accrelist, AmazingTech, and vendors.

site_title: HK plans profits-tax exemption to woo hedge and private equity funds
summary: Hong Kong has proposed a profits-tax exemption for locally domiciled hedge and private equity funds, aiming to attract more funds to the city. The exemption, which would be the first for these types of funds, is expected to put Hong Kong on a level playing field with Singapore. The change, recommended for April 1, 2019, would also potentially attract more overseas asset managers and tech startups. The move comes after years of lobbying by Hong Kong's local asset management industry and a criticism from the European Union that the city's current profits tax regime for funds is "harmful".

site_title: India must regain investor trust
summary: India's reputation as a haven for foreign investors is under threat due to the government's actions, particularly the sudden resignation of RBI Governor Urjit Patel. Patel's departure, similar to that of his predecessor Raghuram Rajan, raises concerns about the autonomy of institutions. The government's aggressive push for fiscal and monetary policies is clashing with the RBI's traditional stance of advocating for a balanced budget and anti-inflationary policies. The appointment of Shaktikanta Das as Patel's successor may not alleviate investor concerns, as the government's actions have already eroded trust.

site_title: Jokowi to give poor Indonesians more money in election year
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo plans to double cash handouts to the poor, known as PKH, to 10 million families, increasing the aid from 19 trillion rupiah to 38 trillion rupiah in 2019. The increased funding is aimed at poverty alleviation and will be given in four phases, starting in January. Widodo is running for re-election in April 2019 and the move is seen as a way to boost popularity and meet development targets, but the Social Affairs Minister denies it's solely for election purposes.

site_title: Giving back is part of EY's DNA
summary: Professional services firm EY prioritizes community engagement and giving back through its staff. The company empowers staff to participate in formal and informal volunteer activities, including non-EY corporate volunteer activities of their choice. EY supports staff in Singapore to make a difference in their local communities through various initiatives, such as the Walk for Rice programme and the SGEnable RISE Mentoring programme, which aims to match students with disabilities with EY staff. The company's commitment to doing social good is woven into its DNA, with efforts focused on beneficiaries including SPD, Club Rainbow, and other charities.

site_title: OUELH to co-build international hospital in Shenzhen
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare (OUELH) signed a non-binding letter of intent with China Merchants Group to co-build an international hospital in Prince Bay, Shenzhen with over 200 beds. The hospital is expected to benefit from the growth of the medical tourism industry in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area. The project is subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals, with both parties negotiating definitive agreements by June 30, 2019. The partnership marks OUELH's commitment to grow its healthcare business in China and follows a strategic partnership announced in November 2017.

site_title: Seletar Airport flight procedures pose no risk to Pasir Gudang port, says Khaw
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan has stated that the country's plans to introduce an Instrument Landing System (ILS) for Seletar Airport, which will provide pilots with a recommended flight path, pose no safety or security risks to operations at Pasir Gudang port in Johor, Malaysia. Khaw clarified that ILS is a tool for pilots, allowing for manual intervention if necessary, and that technical concerns can be addressed through mutual agreement. The move comes as Malaysia seeks to reclaim air traffic services for the airspace over southern Johor, which were delegated to Singapore in 1974.

site_title: Balancing economy and environment
summary: China has made significant strides in controlling environmental pollution, faster than developed countries. Despite decades of double-digit economic growth, China's air, water, and soil pollution have become major concerns. However, since 2017, the Chinese government has taken a tougher stance on pollution, with stricter regulations and enforcement measures. Initial results show optimism, with reduced PM 2.5 levels in major cities and improved air quality. China is now leading the world in environmental pollution control, with a two-pronged approach to clean up its environment, including regulating discharges and cleaning up past pollutions.

site_title: Shell Singapore names Aw Kah Peng as chairman; Goh Swee Chen to retire in Jan 2019
summary: Shell Singapore names Aw Kah Peng as its new chairman, replacing Goh Swee Chen who will retire in January 2019 after 15 years at the company. Aw, a former Singapore Tourism Board CEO, has joined Shell in 2012 and is currently general manager for chemical intermediates in the Asia-Pacific. Her appointment comes after Goh's significant contributions to Shell, including establishing the company as an employer of choice and partner in Singapore, and hosting the first Make the Future in Asia festival.

images.alt_text: Ms Aw Kah Peng will be Shell Singapore's chairman from Jan 1.

site_title: More than half of Westpac shareholders vote against exec pay
summary: Westpac shareholders overwhelmingly voted against the bank's executive remuneration plans, with nearly two-thirds rejecting the proposals. This marks the bank's first time facing such a vote, following a year of misconduct allegations in the finance sector. The rejection is seen as a symbolic blow to the bank's pay practices, with investors demanding change. The Australian Council of Superannuation Investors stated that reducing bonuses by 25% was insufficient, and will vote against similar proposals at other major banks.

site_title: Underlying inflation steady, near Fed's goal
summary: US inflation remained steady in November, matching expectations, with the core consumer price index (CPI) rising 0.2% from the prior month and 2.2% from a year earlier. The increase was driven by rising wages, higher materials costs, and increased prices for housing, medical care, and used cars. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next week, but economists are divided on the path of interest rates beyond that.

site_title: Taiwan in grip of claw crane craze
summary: Taiwan is experiencing a surge in popularity of claw crane arcades, with the number more than doubling last year to become the fourth-largest tax income source in the entertainment industry. For a low NT$10 fee, customers manually lower a metal claw into a glass box to pick up prizes, often including soft toys, electronic gadgets, and fashion accessories. The craze has fueled a culture of enthusiasts sharing tips and swapping merchandise, with over 100 Facebook pages dedicated to the game. Operators see the machines as an effective investment, with some making up to NT$10,000 monthly profit per machine.

site_title: Jumbo opens first Singapore Jumbo Seafood outlet in 10 years in Ion Orchard
summary: Jumbo Group has opened its first Singapore outlet in 10 years at Ion Orchard, marking a return to the market after a decade. The 5,400 sq ft restaurant can accommodate 160 people and includes four VIP rooms. This move aims to attract both shoppers and the corporate crowd. The company now has 17 Jumbo Seafood outlets across Asia and plans to open more outlets in Singapore, including a new Teochew cuisine restaurant and Tsui Wah outlets.

site_title: The tide of gender inequality is blockchanging
summary: Blockchain technology offers a rare opportunity to empower individuals and promote equality, particularly in the tech industry, where women are underrepresented. Despite 66% of girls aged 6-12 being interested in computing, women account for only 4% of STEM field graduates and 13% of startup founders. The industry's patriarchal culture and lack of female representation lead to harassment, suppression, and unequal representation. Blockchain's principles of transparency and decentralization can help create a more inclusive and diverse industry, and education is key to empowering women in this field.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens sharply higher on trade optimism
summary: US stocks opened sharply higher on Wednesday, driven by optimism on trade after the Wall Street Journal reported on China's plans to increase access for foreign firms. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.57%, the S&P 500 gained 0.81%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.35%. This follows President Trump's upbeat comments on trade, adding to earlier market positivity.

site_title: Photonics lights the way for Singapore's Smart Nation
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation initiative is a leader in deploying disruptive technologies, including Internet-of-Things (IoT) and photonics, to improve citizens' lives. Photonics, which enables light-speed and super-energy-efficient data processing, is a game-changer in areas like driverless cars, telemedicine, and 5G services. With photonics, data centres can conserve power, and industries like automotive and healthcare can benefit from cost efficiencies and higher quality monitoring systems. As the nation pushes forward with its Green Data Centre initiative and massive IoT, photonics is poised to become the cornerstone of Singapore's Smart Nation, offering limitless possibilities for the future.

site_title: Red gold: Afghanistan's saffron harvest grows
summary: Afghanistan's saffron harvest has reached 13 tonnes in 2018, up from a tonne in 2013, with the country's farmers now earning a new source of income. The spice, dubbed "red gold," is being cultivated on 6,200 hectares of land, with authorities hoping it can replace the lucrative opium poppy trade. International aid has helped boost the sector, which has generated $35 billion in 2017. Despite falling prices due to mafias importing Iranian saffron, the increased cultivation is seen as a positive sign, with saffron now being exported to 17 countries.

site_title: Madrid temporarily bans 'oldest, most polluting' vehicles
summary: Madrid temporarily banned vehicles made before 2000 and diesel vehicles before 2006 from its city centre and surrounding M-30 ring road until Thursday, aiming to reduce emissions. The move, part of a new anti-pollution protocol, comes as the city battles high pollution levels. The ban affects 17% of Madrid's vehicles and follows similar restrictions in European cities like London and Stockholm. The goal is to reduce gas emissions by 40% in the historic city centre.

site_title: At least 150 lawmakers publicly back PM May ahead of confidence vote
summary: At least 150 Conservative Party lawmakers have publicly backed Prime Minister Theresa May ahead of a confidence vote in her leadership. To remain leader, May needs a simple majority of 158 out of 315 lawmakers. A secret ballot will be held later on Wednesday. However, some lawmakers who publicly support May may privately vote against her.

site_title: EU, Japan clinch record trade accord in shadow of protectionism
summary: The European Union and Japan have clinched a record trade accord, eliminating virtually all tariffs between the two partners. The agreement, which was endorsed by EU governments and the Japanese parliament, will take provisional effect on February 1. It will expand markets for services and public procurement, and bolster regulatory cooperation. The deal surpasses an EU accord with South Korea and marks the bloc's second major deal with a fellow G7 industrial nation, following a pact with Canada. The accord aims to promote a strong EU-Japan partnership in the face of protectionism.

site_title: Biofuel firm Neste to invest 1.4b euros in Singapore production
summary: Finnish biofuel producer Neste plans to invest 1.4 billion euros in Singapore to boost its biofuel production capacity to 4.5 million tonnes annually by 2022. The investment, which exceeds previous expectations, aims to strengthen Neste's competitive advantages in the renewable diesel market. The new production line is set to start in 2022, following existing facilities in Singapore, Rotterdam, and Finland. The move comes as global demand for low-carbon solutions grows, driven by increasing market demand for sustainable energy solutions.

site_title: Underlying US inflation picks up to keep Fed hike on track
summary: US inflation picked up 0.2% in November, matching estimates, as housing, medical care, and used car costs rose. The core consumer price index, excluding volatile food and energy costs, increased 2.2% from a year earlier, steadying around the Federal Reserve's 2% goal. Wage gains and higher materials costs amid the tariff war with China supported inflation. Investors await the Fed's interest rate decision on December 18-19, with some divided on the path beyond a projected hike.

site_title: Apple's "Netflix for Magazines" getting a chilly reception
summary: Apple's "Netflix for Magazines" initiative, which aimed to provide a digital platform for magazine readers, received a lukewarm response. Despite its introduction eight years ago, the idea of paging through magazines on an iPad never gained traction. Subscriptions have continued to decline, and ad revenue has shifted to online giants like Google and Facebook, leaving the publishing industry struggling.

site_title: Iran airlines need 500 planes, official mulls Sukhoi - reports
summary: Iran's Civil Aviation Organization head Ali Abedzadeh says the country needs around 500 planes and may back buying the Sukhoi Superjet 100 if Russia is willing to sell them. Iran's ageing passenger fleet requires upgrades, and the US sanctions on Boeing and Airbus due to the Iran nuclear agreement have limited options. Russian officials claim the Sukhoi Superjet 100 has reduced US parts, making it a viable alternative. IranAir had previously ordered 200 planes, but the US licence revocation has left them seeking alternative options.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare to build international hospital in Shenzhen with China Merchants
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare has signed a non-binding letter of intent with China Merchants Group to jointly build and operate a high-end international hospital in Shenzhen's Prince Bay, with over 200 beds. The hospital is expected to benefit from the growth of the medical tourism industry in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area. The project is subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals, with negotiations set to conclude by June 30, 2019.

site_title: Francis to say first Mass by a pope on Arabian peninsula in UAE
summary: Pope Francis will visit Abu Dhabi in the UAE from February 3-5, marking the first time a pope has traveled to the Arabian peninsula. During his trip, he will celebrate the first Mass by a pontiff on the peninsula at Zayed Sports City stadium, and visit one of the city's largest mosques. The trip aims to promote interfaith understanding and respect for religious freedom, which varies across Gulf countries.

site_title: Opec says it replaced Iran oil loss, sees lower 2019 demand
summary: Opec reported a 11,000-barrel-per-day decrease in oil output in November, despite US sanctions on Iran, as Saudi Arabia pumped at a record rate. The organization lowered its 2019 demand forecast to 31.44 million barrels per day, 100,000 barrels less than previously predicted. This decision comes after Opec and its allies agreed to return to supply cuts in 2019, aiming to lower output by 1.2 million barrels per day. The move aims to prevent a potential glut in the market.

site_title: Airline profits set to return to growth on boost from lower oil
summary: Airline profits are expected to return to growth in 2019, driven by lower jet-fuel costs and expanding economies. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) forecasts a 10% increase in industry-wide net income to $35.5 billion, with North America accounting for nearly half of the total. Europe's net earnings are expected to fall slightly due to intense competition, while Asia-Pacific carriers are predicted to see a profit increase of $10.4 billion. The outlook assumes an average oil price of $65 a barrel, up from $73 this year.

site_title: "I will contest that vote with everything I've got," says Britain's Theresa May
summary: Theresa May will contest a vote of no confidence in her leadership, which was triggered by at least 48 Conservative Party lawmakers expressing loss of confidence in her. The vote, scheduled for Wednesday, increases the chances of a pro-Brexit leader taking over and pursuing a more dramatic Brexit split. If she wins, May cannot face another confidence vote for a year. The leadership crisis comes as Brexit deal negotiations stall and exit day on March 29 looms.

site_title: Reits' asset injections: A little less action a little more discretion, please
summary: Reit investors are wary of recent cash calls by OUE Commercial Reit, Keppel-KBS US Reit, and Cromwell European Reit, which have drawn negative market reactions. The Reits are seeking to fund acquisitions through equity dilution or new debt, raising concerns about sell-downs. Analysts attribute the negative reactions to fears of a negative tax ruling, lower-quality portfolios, and market fatigue. Newcomers to the Reit scene, Keppel-KBS US Reit and Cromwell E-Reit, may have benefited from building a stronger track record of performance before re-tapping the market.

images.alt_text: In September, OUE C-Reit announced a S$587.5 million, massive 83-for-100 rights issue to part-fund the purchase of strata office space in the OUE Downtown building, which diluted DPU (distribution per unit) yield.

site_title: Greece seeks to avert nickel producer Larco shutdown
summary: Greece is seeking to prevent the shutdown of Larco, Europe's largest nickel producer, which owes 280 million euros in unpaid electricity bills to the state-controlled power utility PPC. Larco, 55% owned by the Greek state, employs 1,000 people in Greece. Energy Minister George Sthathakis held talks with PPC and Larco management, and a meeting with workers is scheduled. The European Court of Justice ruled in February that Greece should recover 135.8 million euros in state aid granted to Larco. Authorities are working to ensure no interruption to electricity supply.

site_title: Edition Limited calls off acquisition of Israeli cybersecurity firm
summary: Edition Limited has called off its planned acquisition of Israeli cybersecurity firm Hyperlync, citing unsatisfactory results from financial, legal, and operational due diligence. The two companies mutually agreed to terminate the acquisition, which had been valued at up to US$3.5 million. The decision is not expected to impact Edition's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the year ended December 31.

site_title: Carmakers remain in dark about next EU cap on carbon dioxide
summary: European Union negotiators may attempt to reach a deal on a tighter cap on carbon dioxide from cars by the end of the year, after failing to agree on a 2030 target. The EU Parliament wants a 40% cut, while governments call for a 35% reduction, with a proposed 30% cut by the European Commission. Talks will continue under the Romanian presidency starting in January if no agreement is reached.

site_title: Hitachi to buy ABB power-grid unit for 800b yen
summary: Hitachi Ltd is set to acquire ABB Ltd's power-grids business for up to 800 billion yen (S$9.6 billion). The deal, pending final assessment, would shrink ABB by around a fourth and vindicate activist investor Cevian Capital AB. The power-grids division, valued at over $10 billion, includes power transformers, long distance electricity-transmission systems, and energy storage units. The sale comes after ABB's quarterly results fell short of expectations, and the company's CEO, Ulrich Spiesshofer, defied investor pressure to sell the unit in 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally on talks hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied 1.61% on Wednesday, driven by upbeat developments in China-US trade talks, which boosted investor hopes. The Hang Seng Index rose to 26,186.71, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Economists forecast Singapore's 2019 GDP growth to ease to 2.6% due to trade tensions. Consumer confidence remains low but reached a 3-year high in Q3. Retail sales inched up 0.1% in October, while condo rents rose 0.6% and HDB rents dropped 0.5%. Singapore stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index up 1.33%.

site_title: Sri Lanka parliament demands sacked PM is restored
summary: Sri Lanka's parliament voted 117-0 to demand the reinstatement of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, who was sacked by President Maithripala Sirisena six weeks ago. The move comes amid a bitter power struggle and a potential government shutdown. The parliament has blocked the office of prime minister from spending funds, and officials fear a complete standstill in the public sector if a budget is not approved. The resolution's acceptance by President Sirisena is uncertain, and the crisis may lead to a government shutdown within weeks.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend gains on trade war hopes; UK shares up
summary: European shares rose, driven by renewed optimism on the US-China trade war. The Stoxx Europe 600 gained 0.3% led by technology shares, while retailers fell due to weak quarterly sales from Inditex SA. UK shares rose 0.4% amid news of a potential vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership. US-China trade talks are underway, with President Donald Trump expressing willingness to meet with President Xi Jinping. Investors welcome positive news amidst a negative mood.

site_title: North and South Korean soldiers enter each other's territory
summary: North Korean and South Korean soldiers crossed into each other's territory for the first time, marking a significant step in the demilitarization process. The move was part of an agreement between President Moon Jae-in and Kim Jong Un to dismantle guard posts in the Demilitarized Zone, a heavily fortified area along the border. Inspectors from both sides verified the removal of guard posts and firearms, with armed soldiers shaking hands before crossing into each other's territory. The event marks a peaceful crossing since the division of the peninsula in 1950.

site_title: BHP's US$320m copper mine sale called off, Chile Union says
summary: BHP's sale of its Cerro Colorado copper mine in Chile to EMR Capital Advisors has been called off due to the buyer failing to meet a financing deadline. The mine, valued at US$320 million, was expected to close in the fourth quarter but will remain within BHP's Pampa Norte division. The union had expressed concerns over possible job cuts and the environmental license is set to expire in 2023. BHP will continue to explore options to maximize the mine's value in the long term.

site_title: Europe is losing patience with Theresa May's Brexit chaos
summary: European leaders are losing patience with UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit chaos, with EU leaders consistently stating they regret the UK's decision but won't renegotiate the withdrawal agreement. May faces a vote of confidence in her leadership, but the countdown to March 29, the Brexit deadline, continues. The UK's departure from the EU has damaged its international reputation, with workers voting with their feet, and the economy 0.7% smaller than expected. EU leaders are urging the UK to accept the deal, but May's efforts to wring more concessions are being met with skepticism.

site_title: Indonesia's Tokopedia raises US$1.1b from top investors
summary: Indonesia's e-commerce site Tokopedia has raised US$1.1 billion in funding from top investors, including SoftBank and Alibaba, in its latest financing round. This underscores a push by foreign firms to tap the South-east Asian nation's growing online market. Other major investors, such as Expedia and Tencent, have also been investing billions in Indonesia's tech startups to capitalize on the country's burgeoning digital economy.

site_title: For big tobacco and brewers, grass is greener
summary: Big tobacco and brewers are entering the cannabis industry, with Altria paying $1.8 billion for a stake in Cronos Group and Constellation Brands investing $4 billion in Canopy Growth. This shift is expected to bring significant investments in product development, marketing, and manufacturing, potentially creating big brands in the market. However, long-time cannabis advocates worry that the idealistic entrepreneurs who made this moment possible may get left behind due to the industry's fragmentation and lack of federal legalization in the US.

site_title: Conservative lawmakers trigger no confidence vote in UK PM May's leadership
summary: UK Conservative lawmakers have triggered a no-confidence vote in Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership, citing the Brexit chaos and its impact on the economy. The vote was triggered after 15% of the parliamentary party, 47 lawmakers, signed a petition. The outcome will determine May's fate, with a ballot set to take place and an announcement expected in the evening. The vote's outcome will shape Britain's economy, unity, and global financial standing, with the UK's $2.8 trillion economy at stake.

site_title: Indian voters boot out cow, happiness ministers in state elections
summary: Indian voters have rejected two key ministers in state elections, ousting the country's only dedicated "cow minister" Otaram Dewasi and the "happiness minister" Lalsingh Arya. Dewasi lost by 10,000 votes in Rajasthan, where he had been in charge of the state's cow ministry since 2015. Arya, who was accused of murder, lost by 25,000 votes in Madhya Pradesh. The electoral defeats are seen as a major blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's image, who is seeking a second term in office.

site_title: Malaysia's October factory output up 4.2% y-o-y, above forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index rose 4.2% in October, exceeding the forecast of 3.3% annual growth, driven by a 5.4% annual increase in the manufacturing sector. The mining sector rebounded with a 1.4% annual growth, snapping a five-month decline. Exports surged 17.7% from a year earlier, mainly due to strong demand from China. This growth is a positive indicator for the country's economy.

site_title: Trade war damage to China's economy is already done: Citi economists
summary: Citigroup economists warn that China's economy has already suffered irreparable damage from the trade war with the US, even if a resolution is reached. The tariff war has led to a rise in labor costs, putting 4.4 million jobs at risk, and could cut China's export growth by almost half next year. China's cost competitiveness is losing ground, particularly in labor-intensive sectors, making it difficult to recover from the economic impact. The economists predict that China's GDP growth will slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Singapore retail sales inch up by 0.1% in October as growth tapers off
summary: Singapore's retail sales inched up by 0.1% in October, a slowdown from the previous month's 1.9% year-on-year increase. The growth was supported by sales of medical goods and toiletries, while some segments, such as takeaway food vendors and furniture, saw year-on-year declines. Petrol station sales surged 11.4% in October, while the food and beverage service sector saw a 1.1% year-on-year increase. Economists attribute the slowdown to consumers cutting discretionary spending amid market corrections.

site_title: Bright spots remain for Thai stocks, Philippine peso: DBS analysts
summary: DBS analysts Joanne Goh and Eugene Leow predict a positive outlook for Thai stocks and the Philippine peso despite regional growth risks. Thailand's general election in February 2019 and the Philippine central bank's interest rate hikes are seen as welcome moves. The analysts recommend core holdings in stocks with strong long-term outlook and high yields. For the peso, they note interest rates have stabilized and government bond yields have adjusted, with a preference for the two-year option due to its relative steepness. A smooth power transfer in Thailand is expected to boost domestic consumption and investment.

site_title: Economists fret over trade tensions, shave forecast for Singapore growth in 2019
summary: Economists in a recent poll by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have downgraded their forecast for Singapore's 2019 growth to 2.6% due to higher US-China trade tensions and a slowdown in manufacturing growth. The predicted decline in non-oil domestic exports and moderation in private consumption also contributed to the downward revision. However, some respondents noted that cooling trade tensions could lift the growth outlook, with 47% citing this as a potential upside.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up as trade war fears ease
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.15% on Wednesday, driven by easing trade war fears after Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou was released on bail. The Nikkei 225 index surged 454.73 points to 21,602.75, while the Topix index rose 31.30 points to 1,606.61. A weaker yen and positive media reports on China considering lowering tariffs on US cars also supported the market. Automakers such as Toyota, Honda, and Sony jumped, while Nissan rebounded after tumbling on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,091.65, up 1.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.05% on Wednesday, reaching 3,091.65, after 460.5 million securities worth S$424.5 million were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 189 to 108, with financials leading the active index stocks. DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank saw significant gains, while Ezion Holdings and MMP Resources also rose. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with the Straits Times Index (STI) notching a 5-day rally.

site_title: Singapore venture capital fund TNB Aura's first South-east Asia fund oversubscribed; raises S$31.1m
summary: TNB Aura, a Singapore-based venture capital fund, has successfully oversubscribed its first South-east Asia-focused fund, raising S$31.1 million. The fund primarily invests in data-driven B2B hardware-as-a-service and software-as-a-service companies, with portfolio companies including TradeGecko and Ematic Solutions. The fund's co-founder, Vicknesh R Pillay, expressed gratitude and excitement for the response, looking forward to investing in top startups in the region and establishing the fund as a top player in the area.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars upbeat on Sino-US trade hopes
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Wednesday as tentative signs of easing Sino-US trade tensions boosted risk appetite. The Australian dollar climbed 0.2% to US$0.7219, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.2% to US$0.6887. US President Donald Trump announced trade talks with Beijing were underway, with more meetings likely, and also confirmed China was buying a "tremendous amount" of US soybeans. Global equities and Asian-Pacific shares also gained, with US stock futures upbeat.

site_title: Australia shares rise on hopes for easing US-China dispute; NZ up too
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, tracking global markets on hopes for progress in resolving the US-China trade war. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,605.40. China is reportedly cutting import tariffs on American-made cars, and US President Trump said talks with Beijing are taking place by phone. However, investors remain cautious due to the 90-day deadline for a resolution. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.83% on the back of Trade Me Group's record high after agreeing to be acquired.

site_title: Congresswoman to Google CEO: When I search 'idiot' why do I get pictures of Trump?
summary: Congresswoman Zoe Lofgren asked Google CEO Sundar Pichai how the company's search algorithm shows President Trump's image when searching for the word "idiot". Pichai explained that the algorithm considers over 200 factors, including relevance and user behavior, to determine search results. The hearing aimed to address concerns about Google's search results being manipulated for political reasons, but lawmakers' understanding of the internet was largely lacking. Republicans questioned Pichai about potential manipulation of search results, but he assured them that algorithms are objective and unbiased.

site_title: Singapore condo rents up 0.6% in November; HDB rents drop 0.5%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents rose 0.6% in November, while HDB rents dropped 0.5%. Year-over-year, private rents are up 0.3% and HDB rents are down 1.3%. The number of condo rentals fell 11.2% in November, while HDB rentals decreased 10.1%. Experts predict a potential boost in the rental market due to the growth of the fintech industry, with more expatriates expected to move to Singapore for work.

site_title: Australia shares end firmer as US-China tensions ease; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% to close at 5,653.5, following US President Donald Trump's positive stance on trade relations with China, which raised optimism of easing discord between the two nations. Oil prices climbed over 1% on expectations of an Opec-led supply cut, boosting energy stocks. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.95% after Trade Me Group agreed to be acquired by a British private equity firm.

site_title: SIIC Environment bags 54.6m yuan wastewater treatment project in China's Heilongjiang province
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has been awarded a 54.6 million yuan wastewater treatment project in China's Heilongjiang province, valued at S$10.9 million. The 30-year service concession project, valued at 31,985 square meters, will have a design capacity of 10,000 tonnes per day, which can be scaled up to 40,000 tonnes per day. The project is expected to contribute positively to the group's performance, and SIIC Environment has incorporated a subsidiary to fulfill the project's obligations.

site_title: Hong Kong may hand tax breaks to woo hedge and private equity funds to its shores
summary: Hong Kong has proposed widening tax breaks to include hedge and private equity funds, aiming to attract more of them to the city. Locally domiciled vehicles will be eligible for a 16.5% profits tax exemption for the first time, on par with Singapore. The move comes after years of lobbying by the local asset management industry and follows criticism from the European Union about the city's current tax regime. The change is expected to put Hong Kong on a level playing field with Singapore and attract more overseas asset managers.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has proposed widening tax breaks to include hedge and private equity funds that are domiciled in the city in a move market watchers say should encourage more of them to move there.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on Hyundai Motor group's gains, Sino-U.S. trade hopes
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.44% on Wednesday, driven by gains in Hyundai Motor Co and its affiliates, as investors welcomed fresh hopes of a US-China trade war truce. Hyundai Motor Co's shares surged 6.3% after appointing a new foreign head of research and development, while its affiliates Hyundai Mobis and Hyundai Wia also rose. The won and bond yields also rose, and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index gained 1.31%. The Kospi is down 16.8% this year, but investors remain optimistic amid US President Trump's comments on a potential trade deal with China.

site_title: PODCAST: How to choose more flexible life insurance policies (Money Hacks, Ep 29)
summary: In a recent Money Hacks podcast episode, Walter de Oude, founder of Singapore Life, shares four steps to choose more flexible life insurance policies. The steps include deciding your needs, comparing products across the market, making a commitment to buy, and building a long-term insurance plan with a shield plan, critical event coverage, and disability income plan. De Oude emphasizes the importance of flexibility and modular buying approaches, particularly with term insurance, to suit individual needs. He advises listeners to build their insurance plans as they go along and consult with a financial adviser before making any decisions.

images.alt_text: Money Hacks co-hosts Ernest Luis (extreme left) and Chris Lim (extreme right) host Singapore Life's CEO Walter de Oude (second from right) and Robert Ross, its chief technology officer (second from left), as they chat about how to choose more flexible life insurance policies.

site_title: Marriott breach traced to Chinese hackers, US plans response
summary: The Marriott hotel chain's data breach, which exposed 500 million guest records, is linked to Chinese hackers working on behalf of the Ministry of State Security. The US plans to announce indictments against Chinese hackers and declassify intelligence on China's efforts to gather intelligence on US citizens and companies. This comes as trade talks between the US and China may falter, and the administration considers an executive order to restrict Chinese companies from obtaining critical telecommunications equipment. The breach has added urgency to the administration's crackdown, with Marriott's data containing passport information and credit card details.

site_title: Red tape, funding problems hamper Lion Air black box search
summary: Indonesian investigators are struggling to find the cockpit voice recorder of a crashed Lion Air Boeing 737 MAX due to bureaucratic delays and funding issues. The search for the second 'black box' has been hindered by budget constraints and the need for approvals, prompting the airline to foot the bill in a rare test of global norms on the probe's independence. The search is complicated by the need for a specialized ship to recover the main wreckage, with estimates suggesting a cost of $2.33 million every 10 days.

site_title: Stronger US dollar hits Indonesia despite rupiah resilience: Report
summary: Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, has shown resilience despite a strengthening US dollar, according to a Citi report. The country's net capital flows dropped in 2018, contrary to emerging markets' trend, due to concerns over a widening current account deficit. External debt related to foreign direct investment has grown, but the exclusion of inter-company loans reduced Indonesia's vulnerability to currency shocks. However, currency mismatch risks remain if businesses use overseas funds for domestic uses, posing potential risks to the economy.

site_title: Buyout offer for Cityneon crosses threshold for compulsory acquisition of all shares
summary: Cityneon's special purpose vehicle, West Knighton, has crossed the threshold for compulsory acquisition of all shares, securing a 97.7% stake in the company. The offer, launched by Cityneon group chief executive Ron Tan and Hong Kong entrepreneur Johnson Ko Chun Shun, aims to delist Cityneon and take it private. The acquisition threshold was triggered after the purchase of 68.95% of Cityneon Holdings shares, allowing West Knighton to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares.

site_title: Singapore online printing startup Gogoprint buys Indonesia printing business
summary: Singapore-based online printing startup Gogoprint has acquired Indonesian printing business Prinzio to boost its growth in the Indonesian market. Prinzio, backed by East Ventures, has worked with clients including Google and e-commerce firm Tokopedia. Gogoprint plans to invest in Prinzio's sales and marketing efforts to expand market share. The acquisition will help Gogoprint tap into Indonesia's largest printing market, driven by strong internet penetration and economic growth.

site_title: Asian markets perked up by positive China-US trade news
summary: Asian markets rose on positive China-US trade news, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul gaining 1.9%, 1.4%, and 1.3% respectively. China agreed to cut tariffs on US autos to 15% from 40%, and energy firms rallied after US stockpiles dropped, lifting oil prices. However, the pound remained down due to Brexit concerns, and investors remain cautious amid uncertainty over the UK's divorce from the EU.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won cheer on Hyundai Motor Group surge, US-China trade hopes
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.2% on Wednesday, boosted by Hyundai Motor Group's surge, with shares jumping over 7% after the appointment of a new R&D chief. US-China trade hopes lifted the market, with US President Trump sounding upbeat about a potential trade deal. The Korean won rose, and bond yields also increased, while Hyundai Motor's logistics arm Hyundai Glovis gained 8.8%. The market's price-to-earnings ratio is 12.10, and the Kospi is down 16.8% this year.

site_title: Noble gets key waiver for restructuring bid extended
summary: NOBLE Group has received a second extension until Dec 31 for a key waiver to proceed with its restructuring bid, allowing the company to avoid a buyout offer from creditors. The Securities Industry Council granted the extension due to the additional time needed for a court-ordered administration in Bermuda. Noble anticipates a restructuring effective date of Dec 18, subject to a court order on Dec 14, with existing shareholders retaining 20% of shares in New Noble.

site_title: Asia to grow as expected in 2018 and 2019, trade war poses downside risks: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has reaffirmed its growth forecasts for 2018 and 2019, expecting developing Asia to grow at 6% and 5.8% respectively, driven by strong domestic demand and easing inflation. However, the ADB warned of downside risks from rising trade protectionism. The bank maintained its growth projections for China (6.6% and 6.3%) and India (7.3% and 7.6%) for both years.

site_title: Gunman kills at least four people in French Christmas market
summary: A gunman killed at least 4 people and wounded 11 others near a Christmas market in Strasbourg, France, on Tuesday evening. The suspect, a 29-year-old known to security services, was cornered by police and shot, sparking a lockdown in the city. The motive behind the attack is unclear, but France is on high alert following a series of attacks since 2015. The European Parliament was also put into lockdown.

site_title: Trump says Fed 'would be foolish' to raise rates this month
summary: US President Donald Trump urged the Federal Reserve not to raise interest rates this month, calling it "foolish." Trump, who has criticized Fed Chairman Jerome Powell, said lower rates are needed to support the broader US economy amid a growing trade battle with China. Despite Fed officials signaling a cautious stance on further rate hikes, investors expect a 70% chance of a rate increase. Trump's comments are unusual for a US president, as the Fed's independence is typically respected.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence still in doldrums but hits 3-year high in Q3: poll
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index rose to a 3-year high in Q3, reaching 98 points, despite remaining in pessimistic territory. The index, based on personal finances, job prospects, and spending intentions, has been below the global index level since Q4 2015. Improvements were seen in all three indicators on a year-to-year and quarter-on-quarter basis, but optimism remains elusive.

site_title: Sydney house prices drop most in 30 years since 2017 peak
summary: Sydney house prices have dropped 10.1% since their 2017 peak, surpassing the 9.6% decline between 1989 and 1991, according to CoreLogic Inc. The decline is attributed to tighter mortgage lending standards and nervous buyers. Experts predict the housing market will continue to decline, with potential losses limited due to existing buffers in the form of insurance policies. The Reserve Bank of Australia has expressed concerns about the potential for a significant price decline, but analysts believe a rate rise is unlikely in the near future.

site_title: Malaysia charges ex-1MDB chief and Najib for audit tampering
summary: Malaysia charges ex-1MDB chief Arul Kanda and former leader Najib Razak with tampering with a state audit report into the troubled fund 1MDB. Najib is accused of altering the report to protect himself, while Arul is accused of abetting him. Both have pleaded not guilty and face up to 20 years imprisonment and a fine if found guilty. The charges are the first for Arul, the highest-ranking 1MDB officer to be charged, and come as part of Malaysia's revived investigation into the fund, which is linked to a global scandal of $4.5 billion misappropriated.

images.alt_text: Ex-1MDB president Arul Kanda and Malaysia's former leader Najib Razak were charged for their alleged roles in tampering with a state audit report into the troubled fund.

site_title: BlackRock sees 'prolonged' slump in Australia's housing market
summary: BlackRock's head of fixed income for Australia, Craig Vardy, predicts a prolonged housing slump in Australia, lasting 12-18 months. National home prices may drop another 10% and consumer confidence will be hit in 2019. The housing market has peaked, with residential construction indicating a decline. The Reserve Bank of Australia keeps its benchmark low amid concerns of declining housing prices affecting consumer spending. A change in government could also impact property investors, with potential removal of tax breaks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.87% on Wednesday, driven by a cheaper yen and a rebound in European bourses. The Nikkei 225 index increased to 21,331.08, while the Topix index rose 0.82%. Automakers such as Toyota, Honda, and Nissan advanced, while Sony and Panasonic also saw gains. The US dollar depreciated against the yen, reaching 113.35 yen in early Asian trade. Despite lingering concerns over trade conflicts and Brexit, the market rebounded from recent declines.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 6.14 points (0.37%) to 1,657.09. The market saw 64.8 million lots traded worth RM19.9 million, with 106 gainers outnumbering 34 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.5% to 3,075.1
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.5% to 3,075.1 points. About 40 million shares worth S$81 million changed hands, with Ezion Holdings being the most actively traded stock. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 33. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid positive sentiment despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Global Palm Resources unit to buy 95% stake in oil palm plantation firm owned by CEO and siblings
summary: Global Palm Resources Holdings will acquire a 95% stake in PT Bumi Raya Agro, an Indonesian oil palm plantation firm, for 23.6 billion rupiah (S$2.2 million). The firm is owned by Global Palm Resources executive chairman and CEO Suparno Adjianto and his siblings. The acquisition aims to expand revenue and geographical coverage, and increase Global Palm Resources's oil palm plantation land. No production or sale of crude palm oil and palm kernels have been initiated by PT Bumi Raya Agro.

site_title: Voluntary delisting of LTC approved
summary: Singapore's Steel trading and property group LTC Corp will be delisted after the controlling Cheng family successfully passed a voluntary delisting resolution with 98.5% of shareholders voting in favor. The decision comes after the Chengs failed to procure 90% of shares to take the company private due to minority shareholders refusing to tender their shares at a low price. The exit offer will remain open for acceptance until Dec 27.

site_title: McDonald's unveils plan for cutting antibiotics in beef
summary: McDonald's plans to reduce antibiotics in beef through a three-stage process, starting with a study of top beef markets and establishing reduction targets by 2020. The fast-food giant aims to report progress against targets and joins other companies like Walmart and Tyson Foods in restricting or phasing out antibiotic use in chickens. The move follows warnings about antibiotic resistance and a UN General Assembly resolution, with experts praising McDonald's for taking leadership in addressing the issue, which affects 43% of medically important antibiotics sold to the livestock industry for beef.

site_title: New Zealand's online marketplace Trade Me backs offer from UK firm, shares hit new record high
summary: Trade Me Group, New Zealand's top online marketplace, agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Apax for NZ$2.56 billion, after a rival offer was matched. The deal is subject to shareholder and court approval, with shares reaching a record high of NZ$6.38. The acquisition is seen as a loss for the New Zealand stock market, which faces de-listings and a shift of Xero to the Australian stock exchange. Trade Me shareholders are pleased with the offer, considering it an attractive price given current market conditions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hong Lai Huat, Sunningdale Tech, Chip Eng Seng, Accrelist, KLW Holdings
summary: Hong Lai Huat's S$15.7 million hotel sale in Cambodia has been terminated due to the buyer's partial payment. Sunningdale Tech sold a factory in China for S$28.9 million to a door and furniture maker. Chip Eng Seng Corporation redeemed S$107 million in principal from its Series 002 and S$99.75 million from Series 003 notes. Accrelist called off its proposed acquisition of AmazingTech Pte Ltd due to difficulties. KLW Holdings' first payment to a claimant bounced, delaying settlement.

site_title: US dollar near 1-month high on bounce in US yields, weak pound
summary: The US dollar is near a one-month high against its peers, driven by a rebound in US yields and weakness of the pound, which is battered by Brexit uncertainty. The dollar index rose to 97.420, its highest since November 13, with long-term US Treasury yields bouncing from three-month lows. The pound has lost 1.8% this week, while the euro is a shade higher at $1.1333. China's yuan firmed in offshore trade, and the Australian dollar is up 0.35% at $0.7228.

site_title: Google's CEO, Sundar Pichai, testifies on Capitol Hill
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai testified before the House Judiciary Committee, addressing concerns over the company's market power, plans to relaunch Google in China, and potential bias in its search results. Republicans questioned Pichai about the company's commitment to free expression, while Democrats focused on privacy and competitive practices. Pichai defended Google's practices, stating that the company offers users controls for limiting location data collection and does not sell user data. The hearing also highlighted concerns about Google's handling of user data, including a recent security vulnerability in Google Plus that exposed 52 million users' information.

images.alt_text: Sundar Pichai, Google's chief executive, testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday. Here are some highlights.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed amid trade talks, shutdown angst
summary: US stocks ended near flat, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 24,370.24, after a mixed session driven by positive trade talks and a government shutdown threat from President Trump. Despite reports of China agreeing to cut tariffs on US autos, stocks tumbled in the afternoon after Trump's meeting with Democratic leaders. Investors expressed concerns over the impact of government shutdowns on the market, with banking shares under pressure.

site_title: Accrelist calls off acquisition of stake in blockchain firm
summary: Accrelist, a corporate accretion services provider, has called off its proposed acquisition of a 10% stake in blockchain firm AmazingTech Pte Ltd due to difficulties in fulfilling conditions of the sale and purchase agreements. The deal's termination is not expected to have a material impact on Accrelist's financials. The parties have mutually agreed to release and discharge their obligations, and the consideration of S$1 million will be returned. The decision comes after the period for completion had lapsed.

site_title: KLW says S$1m settlement cheque bounced
summary: KLW Holdings reported that a S$1 million settlement cheque for a legal settlement with investor Michael Chan Ewe Teik bounced upon presentation. The cheque was due for clearance on Dec 10, and KLW is now considering its options against Mr Chan. The company is claiming S$7.8 million from Mr Chan for legal costs and commitment fees. KLW advised shareholders and potential investors to exercise caution when dealing with its shares as the matter is ongoing.

site_title: A weakening profit outlook is the latest worry for the S&P 500
summary: Analysts have reduced forecasts for S&P 500 profits in the fourth quarter to $41.58 a share, a 2.5% decrease from two months ago. This marks the largest reduction in a quarter since 2017. Despite expected 14% growth, the reduction suggests investors are concerned about the market's future direction, particularly regarding trade and the Federal Reserve. Equity valuations have decreased to 15 times forecast earnings over 12 months, raising questions about whether the market is overvalued.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Car of The Year Nominees Pt 1
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars" features a discussion on the nominees for Sgcarmart's Car of the Year. The podcast highlights some of the top contenders, including the MG ZS Hybrid+, BMW's next big thing, and the 2025 Kia Carnival and Sorento. No clear winners are announced, but the podcast emphasizes that the nominees are worth considering for those in the market for a new car. The discussion is hosted by Claressa Monteiro of Prime Time on MoneyFM 89.3.

site_title: When aces take golfers to fancy places
summary: Former North Korean leader Kim Jong-Il reportedly achieved five holes-in-one at a private round of golf at the Pyongyang Golf course, while US President Donald Trump has bagged numerous aces at his golf courses. Trump's 2016 golf game was marked by several aces, including one at a corporate event where General Electric CEO Jeff Immelt shared his recollection of the game. This year, only a handful of aces were recorded at local clubs, with no one winning a car offered as a prize in a corporate golf league.

images.alt_text: As a 16-year-old amateur in 2011, current rookie pro Abdul Hadi won an Audi car for his ace at a corporate event at the Glenmarie course in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Fund in US$800m deal to buy AirAsia planes
summary: US private investment firm Castlelake has agreed to buy a portfolio of 30 narrowbody planes from AirAsia for approximately US$800 million. The deal marks AirAsia's move to monetize its assets as it seeks to transform into a digitally focused firm. Castlelake, which has raised US$1 billion from investors, is expanding its exposure to aviation assets, with this being one of its biggest deals in Asia. The deal is expected to close in the next few weeks.

site_title: Canadian court grants bail to CFO of China's Huawei
summary: A Canadian court granted bail to Meng Wanzhou, Huawei's CFO, who faces extradition to the US on charges of misleading banks about Iran-linked transactions. Meng, 46, was granted bail subject to a $10 million guarantee and electronic monitoring. The decision could help ease tensions between Canada and China, which had threatened severe consequences if Meng was not released immediately. Meng must reappear in court on February 6.

site_title: Europe: Trade war optimism lifts shares
summary: European shares rose 1.5% as optimism over China-US trade talks lifted sentiment, despite two-year lows earlier. The Stoxx 600 benchmark index recovered from worries over slowing global growth. China's preparation to cut tariffs on US car imports and discussions between US and Chinese trade officials boosted markets. The US and China agreed to a ceasefire in their trade war after high-stakes talks in Argentina. The auto and tech sectors led gains, while materials stocks rose due to boosted metal prices.

site_title: Gold steadies near 5-month peak as US rate hike expectations ease
summary: Gold prices steadied near a five-month peak as expectations for fewer US interest rate hikes in 2019 and 2020 eased market concerns. Spot gold held at $1,243.34 per ounce, while US gold futures settled down 0.18% at $1,247.20 per ounce. The US Federal Reserve's signal of potential neutrality supports lower interest rates, reducing the opportunity cost of holding bullion and weighing on the US dollar.

site_title: Oil rises on optimism Opec+ supply curbs will stabilise market
summary: Oil prices rose as Opec+ announced production cuts, with West Texas Intermediate futures gaining 2.8% before settling at $51.65 a barrel. Saudi Arabia plans to slash output to 10.2 million barrels a day in January, while Russia will reduce output by at least 50,000 barrels a day. However, analysts remain cautious about the pact's effectiveness, citing weaker oil demand and booming US shale output. The market is also influenced by US-China trade talks and President Trump's threat to shut down the federal government.

site_title: Violent stock reversals are coming faster than at any time since 2011
summary: US stocks experienced violent reversals, with the S&P 500 wiping out a 1.4% rally on Tuesday and a 1.9% loss on Monday. The Dow Jones fell 53.02 points to close at 24,370.24, with swings of over 500 points. This marks the sixth day this quarter with a reversal of at least 1%, the most since 2011. Market volatility is attributed to shifting narratives on interest rates and US-China trade, causing frustration for money managers who have been caught off guard.

images.alt_text: The 30-stock Dow Average fell 53.02 points to close at 24,370.24 after swinging more than 500 points.

site_title: Nov condo resale prices reverse 3 months of slide with 0.2% gain
summary: Resale prices of private non-landed homes in Singapore increased by 0.2% in November, reversing three months of declines. Year-on-year, prices rose 8.8% from November 2017, but fell 0.7% from their peak in July. Buying activity remained lacklustre, with 662 units resold in November, a 4.6% decline from October. Experts say the resale market has yet to reach equilibrium due to mismatched price expectations between buyers and sellers, and a fair amount of latent demand is expected to build up in the coming months.

site_title: Big coal wants taxpayers to pay for pollution fix
summary: Big coal companies are pushing for taxpayers to fund carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, a $90 billion-a-year cost to slow global warming. CCS captures pollution from industrial plants and injects it underground, reducing greenhouse gases. Industry leaders argue that CCS is necessary and doable, but challenges include funding, environmental opposition, and technical hurdles. Governments and companies are exploring funding options, including carbon taxes, subsidies, and regulations. Despite the hurdles, the industry is pressing ahead, with several projects underway, including a UK government-backed CCS project and a biomass CCS pilot in Europe.

site_title: Singapore firms tap US$4.9b from equity markets year to date
summary: Singapore companies raised US$4.9 billion in equity capital markets (ECMs) from January to December 2018, a 30.1% decline from 2017. This is the lowest annual period in terms of proceeds since 2015. However, follow-on offerings accounted for 70.8% of total proceeds, with the real estate sector contributing 77.4% or US$3.8 billion in proceeds, up 8.2% from 2017.

site_title: Ex-bureaucrat is new Indian central bank chief
summary: Former Indian bureaucrat Shaktikanta Das, 63, has been appointed as the new governor of the Reserve Bank of India for a three-year tenure, succeeding Urjit Patel. Das, who oversaw the government's cash ban programme, will face pressure from the government to loosen curbs on weak banks and ease liquidity. The move aims to address economic concerns ahead of the upcoming election. Das' appointment is seen as a shift towards a less hawkish stance, potentially paving the way for a rate cut, which could help mitigate the impact of the government's budget deficit.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research maintains "hold" ratings on City Developments and Starhill Global Reit. City Dev's shares are trading at attractive valuations but face limited catalysts due to a property market slowdown. Starhill Global Reit's diversified portfolio and attractive yield are seen as positives, with a target price of S$0.75 and 7-8% DPU projections. Executing a development at Wisma Atria could yield upside to net asset value and DPU in the medium term.

site_title: May tours Europe in frantic bid to save Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May embarks on a European tour to salvage her Brexit deal, following a parliamentary vote delay. She met with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and EU leaders in Brussels. The EU had reached an agreement on November 25, but May faces a rebellion over the Northern Ireland clause. The EU may offer a "political declaration" to provide reassurance, but no major concessions are expected. The UK will still leave the EU on March 29, and a no-deal Brexit is expected to be damaging to the economy.

site_title: Great Eastern to acquire Indonesia insurance firm for US$28m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is acquiring Indonesia-registered PT QBE General Insurance Indonesia for US$28 million (S$38.4 million), as part of its strategy to build its general insurance operations in Indonesia. The acquisition, expected to be completed in the first half of 2019, will complement Great Eastern's existing life insurance presence in Indonesia, with the market potential being "tremendous" due to Indonesia's low non-life insurance penetration rate. The transaction is subject to approval by Indonesia's financial services authority and the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Vivendi eyes stake in Indonesia's largest media company
summary: Vivendi, a French conglomerate, is in talks to invest in Indonesia's largest media company, PT Global Mediacom, with a potential deal valued at over $400 million. Vivendi's Canal+ arm is interested in acquiring roughly half of PT MNC Vision Networks, a pay-TV arm, and 10% of PT Media Nusantara Citra, a free-to-air TV operation. The deal could be limited by Indonesian regulations, and other bidders may emerge. Shares of Global Mediacom and Media Nusantara Citra have risen significantly following the news, with Global Mediacom jumping 12% and Media Nusantara Citra rising 2.7%.

site_title: China's Tencent Music raises nearly US$1.1b in US IPO
summary: China-based music streaming company Tencent Music Entertainment Group raised nearly US$1.1 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO), pricing its American depositary shares (ADRs) at the low end of its indicated range. This tops a bumper year for US listings by Chinese companies, with US$7.9 billion raised prior to Tencent Music's debut, the highest amount since 2014. The IPO marks the fourth largest among Chinese firms this year, following video streaming company iQiyi Inc and online group discounter Pinduoduo Inc.

site_title: Last-minute toy shoppers may find only empty shelves in stores
summary: Last-minute toy shoppers may face empty shelves in stores as popular items sell out by the week before Christmas, marking the first holiday season without Toys R Us. Retailers like Amazon, Walmart, and Target are increasing toy inventories, but experts say they aim to sell out by Christmas, potentially leaving shoppers with limited options. The toy industry's sales are highly specific and inflexible, making it a high-stakes market for buyers.

site_title: Markets only now facing up to big risks in 2019
summary: The US stock market is experiencing volatility despite a strong economy, with the S&P 500 down 8% over the last two months. The causes of this volatility are not new, including the effects of three years of Federal Reserve interest rate increases, the ongoing trade war with China, and the expiration of the 2018 tax cut. Economists had expected slower growth in 2019 and 2020, but markets are only now recognizing these risks. The Federal Reserve faces a tricky period, balancing the need to adjust to the early rounds of interest rate increases with the risk of a potential slowdown or recession.

images.alt_text: Markets look forward and the risks looking forward seem increasingly ominous even as everything continues to go swimmingly, especially in the US labour market, as 2018 nears its end.

site_title: En bloc hopefuls cut prices as reality bites
summary: Homeowners in Singapore's en bloc market are adjusting their expectations, with some developers cutting prices. Park View Mansions, a 191,974 sq ft development, relaunched its tender at S$250 million, down 22% from its initial price. Other projects, such as Gilstead Mansion and La Ville, have also lowered their reserve prices. Despite the downward trend, some developers remain optimistic about the market, citing the potential for redevelopment in the Jurong Lake District and the lack of new government land sales sites in the area.

site_title: Insurance coverage gives a view into changing landscape of alternative investments
summary: Rare whisky has seen a 140% appreciation in value over the last five years, prompting insurance companies to expand coverage. Whisky collectors now number over 1,000, with AIG seeing an almost tenfold increase in new submissions for whiskey insurance. The trend also reflects a shift in wealth distribution among younger generations, with luxury items like watches, cars, and whisky gaining popularity. This shift is also evident in the collectible car market, where younger buyers are driving growth, and in the art market, where interest in protection for high-value items is increasing.

images.alt_text: Rare whisky has appreciated 140% in the last five years, according to the Vintage 50 Index compiled by Rare Whisky 101.

site_title: China court bans sales of older iPhones in Apple-Qualcomm row
summary: A Chinese court has ordered a sales ban on older iPhone models from Apple, including the 6S, 7, 8, and iPhone X, due to patent infringement by Qualcomm. The ban, although not enforced yet, affects Apple's business in a crucial market. This dispute is part of a global patent battle between the two US companies. The ban creates uncertainty for Apple's shares, which have been impacted by waning demand for new iPhones. The case is part of dozens of lawsuits between the two companies.

site_title: Uncertainty clouds Asian markets
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed trading session, with the Straits Times Index down 0.43% to 3,059.28, marking a sixth consecutive decline. Global uncertainty over trade talks between China and the US, as well as Brexit concerns, weighed on markets. The Hang Seng and Shanghai Composite rose, but other issues, including the Reserve Bank of India's governor Urjit Patel's resignation, negatively impacted markets. Australian shares, however, ended higher, despite the S&P/ASX 200 hovering near two-year lows.

site_title: India's richest man splurges US$100m on daughter's wedding
summary: Isha Ambani, daughter of India's richest man Mukesh Ambani, has spent $100 million on her wedding festivities, which include a private concert by Beyoncé at the Oberoi Udaivilas hotel in Udaipur, India. The lavish celebrations, dubbed "the big, fat Indian wedding," have drawn international attention, with guests including former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Bollywood stars. The union between Isha and Anand Piramal, a member of India's second-richest family, will unite the business empires of two of India's wealthiest families.

site_title: Malaysia plans RM19.9b rescue of Islamic pilgrim fund
summary: Malaysia's finance ministry has approved a plan to rescue the Islamic pilgrim fund Lembaga Tabung Haji, which requires a RM19.9 billion (S$6.5 billion) special purpose vehicle to manage underperforming assets. This move aims to balance the fund's books by year-end and ensure continued dividend payments for Hajj journeys. The plan, announced on Tuesday, will help the fund stay financially stable and avoid any disruptions to pilgrim journeys.

site_title: Trump team pushes fossil fuels at global climate talks
summary: US President Donald Trump's top energy adviser Wells Griffith pushed for fossil fuels at the global climate talks in Katowice, Poland, sparking protests. The US delegation, led by career bureaucrats, continues to advance the Trump administration's agenda, despite public support for fossil fuels. The administration's stance on climate change has shifted since 2014, when President Barack Obama and Chinese leader Xi Jinping signed a deal to limit greenhouse gas emissions. The US has blocked full endorsement of a critical UN climate report, raising concerns about the country's influence on the talks' success.

site_title: It's a briefcase. Pizza box? No - it's a mini-satellite!
summary: California officials announced the full containment of the Camp Fire, the deadliest wildfire in state history, thanks to a swarm of tiny, orbiting satellites operated by Planet Labs. The satellites, carrying cameras and telescopes, can view the same spot on the ground once or twice a day, enabling rapid environmental monitoring and damage assessments. This technology allows for more complete and regular observation of Earth's environment, and its miniaturization has made it more accessible and affordable for a wider range of interests.

site_title: Thai junta lifts campaigning ban, polls set for Feb 24
summary: Thailand's junta lifted a four-year ban on political campaigning ahead of 2019 elections, with polls set for February 24. The ban was imposed after the 2014 coup, which ousted Yingluck Shinawatra's government. The junta's decision allows political parties to campaign, but analysts warn the military may still restrict rallies and silence critics. The junta leader, Prayut Chan-o-cha, aims to block the Shinawatra clan from returning to power, with a new charter set to limit the number of elected seats and introduce appointed positions.

site_title: Skilled workforce will steer maritime success
summary: Singapore aims to become a digitally driven maritime industry by 2025, driven by partnerships, training, and initiatives to woo and retain talent. The new Tuas mega port will feature automated yard cranes and port equipment, and the International Maritime Centre 2030 Strategic Review outlines the vision for Singapore to be a global maritime hub. The Sea Transport Industry Transformation Map aims to create a value-add of S$4.5 billion and 5,000 jobs by 2025, emphasizing the need to empower and train a future-ready workforce.

site_title: Likely trajectory of Fed policy far from settled
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is expected to raise the target range for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points to between 2.25 and 2.50% in December, effectively aligning with the lower-end range of the longer-run nominal funds rate. The tone of the December statement is likely to be reasonably upbeat, and the chances of altering the phraseology of the forward guidance are high. The composition of the funds rate projections is expected to shift down on average, with the odds of two hikes in 2019 increasing.

site_title: Pound rises off 20-month lows after Brexit blow
summary: The British pound rose 0.4% against the US dollar, recovering from 20-month lows, after Prime Minister Theresa May sought support from European leaders to change her Brexit deal. May met Dutch and German leaders in a last-ditch bid to save her deal before an EU summit on Dec 13-14.
