site_title: Landmark Tower buyer continues to seek funds to finance collective sale
summary: ZACD Group, a Singapore wealth management and real estate services company, continues to raise funds for its stake in the collective sale of the Landmark Tower. The company aims to raise S$55 million by the end of Q1 2019 to pay for its share of the enbloc purchase, which includes a S$286 million site purchase price. The project is expected to launch in the second half of 2019 at a low S$2,000 per square foot price point, targeting young professionals and families.

site_title: Few Venezuelans turn out for municipal elections amid crisis
summary: Venezuela held municipal elections, but turnout was low due to the country's devastating economic crisis. The opposition boycotted the vote, and many Venezuelans preferred to shop for scarce food and medicine instead. Despite this, President Maduro cast his vote, claiming the country has a strong democracy. The ruling Socialist Party is expected to dominate the election, with full results not yet released. The crisis has halved the economy and forced 3 million people to emigrate, with hyperinflation and rampant crime rampant.

images.alt_text: Venezuela held municipal elections to elect some 2,500 counselors on Sunday, though the mainstream political opposition boycotted the vote and widespread apathy kept most people at home during a devastating economic crisis.

site_title: Nissan seeks to block Ghosn's access to apartment in Rio
summary: Nissan is seeking to block former chairman Carlos Ghosn's access to an apartment in Rio de Janeiro, citing a risk that he may destroy evidence related to his financial misconduct. Ghosn, arrested in Tokyo on November 19, is suspected of conspiring with Greg Kelly to understate his compensation. A Brazilian court granted Ghosn access to the apartment, but Nissan is now petitioning a higher court to reverse the decision. Nissan is cooperating with authorities and aims to prevent the destruction of potential evidence.

site_title: Sugar cane key to Mauritius' renewable energy goal
summary: Mauritius, a self-reliant island nation, is shifting towards renewable energy by burning leftover sugar cane stalks and tips, known as "bagasse," to generate 14% of its electricity. The island aims to increase renewable energy to 35% by 2025, with plans to build 11 solar parks and two wind farms. The sugar industry, which generates 60% of the island's electricity, will continue to provide the largest share of renewable electricity from bagasse. However, the industry faces challenges due to declining sugar prices and increased competition from other producers.

site_title: Paving its way to deliver quality healthcare
summary: Clearbridge Health, a Singapore-based healthcare group, plans to focus on partnerships with primary healthcare providers in populous countries and cities. Since its listing in 2017, the company has acquired stakes in Philippine and Indonesian healthcare providers, aiming to deliver quality, low-cost healthcare. Clearbridge Health deals in precision medicine, using technologies to improve clinical outcomes and reduce chronic diseases. The company balances business viability with its core mission of creating stakeholders' value, prioritizing partnerships with healthcare providers and deploying clinically viable technologies. Clearbridge Health aims to expand into Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines, with the goal of becoming profitable by the end of 2019.

images.alt_text: "I project that hopefully by sometime next year, we will cross the inflection point and become profitable." - Jeremy Yee, executive director and CEO of Clearbridge Health.

site_title: For US allies, "mad dog" Mattis is the last adult in the room
summary: US allies are concerned about the impending departure of Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, the last adult in the room, as White House Chief of Staff John Kelly is set to leave. Mattis, nicknamed "Mad Dog," has worked to constrain President Trump's unpredictable policies, particularly on defense and economic issues. His departure would be a significant blow to US allies, who rely on him to guide and restrain the administration. Mattis has been a key player in shaping US foreign policy, and his departure raises questions about who will replace him and whether the US will continue to uphold its traditional values and interests.

site_title: Beyond Asia, BreadTalk has sights set on Europe and US
summary: BreadTalk, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, aims to expand globally, with CEO Henry Chu setting a goal to reach a S$1 billion market capitalization and improve net profit over the next 5-10 years. The company plans to grow its footprint in Europe and the US, with a focus on preserving its brand identity. Recent moves include the opening of the first Din Tai Fung restaurant in Europe and plans for further expansion in the UK, with potential destinations in Italy, France, and Germany.

site_title: Online property sales are booming in China
summary: China's online property sales are booming, with global funds and individuals snapping up distressed properties. Listings on Alibaba's Taobao auction site rose 88% in October, reaching a record 1.3 trillion yuan. Properties are typically sold at 2/3 of market value, with prices pushed up to 90% in heated bidding. Individuals seek to buy online to circumvent austerity measures in larger cities, but buyers must conduct due diligence to understand the situation, as significant taxation costs may not be listed.

site_title: South African gold industry enters final phase of slow death
summary: South Africa's gold industry is in its final stages of decline, with most mines being unprofitable at current prices. The nation's 130-year-old gold industry, which produced half of the world's mined gold, now contributes only 1% to the economy, down from 3.8% in 1993. The industry's demise has been exacerbated by dwindling output, and the ruling ANC is criticizing Gold Fields' plan to cut jobs ahead of elections next year. The industry's collapse marks the end of an era for South Africa's gold mining sector.

site_title: Dollar falls as jobs report disappoints
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro after a jobs report showed employers hired fewer workers than forecast in November, raising concerns about US growth and the Federal Reserve's rate hike plans. Despite this, wage growth was in line with expectations, keeping the Fed on track to raise rates in December. The dollar was 0.32% lower against the euro, and US yields have been chipping away at the greenback's yield differential advantage.

site_title: Saudi Arabia hosts GCC summit amid Qatar tensions, Khashoggi crisis
summary: Saudi Arabia hosts the GCC summit in Riyadh amid tensions with Qatar over the Jamal Khashoggi murder and a protracted boycott. The summit may focus on security issues, including the Yemen war and Iran's regional activities. US officials urge the Gulf states to mend ties, including for a proposed Middle East security alliance. Qatar's withdrawal from Opec appears to deepen the rift, with the boycotting states downplaying the dispute's priority. The GCC's unity remains imperiled, and a near-term resolution to the dispute is unlikely.

site_title: Early Uber investment makes millions for Lance Armstrong
summary: Lance Armstrong, the disgraced cyclist, has seen a significant return on investment in Uber Technologies Inc. after investing $100,000 in venture capital fund Lowercase Capital in 2009. According to Bloomberg, Armstrong's investment has made him around $20 million, despite initial reports suggesting a 10-figure stake. Uber's valuation has soared, with some estimates suggesting it could be worth $120 billion on the public markets. Armstrong attributed his investment to "too good to be true" and "saved our family."

site_title: Failure to recognise vulnerabilities behind my error in Noble
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, experienced a spectacular collapse in 2015 after a short-seller, Iceberg Research, published allegations against the company. The company's failure to recognize vulnerabilities, including mark-to-market accounting, quantitative easing-driven commodity price increases, and the explosion of information, led to its downfall. Noble's operating earnings rose 40% in 2010, but the company's stock doubled and then collapsed, losing 98% of its market value. The company has since agreed to a debt-for-equity restructuring and is now staring at bankruptcy.

site_title: Insuring seniors: devil's in the details
summary: A study commissioned by NTUC Income found that nearly three-quarters of seniors in Singapore (63%) find the standard health underwriting questionnaire tedious, "too broad and vague," and requiring excessive disclosure, making it difficult for them to obtain insurance. This may be a significant barrier to insuring Singapore's ageing population, highlighting the need to simplify and improve the health underwriting process.

site_title: IMF chief economist predicts 'sharper' US slowdown in 2020
summary: IMF chief economist Maurice Obstfeld predicts a 'sharper' US slowdown in 2020, citing a marked slowing in world economic growth. The US growth is expected to slow to 2.5% in 2019, down from 2.8% initially predicted. Obstfeld attributes the slowdown to the fading effects of the Trump administration's fiscal and budgetary measures. Global economic growth is expected to be weaker, with the rest of the world experiencing a 'balloon' effect, affecting the US. Trade frictions, particularly between the US and China, are a major concern for global growth.

images.alt_text: "We have long been predicting somewhat lower (US) growth for 2019 than what we are seeing this year," as the effects of the Trump administration's fiscal and budgetary measures begin to fade, IMF chief economist Maurice Obstfeld said.

site_title: Australian voters shun conservative government in widely watched poll
summary: Australia's conservative government, led by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, is on course for a landslide election defeat, according to a widely watched survey. The survey showed the government's support at 35%, just one percentage point above its record low, and predicted a loss of 21 seats in the lower house of parliament. Morrison's personal approval rating has fallen to a three-month low, and he faces a heavy defeat at the next election, due by May, with few tools to win over voters.

images.alt_text: Australia's conservative government is on course for a landslide election defeat, a widely watched survey showed on Monday, as Prime Minister Scott Morrison struggles to win favour with voters less than six months out from a national poll.

site_title: Sexual harassment in the sky: HK flight attendants fight back
summary: Hong Kong-based flight attendants are speaking out against sexual harassment in the workplace, citing a lack of support from supervisors and inadequate training. Many attendants have reported being harassed by passengers and other airline staff, with some even being told to change their appearance to avoid incidents. Despite efforts by some airlines to address the issue, workers argue that more needs to be done to create a culture of awareness and respect. The Cabin Attendants Union of Hong Kong is calling for an awareness-raising campaign and education on how to deal with harassment.

site_title: Hardy survivors of S-chip fallout worth a second look: analysts
summary: Analysts are reevaluating the Singaporean (S-chip) market, focusing on established companies such as Yangzijiang, China Sunsine, and China Aviation, despite past accounting scandals. Experts caution against complacency, as smaller S-chips struggle to stay competitive. Meanwhile, the Singapore public offer of NTT DC Reit was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: Lean In strives to move beyond Sheryl Sandberg
summary: Lean In, a women's empowerment group founded by Sheryl Sandberg, is shifting its focus away from its former leader. Despite Sandberg's founding influence, the organization's staff and board members have made it clear that the group's mission has evolved beyond her. The organization's president, Rachel Thomas, stated that while Sandberg's book inspired the work, it's no longer the central focus. The group has also rebranded and expanded its initiatives, indicating a move towards independence from Sandberg's influence.

site_title: Danske Bank elects new chairman to steer it through crisis
summary: Danske Bank has elected Karsten Dybvad, a 62-year-old former CEO of the Confederation of Danish Industry, as its new chairman amid a multi-billion euro money laundering scandal. The election follows the ousting of Ole Andersen, who was ousted by the bank's top shareholder, the Maersk family. Dybvad will lead efforts to restore the bank's image and find a new CEO to address potential legal cases, particularly in the US. The move aims to minimize fines and maintain day-to-day business operations.

site_title: Grave dilemma: S African cities short of cemetery space
summary: South Africa is facing a grave shortage of cemetery space due to population growth, urbanization, and cultural resistance to cremation. Cities like Johannesburg and Durban are experiencing high demand for burial plots, with some areas reaching capacity in as little as 50 years. Authorities are exploring creative solutions, including reusing graves and promoting cremation, but resistance from traditional communities and concerns about cultural practices hinder progress. If left unaddressed, the shortage could lead to a crisis, with officials considering expropriation of land to address the issue.

site_title: Neymar is brand ambassador of Qatar National Bank
summary: Brazilian soccer star Neymar has been appointed as the global brand ambassador for Qatar National Bank (QNB). The 25-year-old forward, known for his massive social media following, shares the same values as the bank, including a pursuit of excellence and achieving great results. This partnership comes as PSG is set to end its decade-long relationship with Emirates Airline, following a soured relationship between Qatar and the UAE. Neymar's contract with QNB is part of his club's efforts to secure more lucrative sponsorship deals.

site_title: Brexit surprise or Fed U-turn on rate hikes may break downtrend
summary: The US stock market is experiencing wild swings due to developments in the trade war and Brexit. Despite a brief boost from reduced tensions between the US and China, the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted last week after the arrest of a Huawei executive, wiping out a 4% gain from the previous week. A weak jobs report and the threat of a US-China trade war ceasefire being derailed also contributed to the volatility. A potential Brexit surprise or a Federal Reserve U-turn on rate hikes could break the downtrend and lead to a relief rally in global stocks.

site_title: China factory prices rise at slowest pace since Oct 2016
summary: China's factory prices rose at their slowest pace since October 2016, with a 2.7% increase in November from a year earlier, according to the National Statistics Bureau. Domestic demand lost momentum, and consumer inflation eased due to lower food prices. The producer price index (PPI) fell 0.2% on a monthly basis, marking the weakest factory activity in over two years. The slowdown in domestic demand adds pressure on policymakers, who are also dealing with a trade war with the US and concerns about the tariff war escalating.

site_title: Centurion hits first closing of global student housing fund
summary: Centurion Corporation has announced the first closing of its second student accommodation fund, the Centurion Student Accommodation Fund, with a total committed capital of S$70 million. The fund aims to generate stable income through investments in purpose-built student accommodation globally. A "third-party cornerstone investor" has committed S$60 million, while Centurion's wholly-owned subsidiary has contributed S$10 million. The fund currently holds a 133-bed facility in the UK and is expected to deliver a total return. The successful first closing reflects confidence in Centurion's management capabilities and the PBSA asset class.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights reports on the tanker and dry bulk market for the week ending December 9, 2018. VLCC rates in the Middle East Gulf softened to WS 97/97.5 for 270,000mt to China, while rates to the US Gulf remained steady at WS 43/43.5. In other news, Tesla launched its first Indian store, Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, and Nissan is poised to issue a record-high coupon in a US$4 billion bond sale.

site_title: Dutch hospitals to stop buying body parts from US
summary: Two major Dutch hospitals, Academic Medical Centre (AMC) and Erasmus Medical Centre, will stop importing human body parts from US firms amid investigations into body brokers that obtain bodies through donation and sell parts for profit. The decision was made on ethical grounds, following reports by Reuters on how brokers acquire body donations. The hospitals bought body parts, including heads and joints, for research and training courses, but will drop the suppliers in response to concerns raised by Reuters. The move comes after US authorities suspect MedCure, a US-based broker, sold body parts tainted with disease to customers.

images.alt_text: A view of the laboratory at the Academic Medical Centre (AMC), showing a place where body parts were used for research and training, in Amsterdam.

site_title: Highlights of some retirement income endowments
summary: Manulife offers endowment products to help individuals save for retirement and withdraw an income over several years. These products can simplify asset allocation, but come with a cost and require a long-term commitment. Early surrender may result in minimal cash value. Prudential also provides a single premium retirement income plan, which is another option for those seeking to manage their retirement income.

site_title: Post-retirement investing: how much to put in and take out
summary: A post-retirement investment strategy is crucial for ensuring a sustainable income in the decumulation phase. Large fund houses like JP Morgan Asset Management and BlackRock are offering products that cater to this phase, which involves investing while withdrawing an income. Key considerations include longevity, sequence of return risk, withdrawal rate, and investment risk. Experts recommend planning for 30 years or more of living expenses, taking into account household income, inflation, and asset allocation. A flexible withdrawal rate approach, considering market returns, can also help mitigate risks and ensure a sustainable income in retirement.

images.alt_text: There is a wealth of literature and products to help you save for retirement, but what happens when you are in retirement is something of a void.

site_title: Libyan state oil firm scrambles to keep El Sharara oilfield open
summary: Libyan state oil firm NOC has confirmed that the El Sharara oilfield remains open despite a threat from security forces to shut down production. The field, which produces 315,000 barrels of oil per day, was targeted by the Fezzan Anger Movement after they announced a closure. NOC accused the security guards of facilitating the protests and warned of "catastrophic consequences" if production is shut down. The situation remains tense, with engineers attempting to negotiate with the security guards and tribesmen to avoid a shutdown.

site_title: No support from Merkel's party for Germany taking stake in Deutsche Bank
summary: Germany's ruling party, the Christian Democratic Union, opposes taking a stake in Deutsche Bank AG using public funds, despite government support for a merger with Commerzbank AG. Senior officials cite concerns about taxpayers' money and the argument for a 'big bank' as insufficient justification. The government has explored alternative scenarios, including Deutsche Bank raising money from German industrial companies or creating a holding company to own stakes in both banks. Despite Finance Minister Olaf Scholz's repeated statements on the need for strong banks, the CDU's resistance signals substantial political opposition to deploying public funds.

site_title: Belgium's Africa Museum had a racist image. Can it change that?
summary: Belgium's Africa Museum in Tervuren reopened after a $73 million renovation, aiming to shake off its racist and pro-colonial image. The museum, which had collected over 120,000 items from Congo and Rwanda, has reordered its displays to highlight the problems of colonialism and feature new wall texts. However, some critics argue that the artifacts' presence in a Belgian museum remains problematic, and pressure to return items to their countries of origin is growing, including from Congo's President Joseph Kabila and Congolese artist Aimé Mpane.

site_title: Brexit vote to go ahead in Parliament: minister
summary: UK's Brexit vote is set to proceed as planned on Tuesday, despite reports suggesting Prime Minister Theresa May may delay it to seek a better EU deal. Brexit minister Stephen Barclay confirmed the vote will go ahead, while lawmakers and EU leaders express concerns over the deal, particularly the Irish "backstop". The deal's rejection could leave May's future as prime minister uncertain and put Britain in "uncharted waters" if it loses the vote, with EU leaders set to meet in Brussels on Thursday.

site_title: Bunge is open to talks with Glencore, ADM as CEO set to leave: source
summary: Bunge Ltd is set to announce the departure of its CEO, Soren Schroder, which clears the way for further talks with potential buyers, including Glencore and Archer-Daniels-Midland Co (ADM). The company has been open to re-engaging with these suitors following an agreement with activist investors in November. Bunge, which has struggled with the US-China trade war and agricultural downturn, is worth $8.3 billion and could be the subject of a major shake-up, with a potential deal involving the "ABCD" group of companies dominating agriculture for over a century.

site_title: Singapore venture capital firm eyes North Asia play
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm Golden Equator Capital (GEC) is launching a S$120 million fund with Korea Investment Partners (KIP) to help South-east Asian startups expand into North Asia, excluding China. GEC aims to build regional icons that can scale globally. The firm is leveraging KIP's 32 years of experience and connections to chaebols, powerful family-run conglomerates in South Korea, to facilitate M&As and investments in the region.

site_title: Manafort lied about Trump administration ties, Mueller says
summary: Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort lied to prosecutors about his contacts with a business associate with ties to Russian intelligence and his efforts to reach someone in the Trump administration. Mueller's filing states Manafort misled investigators about his communications and a meeting with Konstantin Kilimnik, and that he authorised someone to speak to a Trump administration official on his behalf. Manafort was convicted of bank and tax fraud and had breached his plea deal by lying to investigators, leaving the possibility of a new charge open.

site_title: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres starts young but grows fast
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) is rapidly expanding its presence in Singapore, with its Loyang site set to be completed in 2020. The 290,000 sq ft facility will be the largest in the group's portfolio, boasting a 35 megawatt capacity and a market-leading power usage efficiency of 1.3. STT GDC aims to further solidify its position among the top five data centre providers in Singapore with its Loyang site. The company has achieved rapid growth, considering it was founded in 2014, and is now a major player globally, with over 70 data centres across Asia, China, India, Thailand, and the UK.

site_title: Role of non-profit boards in driving innovation
summary: Non-profit boards play a crucial role in driving innovation within organizations. A survey found that CEOs and chairs of social service organizations in Singapore felt that technology could increase efficiency and create new solutions. However, resource constraints may limit innovation in non-profit organizations. Despite this, innovation can lower per-client operating costs, freeing up resources for growth. Non-profit boards should set the innovation agenda, working with management to leverage technology and create new solutions, ultimately benefiting the organization and its clients.

site_title: Noble disputes regulators' allegations of improper accounting
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, is disputing allegations of accounting irregularities by Singapore regulators, who claim the company's figures may be inaccurate. Noble has submitted a comprehensive response to the allegations, which include issues with derivative treatment, recognition of gains and losses, and classification of assets. The company denies targeting any individuals in the probe, but regulators say their scrutiny encompasses Noble and its officers. The dispute raises questions about the uncertainty and dispute over the company's numbers, with experts citing the use of estimates and assumptions in commodities trading.

site_title: Slow recycler Turkey seeks better uses for its trash
summary: Turkey, a country with a poor recycling record, is launching a pilot project to promote recycling through vending machines at three Istanbul subway stations. The machines give extra credit on the city's public transport card for each plastic bottle or can deposited. The initiative aims to increase public awareness and reduce waste, with the goal of recycling 35% of waste by 2023. The Turkish government has also announced plans to introduce a compulsory charge for plastic bags and to increase recycling rates, with the aim of reducing plastic bag usage from 440 to 40 per year by 2025.

site_title: Bruised eurozone economy stumbles on after 2018 beating
summary: The eurozone economy is experiencing a slowdown after a year of challenges, including freezing weather, trade wars, and budget disputes. Germany's economy contracted over the summer, while Italy is at risk of a triple-dip recession. Despite this, economists believe growth will continue, albeit at a low level, with the European Central Bank preparing to halt its stimulus program. Global trade tensions, particularly with China, are a concern, but economists forecast growth above long-term potential, with some predicting a potential rebound if US-China trade tensions ease.

site_title: US-China trade talks, data to give market direction
summary: US-China trade talks and data will influence market direction in the final weeks of the year. The arrest of Huawei's CFO and concerns over the US economy's outlook due to a yield curve inversion added uncertainty. Despite this, investors are looking for upside to close the year. Markets are also reacting to various corporate and regulatory news, including NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed public offer, Creative Technology's revenue warning, and London's plans to increase Heathrow fees.

site_title: Switzerland plays for time in stock market stand-off with EU
summary: Switzerland has delayed a decision on a framework agreement with the European Union, opting for a national debate instead. The EU has urged a "swift" consultation period, but Switzerland's government is seeking to avoid a confrontation with the EU and its citizens. The agreement would affect how Switzerland adopts EU law, but its approval is uncertain due to opposition from nationalists and labor unions. The Swiss equity market's equivalence status with the EU expires on December 31, and Switzerland is trying to find a loophole to prevent a market downturn.

site_title: Buick claims to solve age-old dilemma: Where to hide Xmas gifts
summary: Buick's 2019 Enclave luxury SUV claims to solve the age-old dilemma of hiding Christmas gifts by offering numerous storage compartments, including a large cargo hold and a centre console with a false floor. A survey conducted by The Harris Poll found that 82% of parents struggle to find new hiding spots for gifts each year. The SUV's hidden storage space aims to provide a solution to this problem, but some experts note that it may not be a foolproof solution, as many SUVs already have open trunks.

site_title: Din Tai Fung brand strong enough to grow in Europe, says BreadTalk chief as first outlet opens in London
summary: BreadTalk, a Singapore-based company, has successfully opened its first Din Tai Fung outlet in London's Covent Garden district. The 8,000 sq. ft. restaurant features an open-concept kitchen and signature steamed dumplings. CEO Henry Chu believes the brand's 50-year history, Michelin Star, and global presence make it strong enough to grow in Europe. Despite concerns about the UK's exit from the EU, Chu plans to hire staff from Taiwan and Singapore to support operations, and also aims to hire locals. This marks the 153rd Din Tai Fung outlet globally, with plans for more locations in Singapore, Thailand, and other international markets.

site_title: S$23m in buybacks; 3 Hong Fok directors increase interests
summary: Straits Times Index (STI) declined 5.2% for the year, amid regional downturns. For the five trading sessions ended Dec 6, the STI gained 0.2%, outperforming other regional benchmarks. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Share buybacks totaled S$23m, with 3 Hong Fok directors increasing their interests.

site_title: Centurion announces first closing of global student housing fund
summary: Centurion Corporation has announced the first closing of its global student housing fund, raising S$70 million. The fund, which excludes the US, aims to generate stable income and deliver a total return. A third-party cornerstone investor, a reputable educational institution, committed S$60 million, while Centurion Overseas Investments contributed S$10 million. The fund currently holds a 133-bed facility in the UK and expects to receive capital contributions by Dec 14. This marks the second student accommodation fund from Centurion, following a successful inaugural private fund that closed last year.

site_title: Oil may see a short-term recovery
summary: Oil prices have plummeted by over 30% from their peaks, with Brent and WTI falling 20% in November. The decline was triggered by a surge in global oil supply, US sanctions on Iran, and weak global demand. Despite this, analysts believe oil prices may see a short-term recovery, with prices potentially rebounding above $52.20 and reaching a medium-term target of $58.95. However, a bearish scenario also exists, with prices potentially retreating to $48 and $46 supports.

site_title: China urges Canada to release Huawei CFO
summary: China has warned Canada that releasing Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, arrested on Dec 1, would be "extremely nasty" and could lead to severe consequences. Meng faces extradition to the US on charges of covering up Huawei's links to Iran despite sanctions. China's Vice-Foreign Minister Le Yucheng summoned Canada's ambassador to Beijing and urged the release of Meng, citing a breach of her lawful rights. The warning comes amid strained relations between the two countries, with China threatening to freeze high-level visits and exchanges if Meng is not released.

site_title: Uzbekistan pulls out the stops for fine winemaking
summary: Uzbekistan is launching an ambitious state-led winemaking drive, aiming to increase wine exports by 60% by 2021 and double the area under cultivation. President Shavkat Mirziyoyev's plan includes introducing internationally renowned grape varieties such as Chardonnay and Cabernet, and partnering with foreign investors. However, industry experts have raised concerns about Uzbekistan's ability to produce fine wines, citing climate and labor challenges. Despite initial reservations, some local farmers, like Abdumutal Yuldashev, are optimistic about the prospects and plan to expand their operations.

site_title: China's trade surplus with US hits record even as growth slows
summary: China's trade surplus with the US reached a record $35.6 billion in November, driven by a 9.8% rise in exports and a 25% decline in imports. Despite a slowdown in global demand and uncertainty over the trade war, shipments rose 5.4% in November. Economists predict a further slowdown in China's economy, with export growth expected to decline to low single-digits next year. The record trade surplus comes as the US and China agree to work toward a substantive agreement within 90 days, potentially buying time for manufacturers to adjust to the trade war.

site_title: Ted Baker founder steps aside as retailer probes new allegations
summary: Ted Baker founder Ray Kelvin will take a voluntary leave of absence after company officials learned of "further serious allegations" regarding his conduct, following reports of unwanted hugs and other incidents. Kelvin will step aside as CEO while an independent investigation is conducted. The company has also created a committee of non-executive directors to address employee concerns. The allegations have led to a significant drop in the company's shares, raising speculation about a potential takeover. Acting CEO Lindsay Page will take over Kelvin's role.

site_title: Germany's Street Scooter gets green light for full production of small e-van
summary: Germany's Street Scooter unit has received approval from federal transportation authorities to start full production of its small electric minivan, the WORK. This comes as cities struggle to meet EU pollution norms, with diesel-powered vehicles a key culprit. The production ramp-up will enable Street Scooter to meet growing demand and increase its capacity to up to 20,000 electric vans per year, with a second plant in Dueren. This move is seen as a positive step towards reducing emissions in Germany's transportation sector.

site_title: Huawei CFO being prosecuted for fraud, Canada says
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou was charged with conspiracy to defraud banks and denied bail due to her wealth, which would allow her to pay and flee. The US alleges Huawei used a firm to do business with Iran, breaching sanctions, and Ms Meng hid ties between the companies. The Canadian court hearing was part of the US extradition request, which aims to bring Ms Meng to the US to face charges.

site_title: Comey says he'll return for more closed-door GOP questioning
summary: Former FBI Director James Comey said he will return for a second meeting with House lawmakers on December 17 after a day of closed-door questioning related to Hillary Clinton's emails. Comey expressed concern over the lack of transparency and stated that the FBI does not want him to discuss an ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential campaign. Despite Republicans' demands for Comey to testify on his handling of the Clinton email case and the FBI's investigation into Russian ties to Trump's campaign, Democrats have criticized the probe as unwarranted and premature.

site_title: China Nov exports gain 5.4% y-o-y, imports up 3%, far below forecasts
summary: China's November dollar-denominated exports rose 5.4% from a year earlier, below forecasts, while imports expanded 3.0% also below expectations. This resulted in a trade surplus of US$44.74 billion. Analysts had predicted a 10% increase in exports and 14.5% increase in imports. The weak export outlook, due to US tariffs and China's slowing economy, has led policymakers to focus on growth-boosting measures.

site_title: China launches rover for first far side of the moon landing
summary: China successfully launched the Chang'e-4 lunar probe mission, becoming the first nation to land on the far side of the moon. Launched on December 8, 2018, the rover is expected to land around the New Year to carry out experiments and survey the untrodden terrain. The mission marks a significant milestone in China's space program, with the country aiming to establish a crewed space station by 2022 and eventually send humans to the moon.

site_title: Neo-Nazi guilty of murder over Charlottesville rampage
summary: A US jury found James Alex Fields Jr, a neo-Nazi, guilty of murder and multiple counts of aggravated malicious wounding for killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer at a 2017 white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. Fields was found guilty of first-degree murder and various other charges, carrying a possible life sentence. The verdict came after a two-week trial, with prosecutors arguing that Fields intentionally targeted counter-protesters, while defense lawyers claimed he was scared and hoping for a lesser charge. The guilty verdict brings closure to the victims' families and marks a significant step in holding those responsible for the violence accountable.

site_title: Airbus wins December deliveries some breathing room after busy November
summary: Airbus has trimmed its December delivery target to 109 aircraft, down from 127 last year, to reach a core target of 782 deliveries for 2018. The company had initially set a target of 800 deliveries but excluded 18 A220 models previously, cutting the core target by 2%. Despite struggles with engine delays and industrial problems, Airbus is expected to meet its softened target, with a razor-thin margin for error. The company delivered 673 aircraft up to the end of November, with November seeing an acceleration of deliveries to airlines linked to China's HNA Group.

site_title: Tesla poised to shrug off tweet chaos as sentiment turns
summary: Tesla shares are poised to rebound after a year of losses, with a 3% gain in the morning. Jefferies analyst Philippe Houchois upgraded his rating to "buy" from "hold", citing improvements in battery technology and a strong brand. Houchois raised his price target to $450, citing potential mergers and acquisitions as a floor to valuation. Despite governance concerns, Houchois believes Tesla is well-positioned to outperform electric vehicle peers in the coming year. This comes after a tumultuous year for the company, following Elon Musk's failed attempt to take the company private.

site_title: UBS executive says investors hyperventilating over normal swings
summary: UBS executive Tom Naratil says recent market turbulence is normal and brings opportunities for wealth management. The CBOE Volatility Index reached its highest monthly average since February, while bond and currency volatility gauges also jumped. The S&P 500 declined 4.6% this week, its largest drop since March. Naratil believes the increased demand for advice due to uncertainty will benefit UBS' wealth-management business.

site_title: Uber files confidentially for IPO
summary: Uber Technologies filed confidential documents with regulators for an initial public offering (IPO), potentially the largest IPO next year and one of the five biggest of all time, valuing the company at $120 billion. Uber's rival Lyft also submitted its IPO prospectus, amid equities markets turmoil. The company's revenue growth slowed to 38% in the third quarter, resulting in a $1.1 billion loss. Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has financial incentives to take the company public next year, while investors have pushed for an IPO to free them to sell shares.

site_title: Sports world hopes for level playing field after Brexit
summary: The UK's sporting world is concerned about the impact of Brexit on players, fans, and investors. New immigration restrictions could limit access to top European talent, affecting the Premier League and other sports. Some, like billionaire owner Steve Lansdown, see this as a positive for British players, while others, like chairman Phil Garlick, warn of "hugely damaging" consequences. The uncertainty also affects other sports, including rugby, Formula One, and horse racing, with potential travel chaos and decreased investor backing.

site_title: As Paris braces for battle, another brawl looms on Renault board
summary: Renault, a French carmaker, is bracing for a leadership crisis as CEO Carlos Ghosn faces possible charges in Japan. Ghosn, who has been arrested on allegations of financial misconduct, may be removed from his post, creating a dilemma for Renault's board and the French government. The situation has put France's government in a bind, as Ghosn has clashed with President Emmanuel Macron and the government over pay and other issues. Renault's board is divided on how to proceed, with some members considering a more permanent solution, and the company is conducting its own investigation into Ghosn's pay package.

site_title: Rise in payrolls and wages in November is less than forecast
summary: US payrolls and wages rose by less than forecast in November, with 155,000 new jobs and a 0.2% increase in average hourly earnings. The unemployment rate remained at 3.7%, its lowest in almost five decades. Despite a cooling economic growth, the data may lead to a slower pace of Federal Reserve interest rate increases, with Fed chairman Jerome Powell describing the labor market as "very strong".

site_title: IP watchdog says the word 'Brent' cannot be trademarked
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office ruled that the term "Brent" cannot be trademarked due to its common usage in the financial services industry. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) challenged Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) Holdings Inc's trademark registrations of "Brent" and "Brent Index" for financial services. The office concluded that ICE's trademark registrations are invalid as the words lack distinctive character and are used by other traders. The decision allows other companies to use the terms without needing a defense under the Trade Marks Act.

site_title: Fed wants you to know: It's shifting to more cautious rate path
summary: The Federal Reserve is shifting away from a mechanical pace of interest-rate increases every quarter, indicating a slower pace of tightening next year. Fed Governor Lael Brainard stated that the gradual path of rate increases has served well, but the policy path will depend on the evolving outlook. This change in approach aims to give policymakers more time to assess the effects of policy as the economic environment changes.

site_title: SGX's derivatives flow faster in Nov as securities dry up
summary: SGX's derivatives trading volumes surged in November, reaching a record high of 19.6 million contracts, despite a decline in securities trading. The exchange's total derivatives volume rose 9% year-on-year, driven by growth in commodities derivatives, iron ore derivatives, and forward freight derivatives. In contrast, securities market turnover declined 11% from October and 24% from November 2017, with the daily average value of securities traded down 3% from October and 21% from November 2017.

site_title: US shale producers see Opec pullback helping 2019 profits
summary: US shale producers are optimistic about their 2019 profits after Opec agreed to trim output by 1.2 million barrels per day, boosting crude prices to nearly 2% higher. Prices closed at US$52.61, above the expected US$40s per barrel, and above US$76 in early October. This move is seen as a relief for US companies, allowing them to profitably expand drilling next year, with Chevron increasing its 2019 capital spending budget by 21%. Oil prices are considered a "sweet spot" for US producers and consumers, with stable prices seen as key to attracting investors back to the energy sector.

site_title: Homegrown SC Auto launches first made-in-Singapore bus to meet demand for coaches
summary: SC Auto, a Singapore-based bus manufacturer, has launched its first made-in-Singapore bus, the SC Neustar, after a $6 million investment in development and manufacturing. The bus features a lightweight design, improved fuel efficiency, and meets Euro 6 emission standards. SC Auto has doubled its factory area to 200,000 sq ft and plans to reach $100 million in annual revenue in 3-4 years. The company has become the only integral coach bus manufacturer in Asia, and its expansion to Myanmar will increase production five-fold.

site_title: HK tycoon Gordon Wu tunnelling out of public markets
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Gordon Wu is planning to take his company Hopewell Holdings private with a $2.7 billion bid, offering shares at a 47% premium to their last public price in 1994. The offer is less generous than expected, with analysts suggesting a 27% discount to net asset value. Wu's ambitious infrastructure projects have not swayed investors, with shares trading at 56% below book value. The move may inspire peers to follow suit, but Wu's bid is seen as unlikely to win over investors due to its lower valuation.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles, indexes post biggest weekly losses since March
summary: US stocks plummeted 2% on Friday, posting the largest weekly losses since March, due to concerns over US-China trade tensions and interest rates. The S&P 500 erased its previous week's gains, following a weekend truce between Washington and Beijing. The sell-off was led by declines in big Internet and technology shares, with investors seeking signs of a trade-tension cloud over the stock market dissipating.

site_title: HDB to launch around 15,000 new flats in 2019
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to launch approximately 15,000 new flats in 2019, including around 2,000 with shorter wait times in Tengah, where residents can expect to collect keys in 2-3 years. This is part of HDB's efforts to provide affordable and quality housing to Singaporeans, with first-timer families able to book flats within their first or second try. HDB has also introduced initiatives such as a new resale portal to shorten transaction times, with up to S$80,000 in housing grants available for first-time homebuyers.

site_title: British tycoon buys controlling stake in fintech Singapore Life
summary: British tycoon Michael Spencer's private investment vehicle IPGL acquires a 33.8% stake in Singapore Life, increasing his holdings to 63.2%. The deal values Singapore Life at US$156 million. IPGL aims to invest in further rounds as Singapore Life expands, supporting its high-growth fintech strategy. The acquisition comes after Singapore Life's acquisition of Zurich Life Singapore's business portfolio in January. The deal has been approved by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Best World COO lauds new China strategy as share price surges
summary: Best World International, a skincare maker and distributor, has seen a surge in its share price after reporting a 97% year-on-year increase in revenue and a 145% year-on-year increase in third-quarter net profit. The company's COO, Huang Ban Chin, attributed the growth to its new franchise business model in China, which allows for greater control over development and higher revenue recognition. The company has also arrested sales declines in Taiwan and has a strong balance sheet with S$134.2 million in cash. Huang does not rule out taking on leverage for acquisitions, and analysts expect the sales momentum to continue in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Personal branding of corporate honchos - law of diminishing returns?
summary: A growing trend in the corporate world suggests that personal branding of top executives may eventually give diminishing returns to the company. The examples of ousted CEOs Carlos Ghosn, Unilever's Paul Polman, and ICICI Bank's Chanda Kochhar illustrate how a strong personal brand can sometimes overshadow a company's performance. Despite their high-profile achievements, these executives' personal brands did not necessarily drive significant gains for their respective companies, highlighting the potential risks of prioritizing individual image over corporate interests.

site_title: Reits
summary: Real estate markets worldwide continue to show resilience. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. US mortgage rates have climbed after five straight weeks of declines, and Manhattan rents have hit a record high with more increases anticipated. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, while Goldman Sachs has acquired significant hotel and retail assets in Seoul. New World Development is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy location.

site_title: Unitholders vote not to wind up AIMS fund
summary: Unitholders of the dual-listed AIMS Property Securities Fund voted against winding up the fund by a six-point margin. The real estate fund was kept intact after a meeting called by the manager in Sydney. However, a second vote is scheduled for December 10, where 18.6% of the fund's unitholders, Samuel Terry Asset Management and Sandon Capital Investments, will decide the fund's fate, citing related-party investments. The fund's manager, AIMS Capital Management, has divested its stake, leaving entities related to the manager with an interest in the fund.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Kampung Admiralty project attracts international attention
summary: Kampung Admiralty, a Singaporean HDB retirement community designed by local architecture firm Woha Architects, has gained international attention after winning the World Building of the Year award at the World Architecture Festival in Amsterdam. The project, which combines healthcare, housing, and education, has become a destination for foreigners looking to learn about and photograph its innovative design and community amenities, including a medical center, childcare facilities, and a rooftop garden. The award marks the first time a homegrown architecture practice has won the title, and it has catapulted the development into the spotlight, with city governments and businesses expressing interest in learning from its design and operations.

site_title: 'I was vindicated a long time ago,' says Iceberg's Arnaud on Noble probe
summary: French national Arnaud Vagner, former employee of Iceberg Research, claims vindication after Noble Group's relisting cancellation due to Singapore authorities' probe into its financial position. Vagner had long criticized Noble Group, labeling himself as a "disgruntled" ex-employee. The cancellation of Noble's relisting allows Vagner to "expose" other targets, as he moves on from the controversy.

site_title: Ellipsiz set to beef up ready-to-eat meal JV
summary: Ellipsiz, an engineering services provider, is expanding its ready-to-eat meal venture through a joint venture with celebrity chef Justin Quek's culinary consultancy, "Chef & Chefs." The move aims to grow Kalms SG's vending machine business by 20-30% annually. Ellipsiz invested S$10 million in Kalms Investment in May and will share revenue with Kalms SG. The joint venture will allow Kalms SG to control its product range and benefit from direct involvement in production and sales. The partnership is expected to complement Ellipsiz's product distribution business.

site_title: US consumer credit rose most in 11 months in October
summary: US consumer credit rose by $25.4 billion in October, exceeding estimates, as Americans stepped up borrowing to finance purchases. This marks the largest increase in 11 months, driven by credit-card and non-revolving debt. The strong job market and lower taxes are also contributing to rising consumption. The 7.7% seasonally adjusted annual rate of credit growth is the fastest in 11 months, indicating continued consumer spending momentum, despite potential borrowing cost increases in December.

site_title: Market, economists drifting apart
summary: Wall Street traders are betting against the Federal Reserve raising interest rates in 2019, while economists expect 3-4 hikes. This divergence comes amid a repricing of debt futures, with the benchmark 10-year note yield falling to 2.82%. Economists from firms like Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley forecast varying numbers of rate hikes, with some predicting a pause by the end of 2019. The market and economists are drifting apart, with risk-averse sentiment contributing to the shift in Treasury yields.

site_title: SoftBank seeks to assuage investors on mobile outage before IPO
summary: SoftBank held emergency conference calls with institutional investors to address concerns about a mobile outage that affected users in 11 countries, including Japan, before its 2.65 trillion yen IPO. The outage, caused by a software problem from Ericsson, disconnected users for over four hours, sparking social media backlash. SoftBank shares fell 3.3% as the company took extra precautions to reassure investors, despite the IPO being fully subscribed. The issue highlights the challenges of launching a major IPO amidst technical issues.

site_title: HK shareholder makes general offer for Sunrise Shares at S$0.017 apiece
summary: Hong Kong-based businessman Wong Siu Fai, now holding 34.22% of Sunrise Shares, will make a general offer for the remaining shares at S$0.017 apiece. The deal values Sunrise at about S$3.03 million. Wong's stake was acquired through Quality Able, which holds a 4.49% stake in Sunrise. The offer is conditional on receiving valid acceptances, and Wong intends to maintain Sunrise's Catalist listing on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: China expresses concern over reported Japan government ban on Huawei, ZTE
summary: China's Foreign Ministry expressed concern over reports that Japan plans to ban government purchases of equipment from Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and ZTE Corp, citing potential economic and diplomatic implications.

images.alt_text: China's Foreign Ministry said on Friday that it was seriously concerned over reports that Japan plans to ban government purchases of equipment from China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and ZTE Corp.

site_title: Medinex opens 14% above IPO price on debut
summary: Medinex, a Singapore-based medical support services company, made its Catalist debut on Friday, opening at S$0.285, 14% above its IPO price of S$0.25. The shares traded sideways, with a day-high of S$0.29 and a low of S$0.27, before closing at S$0.28 after 8 million shares changed hands.

site_title: Singapore: a global playground of infinite possibilities
summary: Singapore has emerged as a top MICE destination, hosting high-profile events such as the US-North Korea Summit and the Bloomberg New Economy Forum. The country's ability to deliver distinctive experiences, combine work and play, and showcase its unique culture and attractions has made it a go-to destination for international business leaders. With its modern, safe, and well-connected infrastructure, Singapore is inspiring imagination and connecting the world to possibilities, solidifying its position as a global playground of infinite possibilities.

site_title: A case of foot-in-mouth disease
summary: Dolce & Gabbana sparked outrage in China after releasing a series of social media ads featuring a Chinese woman struggling to eat with chopsticks, with co-founder Stefano Gabbana responding with insulting comments. The backlash led to the cancellation of their Shanghai fashion show and the removal of their products from Chinese retailers. The incident highlights the importance of cultural sensitivity and prompt apology in crisis management. Key takeaways include owning up to mistakes, killing it with kindness, and crafting classy responses to customer complaints.

images.alt_text: According to one estimate, the Dolce & Gabbana PR disaster could potentially cost the brand 400 million euros (S$623 million) in lost sales in China alone.

site_title: KONE opens new regional headquarters in Singapore
summary: KONE has opened a new regional headquarters in Singapore, marking the company's expanded presence in the Asia-Pacific region. The 25,000 square foot facility will house the regional headquarters, Singapore country office, a customer call center, and a technology display center. This move comes as KONE's revenues from the Asia-Pacific region reached €1 billion (S$1.6 billion) in FY17. The new headquarters will support the company's growing presence in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on relief at US Fed report
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday due to relief over a US Federal Reserve report that may soon pause interest rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.82%, and the Topix index gained 0.61%. This news also boosted US markets.

site_title: Laws of attraction, dating and factor-based investing
summary: Investors can identify and target stocks with desirable characteristics, or "factors," that are proven to lead to higher expected returns over the long term. Factor-based investing involves a systematic and rules-based approach to selecting stocks with these desired traits, such as size, value, and profitability. While not every factor exposure guarantees a return premium, research has shown that certain factors are reliable drivers of long-term returns. Investors should focus on factors that are persistent across time periods and markets, and implement a strategy that captures these premiums in a cost-efficient manner, rather than trying to outguess the market.

site_title: Battle among London's finest
summary: The English Premier League season is nearing its midpoint, with Manchester City leading the pack two points ahead of Liverpool. Meanwhile, Tottenham Hotspur and Chelsea are vying for third and fourth places, with Tottenham's success attributed to manager Mauricio Pochettino's tactics and Harry Kane's goal-scoring prowess. Chelsea's struggles are attributed to lack of motivation and the departure of Eden Hazard, while Arsenal has found new life under Unai Emery's coaching, with a strong defensive record and ability to claw back from deficits.

images.alt_text: Tottenham Hotspur striker Harry Kane in a duel with Arsenal defender Rob Holding (centre) and goalkeeper Bernd Leno during the derby match at the Emirates Stadium in London on Dec 2.
Chelsea manager Maurizio Sarri has himself admitted that his club is not strong enough to compete with Manchester City for the league title.

site_title: Japan's October household spending falls unexpectedly
summary: Japan's household spending unexpectedly fell in October, marking a third straight month of decline. Real wages also slipped, adding to concerns about the country's economic strength amid global trade frictions. Firms are becoming increasingly pessimistic about Japan's economic prospects due to the China-US trade war and a scheduled sales tax hike.

site_title: Huawei case reveals the real US trade war with China
summary: The US-China trade war has taken a new, stealthier form, with the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, highlighting a conflict over domination of the information-technology industry. The US accuses Huawei of breaching US sanctions by selling technology to Iran, but the move also aims to restrict Chinese companies' access to critical US technology, including computer chips. This "high-tech trade war" involves export restrictions, investment restrictions, and a focus on preserving US technological dominance, with the goal of preventing Chinese companies from copying or stealing American ideas and technologies.

site_title: Impasse broken, Opec agrees to larger-than-expected output cut
summary: OPEC has agreed to a larger-than-expected output cut of 1.2 million barrels per day, with OPEC itself responsible for 800,000 barrels. Iran secured an exemption from cuts due to US sanctions, and crude prices surged 5.4% in London. The deal was reached after two days of negotiations in Vienna, with Russia playing a key role in brokering the agreement between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The agreement will be reviewed in April, and producers will use October production levels as a baseline.

site_title: Ethics in focus: Trading in unit trusts
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower aims to reduce the cost of investing for CPF members by lowering and removing sales charges and wrap fees for CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) members. The practice of buying and selling investment products at the expense of the investor, known as churning, is considered unethical and illegal. A case study illustrates how frequent buying and selling of unit trust funds can result in unsuitable investments, despite the investor's long-term investment horizon. The Ministry's efforts aim to curb churning and promote more client-centric investment advice.

site_title: Japan Foods, Minor S'pore to take F&B brands to the region
summary: Japan Foods Holding and Minor Singapore have signed a binding memorandum of understanding to form a joint venture to grow their regional F&B operations. The venture will be funded with S$2.3 million in shareholder loans and will see Japan Foods operate Thai eateries in Japan and Minor Singapore operate Japanese restaurants in Thailand and China. A definitive agreement must be reached in six months, with no expected impact on Japan Foods' consolidated earnings. Japan Foods' flagship brands include Ajisen Ramen and Menya Musashi, while Minor Singapore operates Thai Express and other chains.

site_title: Kuroda defends Japan central bank's ETF purchases
summary: BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's ETF purchases, stating that they do not cause distortions in the stock market. Criticisms that ETFs' huge presence is inflating stock prices beyond fundamentals are premature, according to Kuroda. The BOJ is committed to buying 6 trillion yen of ETFs per year to achieve its 2% inflation target, and Kuroda rejected the idea of an exit strategy or spinning off ETF holdings.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda said BOJ's ETF buying was part of efforts to achieve its inflation target.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.80 points to 1,680.54, as losers outnumbered gainers 427 to 292, with a total volume of 1.9 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion.

site_title: See all the Vermeers in the world - on your phone
summary: A free augmented-reality app, "Meet Vermeer," allows users to view all 36 authenticated paintings by Dutch artist Johannes Vermeer in a virtual museum. The app features high-resolution images from 18 museums and private collections, including the Mauritshuis, Metropolitan Museum of Art, and National Gallery of Art. Users can explore the virtual museum, zoom in on paintings, and examine them closely. The app aims to increase accessibility to Vermeer's works, which are often scattered across the world, and may reduce the need to travel to see them in person.

site_title: Tech to the fore for Singapore's seniors
summary: Singapore's rapidly aging population, with elderly citizens making up almost half of the total population by 2050, is leveraging technology to maintain independence and autonomy. Seniors are using devices such as emergency buttons, GPS trackers, and robots with voice assistance to stay connected and receive care. Technology is also improving their quality of life, enabling video-conferencing with healthcare providers, monitoring their health, and providing social interaction through robots and social media. As a result, 80-90% of seniors want to stay in their own homes as they age, highlighting the benefits of embracing digital transformation.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The Singapore Government Land Sales (GLS) programme for 2020 has seen a 19.5% cut in private housing supply. The majority of the remaining supply is concentrated in mass and mid-market segments, accounting for 48% and 47% respectively. High-end units make up only 5%. The government considered the significant supply pipeline and existing vacant private units in making this decision.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 4.4 points or 0.1% to 3,111.12. Trading volume was high, with 978 million shares worth S$856 million changing hands. The most actively traded stock was Ezion Holdings, which rose S$0.001 to S$0.057. Gainers edged out losers 176 to 175, marking a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: KONE boosts presence here with new HQ
summary: KONE, a Finnish elevator maker, has expanded its presence in Singapore with a new 25,000 square foot Asia-Pacific headquarters. The facility, launched on December 7, 2018, houses the company's regional headquarters, customer call center, and technology display area. KONE's revenues from the Asia-Pacific region reached nearly one billion euros in FY17, with the region experiencing 8.2% growth in the third quarter of 2018. The company employs 26,720 employees in the region, nearly half of its total workforce.

site_title: Ride-hailing firm Lyft races to leave Uber behind in IPO chase
summary: Lyft, a ride-hailing firm, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO), beating rival Uber in the process. The IPO, valued at $20-$30 billion, will test investors' appetite for the ride-hailing business, which remains unprofitable. Lyft's IPO follows a string of high-profile tech company IPOs this year, but market turmoil could dampen enthusiasm for other 2019 hopefuls. Lyft's filing comes after Uber moved up its target IPO date and some venture capitalists are urging portfolio companies to hurry up and file.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap losing streak on talks of Fed pause; won steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended the week up 0.34% after snapping a three-session losing streak, amid speculation of a potential pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hike cycle. The won steadied against the dollar, while bond yields fell. Foreigners were net buyers of 11 billion won worth of shares, leading the rally. However, concerns over Sino-US relations and the arrest of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou remain, threatening to chill trade talks. The Kospi is down 16.2% so far this year.

site_title: Low Keng Huat Q3 net profit falls 60%
summary: Low Keng Huat's Q3 net profit dropped 60% year-over-year to S$2.63 million due to declining revenue from the investment, hotel, and absence of development revenue. Revenue fell 31% to S$9.24 million. The company attributed the decline to a subdued residential property market due to recent property cooling measures. Low Keng Huat plans to be selective in land bidding and investment projects while maintaining rental rates for renewals.
