summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 11.87 points or 0.4% to 3,155.92, as about 1.26 billion shares worth S$873 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 248 to 130, with the most actively traded stock being DISA.

site_title: Oil prices fall on swelling glut, economic growth concerns
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday due to a swelling global supply glut and concerns over economic growth. US crude inventories rose by 5.4 million barrels, and Saudi Arabia produced a record 11.3 million barrels per day in November. The Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is expected to discuss supply cuts to support prices. Global economic growth is also a concern, with investors worried about a potential slowdown and ongoing trade disputes between the US and China. Oil prices are expected to average $70 and $59 per barrel in 2019, according to Bank of America.

site_title: BreadTalk enters Europe with Din Tai Fung's London flagship
summary: Din Tai Fung, a Taiwanese restaurant famous for its "xiao long bao" (steamed pork dumplings), has opened its first European location in London's Covent Garden district. The 250-seater restaurant is the 153rd Din Tai Fung globally and marks the brand's entry into Europe. The restaurant is a joint venture between Taster Food UK Limited and Din Tai Fung Restaurant Co, with plans for at least two more locations in London. The opening is seen as a "major milestone" for the company, with potential for 20 UK locations and further expansion into Europe.

site_title: Biggest iPhone assembler warns trade war may last a decade
summary: Foxconn Technology Group Chairman Terry Gou warns the US-China trade war may last 5-10 years, impacting global supply chains. He predicts a shift from globalization to polarization, with economic and technological competition between the US and China forcing China to change its production and development methods. Mexico and Vietnam are identified as countries likely to benefit from the trade tensions, while the US plans to build barriers to prevent China from acquiring key technologies and components.

site_title: Kimly: Business as usual after arrest of key directors
summary: Kimly, a Singapore-based coffeeshop chain, will continue to operate normally despite the arrest of its executive chairman Lim Hee Liat and executive director Chia Cher Khiang on securities law-related allegations. Both directors will carry on with their duties while on bail, ensuring the smooth operation of the company.

site_title: EU pushes euro to break dollar dominance
summary: The EU Commission has proposed a plan to reduce the dollar's dominance in the global economy and strengthen the euro's role, particularly in energy transactions. European capitals are frustrated with the US dollar's reserve currency status, which grants the US significant diplomatic and economic power. The EU aims to create a more multipolar world, allowing other countries to have more control over their economies. This move could potentially weaken the US dollar and increase the euro's influence in international trade.

site_title: Hyundai, Gwangju city eye deal on low-cost carmaking joint venture
summary: Hyundai and the city of Gwangju are set to sign a deal on a low-cost carmaking joint venture, despite opposition from labour unions who fear job losses and lower wages. The joint venture aims to produce 100,000 mini-SUVs annually starting in 2021, with Hyundai investing 53 billion won and the city spending 59 billion won. The annual wage is 35 million won, less than half the average wage for existing Hyundai workers. The move is seen as a bid to align with the government's goal of keeping manufacturing jobs in South Korea amid US President Trump's tariffs.

site_title: Revamped venue and a focused programme
summary: The Miami Beach Convention Center has completed a 3-year, $615 million renovation, adding 10% more space and updating its exterior with hurricane-resistant aluminum fins. The revamped venue will host the 17th edition of Art Basel Miami Beach, featuring over 250 galleries from 35 countries, with a new 60,000 sq. ft. ballroom and special commission by Mexican artist Abraham Cruzvillegas. The fair is also cutting two sectors, Public and Film, in a move to gather collectors closer to the main event, and is expected to maintain its role as a bridge between North and South American art markets.

images.alt_text: The recently renovated Miami Beach Convention Center in Miami Beach, Florida, which hosts the 17th edition of Art Basel Miami Beach, has a refreshed look with about 500 angled aluminum fins intended to evoke waves.

site_title: Will Americans be ready for the 'Next America'?
summary: The US is poised to face a new era, dubbed the "Next America," characterized by rapid technological advancements and shifting demographics. By 2020, the economy will require new policies to address issues like 5G technology, artificial intelligence, and the gig economy, which will accelerate business, entertainment, education, and healthcare. The government must adapt to these changes, including revising regulations for self-driving cars, drones, and robots, and ensuring continuous lifelong learning and antitrust policies. The growing influence of tech giants, such as Facebook and Amazon, also demands closer scrutiny. The Next America will require significant investments and policy changes, which may necessitate raising taxes or trimming military spending.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singtel Group has consolidated its cybersecurity businesses under the Trustwave umbrella, combining resources from Optus and NCS. Singapore has unveiled a plan to help media companies develop digital capabilities. The COE for cars fell to a year-low of $23,568. Sysma Holdings secured an $18.6m contract to build a two-storey Good Class Bungalow. Commercial space at Coronation Shopping Plaza is on sale for $35m. Singapore shares ended lower on Wednesday, closing 11.87 points down 0.4% to 3,155.92.

site_title: Malaysia's PRG to take up to 26.3% stake in Capital World for as much as S$16.5m
summary: Malaysia-listed PRG Holdings is set to acquire up to 26.3% stake in Capital World for up to S$16.5 million through the issuance of new shares and options at S$0.035 apiece. Under the deal, PRG will subscribe for 265 million new shares for S$9.28 million and have the option to subscribe for up to 205 million more new shares for S$7.18 million. Capital World plans to use the funds for the Capital City project and working capital.

site_title: 'Betrayed' Lion Air preparing documents to cancel Boeing orders
summary: Indonesia's PT Lion Mentari Airlines is preparing to cancel Boeing aircraft orders after Boeing stated the carrier is to blame for the Lion Air crash that killed 189 people. The airline's founder, Rusdi Kirana, feels "betrayed" and is considering cancellation documents. A preliminary report from Indonesia's transportation safety commission found Lion Air needs to improve its safety culture, but did not list the cause of the accident.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's PT Lion Mentari Airlines is preparing documents to cancel the rest of its aircraft orders from Boeing Co after a statement from the aircraft manufacturer suggests that the carrier is to blame for the crash that killed 189 people, its founder Rusdi Kirana said.

site_title: Making salary information public helps close the gender pay gap
summary: Researchers from several business schools analyzed pay data from Danish companies before and after a 2007 law requiring pay transparency by gender. The study found a 7% reduction in the gender pay gap, with women seeing larger wage increases at firms that had to report pay data. The results suggest pay transparency helps close the gap, and the study's findings raise the bar for policymakers and business leaders to address the issue.

site_title: 'Legal risk' in Brexit deal clause: Attorney-General
summary: Britain's top government lawyer, Attorney-General Geoffrey Cox, warned ministers of a "legal risk" in the Brexit deal due to the backstop clause, which could keep the UK in a customs union with the EU indefinitely. The backstop would maintain an open border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, potentially subjecting the UK to protracted negotiations. This arrangement has been met with criticism from Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, which could impact the government's stability. The advice highlights the potential for a "difficult precedent" for the EU and raises concerns about the UK's long-term economic implications.

site_title: A different Brexit? British MPs take back control
summary: British MPs voted to give themselves a bigger say in what happens if Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal is rejected, passing an amendment that allows them to amend a statement on the next steps. The amendment, backed by former attorney general Dominic Grieve, passed by 321 votes to 299. The move could potentially lead to a Norway-style agreement, where Britain joins the European Economic Area, or even a second referendum. The decision comes as MPs are sharply divided over the various possible versions of Brexit, and both the Conservatives and Labour have committed to leaving the EU.

site_title: Weak consumer sentiment causes COEs to end mostly lower
summary: Singapore's latest COE tender ended mostly lower, with prices at their lowest for the year. COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finished at $23,568, while commercial vehicle COE ended at $27,009. Motorcycle premium rose to $3,399, defying the trend. Industry experts expect demand to remain subdued until the Singapore Motorshow in January, citing weak consumer sentiment.

site_title: Shipping Giant Maersk aims for zero net carbon emissions by 2050
summary: Maersk, the world's largest shipping company, aims to cut its net carbon emissions to zero by 2050. To achieve this goal, the company plans to develop carbon-neutral vessels by 2030 and invest significantly in innovation and fleet technology. Maersk has already invested approximately $1 billion in energy-efficient solutions over the past four years. The company's Chief Operating Officer, Soren Toft, stated that the next 5-10 years will be crucial in reaching this goal.

site_title: Fashion retailer Joules preps for no-deal Brexit with EU facility
summary: Fashion retailer Joules Group Plc is preparing for a no-deal Brexit by establishing an EU-based distribution facility and bringing its 2019 spring-summer collection to the UK earlier. The company aims to minimize disruptions and has posted a 17.6% revenue rise in the 26 weeks to Nov. 25. Joules forecasts its full-year 2019 profit before tax to be in line with expectations, citing strong sales growth and a robust wholesale order-book. The company also plans to hedge currency and increase administrative activities ahead of the UK's planned departure from the EU.

site_title: Philippine taxes on sugary drinks could avert thousands of deaths, WHO study says
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has found that implementing taxes on sugary drinks in the Philippines could avert 24,000 premature deaths from diseases such as diabetes, stroke, and heart failure over the next two decades. The taxes could cut consumption and result in nearly 6,000 deaths from diabetes, 8,000 from stroke, and over 10,000 from heart diseases. The WHO suggests that the tax may help reduce obesity-related premature deaths and improve financial well-being in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: The Philippines could avert 24,000 premature deaths linked to diseases such as diabetes, stroke and heart failure in the next two decades after it adopted taxes on sugar-sweetened beverages, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares suffer big losses after Wall St rout
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.62% on Wednesday following a Wall Street rout, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 26,819.68. Concerns over the US-China trade ceasefire and US economic outlook contributed to the losses. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.61% to 2,649.81, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.48%. The market downturn was a result of traders' apprehension about the impact of the trade ceasefire on global markets.

site_title: Northern Irish DUP says UK government's Brexit legal advice is devastating
summary: The Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) is unhappy with the UK government's full legal advice on Brexit, stating it's "devastating." The advice reveals that Northern Ireland would be in the EU Customs Union while Great Britain is not, under the backstop provision. This contradicts the government's position, leading to DUP criticism. The government was forced to publish the advice after being found in contempt of parliament for failing to do so.

site_title: Turner Prize goes to Charlotte Prodger for films shot on iPhone
summary: Charlotte Prodger, a Glasgow-based artist, won the 2018 Turner Prize for her video works shot on an iPhone. Her film "BRIDGIT" features painterly clips of everyday scenes overlaid with passages from diaries, books, and music. Prodger, 44, was recognized for her innovative use of technology in creating visually striking and introspective works. This marks the first time an iPhone has been used to win the prestigious British art award.

images.alt_text: Prodger, 44, won the prize for her video works including BRIDGIT, a 33-minute film that features painterly clips of everything from swans feeding among some rocks to a T-shirt drying on a radiator. The images are overlaid with Prodger and her friends reading excerpts from the diaries she wrote as a queer teenager in rural Scotland, passages from books, and music such as snatches of a pirate radio station.

site_title: As growth risks recede, ECB should move towards the exit: Vasiliauskas
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should maintain its plans to dial back stimulus as growth risks for the euro zone appear balanced, according to Governing Council member Vitas Vasiliauskas. The ECB has been slowly reducing stimulus and plans to formally end its bond purchases scheme this month. Vasiliauskas played down expectations for changes in the re-investment of maturing debt, saying the changes should be technical and market-neutral. The ECB will release new forecasts next week, which are expected to lower its GDP projection due to a slowdown in growth.

site_title: OUE, OUE Hospitality Trust slip as Mandarin Orchard Singapore faces food poisoning probe
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore is under investigation after dozens of people fell ill after attending a wedding banquet. The incident has led to a decline in shares of OUE Hospitality Trust and its sponsor, OUE. The companies' stocks slipped 2.2-2.6% due to the ongoing investigations and reputational risk. Analysts warn that further regulatory action could put pressure on the stock price, with clarity on the matter expected to take a few days.

site_title: Barclays to keep Swiss private banking growth momentum in 2019
summary: Barclays expects to grow its Swiss private banking business by over 10% in 2019, following a successful expansion in 2018. The bank plans to recruit more relationship managers, product specialists, and investment experts in Zurich and Geneva to capitalize on the growth. Barclays embarked on an international hiring spree in its wealth management division last year, targeting high-net-worth individuals. The bank's Swiss head, Gerald Mathieu, attributed the growth to a growing pool of millionaires and billionaires.

site_title: BT Group to remove Huawei equipment from its core 4G network: FT
summary: BT Group will remove Huawei equipment from its core 4G network within two years, following an internal policy to keep the Chinese company's equipment at the edge of telecoms infrastructure. This move aligns with the US government's efforts to persuade allied countries to avoid Huawei's equipment due to security risks. BT has also excluded Huawei from bidding for 5G contracts. This decision follows similar bans in Australia and New Zealand, which cited national security concerns.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end lower as trade worries dent sentiment
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended down 0.62% at 2,101.31, following Wall Street's decline due to concerns over the Sino-US trade war. The won fell 0.79% against the US dollar, with bond yields also edging lower. US President Donald Trump's threat to impose "major tariffs" on Chinese goods raised doubts about a potential trade deal. The country's economic slowdown and financial instability have become top concerns for industry experts, overshadowing household debt and property market instability.

site_title: 'People do not rate telcos highly', says StarHub executive, while axing default mobile contract plans
summary: Singapore telcos' reputation is in decline, according to StarHub executive Johan Buse. The company has introduced three contract-free SIM-only plans, available from $25 to $80 per month, in an effort to boost subscriber numbers. Despite this shift, customers can still opt for two-year contracts to receive new handsets. Buse stated that people do not rate telcos highly, and the company aims to earn back customers' trust.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on worries over growth
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.53% lower on Wednesday due to US economic growth concerns, following a Wall Street plunge. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 21,919.33. Investors are cautious ahead of US jobs data, which may influence economic growth. This is part of a broader market trend, with stocks on other exchanges also experiencing volatility.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.8% to 6,968.85 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices losing 1.2% and 1.0% respectively. The declines were attributed to concerns about the US economic outlook, Brexit strains, and falling oil prices.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares follow Wall Street down, but losses are milder
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, following a decline on Wall Street, amid concerns of a US recession and slowing global growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,668.84, down 44.70 points. The US Treasury yield curve's flattening also sparked recession concerns. Investors were unnerved by doubts over Sino-US trade talks. The decline was milder than the 1.0% drop on Tuesday.

site_title: Googlers write to CEO demanding equal treatment for contractors
summary: A group of Google employees and contractors wrote to CEO Sundar Pichai demanding equal treatment and better working conditions. The letter, signed by thousands of contractors, requested access to company-wide emails, town hall meetings, and benefits. Contractors, who make up over half of Google's workforce, feel mistreated and ignored, citing unequal treatment, inadequate healthcare, and limited opportunities for advancement. The letter comes amid criticism of Google's handling of sexual misconduct, contracts with the US military, and plans to build a censored search engine in China.

site_title: Luxury 'Red Flag' models buck China auto sales slump
summary: China's luxury 'Red Flag' sedan, also known as "Hongqi," is bucking the trend of declining car sales in the country. The brand, popular among government officials and Communist Party leaders, is seeing a surge in sales due to President Xi Jinping's push for national economic "self-reliance." The government and state companies are purchasing the cars, while patriotic citizens are also buying them. The "Red Flag" model is known for its black design and chrome grille, and is seen as a symbol of China's economic strength.

site_title: New Beiersdorf CEO poaches from rivals in management reshuffle
summary: Beiersdorf appoints new CEO Stefan De Loecker, who shakes up top management, poaching managers from rivals Procter & Gamble and Reckitt Benckiser. Asim Naseer, P&G's global marketing director for skin care, becomes head of consumer brands, while Ramon Mirt, Reckitt Benckiser's Europe business head, takes charge of Near East and Americas regions in March. The new CEO aims to make the company more digitally savvy and expand internationally, with a focus on international diversity and market expertise.

site_title: Beijing to offer financial help to companies that keep staff on payrolls
summary: China's state council announced it will offer financial help to struggling companies that keep staff on payrolls, returning half of unemployment insurance fees for firms that maintain current or planned job cuts. The government will also provide subsidies to out-of-job workers undergoing job training. The move aims to address the impact of economic downward pressure on employment, with Beijing seeking to stabilize employment amid the trade war with the US.

site_title: Huawei said to debut 3-D camera phone powered by Sony sensors
summary: Huawei is set to unveil a 3D camera phone powered by Sony sensors, code-named Princeton, later this month. The phone's camera can accurately measure distances by bouncing light off surfaces, allowing users to generate 3D models of themselves and the environment in real-time. This technology has the potential to change how people view the world and could boost sales for Huawei, which is facing cooling global demand. The camera will also enable developers to control apps and games with hand gestures, generating billions in revenue for Sony.

site_title: China is said to be preparing to buy US LNG and soybeans again
summary: Chinese officials have begun preparations to restart imports of US soybeans and liquefied natural gas, according to two officials with knowledge of the discussions. This comes after the US and China temporarily halted the exchange of tariffs, promising to try and resolve their differences by March 2019. Chinese purchases of US soybeans and LNG collapsed after Beijing imposed tariffs in retaliation for US import taxes. The preparations do not necessarily mean China will cut retaliatory tariffs or reimburse buyers for tariffs, but rather take necessary steps for the purchases.

site_title: Canary Wharf lures new bank tenant in win over London's City
summary: Canary Wharf Group Plc has secured a major win by luring the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) to its 5 Bank Street tower in East London. The EBRD will lease space at the under-construction tower, marking a significant victory for the financial district as it battles Brexit and a decade-long retreat of banks. This move comes after EBRD opted to leave its current location in the City of London. The deal is seen as a boost to Canary Wharf's reputation as a viable alternative to the City.

site_title: Hong Kong fund Oasis fails to block takeover of Japan's Alpine
summary: Hong Kong-based fund Oasis Management failed to block the takeover of Japan's Alpine Electronics Inc by its larger affiliate Alps Electric Co at a shareholder meeting. Oasis Management, Alpine's No.2 shareholder, had argued the proposed deal offered an unfairly low valuation. The proposed share swap indicates an offer price of 1,791 yen per Alpine share, below the target firm's last close of 1,819 yen. The setback highlights the struggle activist investors face in Japan to get firms to adopt their proposals.

site_title: Malaysian police to seek extradition of Jho Low, 4 others charged over 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysian police will request the extradition of Jho Low and four others if found in other countries, amid charges over the 1MDB scandal. The five were charged in absentia on Tuesday and issued arrest warrants. The charges mark a significant development in the ongoing investigation into the misuse of funds from the state-owned 1MDB. The police have vowed to pursue the extradition of the fugitives if they are discovered in other countries.

images.alt_text: Malaysian police will request the extradition of fugitive businessman Low Taek Jho and four others if they are discovered in other countries, national police chief Mohamad Fuzi Harun said on Wednesday.

site_title: Fugitive businessman Jho Low's super-yacht will be sold for nine-digit price, says 1MDB lawyer
summary: A Malaysian lawyer says the super-yacht Equanimity, allegedly owned by fugitive businessman Jho Low, will be sold for a nine-digit price (RM100-999 million) before March 31. The sale is part of the judicial sale by private treaty for 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB). The sale will be conducted through the Sheriff of the Admiralty Court, with the goal of closing the sale by March 31. The sale price is significantly lower than the estimated value of RM1 billion.

site_title: Holiday trash surge makes matters worse for struggling recyclers
summary: The US holiday season has led to a surge in trash generation, particularly among recyclers, due to increased contamination rates. Americans produce 25% more trash during holidays, but companies like Republic Services face lower prices for contaminated materials, resulting in a projected $500 million decline in recycling profits. Companies are urging consumers to take extra time to properly sort recyclables, as contamination rates have spiked to 30% from 10% historically. This could hinder investment in recycling infrastructure.

site_title: Einstein letter doubting God auctioned for US$2.89m
summary: A handwritten letter by Albert Einstein, dated 1954, was auctioned for US$2.89 million. The letter, written in German to philosopher Eric Gutkind, expresses Einstein's skepticism about God, stating that the word "God" is "the expression and product of human weaknesses." This letter surpassed its estimated value of US$1.0-1.5 million, setting a record for an Einstein letter. It was previously sold for US$404,000 in 2008 to a private collector.

images.alt_text: A handwritten letter by Albert Einstein in which the physicist doubts the existence of God was auctioned Tuesday for US$2.89 million.

site_title: More Singapore SMEs expect lower turnover in 2018, cite challenging business climate: DP Info poll
summary: Singapore SMEs expect a decline in turnover in 2018, citing a challenging business climate, particularly due to the US-China trade war. 15% of SMEs project negative turnover growth, up from 11% in 2017. High manpower costs and increased domestic competition remain top concerns. Cash flow issues, including delayed payments from customers, also affect SMEs. Despite this, firms are proactively driving productivity improvements and business transformation, according to a DP Info survey of 2,557 SMEs.

site_title: Divided UK braces for once-in-a-lifetime Brexit vote
summary: The UK prepares for a historic Brexit vote on December 11, with divided MPs urging their constituents to pressure them into supporting a compromise deal or a cleaner break with Europe. Polls indicate a minority support for Prime Minister Theresa May's deal, while hardliners and moderates campaign for different visions of Britain's future. The public debate is marked by deep divisions, with many Britons expressing pessimism and frustration with the ongoing process. The outcome remains uncertain, with some advocating for a second referendum, while others fear a no-deal Brexit or continued gridlock.

images.alt_text: As British MPs prepare for a historic vote on the future of Brexit, the country is back on a campaign footing and the bitter divisions of the 2016 referendum have re-surfaced.

site_title: Australia rare earth miner Lynas eyes legal options on Malaysia plant review
summary: Australian rare earth miner Lynas Corporation is considering legal options after Malaysia added new conditions to licence renewals for its US$800 million plant, including requirements for waste management and the export of radioactive residues. The plant's temporary storage licence for radioactive residue is set to expire in September 2019, while its approval for non-radioactive waste storage is valid until February 2019. Shares fell 19% as a result, but some analysts remain optimistic on the plant's future, citing the low levels of radioactivity and access to a rehabilitation fund.

site_title: Bank of America names two executives to replace late wealth management head
summary: Bank of America has appointed two executives, Andy Sieg and Katy Knox, to replace the late global wealth management head Terry Laughlin. Sieg, head of Merrill Lynch Wealth Management, and Knox, president of Bank of America's private bank, US Trust, will report directly to CEO Brian Moynihan. Wealth management has been a bright spot for the bank, with profit surging 28% in the first nine months of the year. Sieg's focus on increasing referrals to other products aligns with Laughlin's approach, and he is well-suited to please the firm's financial advisors.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon session down 1.04% at 3,134.76
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon, slipping 1.04% to 3,134.76 due to trade war concerns. Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 91, with Thai Beverage Public Co and OCBC Bank leading declines. DBS Group Holdings also fell 1.8% as trade war worries weighed on the market.

site_title: Takeda shareholders give nod for US$59b Shire acquisition
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical approved its $59 billion acquisition of London-listed Shire, creating a global powerhouse with a stronger pipeline but massive debt. Almost 90% of shareholders voted in favor, with Takeda issuing new shares and securing $30.9 billion in bank loans. The deal is expected to boost underlying earnings, but analysts warn of integration challenges and the need for Takeda to bolster its experimental therapies to compete in the long term.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St rout as confusion, uncertainty reign
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday following a Wall Street rout, amid a "perfect storm" of problems including uncertainty over a US-China trade agreement and concerns about the US economy. The Dow slipped 3.1%, S&P 500 3.2% lower, and Nasdaq 3.8% off. China's commerce ministry called the agreement "successful" but provided few details, while US President Trump shifted his tone, leaving investors uncertain. The US economy's yield curve also narrowed, raising fears of a recession.

site_title: Singtel puts global cybersecurity businesses under Trustwave umbrella
summary: Singtel has consolidated its global cybersecurity businesses under the Trustwave umbrella, pooling resources from its 2,000 cybersecurity employees worldwide, including those from Optus and NCS. The consolidation brings in the Singtel Cyber Security Institute, a 10,000 sq ft facility in Singapore. A new logo and corporate website have also been introduced, marking the revamp.

site_title: Qualcomm unveils new smartphone chips to fire up race to 5G services
summary: Qualcomm unveiled the Snapdragon 855, a new smartphone chip designed to support 5G services. The chip will enable faster data speeds, lower latency, and support for AI-powered features such as image recognition and fingerprint scanning. The technology is expected to be integrated into 5G flagship smartphones available next year, with major carriers like AT&T and Verizon already planning to offer 5G services. The new chip is seen as a key component in the transition to 5G, which promises a significant upgrade in mobile services and capabilities.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.58 points to 1,683.41 at 9am on Wednesday, with volume reaching 43.72 million lots worth RM24.25 million. Losers outperformed gainers 195-32.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 1.1% to 3,131.48
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 36.31 points or 1.1% to 3,131.48. The decline followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with losers outpacing gainers 119 to 20. The trading volume was 55.7 million shares worth S$104.2 million.

site_title: Urban planners look to Vienna to solve housing crises
summary: Vienna, Austria, is hosting a conference on affordable housing, with experts seeking solutions to the city's housing crises. The city's public housing model, which includes subsidized rents and a large stock of affordable units, is drawing attention from around the world. Vienna's average rent of 9.6 euros per square meter is significantly lower than other major European cities, with 60% of the city's 1.8 million inhabitants living in publicly or housing association-owned properties. The city's approach to social housing, which includes capping rents and preserving a mix of income levels, is seen as a model for other cities struggling with housing affordability.

site_title: Trump threatens tariffs if can't reach 'real deal' with China
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to impose "major tariffs" on Chinese goods if a trade deal is not reached. Trump stated that the US will either have a "REAL DEAL" or no deal at all, with tariffs being charged on Chinese imports. The threat comes after a series of trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on worries over growth
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a decline on Wall Street, amid concerns over US economic growth. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.25% to 21,761.23, while the Topix index dropped 1.36% to 1,626.79. Investors are cautious ahead of key US jobs data, contributing to the market's uncertainty.

site_title: US comedian Kevin Hart to host Oscars
summary: US comedian Kevin Hart announced on Tuesday that he would host the 91st Academy Awards in February, fulfilling his long-held dream. Hart expressed his excitement on Instagram, stating that the day had finally come for him to host the Oscars. This marks a significant milestone for the comedian, who has been in the entertainment industry for years.

site_title: Malaysia records highest trade surplus as exports surge in October
summary: Malaysia posted its largest trade surplus ever in October, with exports surging 17.7% and imports rebounding 11.4%. Exports to China rebounded 33% year-on-year, while manufactured goods rose 19.9% and mining goods 29.6%. The trade surplus jumped to RM16.3 billion, surpassing the previous record of RM15.3 billion in September. Strong demand from China and higher shipments of manufactured and mining goods contributed to the surge.

images.alt_text: Malaysia posted its largest trade surplus ever in October as exports surged, while imports also rebounded, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Glencore's Singapore head of oil becomes LNG boss as Mark Catton retires
summary: Glencore's Singapore head of oil, Chin Thean Quek, has become the new director of the company's liquefied natural gas (LNG) division after Mark Catton's retirement. Chin, an ex-Goldman Sachs and BP trader, took over from Catton, who headed up the company's Singapore operations for 18 years. The move is part of Glencore's leadership shake-up, which also includes the retirement of head of copper marketing Telis Mistakidis. Chin will lead the LNG trading team out of London, with Nathan Arentz from the gas trading division also taking on a key role.

site_title: Siemens looks for faster growth in 'smart' buildings, eyes acquisitions
summary: Siemens aims to outpace the 3% growth of the construction market next year, focusing on smart buildings and acquisitions. The company's building technologies division expects to grow 1% above the market, targeting Asia and digital buildings. Siemens' building technology business reported a 6% sales increase in 2018, despite a 29 million euro profit decline. The division will be merged into Smart Infrastructure, a new division with a 10-15% profit margin goal, and Rebellius will oversee the business as COO. Siemens considers acquisitions to support growth.

site_title: Brexit firebrand Nigel Farage quits UKIP
summary: Nigel Farage, a key figure in the UK Independence Party (UKIP), resigned as party leader and member, citing the appointment of far-right activist Tommy Robinson as an adviser. Farage, who co-founded UKIP and led the party for nearly a decade, wrote in a column for the Daily Telegraph that the party is "not the Brexit party our nation so badly needs." His resignation comes after a period of internal conflict within the party.

site_title: Turner Prize goes to Charlotte Prodger for films shot on iPhone
summary: Charlotte Prodger, a Glasgow-based artist, has won this year's Turner Prize for her film "BRIDGIT," which features painterly clips of everyday life overlaid with personal and literary content. Prodger, 44, is the third woman in a row to win the prestigious British art award, which comes with a £25,000 cash prize and increased profile. Her use of technology and focus on queerness were highlighted by judges, who praised her work as a breakthrough and a use of familiar technology to create something profound.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Kimly, Acromec, Datapulse Technology, Singapore Exchange, Sysma Holdings
summary: Several companies have seen developments affecting trading on Wednesday, December 5, 2018. Kimly's executive chairman and director were arrested on suspicion of making false market-related statements. Acromec signed a waste-to-energy power plant deal with Chew's Agriculture. Datapulse Technology reported a net profit of $131,000 for the first quarter. The Singapore Exchange is redeploying staff to grow its global footprint. Sysma Holdings secured an $18.6 million contract to build a Good Class Bungalow.

site_title: Indonesia relaxes palm oil levy rules: finance ministry
summary: Indonesia has relaxed palm oil levy rules, allowing exporters to avoid paying levies when prices are below US$570 per tonne. The levies will be charged at US$10-25 when prices range between US$570-619 per tonne and US$20-50 when prices exceed US$619 per tonne. The new regulation, effective immediately, differs from previous rules, which required exporters to pay US$20-50 per tonne regardless of prices. The move follows a drop in palm oil prices.

site_title: Pacific Radiance gets a month's extension on court protection for its assets
summary: Pacific Radiance, a struggling offshore and marine group, has been granted a month's extension on court protection for its assets until January 14, 2019. The company had initially sought moratoria to protect its assets from various legal processes. Two vessels deemed non-essential to the company's restructuring plan have been sold, and noteholders have agreed to redeem their notes in a cash-and-equity option. The extension will give Pacific Radiance more time to work on its restructuring plan, which aims to address debt issues resulting from the oil and gas downturn.

site_title: China says to move quickly on US trade consensus
summary: China vowed to quickly implement agreed-upon trade issues with the US after a successful meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump. The commerce ministry stated that economics and trade teams will push forward negotiations within 90 days, following a clear timetable and roadmap. This move aims to move the US-China trade consensus forward, addressing specific issues already agreed upon.

images.alt_text: The commerce ministry said talks between presidents Xi Jinping and Donald Trump at the weekend had been "successful" and it was "confident" of their agreement's implementation.

site_title: Singapore unveils plan to help media industry be digital-ready
summary: Singapore has unveiled the Media Industry Digital Plan (IDP), a step-by-step guide to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and media professionals develop digital capabilities. The plan includes a digital roadmap with solutions to guide adoption of technology, training courses, and pre-approved digital tools. SMEs can access free advice from consultants and apply for grant support for eligible projects. The plan aims to help the media industry thrive in the digital economy, with the industry contributing S$2.4 billion to Singapore's economy.

site_title: Australian economy stalls as consumers spend less
summary: Australia's economic growth stalled in the third-quarter of 2018, with consumer spending slowing down and house prices falling further. The G-20 economy grew only 0.3% between July and September, the slowest rate in two years. This news comes as Australians spent less on big-ticket items like cars and clothing, while spending on essentials increased slightly. The Australian economy expanded around 2.8% over the last year, trailing forecasts and raising doubts about the ruling Liberal Party's appeal to voters ahead of elections next May.

site_title: Surprised by cheap clean energy, coal stalwart adds renewables
summary: Japanese trading house Marubeni Corp plans to add 1 gigawatt of clean energy over the next five years, halving its coal-fired generation by 2030. The company, which generates about a quarter of its power from coal, cites falling renewable energy costs as the reason for the shift. Renewable energy costs have plunged 53% for solar power and 39% for onshore wind, making the business case for shifting away from coal stronger. Marubeni aims to double its clean energy share to 20% by 2023 and cut its coal capacity by selling projects or not extending contracts.

site_title: Fonterra to unwind Darnum JV with China's Beingmate
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, has reached a provisional agreement to unwind its 20% stake in the Darnum joint venture in Victoria, Australia, with Chinese infant formula group Beingmate. The decision follows Fonterra's strategic review of its investments, which includes its Darnum joint venture. The company will provide further details on the unwinding at its quarterly update later this week. This move comes after Fonterra posted its first annual loss in 2018, partly due to a NZ$405 million writedown on its stake in Beingmate.

site_title: Ghosn faces new under-reporting charge worth 4b yen
summary: Tokyo prosecutors plan to "rearrest" ousted Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn and his former representative director Greg Kelly on Monday, amid a new accusation of under-reporting Ghosn's salary by about 4 billion yen (S$48.5 million) over the last three years. This allegation joins an existing charge of under-reporting Ghosn's pay by 5 billion yen in official filings from 2010 to 2015. The new charge brings the total to 9 billion yen (S$109.5 million) in under-reported compensation.

site_title: Volkswagen may use Ford's US plants to build cars, deepening alliance
summary: Volkswagen is building a global automotive alliance with Ford, with the potential to use Ford's US plants for car production. VW CEO Herbert Diess said the company is considering building a second US plant and may use unused Ford capacity. Ford executive chairman Bill Ford confirmed talks are going well, but no definitive details have been discussed. The alliance aims to strengthen the American automotive industry and may also involve Ford sharing platforms with VW. VW will not take an equity stake in Ford as part of the alliance.

site_title: UK retail needs Internet tax 'shock', says billionaire boss
summary: Billionaire Mike Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, has called for the UK government to levy a tax on retailers with online sales exceeding 20% of revenue to support traditional shopping districts. Ashley believes the tax would be a "massive electric shock" for the sector, encouraging retailers to invest in physical stores. He also proposes offering free business rates for five years if retailers invest in local sites, in an effort to save high streets from the impact of online competition.

site_title: Trump meets with German auto executives
summary: US President Donald Trump met with executives of Germany's top three auto manufacturers, BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen, amid efforts to resolve trade imbalances. The meeting aimed to encourage the automakers to produce more in the US, where they already have significant plants. The White House stated that Trump shared his vision for a more friendly business environment, while BMW described the meeting as constructive but emphasized that international trade policy responsibility rests with institutions. The meeting follows a July truce and a US$30 billion trade deficit with Germany in cars and auto parts.

site_title: Construction firm MMP Resources acquiring S$25m stake in natural gas JV company
summary: Construction firm MMP Resources is acquiring a 50% stake in a joint venture company owning Russia's Asia One gas field for S$25 million. The joint venture, valued at S$50 million, mainly supplies natural gas. MMP will pay a cash first tranche and the remaining sum in shares. The acquisition aims to diversify MMP into the natural gas and energy business, providing shareholders with better returns and long-term growth. Following the acquisition, MMP will be deemed a "mineral, oil and gas company" and intends to dispose of its existing Japanese assets.

site_title: 'Zero' doubt Saudi crown prince directed Khashoggi murder: GOP senators
summary: US Republican senators, including Chairman Bob Corker and Senator Lindsey Graham, have stated that they have "zero" doubt Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman directed the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The CIA's director, Gina Haspel, briefed the senators on the evidence, which includes a recording of the murder and messages exchanged between Prince Mohammed and his aide Saud al-Qahtani. Graham described the prince as "crazy" and "dangerous" and said he would be convicted in a jury trial. The senators' statements contradict the White House's downplaying of possible links between Prince Mohammed and the murder.

site_title: KKR to take 'significant stake' in V3 with up to S$500m investment
summary: KKR is investing up to S$500 million in V3, a Singapore-based massage chair and lifestyle products group, valuing the company at S$1.7 billion. The investment is a significant stake for V3, with KKR's Asian Fund III backing the deal. V3's chairman, Ron Sim, welcomes the investment, citing its potential to drive growth, including expansion in Japan and China, and exploring mergers and acquisitions opportunities.

site_title: US: Stocks end down more than 3.0% on trade, growth worries
summary: US stocks plummeted 3.0% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 3.1% and the S&P 500 tumbling 3.2%, amid concerns over slowing US growth and trade conflict. The US-China tariff truce has sparked skepticism, with investors questioning the agreement's details. US President Donald Trump signaled a harder line, saying he'd "happily" sign a "fair" deal but also be ready to impose tariffs. The drop in stocks also coincides with a narrowing yield gap between short- and long-term US Treasury notes, raising recession concerns.

site_title: The best wine books of 2018
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The best wine books of 2018 include "The Sommelier's Atlas of Taste: A Field Guide to the Great Wines of Europe" by Rajat Parr and Jordan Mackay, which explores the concept of terroir, and "What Makes a Wine Worth Drinking: In Praise of the Sublime" by Terry Theise, which delves into the philosophical aspects of wine. Other notable books include "Amber Revolution: How the World Learned to Love Orange Wine" by Simon J. Woolf, "Godforsaken Grapes: A Slightly Tipsy Journey Through the World of Strange, Obscure, and Underappreciated Wine" by Jason Wilson, and "Flawless: Understanding Faults in Wine" by Jamie Goode.

site_title: Visa, Mastercard offer to cap tourist card fees to end EU probe
summary: Visa and Mastercard have offered to cap tourist card fees in the European Union to stave off fines and end an EU antitrust investigation. The proposed fees, 0.2% on non-EU debit card payments and 0.3% on credit card payments, would bring them in line with EU card fees. The European Commission, which has investigated payment and credit card fees, says these fees ultimately result in higher prices for consumers. The offer aims to end a decades-long crackdown and avoid a potential US$650 million fine for Mastercard.

site_title: Pound hits 2018 lows then recovers as parliament gets more Brexit say
summary: The British pound briefly hit 17-month lows at US$1.2659 due to the UK parliament's contempt finding against Prime Minister Theresa May's government for refusing to release full Brexit legal advice. However, the pound recovered after the parliament voted to give lawmakers more power over Brexit steps, potentially neutering the threat of a no-deal Brexit. The pound traded around US$1.2714, with a low against the euro since September 25 at 89.450 pence.

site_title: Kanye West called out for handphone use during The Cher Show
summary: Kanye West was called out for using his phone during the opening night of The Cher Show on Broadway. The actor playing Sonny Bono took to Twitter to address the incident, stating West was taking notes but later apologized. This is the latest in a series of cellphone distractions at Broadway shows, with performers increasingly calling out audience misbehavior. West's representative claimed he was impressed by the production, but West's actions reflect a growing trend of audience disruptions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares dive at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.89% at the open on Wednesday, mirroring a sharp sell-off on Wall Street due to investor concerns over the China-US trade deal. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,745.69, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 1.36% and 1.74% respectively. The sell-off was attributed to a decline in global markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Xi arrives in Portugal to boost trade ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Portugal on December 4, 2018, for a two-day visit to boost economic ties, despite concerns over China's growing influence in Europe. Xi signed cooperation agreements, including one to bring Portugal's southwestern port of Sines into China's "new Silk Road" initiative, offering loans for infrastructure development across Asia, Europe, and Africa. This move is seen as a significant step for Portugal, one of western Europe's poorest countries, which has been opened to Chinese investment since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on doubts over US-China trade truce
summary: European shares fell on Tuesday, with Germany's DAX and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index declining 1.1% and 0.8% respectively. Investors questioned the US-China trade truce, citing concerns it won't lead to a long-term deal. Commerzbank rates strategist Christoph Rieger attributed the decline to "suddenly not promising" US-China trade talks. The uncertainty has led to a decline in auto stocks, contributing to the overall drop in European shares.

site_title: Crisis-hit Sri Lanka suffers credit rating cuts
summary: Sri Lanka's credit ratings were downgraded by two international agencies, Fitch and Standard and Poor's, due to the country's ongoing political crisis. The downgrade follows a series of events, including the removal of the prime minister and a court ruling stripping the new prime minister of power. Moody's had previously lowered the rating to B2. The crisis has led to a depreciation of the exchange rate and outflows from the local bond market, further undermining investor confidence. The country is now expected to face tougher times with a challenging external environment.

site_title: Prosecutors to subpoena Trump hotel business records
summary: Prosecutors in Maryland and Washington have issued subpoenas for records of 13 private businesses owned by Donald Trump, focusing on the Trump International Hotel near the White House, as part of an investigation into whether the president is illegally benefiting from foreign governments. The investigation, filed in June 2017, claims the hotel has unfairly siphoned off business from local businesses due to its proximity to the White House. The lawsuit, filed by the attorneys general of Washington and Maryland, seeks to ensure Trump serves the American people without financial entanglements with foreign governments and officials.

images.alt_text: Prosecutors in Maryland and Washington announced on Tuesday subpoenas for the records of 13 private businesses owned by Donald Trump as part of an investigation into whether the US president is illegally benefitting from his Washington hotel.

site_title: BOE's Mark Carney hits back at critics of Brexit scenarios
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney defended the central bank's Brexit warnings, stating that the scenarios were based on detailed preparatory work to ensure banks' readiness. Carney disputed critics' claims that the warnings were scare-mongering, saying the worst-case scenarios were low-probability events. He also expressed opposition to ceding decision-making over banking rules to the EU after Brexit, citing the UK's large financial services sector.

site_title: Volkswagen says next generation of combustion engine cars to be its last
summary: Volkswagen plans to roll out its last generation of combustion engine cars in 2026, marking its commitment to phase out diesel and petrol cars as it aims to meet the 2015 Paris climate deal's emissions targets by 2050. The carmaker aims to offer over 50 electric models by 2025 and predicts the last vehicle with a combustion engine will be sold around 2040. This move follows Volkswagen's 44 billion euro electric offensive by 2023 and comes as the company seeks to close the gap with Asian competitors and US tech giant Tesla, amid efforts to recover from the "dieselgate" emissions scandal.

site_title: Japan to ramp up public works spending to decade-high next year: Nikkei
summary: Japan plans to increase public works spending to a decade-high of 7 trillion yen (S$36.8 billion) in the next fiscal year to ease the impact of a scheduled sales tax hike in 2019. The government aims to repair aged infrastructure over three years, with 2 trillion yen allocated for the next fiscal year. This move aims to boost economic growth and prevent recession, as Japan seeks to rein in its massive public debt. The total budget is expected to exceed 100 trillion yen next fiscal year.

site_title: Oil curbs gains amid trade, output cut uncertainty
summary: Oil prices pared gains amid concerns over a trade war between the US and China, with US President Donald Trump stating he would revert to tariffs on China if a deal couldn't be reached. This led to a market selloff, with Wall Street falling over 3% and oil prices pulling back alongside other assets. The uncertainty over global crude supply cuts also contributed to the volatility.

site_title: Singapore-listed coal plays getting harder to fire up
summary: Singapore-listed pure-play coal stocks, Golden Energy and Resources, Geo Energy Resources, and Blackgold Natural Resources, have seen their stock prices dwindle due to waning demand from China and declining coal prices. The companies, all Indonesian upstream thermal coal companies, are struggling to gain traction despite recent mergers and acquisitions activity in the coal space. The dim outlook for these coal stocks is largely attributed to China's reduced coal imports and the overall decline in global coal prices. As a result, investors are losing interest in these coal plays, making it challenging for them to "fire up" their stock prices.

site_title: Investment Outlook 2019
summary: Key investment outlook events include NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed and Creative Technology warning of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada, while London's Heathrow considers increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In Asia, Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth day ahead of GDP data, and MAS and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Trump versus the Fed: a very public feud
summary: US President Trump is engaged in a public feud with the Federal Reserve, led by Chairman Jerome Powell, over interest rate hikes. Trump is unhappy with the Fed's decision to raise rates, citing a strong economy and low unemployment, and has criticized Powell's nomination. Economists argue that the Fed's independence is crucial for making decisions, and that Trump's public attacks could lead to economic uncertainty and decreased confidence. The Fed has historically made mistakes, but its independence is preferable to politically driven policies. Trump's actions risk feeding a prolonged feud and could have significant consequences for financial markets and the economy.

site_title: President retweets false claim that Paris rioters 'want Trump'
summary: US President Donald Trump retweeted a false claim that French rioters in Paris chanted "We want Trump" during protests, sparking widespread debunking. The claim was made by conservative student activist Charlie Kirk, who was subsequently retweeted by the President. However, an AFP fact check revealed the video used to support the claim was actually shot during a protest for Tommy Robinson, a former British far-right leader, and not during the "yellow vests" protests in Paris. The incident highlights the President's tendency to spread misinformation.

site_title: Unrest in Malaysia: opposition parties out to show their strength
summary: Malaysia is bracing for a massive rally by opposition parties PAS and Umno in Kuala Lumpur, with at least 500,000 Malay Muslims expected to attend. The rally, originally planned as a protest against a UN human rights treaty, is seen as a show of strength by both parties to counter the PH government's pledge to "firmly espouse" the treaty's principles. The rally comes as Umno seeks to re-energize its party faithful amid corruption scandals and PAS pushes its Islamic agenda. The PH government has backed off signing the treaty, citing a lack of parliamentary numbers to amend the constitution.

site_title: S-E Asia GDP growth to slow in 2019 amid trade war: ICAEW
summary: South-east Asia's GDP growth is expected to slow to 5% in 2019, down from 5.3% in 2018, due to the ongoing US-China trade war. Singapore's GDP growth is forecast to moderate from 3.3% to 2.5%, while Malaysia's economy is expected to ease from 4.8% to 4.5%. Indonesia and the Philippines are expected to be the least affected, while domestic demand is expected to provide some relief. The trade tensions are seen as a medium-term structural change rather than a short-term remedy, with some economies potentially benefiting from the relocation of supply chains.

site_title: Trendy avocados removed from UK menus amid environmental concerns
summary: Some UK restaurants are removing avocados from their menus due to environmental concerns, citing water-intensive farming practices in South America. The move is seen as a response to the Western world's "obsession" with the fruit, which contributes to greenhouse emissions and pressure on local water supplies. Similar bans have been implemented in Bristol and south London, with the trend gaining traction. Experts say a wide-scale ban of avocados may not solve the environmental issues, but it raises important questions about food sourcing.

site_title: Tumblr to strip nudity from its platform
summary: Tumblr has announced it will ban nearly all nudity from its platform, effective December 17, as part of a change to its terms of service. The decision comes after Apple dropped Tumblr's software from the App Store following the discovery of child pornography on the site. Nudity, including female nipples, will be allowed in certain contexts, such as breast-feeding or health-related content. The move has sparked criticism and complaints from users who rely on the platform for explicit content.

site_title: EU finance ministers clinch eurozone reform deal
summary: EU finance ministers reached a deal on eurozone reform, agreeing to strengthen the European economy's financial plumbing but falling short of ambitious plans. The reforms, agreed after 18 hours of negotiations, include expanding the European Stability Mechanism and enhancing EU-backed reforms, but do not include a eurozone finance minister or a crisis-fighting budget. The deal now needs EU leader approval at a summit next week and marks progress in reforming the euro area, according to German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz.

site_title: Shipping and the trade war torpedo
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have agreed to a 90-day halt on new trade tariffs, giving hope for a long-term trade agreement. This temporary deal is expected to benefit the global shipping industry, which has already been impacted by the US-China trade war. Dry Bulk Freight Forecaster reports a decline in US soybean imports to China, leading to increased shipments to other destinations like Brazil and Argentina. The International Chamber of Shipping and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development have expressed concerns about the impact of trade wars on seaborne trade, with both organizations advocating for continued cooperation and dialogue.

site_title: Trump meets Bush family ahead of funeral
summary: President Donald Trump met with the Bush family, including former presidents George W. and Laura Bush, at Blair House ahead of Wednesday's state funeral for George H.W. Bush. Trump, who previously clashed with the Bushes, made an effort to demonstrate unity. The meeting was seen as a show of peacemaking, with the Bush family assuring Trump that eulogies at the funeral would avoid criticism. Trump will sit in the front row at the funeral but will not deliver a eulogy.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump went in person on Tuesday to pay his respects to the grieving Bush family in his latest show of peacemaking with the political clan he once fought bitterly.

site_title: Make privileged-access security a priority to protect patient data
summary: Singapore's increased adoption of digital healthcare solutions has created a target-rich environment for cyber attackers. To protect patient data, privileged-access security must be prioritized, as it's no longer just an IT concern but a public safety and infrastructure issue. The country's Smart Nation initiative must incorporate security planning and support as an integral part of its digital transformation.

site_title: First book written about a stock market selling for US$200,000
summary: The first book about a stock market, "The Confusion of Confusions" by Joseph Penso de la Vega, is being sold at Sotheby's Rare Books and Manuscripts online auction with an estimated value of $200,000 to $300,000. Written in 1688, the book is a primer on the Amsterdam stock exchange and provides investment advice, including descriptions of market mechanics and warnings about dishonest practices. Only a few copies of the first edition are known to exist, and the sale is expected to attract a private collector, possibly in finance.

site_title: Insurers need to do more to capture the millennial market
summary: Established insurers struggle to deliver value to their younger customers, particularly millennials who expect personalized, hassle-free service. A Bain & Company survey found that only 20% of millennials in the US give their property-and-casualty providers high scores for key elements such as motivation and affiliation. Insurers are taking steps to address the issue, with some creating digitally oriented, low-cost, and customer-centric companies. Loyalty leaders excel in core business, delivering personalized experiences, and innovating to stay ahead of insurgents. Insurers that deliver value to customers, including millennials, can put themselves on a path to sustained loyalty and lasting growth.

site_title: Acromec joint venture to power new energy plant with chicken waste
summary: Acromec, a Singapore-based engineering-services provider, is diversifying into renewable energy through a joint venture with Malaysian alternative energy company Green Energy Resources. The 80:20 joint venture, Acropower, will build, own, and operate a waste-to-energy power plant using chicken manure, with Chew's Agriculture supplying the manure. The plant is expected to start operations by March 2020 and generate at least S$1.5 million in revenue annually. This move aims to expand Acromec's value chain and deliver sustainable revenue streams.

site_title: NASA space probe reaches asteroid deemed potential threat to Earth
summary: NASA's Osiris-Rex space probe has reached the asteroid Bennu, a potential threat to Earth in 150 years. Launched in 2016, the seven-year mission aims to collect a sample from Bennu's surface and return it to Earth. Bennu, a rocky mass about a mile wide, is rich in organic compounds and water, which scientists believe delivered life to Earth. The spacecraft will pass close to Bennu in December, collecting a sample and later jettisoning it for a parachute descent in 2023. Scientists will study the sample to understand the asteroid's trajectory and potential impact on Earth.

site_title: Here's how Europe plans to challenge the US dollar's dominance
summary: The European Union is set to unveil plans to challenge the US dollar's dominance in global markets, including energy, by developing trustworthy interest rate benchmarks and a fully integrated instant payment system. The EU aims to strengthen the international role of the euro and reduce reliance on the US dollar. Key proposals include using the euro as default currency in energy contracts and creating euro-denominated price benchmarks for crude oil. The move seeks to mitigate the "exorbitant privilege" of the US dollar, allowing Washington to enforce its foreign policy goals globally.

site_title: SGX rejigs listings team, makes new appointments as it expands abroad
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has made changes to its listings team, expanding its presence overseas. From January 1, 2019, Mohamed Nasser Ismail will take on the role of head of equity capital markets, overseeing mainboard initial public offerings and other responsibilities. This move is part of SGX's efforts to boost its overseas listings.

site_title: Greenworks arranges US$440m for clean-energy real estate
summary: Greenworks Lending, a provider of financing for commercial properties, has secured US$440 million in funding for clean-energy projects. This includes a US$250 million commitment from CarVal Investors and a US$150 million bond sale. Greenworks' model, PACE, allows for clean-energy systems to be repaid through property-tax assessments. The company's chief operating officer, Alexandra Cooley, stated that this is "repeatable," indicating the success of the model. Guggenheim Securities arranged the deal, and TIAA Investments purchased the notes.

site_title: China to encourage some "zombie" firms to restructure
summary: China plans to encourage "zombie" firms with remaining business value to restructure and attract strategic investors, aiming to cut debt to reasonable levels and improve bankruptcy procedures. The goal is to curb soaring corporate debt and address capacity gluts in sectors like steel and coal. Beijing aims to ensure a smooth exit for hundreds of insolvent companies to prevent unemployment and maintain social stability.

site_title: Oil prices rise 1% on hopes of Opec-led output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday, driven by expectations of Opec-led supply cuts and a reduction in Canadian output. US WTI crude futures reached $53.53 per barrel, up 58 cents, and international Brent crude oil futures reached $62.39 per barrel, up 70 cents. Goldman Sachs expects Brent to exceed $60 per barrel if Opec and Russia cut 1.3 million barrels per day. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) will meet on December 6 to agree on a joint output policy.

site_title: Q-and-A site Quora reports data breach of 100m users
summary: Quora reported a data breach exposing the account information and private messages of approximately 100 million users. The breach occurred due to a malicious third-party attack on the company's computer systems. Quora stated that sensitive information, such as credit card numbers, was not collected, reducing the risk of identity theft. The incident comes as a reminder of the vulnerability of digital data, following recent breaches at Marriott and other companies.

site_title: Singapore firm to launch blockchain accelerator for startups
summary: Singapore venture capital firm Trive Ventures has launched a six-month blockchain accelerator for later-stage startups, with the backing of Enterprise Singapore and partners PwC Singapore and Icon Foundation. Eight startups will be selected for the Tribe Accelerator programme, focusing on product development and mass adoption of blockchain technology. The incubation programme will kick off in Q1 2019, aiming to create innovative and disruptive blockchain startups to capture growth opportunities locally and overseas.

site_title: STI retreats as market confidence fades
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 22.83 points, or 0.7%, to 3,167.79 on Tuesday, as market confidence waned amid conflicting US and Chinese statements on trade truce negotiations. The benchmark index was partially reversed from Monday's rally, driven by the positive sentiment surrounding the US-China trade talks. Investors were left guessing due to inconsistent messages from top US officials, leading to volatile price action in financial assets.

site_title: Mrs May battles for Brexit withdrawal deal in decisive week
summary: Theresa May's Brexit withdrawal deal is set to be debated in the House of Commons, with a key vote on Dec 11. Many MPs remain undecided, and a significant defeat could lead to her resignation. If the government loses by 200 votes, it's seen as a catastrophic outcome for May. The outcome of the vote will have significant implications for financial markets and the UK's future in the EU.

images.alt_text: Anti-Brexit demonstrators protesting outside the Houses of Parliament in London this week. The electorate is divided now as well, and polls have indicated that more are now leaning towards staying within the EU.

site_title: World's most popular travel destinations of 2018
summary: Jerusalem is poised to lead growth in inbound arrivals, with a 38% increase in 2018 to 4.8 million arrivals, according to Euromonitor International's Top 100 City Destinations report. Worldwide, inbound arrivals are expected to increase 5% to 1.4 billion trips in 2018. Asia continues to rise, with cities like Japan and India showing strong growth, while the Middle East and Africa are expected to benefit least due to terrorist attacks. Hong Kong leads the list of cities with the most arrivals, with 29.8 million forecast for 2018.

site_title: Morgan Stanley predicts Ford to cut 25,000 jobs in overhaul
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts Ford Motor Co will cut 25,000 US jobs as part of its $11 billion restructuring. This exceeds General Motors Co's announced job cuts. The exact details of Ford's plan have not been released, but Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas predicts larger cuts. The restructuring is part of Ford's efforts to adapt to the changing automotive landscape.

site_title: Canada housing has achieved soft landing, says home builder
summary: Canada's housing market has achieved a "soft landing" thanks to government regulations that cooled soaring home prices, according to Mattamy Homes CEO Brad Carr. The regulations, including a foreign buyers tax and stricter mortgage lending rules, have led to a dramatic cooling of the market since their implementation in January. Prices and sales have stabilized, and builders are now lobbying to relax mortgage regulations. Mattamy Homes expects 30% unit sales growth in the US next year, with a target of 5,000 units per year in both countries.

site_title: Euro rises as drop in Treasury yield whacks US dollar
summary: The euro rose above $1.14 on Tuesday, driven by a decline in US Treasury yields, which weakened the US dollar. This move was accompanied by gains in the yen, Chinese yuan, and other trade-linked currencies. The US dollar index fell 0.6% to its weakest level since November 22, amid concerns about a potential US economic slowdown. The recent trade truce between the US and China also boosted investor confidence in riskier currencies.

site_title: Cross-border airspace management not incompatible with sovereignty, says Singapore MOT
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Transport (MOT) has stated that providing air traffic services over south Johor does not compromise Malaysia's sovereignty. The claim comes after Malaysia protested new flight paths proposed over Seletar Airport. This clarification was made in response to Malaysia's delegation of airspace management to Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Transport (MOT) has rejected the contention that Malaysia's sovereignty is compromised in any manner because Singapore provides air traffic services over south Johor.

site_title: SIA, Singtel's Innov8 invest in data startup
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has made its first startup investment since launching a digital innovation blueprint in January, taking a minority stake in data startup Data Republic through a Series B funding round led by Singtel's Innov8 venture capital arm, which raised A$22 million.

site_title: Singapore startup creates Philippines' first national prescription tracking system
summary: A Singapore startup, mClinica, has created the Philippines' first national prescription tracking system, addressing the country's lack of real-time information on pharmaceuticals and national health programmes. This system aims to improve the efficiency of pharmacies and inform policy-making. mClinica also operates data, education, and patient programme platforms. The development of this tracking system is a significant step forward for the country's healthcare sector, enabling better management of prescriptions and healthcare services.

site_title: Setting the scene for the new year
summary: Nine industry leaders share their views on the 2019 outlook, with a focus on promoting inclusivity in the workplace. They emphasize the importance of self-regulation, gender diversity, and embracing change to drive business success. Key hopes include companies committing to gender diversity by a certain timeframe, leveraging fintech technologies, and promoting women's representation in leadership positions. The leaders also highlight the need for greater transparency and accountability in board diversity matters, and encourage stakeholders to demand evidence of women in senior leadership roles.

site_title: Lion Air ponders cancelling Boeing jets in worsening row over crash: sources
summary: Lion Air, Indonesia's largest airline, is reviewing its Boeing 737 MAX orders worth $22 billion following a fatal crash that killed 189 people in October. The airline's co-founder, Rusdi Kirana, is upset with Boeing's statement on the crash investigation, which he believes deflects attention from design changes. Lion Air may cancel remaining orders, which would put pressure on Boeing and require lengthy negotiations. The airline's review comes as Boeing faces scrutiny over its maintenance record and pilots' actions, and as US pilots criticize the manufacturer for not disclosing the MCAS system in the 737 MAX manual.

site_title: Brexit derivatives brinkmanship pits UK firms against Brussels
summary: UK derivatives-clearing giants, including London Stock Exchange Group, are pushing the European Union to guarantee they can continue serving the bloc's biggest banks in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The EU's European Commission must provide legal certainty on clearing trillions of dollars of derivatives contracts by Christmas or face notification from UK firms to close out positions. Clearinghouses need an ironclad guarantee due to their own rules requiring three months' notice, and a fix is crucial to prevent EU banks from being kicked off UK clearinghouses, which hold £60 trillion of over-the-counter derivative contracts.

site_title: British construction PMI growth edges up to 4-month high
summary: UK construction activity grew at a 4-month high in November, driven by house building and commercial work. The IHS Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.4 from 53.2 in October, beating economists' forecasts. Construction hiring was robust, while business confidence improved from a 5-year low. However, Brexit-related uncertainty weighed on firms' outlook for the coming year, with Prime Minister Theresa May facing a challenge in winning parliamentary backing for her Brexit plan.

site_title: Flattening yield curve just produced its first inversions
summary: The US Treasury yield curve has inverts for the first time in over a decade, with the 3- to 5-year spread falling to negative 1.4 basis points on Monday. This move could signal the end of the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle and may prompt the central bank to cut interest rates in 2020. The 2- to 10-year spread also fell below 15 basis points, the flattest since 2007. Analysts attribute the inversion to easing global trade tensions and expectations of lower interest rates next year, but caution against over-interpreting the move.

site_title: Porn star jokes about sexual tryst with Trump
summary: Stormy Daniels, a porn star and memoirist, appeared at a Washington bookshop to promote her memoirs, comparing President Donald Trump to Burt Reynolds, but with socks, in a humorous and profane remark. The event was attended by a crowd of bookish types and a moderator, and Daniels' appearance was seen as entertaining. The comment was likely in response to Daniels' alleged tryst with Trump, but the exact quote was not provided in the article. Daniels' memoirs have generated significant attention, and her appearance at the bookshop was notable for its contrast with the establishment's usual highbrow literary fare.

site_title: Kimly's exec chairman, exec director arrested by CAD, released on bail
summary: Kimly's executive chairman Lim Hee Liat and executive director Chia Cher Khiang were arrested by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) on Tuesday for allegedly being involved in an offence under Section 199 of the Securities and Futures Act. They were released on bail and continue to assist in investigations. The arrest comes amid a probe into Kimly's initial public offering and acquisition of drinks maker Asian Story Corp (ASC), which was previously terminated. No formal charges have been made against them yet.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux, a cash-strapped water company, has been given a new deadline to find a buyer for the loss-making Tuaspring plant, with Maybank pushing the date back to Dec 28. The original deadline was Oct 15 under a July agreement. Hyflux still must meet the terms of the original deal, including Maybank's right to terminate the collaboration agreement if the new deadline is breached. The Singapore Exchange has also added 11 companies to its watch-list for possible delisting due to pre-tax losses and failing to maintain a minimum market capitalisation.
